#Cambodia could see more reliable and cheaper electricity after several Cambodian utility workers and regulators visited the U.S. earlier this month, met with their American counterparts and toured National Renewable Energy Laboratory facilities in the states of Washington and Colorado. 

     

The delegation focused on consumer satisfaction, metering, service quality, and renewable energy, all areas that the Electricity Authority of Cambodia has worked to reform in partnership with the Power Sector Program run by U.S. Department of State.

Two events this past weekend - the Technovation Cambodia National Pitch  and #Fishackathon 2016 - showed people in #Cambodia and around the world how #technology can be used to make positive changes globally.

Hosted by USAID Cambodia's Development Innovations project, the Technovation Cambodia National Pitch featured 14 talented teams of young women aged 10-18 who identified community problems, built mobile apps to address their key issues, designed business plans and pitched their ideas to a panel of judges representing the U.S. Embassy, the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport, Digital Mobile Innovations, and Development Innovations Cambodia. More than 500 students, tech professionals, and supporters were in attendance. Congratulations to all of this year's teams!

In its third year, Fishackathon  sponsored by the U.S. Department of State  is now a worldwide event that connects science and computer programming with addressing threats to sustainable fishing. Coders, technologists, and designers from over 40 cities internationally spent the weekend developing usable solutions to problems that the world's fisheries are facing today. To learn more, please visit http://www.fishackathon.co/.

    Fishackathon 2016

Ambassador Todd: "...Ideally, we believe the best place for a child is with his or her parents, or with extended family members.

If this is not possible, however, we believe adoptions should be available to ensure children have an opportunity to grow up in a family setting.

Since 2008, the United States has worked within the framework of the Hague Convention whenever considering any inter-country adoption. We do this to safeguard the interests of children, birth parents, and adoptive parents..."

UPDATE: The transcript of Sophanna's question and President Obama's answer is included below.

Congratulations to Cambodian #YSEALI member Sophanna, who was picked by President Obama to ask a question during the Presidents YSEALI Town Hall this afternoon in Luang Prabang, Laos. Sophanna asked the President about which of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals is most important. You can see the Presidents answer (ending poverty)  and the entire Town Hall  by following this link: https://www.whitehouse.gov/live/president-obama-holds-yseali-town-hall-0.

PRESIDENT OBAMA:  Okay.  So, Cambodia, we have somebody from Cambodia?  Right here, this young man.  By the way, everybody looks very good in their native clothes.  Those of you who are just wearing shirts, you look good too.  (Laughter.)  But I appreciate how nice everybody looks today.  Go ahead.
 
Q    Thank you, Mr. President.  And actually my question was taken by one of the fellows, so I just start with the second question.  If the 17 goals of the SDG were implemented in the United States, which goals should be the top priority, and why is it?  And how you got to deal with it?  Thank you.  (Applause.)
 
PRESIDENT OBAMA:  That's a good question.  So for those of you who didn't hear the question, SDG is the Sustainable Development Goals that were an update on the original set of goals.  Keep in mind how much progress we've made on those goals over the last 20 years.
 
The number of people who we've seen rise out of extreme poverty, the number of people who are now able to have enough to eat, the reduction in infant mortality has been remarkable.  So we've made real progress.  Worldwide, people are much better off now than they were just 20 years ago, and I think we can make similar progress going forward.
 
I've actually asked our teams to look at where in these Sustainable Development Goals do we have work to do in the United States?  And although we're still evaluating that, I would say that the areas where we still fall short are -- there are still too many children in poverty in the United States.  Now, they're not suffering extreme poverty of the sort that you see in parts of India or China or Laos or Cambodia, but we have children who are very poor and who still aren't getting enough to eat.  That is also connected to education.  And we still have a lot of children in a country so wealthy that on a day-to-day basis are not getting the kinds of educational opportunities that they deserve.
 
So I would say that the way forward for us involves addressing those pockets of poverty, and starting with kids.  And we have enough wealth to do it.  The question is whether we have the political will to make the investments in these communities, many of which are in inner cities.  Oftentimes they are poor African American or Latino who are still held back historically by discrimination.  And sometimes it's harder to get the society as a whole to invest in these kids.
 
But if we're going to be successful, we're going to have to do it.  This goes to a question that was asked earlier -- the United States, by the year 2050 -- which is only 35 years from now -- will no longer be a majority-white country -- think about that -- because the birth rates for particularly people of Hispanic background, but also Asians, in American, is much faster, much higher. 
 
So if those kids today who are poor aren't provided opportunity, our society as a whole is going to be poorer, because that's going to be the workforce of the future.  And that's where I think we have to make the most progress.

Wildscan      USAID  Wildlife Alliance  Freeland    

Wildscan - a mobile app used to help in the fight against illegal wildlife trading - recently launched in #Cambodia with Khmer translation. USAID Cambodia, Wildlife Alliance and Freeland  organized a launch event at the Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Centre, giving participants the chance to test the new app's features.  

             Wildscan      

I think that having WildScan in Khmer will benefit law enforcement in the country, said Khem Vuthyravong, Project Manager for Wildlife Alliances Wildlife Rapid Rescue Team, which has rescued over 62,000 live animals from the wildlife trade since 2001. It is easy to use, allowing for everyone to quickly identify a range of different animals.
 
Wildscan  Adroid  Iphone               http://freeland.org//wildlife-identification-app-launches/  

WildScan  available on both Android and Apple mobile devices  has been downloaded more than 1,000 times and is available in six Southeast Asian languages, with more to be added in the future. With information and photos for more than 500 animals and products, the app can also be used as an effective education tool. Learn more by visiting http://freeland.org/press-releases/wildlife-identification-app-launches-cambodia/.

Preserving History at Phnom Kulen
- From the Ambassador's Penh

Cambodia is known around the world for its amazing cultural patrimony, from archaeological sites to traditional folklore to Apsara Dance.  The U.S. government is a proud supporter of cultural heritage in Cambodia, particularly through the Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation Program (AFCP).  Since 2001, Cambodia has received 16 AFCP grants totaling more than $2.3 million, which puts it in second place worldwide (after only Afghanistan).  That is a testament not only to Cambodias extraordinary cultural heritage but also to the many great partners that we work with, including the Ministry of Culture and Fine Arts, UNESCO, and many cultural institutions and NGOs.

One of our most recent AFCP projects is the mapping, documentation, and preservation of Angkorian sites on Phnom Kulen.  The project is being carried out by the Archaeology and Development Foundation  (ADF) in cooperation with the APSARA National Authority and the Ministry of Environment.  The project is led by Dr. Jean-Baptiste Chevance, who is working with an amazingly talented team of Cambodian archaeologists and workers.
Phnom Kulen is a sandstone plateau located 40 kilometers northeast of the Angkor Archaeological Park and Siem Reap town that has been considered sacred for at least a thousand years.  Phnom Kulen is famous today for the Preah Ang Thom pagoda and its reclining Buddha.  The area remained largely unexplored for a long period of time and contains a myriad of significant archaeological remnants  from sculpted riverbeds and caves to ancient waterworks and temples.

Since 2008, ADF has been carrying out a systematic archaeological study and mapping project.  In 2012, ADF began to use an airborne laser scanning technology called LiDAR with the help of the University of Sydney.  Using LiDAR, ADF was able to uncover an unprecedented urban network, confirming the existence of Mahendraparvata, the renowned capital of Jayavarman II that dates to the 9th century.  The U.S. governments AFCP grant has helped ADF to complete the inventory of previously unknown features and to protect the sites from destructive agricultural practices.  
In addition to preserving cultural heritage, AFCP programs also help to build local expertise.  Thanks to the Phnom Kulen project, ADF has been able to train five Cambodian archaeologists in ground surveying techniques and in the use of LiDAR and Global Positioning Satellites.  Cambodian staff also play a crucial role in building awareness by local residents about the work that is being done and how it supports their communities.

An ongoing challenge that conservationists face at Phnom Kulen (and elsewhere) is the threat of deforestation.  At Phnom Kulen National Park, only 20 percent of the original forest cover remains  much of the rest has been turned into cashew nut plantations.  This not only damages the environment, but it also destroys important archaeological evidence.  Illegal logging is also a continuing challenge to conservation efforts.  Considering Phnom Kulens cultural and scientific value, it is essential that we look for solutions to protect the resource, including alternative agricultural practices and tourism development.

I am extremely proud that the U.S. government is playing an important role in the study and preservation of Phnom Kulen, and we look forward to supporting new cultural preservation projects in the years to come.  

Photo:  ADF archaeologist Sakhoeun Sakada in Phnom Kulen National Park.

Cambodian Acid Survivors Charity is an INGO registered in the U.S. which is committed to empowering and supporting survivors of acid burns and eliminating acid violence through legal reform and preventative education.  The center for acid attack victims is located in Srok Angk Snuol, Kandal Province, on a dirt road adjacent to the Bridgestone tire factory on Hwy 4.  The Cambodian Acid Survivors Charity (CASC) was established in 2006 by its sister organization, The Childrens Surgical Center, in response to a growing number of acid burn survivors seeking treatment at the center.  CASC is the only organization in Cambodia dealing exclusively with the issue of acid burns and acid attacks.  Using a holistic approach, they work at several levels to support and empower survivors of acid burns, as well as towards the elimination of acid violence altogether.  According to Ziad Samman, the CASC coordinator, in Cambodia there are currently around 233 acid attack survivors on the national registry.  Last year alone there were 28 acid attacks resulting in 33 victims.  While this number is alarming, Mr. Ziad feels that the number may be far greater and possibly as high as over 100 per year.  If you, or anyone you know is suffering from an acid attack, please contact the CASC Emergency Hotline number  at 092-600-031.  All services are free of charge.

Check out "'Tis Minnesota" - the latest music video by Cambodian composer, singer, and musician Young Yorn! Born in Kampong Thom, Yorn plays traditional Khmer music and has been involved with the arts in Cambodia for more than ten years, working with organizations like the Department of Fine Arts & Culture in Phnom Penh and the Apsara Arts Association. He is also an alumnus of the U.S. Department of State's OneBeat Program, which brings together musical leaders from around the world to develop a global network of civically engaged music initiatives.

In "'Tis Minnesota," Yorn sings about his experience visiting the U.S. state of Minnesota. He has also composed music about his time in Florida and New York. Today, Yorn continues to share his music with the world, performing in many festivals in Cambodia, the United States, and beyond. Congratulations Yorn!

See more at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LVQSoANP92g.

Alison  Kyra Carter   University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign         

When you picture Angkor Wat, you might think of the imposing and elegant temple surrounded by a thick forest of trees. However, archaeologists now know that when Angkor Wat was built, it was surrounded by a series of mounds that are likely places where people lived. Dr. Alison Kyra Carter, Visiting Assistant Professor, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

    ?  Greater Angkor Project (GAP)   Sydney 

Much of what is known about life at Angkor Wat comes from inscriptions on stone temple structures, which only tell the stories of the elites. But what about the lives of the ordinary citizens who made Angkor one of the largest population centers of its time? This question is a topic of interest for the scientists of the Greater Angkor Project (GAP)  a joint initiative between the Apsara Authority  and the University of Sydney.

  GAP   Alison Kyra Carter            Carter   Khmer Times      Carter   https://kh.usembassy.gov//household-archaeology-angkor-wa/ 
(   )

Last year, a GAP team led by U.S. archaeologist Dr. Alison Kyra Carter and her colleague Chhay Rachna carefully excavated a single mound that scientists believe used to be the site of a household. This painstaking and difficult work led to some amazing new discoveries, which Dr. Carter wrote about in a recent essay first published in the Khmer Times. The archaeologists found evidence of household activities, including what the people ate and how they cooked their food. 

To read Dr. Carters essay in Khmer, click here: https://kh.usembassy.gov/km/household-archaeology-angkor-wat-kh/

To read the essay in English, click here: http://www.khmertimeskh.com/news/26973/household-archaeology-at-angkor-wat/.

(Note: This article was translated by the U.S. Embassy with the permission of the author and the APSARA Authority.)

The 2016 White House Easter Egg Roll, hosted on Monday by President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama, welcomed more than 35,000 jubilant visitors to the White House lawn with the theme Lets Celebrate, in honor of President Obamas final year in office. This annual tradition is a fun way to celebrate the Easter holiday and is also a reminder of the beginning of the spring season. 

The Easter Egg Roll at the White House is a 138-year-old tradition started by President Rutherford B. Hayes when he invited a group of young children to roll Easter eggs on the lawn. This year's event was a fun-filled day of activities including the egg-roll, musical performances, cooking demonstrations, celebrity appearances, fitness activities and more. 

The President and Mrs. Obama also took time to read the classic story Where the Wild Things Are to a group of young children. Watch the video and see them act out the characters from the book!  Watch the full video from today's event and learn more about the history of the Easter Egg Roll here https://www.whitehouse.gov/eastereggroll

Speaking of media, a few days ago President Obama attended his final White House Correspondents Dinner. The annual event is traditionally attended by the President & First Lady and is famous for being the one night a year when the President is free to tell as many jokes as he can (often at his own expense). President Obama also had a serious message, taking time to thank the press for their work:

I know that there are times that weve had differences. But weve always shared the same goal  to root our public discourse in the truth; to open the doors of this democracy; to do whatever we can to make our country and our world more free and more just. And Ive always appreciated the role that you have all played as equal partners in reaching these goals.

Where Will YSEALI Take You?

Three English teachers from Cambodia, Seng Sovannsak, Chhoun Vychhean, and Heng Chanmolika, are participating in a Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) English Institute at the University of South Carolina in the United States.  The three Cambodians have joined more than 20 other English teachers from Southeast Asia to learn how to better teach the English language.  

Seng Sovannsak, Chhoun Vychhean, and Heng Chanmolika were selected to attend the YSEALI Institute because of their participation in the English Access Microscholarship Program - Headquarters, or ACCESS.  ACCESS provides a foundation of English language skills to talented 13- to 20-year-olds from economically disadvantaged communities through after-school classes and intensive sessions. Ms. Chanmolika, Mr. Sovannsak, and Mr. Vychhean teach English for the ACCESS program.  You can read more about the English Access Microscholarship Program here: http://goo.gl/45eRUA.

You can learn more about the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative and how you can join at http://goo.gl/8ibQMO.

#YSEALIGenEarth is in full swing today, with participants visiting the Angkor Centre for Conservation of Biodiversity (ACCB) at Kbal Spean.  ACCB staff met with the #YSEALI members to talk about critical issues affecting wildlife and biodiversity in Cambodia.  The lessons learned will be a part of the action plans being developed this week, which the youth leaders will take back to their communities throughout Southeast Asia.

YSEALI River Rehabilitation Project, Day Three

On Monday morning, Professor Eric Pallant went to the Ministry of Environment and met with 30 officials from the Department of Pollution Control.  After a brief presentation by the Ministry about current strategies to control water pollution in Cambodia, Professor Pallant addressed some of the participants most pressing concerns and answered questions.  Among the items discussed was the question of how to address the discharge of harmful wastes from factories into nearby streams and rivers.  Professor Pallant explained how public shaming via social media can be an effective means to curb pollution where other enforcement efforts are ineffective.  If major polluters know they will be exposed in the media, hopefully they will take pollution seriously and take steps to avoid public shaming.

Following the roundtable discussion at the Ministry, Professor Pallant continued his three-country tour, flying to Vietnam where he will work with the YSEALI Streams of Hope team there.  From there he will go on to the Philippines to speak again about maintaining healthy waterways.

You can follow the rest of Eric Pallants River Rehabilitation speaking tour in support of YSEALIs Streams of Hope project at U.S. Embassy, Manila Philippines Facebook page and U.S. Embassy in Hanoi Facebook page.  For updates on Twitter, follow #StreamsOfHope from @USEmbPhnomPenh or @USEmbassyManila.

Launched in 2013 by U.S. President Barack Obama, the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) consists of bright young leaders aged 18-35 years from Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, Burma, Philippines, Laos, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.  These young leaders have innovative ideas for tackling what they have identified as their generations greatest challenges in the ASEAN region: economic development, environmental protection, education, and civic engagement.  Every day, they are coming up with creative solutions  like using beneficial microbes to clean rivers or creating job opportunities by selling products made from water lilies.  The United States is partnering with these extraordinary young men and women through YSEALI.  YSEALI provides training and funding to up-and-coming community leaders and social entrepreneurs.  More on YSEALI here: https://youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov/

Taking Care of Our Animals
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Cambodia is home to an amazingly diverse collection of animals.  One animal  the elephant  has long been part of Cambodian history.  Elephants have assisted human endeavors in various ways for centuries; from helping Cambodians sustain themselves through agriculture and forestry, to even taking Khmer warriors into battle.  If you have visited the Angkor Wat area, I am sure that you noticed the images of elephants carved on the walls of ancient Khmer temples.  Elephants can still be seen in Cambodia today carrying crops, lumber and just about anything else, including tourists.  Unfortunately, the number of elephants in Cambodia has decreased over the years due to illegal poaching and mistreatment.  I recently had the pleasure to learn more about these endangered animals at the Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center during a visit with my Youth Council.

Today, I want to focus on a very special elephant named Sambo, one of Phnom Penhs most famous attractions.  For more than 30 years, Sambo spent nine or more hours a day carrying tourists around Wat Phnom.  Sambos work helped support her owner, Sin Sorn, and his family.  However, the numerous hours spent walking on the hard pavement of Phnom Penhs streets caused Sambo to develop chronic foot infections.  After her plight received worldwide attention in 2012, a nongovernmental organization was able to provide Sambo with the medical treatment she dearly needed.  

I was delighted to learn that Sambo is retiring to a special elephant sanctuary in Mondulkiri Province, where she will live with other elephants and receive proper veterinary care.  Sambos retirement and transportation to her new home is a wonderful example of what can be accomplished by working together.  This collaborative effort was supported by the U.S. government through the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), Cambodias Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, the Alexander Abraham Foundation, and private citizens.  A farewell ceremony was held in her honor in Phnom Penh last week and I was pleased to see a number of Cambodian and international media outlets covering the event.  Sambos story is truly uplifting and helps put the people of Cambodia in a positive light.

This week, I have been eagerly waiting for news about Sambos journey to her new home.  So I was delighted to hear that five days after leaving Phnom Penh, Sambo safely arrived at the Elephants Livelihood Initiative Environment project inside the Seima Protected Forest.  From the reports I received, she looks happy in her new home and will meet other elephants in the next few days.  I would like to thank everyone who made all of this possible; especially the people who cared for Sambo during the long journey to Mondulkiri. 

I believe that all animals deserve to be treated well.  As a reader, you know that I am an animal lover and my family has had a dog for nearly as long as I can remember.  By treating Sambo and other animals with respect and dignity, our society demonstrates compassion.  I commend Mr. Sorn for agreeing to let Sambo  now 52 years old  retire and spend the remaining years of her life in a natural habitat with other elephants.  As Mr. Sorn said, We owe Sambo a great debt and it is time to pay her back.  I couldnt agree more.

PRESS RELEASE

The U.S. Embassy in Cambodia welcomes todays historic guilty verdict by the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia (ECCC) against Nuon Chea, the deputy to Pol Pot, and Khieu Samphan, a former head of state, for crimes against humanity committed during the Khmer Rouge regime.  We express our gratitude to the judges and other representatives of the tribunal for their hard work and commitment to justice.

The U.S. Government has long supported the goal of prosecuting those most responsible for the atrocities perpetrated by the Khmer Rouge regime, which claimed as many as 2.2 million victims and brought unimaginable hardship and misery to the people of Cambodia.  We hope that this verdict will offer a measure of peace and justice to the families of the victims of the Khmer Rouge.

The U.S. Government will continue to support the efforts of the ECCC to bring justice to the Cambodian people, to shed light on the horrific crimes of the Khmer Rouge regime, and to strengthen the rule of law in Cambodia.

John Kerry       Washington, D.C.     Barack Obama  Leonado DiCaprio    ,     

On September 15-16, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry convened heads of state, scientists, business leaders, NGOs, and others to Washington, D.C. for the third #OurOcean conference.  President Barack Obama and actor Leonardo DiCaprio delivered remarks at the conference, which generated more than $5.2 billion in commitments to help protect the ocean and inspired nearly 40 significant new or expanded marine protected areas.

                  

Cambodian Minister of Environment Say Samal gave a presentation outlining steps the Cambodian government has taken to support environmental preservation, including the creation of Cambodias first marine protected area, which covers 405 square kilometers in the waters of the Koh Rong Archipelago. Minister Samal noted that Cambodia has worked to improve natural resource protection, biodiversity conservation, and sustainable development. He called on countries to show more commitments to improving the environment through dedicated funding and by transferring technology to developing countries to support enforcement of environmental regulations.

  Catherine Novelli   

During his visit, Minister Samal also met with Catherine Novelli, Under Secretary for Economic Growth, Energy, and the Environment for the U.S. State Department.

   http://1000oceanactions.org/ 

Click here to see how countries around the world are working to save our oceans: http://1000oceanactions.org/.

To combat child malnutrition, USAIDs Quality Health Services project works with health centers and referral hospitals in Cambodia to improve reproductive, maternal, newborn, and child health and nutrition services.  The project focuses on strengthening screening, counseling, referral, prevention, and treatment of child malnutrition, particularly severe acute malnutrition, and malnutrition-related diseases.  Learn more about this project, here http://bit.ly/1bOk2ac
#USAID #Cambodia USAID - US Agency for International Development

"All people deserve to live free from fear, violence, and discrimination, regardless of who they are or whom they love." - President Obama

May 17 is International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia (#IDAHOT), which stands as a reminder that #LGBTI rights are also human rights. In #Cambodia, the NGO Khana Cambodia plays a leading role in providing quality care and support to members of the LGBTI community throughout the country. KHANA's work includes giving technical assistance to implementing partners and community workers, providing health services, case documentation on human right abuses, advocacy campaigns, and much more. LGBT persons who benefited from these efforts have expressed a great sense of relief with being able to be themselves, thanks to the support and counseling received from KHANA. The United States is proud to support KHANA through USAID Cambodia and the Flagship HIV/AIDS Project, part of The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). Learn more about KHANA and what they are doing to promote #PRIDE and #HumanRights in Cambodia at www.khana.org.kh.

#may17IDAHOT

It is estimated that as many as 27 million men, women, and children are victims of human trafficking around the world.  

To help free victims, prevent exploitation, and bring traffickers to justice, the U.S. Department of State issues the Trafficking in Persons Report each year.  The report represents an updated, global look at the nature and scope of trafficking in persons, and the broad range of actions governments can take to confront and eliminate it.  

U.S. Secretary of State Kerry will release the 2014 Trafficking in Persons Report tonight at 8:00 pm (Cambodia time).  Watch it live and learn more about this important human rights issue:  http://state.gov

As part of their humanitarian efforts in #Cambodia, the U.S. Navy Seabees - Mobile Construction Battalion 3 recently completed a civil construction project at Prey Sbat Health Center in Takeo Province. After finishing their work, the team was also able to use some of the materials from the project to place a concrete floor in a nearby home for a family of six. Mrs. Srey Roth - the mother of the house - was very appreciative of the new floor and says, "It will help my business during the rainy season. Now customers won't have to stand in the mud when buying my vegetables."

To learn more about the U.S. Navy Seabees and the work that they do in Cambodia and other countries around the world, please visit http://www.public.navy.mil/seabee/Pages/default.aspx.

Seven Cambodian students will attend U.S. universities to pursue Masters degrees in law, economics, agriculture, journalism, and computer science as the latest recipients of the U.S. governments Fulbright Foreign Student Fellowship.  

On Tuesday, the U.S. Embassy hosted a ceremony to congratulate the students for being selected for this highly competitive scholarship program.  Public Affairs Officer Sean McIntosh presented the students with certificates of recognition.  He praised the students academic excellence and commitment to community service, and encouraged them to mentor younger Cambodians when they return from their studies in the United States.

Have you heard about the positive impact young Cambodians are making in the community?  Earlier this week, 6 members of the Fulbright and Undergraduate State Alumni Association of Cambodia (FUSAAC) volunteered to teach soft skills to 40 English Access program students in the Kampong Chhnang province.  The students were full of energy as they participated in a community outreach project while learning to build confidence and enhance their study habits.  The English Access Microscholarship program is available to students in 7 provinces throughout Cambodia.  To learn more about this program, click here: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/access_-_cambodia.html

50 States in 50 Days: Day 37 - Nebraska

Carhenge is an automobile replica of Englands Stonehenge.

Completed in 1987, Carhenge is a memorial to Local engineer Jim Reinders father and a must-see when youre in Nebraska.

Reinders placed 38 automobiles from the 1950s and 1960s to assume the same positions and proportions as Stonehenge and painted the structure gray.

Explore more: http://goo.gl/e69pF

(System of Rice Intensification)           (English) https://share.america.gov/passion-produces-sustainable-rice/

A number of farmers in #Cambodia are using the System of Rice Intensification (SRI), a rice planting method that produces bigger crops while using less water and fewer seeds.  SRI is one of many sustainable practices that are revolutionizing agriculture and preserving the environment, making a difference in the lives of millions of farmers worldwide.  Learn more about SRI at https://share.america.gov/passion-produces-sustainable-rice/

Photo: Rice farmers in Cambodia using sustainable farming methods. (Courtesy of SRI International Network)

Please join us in congratulating the latest Cambodian winners of the YSEALI Seeds for the Future Grant Competition!  After reviewing hundreds of applications by young leaders throughout ASEAN, two Cambodian-led projects  Local Youth Volunteering in Action and Young Eco Ambassador: Catalyst  were among the 18 finalists chosen.  With this support from the United States, Local Youth Volunteering in Action will provide educational support to children in rural Cambodian communities, while Young Eco Ambassador: Catalyst will focus on environmental awareness in Cambodia and throughout the region.

Members of the Urbral Shapers and Gen Y Leaders Xchange 4 Action projects  winners of last years competition  recently met with this years winners to congratulate them and share their own experiences.  One of these role models is Kim Kosoma, who has worked with her team to focus on anti-corruption and youth leadership development in Cambodia and Thailand.  In recognition of her efforts, Kosoma was selected to attend the Rising Stars Regional Exchange Program in Jakarta, Indonesia later this month.

The U.S. Embassy wishes good luck to all of our #YSEALI Seeds for the Future Grant winners.  To learn more about the YSEALI Seeds for the Future Grant and other funding opportunities, please visit http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/grant_programs.html.

Hurry up!!!

The deadline for Teaching Excellence and Achievement Program (TEA) has been changed to March 30, 2013.

More info: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/tea.html

Eligibility and Selection Criteria:

* Be secondary-level, full-time teachers

* Have a Bachelor's degree or the equivalent

* Have five or more years of classroom experience in English as a Foreign Language (EFL), social studies, math, or science

* Reside in the country of citizenship (Cambodia) at the time of application

* Have English language skills adequate to develop lesson plans, conduct research, audit classes in U.S. host universities, and team-teach in U.S. schools (TOEFL score of 450 or equivalent); and

* Have had little or no experience in the U.S.

William Heidt        

      

 Heidt          

 Heidt                

Ambassador William Heidt presented his credentials as Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the United States of America to the Kingdom of Cambodia to Samdech Vibol Sena Pheakdey Say Chhum, Acting Head of State and President of Cambodian Senate, on Wednesday morning, December 2, 2015, during a ceremony at the Senate in Phnom Penh.   Cambodian Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister H.E. Hor Namhong was also present at the credentials ceremony. 

In his remarks, Ambassador Heidt told Samdech Vibol Say Chhum that during his term as Ambassador he hopes to deepen and strengthen U.S.-Cambodian relations.  Since we arrived in September, we have been very impressed by the progress Cambodia has made over the last 15 years, Ambassador Heidt said.  I look forward to working with the Government, the private sector, civil society, and ordinary Cambodians to build a stronger relationship between the United States and Cambodia.

#AmbHeidt

Ambassador Todd:  "I meet daily with government officials, politicians, business leaders, and civil society leaders, but I also enjoy discussions with my tuk-tuk driver, the lady who runs the kuy teav noodle stand around the corner from my house, and the young students who are part of my Youth Council.  From these conversations, it is clear to me that change to most Cambodians isnt some intangible concept; what they want is for the government to address the specific problems that affect their daily lives and to expand opportunities for all the countrys citizens, not just an elite few.  Concerns about respect for personal freedoms and the rule of law and the need for a livable wage are themes that I consistently hear..." 

Click the links to read Ambassador Todd's column "Creating Opportunities for All Cambodians through Change"

Changing People and Communities with Soccer
- From the Ambassador's Penh

"As many of my readers may know, the U.S. Womens National Team recently won the 2015 FIFA Womens World Cup.  Americans all over the world are celebrating this electrifying victory by our national womens soccer team.  I am very proud of these young athletes, who have shown that anything is possible through hard-work and resolve.  Congratulations to all members of the U.S. Womens National Team!

As Nelson Mandela once said, Sport has the power to change the world.  Events like the FIFA Womens World Cup show us all that a universal passion for sports can transcend linguistic and sociocultural differences to bring people together.  Sports also play a role in shaping strong, inspiring individuals.  As the members of the U.S. Womens National Team have shown, participation in sports teaches leadership, teamwork, and communication skills that can help young people succeed in all areas of their lives.  It is great to know that this is also taking place in many forms here in Cambodia."

Read more: http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/changing-people-and-communities-with-soccer/ (English)

Ambassador Todd: "Cambodia is home to a diverse population of wildlife, including some of the planets rarest creatures. Sadly, as in other parts of the world, human activities are threatening the survival of these animals. When my Youth Council and I discussed environmental issues affecting Cambodia, we agreed that dwindling wildlife was among the worst consequences of environmental degradation in this country. To learn more about the situation of endangered animals in Cambodia and the efforts to protect them, my Youth Council and I visited the Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center last week..."

U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh, Cambodia added a new photo to the album: U.S. Navy Seabees in Cambodia.

The Role of the Youth and Social Media in Cambodias Development 

The Cambodian elections remain the most popular topic of interest to readers, many of whom have asked, What is the latest U.S. position on the elections?  So I am very happy to take this opportunity to continue dialoguing with readers about this historic moment in Cambodias history.   Obama       https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2016/03/22/live-update-mornings-attacks-brussels 

The thoughts and the prayers of the American people are with the people of Belgium.  We stand in solidarity with them in condemning these outrageous attacks against innocent people.  We will do whatever is necessary to support our friend and ally, Belgium, in bringing to justice those who are responsible.  And this is yet another reminder that the world must unite, we must be together, regardless of nationality, or race, or faith, in fighting against the scourge of terrorism.  We can - and will - defeat those who threaten the safety and security of people all around the world.

In a Proclamation, President Obama ordered that U.S. flags be flown at half-staff in the United States and around the world to honor the victims of the attack. Please visit The White House website at https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2016/03/22/live-update-mornings-attacks-brussels for more details.

(April 25, 2015) U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry's official statement regarding the recent earthquakes in Nepal:

I join the people of the United States in expressing our deepest condolences to all of those affected by today's earthquake in Nepal, including the families of those who died in Nepal, India, China, and Bangladesh.

We are working closely with the government of Nepal to provide assistance and support. Ambassador Bodde has issued a disaster declaration in order to immediately release an initial $1 million for humanitarian assistance. USAID is preparing to deploy a Disaster Assistance Response Team and is activating an Urban Search and Rescue Team to accompany disaster experts and assist with assessments of the situation.

To the people in Nepal and the region affected by this tragedy we send our heartfelt sympathies. The United States stands with you during this difficult time.

Happy #WorldHealthDay!  Every year on April 7 we pause to celebrate World Health Day, sponsored by the World Health Organization (WHO).  The goal of World Health Day is to raise awareness of important global health concerns like food safety, mental health, and traffic accidents.

This years World Health Day is focused on diabetes, which affects nearly 350 million people worldwide.  Diabetes  a serious condition that affects the way your body uses blood sugar  is increasingly seen in low and middle-income countries like Cambodia.  Fortunately, many cases of diabetes can be prevented through simple steps like a healthy diet and regular exercise.

In Cambodia, the U.S. government is helping to reduce the impact of diabetes and other diseases by improving nutrition and increasing access to quality health care services.  This important and life-saving work is supported by a number of agencies including the USAID - US Agency for International Development, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ( CDC), and The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).

U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh staff teamed up with U.S. Missions around the world to mark #WorldHealthDay by wearing the color green.  For more on World Health Day, go to http://www.who.int/campaigns/world-health-day/2016/en/

Returning a Symbol of Cambodias Heritage
-From the Ambassador's Penh

During my time as Ambassador, I have come to appreciate Cambodias unique cultural heritage  a source of tremendous pride and identity for the Cambodian people.  Like many of you, I am troubled by reports about priceless artifacts that have been stolen and trafficked.  However, I am encouraged that individuals, institutions, and governments are working in partnership to protect the rich cultural heritage of Cambodia and the proud history of the Khmer people.

This week, we witnessed a success story in the ongoing efforts to repatriate looted art to Cambodia.  During an official handover ceremony at the Council of Ministers building on Tuesday, Deputy Prime Minister Sok An welcomed the return of Hanuman, a 10th century statue of the Hindu monkey god which was looted from Prasat Chen at Koh Ker during the turbulence of the Khmer Rouge era.  The Hanuman statue had been in the possession of the Cleveland Museum of Art since 1982.

Along with the Duryodhana, Bhima, and Balarama statues that were returned last year and the twin Pandava Kneeling Attendant statues that were returned in 2013, the Hanuman is the sixth statue from Prasat Chen that has returned to Cambodia.  I am pleased that these statues are back where they belong.

I would like to congratulate the Cleveland Museum of Art and its director, Dr. William Griswold, for their efforts to return the Hanuman statue after the museum uncovered information about the statues provenance.  The Cleveland Museum of Arts efforts reflect the highest ethical standards and demonstrate a true commitment to the preservation of Cambodias cultural heritage.  

I also applaud the Cleveland Museum of Art for signing a memorandum of understanding with the National Museum of Cambodia to collaborate on future projects.  This agreement between the two institutions is an excellent example of the strong bonds of friendship, cooperation, and respect between our two nations.  As Dr. Griswold said, We are very happy to provide assistance to the National Museum and to be working with our Cambodian colleagues from whom we are learning more and more about the art and culture of Cambodia.  We are very excited about the possibilities for increasing the American publics awareness of and appreciation for Khmer art through loans to our museum.

For many years, the U.S. Embassy has worked with Cambodia to help protect the Kingdoms unique historical and cultural heritage and to encourage others to do the same.  I believe this repatriation underscores the deepening relationship between our two countries.  I look forward to continuing this partnership to safeguard Cambodias cultural legacy for future generations.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

To read more entries from Ambassador Todd's blog with Khmer translation, go to: blogs.usembassy.gov/todd

Our objective is clear: we will degrade, and ultimately destroy, ISIL through a comprehensive and sustained counter-terrorism strategy. President Barack Obama, September 10, 2014

On Wednesday night, President Barack Obama introduced his four-point strategy to combat the terrorist group known as ISIL to the American people.  After demonstrating the threats posed by ISIL, President Obama explained that this is not Americas fight alone and that America leads a broad coalition to roll back this terrorist threat.  The President then outlined his four-point strategy.

Ambassador Todd: "Decades of conflict, ending in the 1990s, left Cambodia with lingering dangers caused by millions of pieces of explosive remnants of war. Each year, landmines and UXO kill and injure scores of Cambodians.

The good news is that the number of casualties from landmines and UXO in Cambodia has steadily and dramatically declined over the past decade. Of course, any number above zero is still too high, which is why the United States invests significantly in humanitarian mine action and UXO clearance operations in Cambodia."

Ambassador Todd:
"I believe every Cambodian child should have the opportunity to complete their education.

Thats why Im pleased that the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) has been working closely with the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport to address the school dropout dilemma.

The USAID-funded School Dropout Prevention Pilot (SDPP) Program is a five-year applied research program aimed toreducethe number of dropouts from lower secondary schools in Cambodia.

Working with local partner Kampuchean Action for Primary Education (KAPE), the SDPP Program helped reduce dropouts among lower secondary students from 215 schools in Banteay Meanchey, Battambang, Kampong Speu, Prey Veng, Pursat, and Svay Rieng provinces.

Between 2012 and 2014, nearly 60,000 children benefited from the program, which helped reduce the dropout rate by 2.5 percentage points.

And among at-risk students, the programs Early Warning System reduced dropouts by 7 percentage points.

This is wonderful news and I couldnt be happier with the results."

Read more: http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/working-together-to-reduce-school-dropoutsin-cambodia/

Peace Corps Helping Girls to Become Leaders
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Last week, I mentioned that many girls in Cambodia face numerous challenges to stay in school.  Girls in Cambodia also face obstacles that inhibit them from voicing their opinions and playing an active role in their communities.  Today, I want to highlight the efforts of our dedicated U.S. Peace Corps Volunteers who are making a difference in Cambodia.  Since 2006, more than 360 Peace Corps Volunteers have served in Cambodia.  As part of their various education and health projects, the Volunteers are also working with students, families, and the communities where they serve to empower young women and to find solutions that allow girls to stay in school.

When First Lady of the United States Michelle Obama visited Cambodia two weeks ago, she delivered a speech to the very first Let Girls Learn workshop for Peace Corps Volunteers and the local leaders, educators, and students they work with.  Mrs. Obama told the workshop participants youre the embodiment of what Let Girls Learn is all about.  Its really about Peace Corps Volunteers, community leaders, parents, and girls themselves working side-by-side to help girls go to school, and, more importantly, stay in school.  Eventually the Peace Corps will conduct these girls education workshops for all of its nearly 7,000 volunteers and tens of thousands of community leaders in the countries they work in.

In support of the Let Girls Learn initiative, Peace Corps is promoting and helping fundraising efforts for girls empowerment programs such as Camp GLOW (Girls Leading Our World).  These camps, held all across the world in every Peace Corps country, are designed to encourage young women to become active citizens by promoting gender equality, developing leadership skills, improving self-esteem, increasing knowledge of womens health issues, and supporting aspirations and career goals.  These camps offer adolescent girls self-development opportunities in a fun and friendly atmosphere and instill in each young woman the belief that she can make a difference in her community and country.

Here in Cambodia, more than 2,400 Cambodian students participated in GLOW camps and workshops conducted by Peace Corps Volunteers last year.  Just last weekend, eight Volunteers and their counterparts organized a three-day GLOW camp in Prey Veng for 64 girls from Prey Veng and Svay Rieng.  The camp provided a safe space where the girls could learn about general and reproductive health, the dangers of human trafficking, and about healthy relationships and domestic violence.  The girls also learned about resume writing, attending college, and applying for scholarships in a workshop designed help them prepare for future opportunities.  Another six camps will be held across Cambodia in May and June of this year. 

I want to thank all the Volunteers and their counterparts for working so hard to make the GLOW camps so successful.  It is truly inspiring to see how the camps have encouraged girls to discover their voices.  I know these efforts are having a tremendous impact from the testimony I hear from organizers and participants.  Kelly Confer, one of the Volunteers who helped organize the GLOW camp in Prey Veng, said the girls now have the knowledge and have been given the tools to continue their education.  Tara Kelly, a Volunteer in Kampong Cham said, I see incredible change from my young female students in just two years.  I see them thinking about their futures for the first time.  I see them standing up confidently in class.

More importantly, the young women that Tara mentors are transferring their passion to work towards change to other young women just like them.  Samanik, Taras host sister, attended the Let Girls Learn workshop in Siem Reap and contributed often during the group activities.  The remarks by Mrs. Obama have inspired Samanik to help her peers get an education.  She has many friends who have dropped out of school.  Now she is coming up with ideas to get her friends back in school and using social media to promote girls education.  Samanik is an example of how a personal relationship with a Peace Corps Volunteer can lead to big changes in one girl.  I truly believe these personal relationships the Volunteers have developed with their students and others in the community have helped change peoples minds about the importance of girls education.  I couldnt be more proud of Samanik, Tara, and everyone else making a difference in the lives of Cambodian girls. 

The First Lady told Samanik and the other Cambodian girls we need you to be the leaders of tomorrow.  Mrs. Obama added, When you have the chance to fulfill your potential, theres no limit to what you can achieve.  I couldnt agree more.  And thanks to the Peace Corps GLOW camps, girls are empowered to voice themselves and participate in their community and country.  

#AmbTodd #Cambodia Peace Corps Cambodia #FLOTUS

Cambodia's Mobile Phone Culture
-From the Ambassador's Penh

No matter where I travel in this country, every Cambodian I meet tells me how much they love their mobile phone!  Since I arrived nearly three years ago, I have watched with astonishment the dramatic growth in the use of mobile phones in Cambodia.  According to the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, the number of mobile phone subscribers in Cambodia topped 20 million in 2013  which means there are five million more mobile phone subscriptions than there are people in Cambodia. 

The reach of mobile phones in Cambodia is hard to miss, with over 90 percent of the population having access.  Today, mobile phones play a big role in improving the lives of people by providing access to information in places where landlines or the Internet are not available.  The transformative effect that mobile phones are having on Cambodian society is evident in a number of examples.  More people are starting to access resources for English language education through their phones.  Farmers living in rural provinces today can now use a basic mobile phone to make calls and receive text messages about commodity prices on cassava or the latest market price of rice.  Students are using their smart phones to connect with others on the Internet and participate in online discussions.  For some Cambodians, accessing news and information via online media through the phone either compliments or replaces traditional media.  So as you can see, there is tremendous opportunity for mobile phone technology to enhance the lives of every Cambodian.   

The rise of mobile applications (apps) for smart phones allows people to shop, video chat, navigate streets, and much more.  Smart phone apps are designed to make our lives easier and more efficient.  With the trend of smart phones becoming more popular in Cambodia, the demand for quality application developers who know the local market is increasing as well.  Currently, there are very few apps developed for the Cambodian community.  Thats why members of my Embassy staff have spoken to information technology students at Cambodian universities and encouraged them to become part of the community of mobile application developers. 

Did you also know there is an app for teachers and students looking to build their English skills?  They can download the free American English Mobile App developed by the U.S. Department of State anytime, anywhere on their mobile phone.  The app works with almost any phone and users can download audiobooks, e-books, music, dictionary and translation tools, and much more.  In addition to this, we support the development of mobile apps through the USAID-funded Development Innovations program and its Social Innovation Lab, which helps promote the use of technology to meet Cambodias development challenges. 

Mobile phone technology can also help Cambodians deal with specific issues affecting them.  In the health sector, mobile technology helps key populations stay healthy and receive the treatment and care they need.  In this endeavor, the U.S. government has assisted in the development of an interactive voice response (IVR) system and smart phone apps to support HIV prevention and treatment, expanded the use of a mobile phone alert system that rapidly shares tuberculosis diagnoses via text messaging, and developed a mobile phone application to improve malaria prevention and treatment.  

Are you one of the many people in Cambodia who uses a mobile phone to access the Internet and social media platforms like Facebook?  If so, I encourage you to like the U.S. Embassys Facebook page if you are not already a fan.  There you will find all the most current information about the programs we offer. 

Do you have a mobile phone?  I am eager to hear how mobile technology has made an impact in your daily life. 

#AmbTodd

The President will travel to Bangkok, Thailand; Rangoon, Burma and Phnom Penh, Cambodia from November 17-20.

In Thailand, he will meet with Prime Minister Yingluck to mark 180 years of diplomatic relations and reaffirm the strength of our alliance.

In Burma, the President will meet with President Thein Sein and Aung San Suu Kyi and speak to civil society to encourage Burmas ongoing democratic transition.

In Cambodia, the President will attend the East Asia Summit and meet with the leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

During his interactions in the region he will discuss a broad range of issues including economic prosperity and job creation through increased trade and partnerships, energy and security cooperation, human rights, shared values and other issues of regional and global concern. 

Additional details about the trip will be released at a later date.

Celebrating Khmer New Year
-From the Ambassador's Penh

I want to take this opportunity not only to wish a Happy Khmer New Year to all Cambodians, but share how we celebrated this important holiday at the U.S. Embassy last week.  As you can see in these photos, we had a wonderful time marking the arrival of the Year of the Goat!  Thanks to our Cambodian staff members who organized the annual New Year celebration for the community, we enjoyed traditional Khmer culture, games, food, and dance.  In particular, I want to recognize the commitment of our Local Employee Committee members who work diligently to help us maintain high employee morale year round.

The beauty of Cambodian culture was on full display with performances by the children from the National Action Culture for the Orphan Poor Children Association (NACOPCA), an NGO dedicated to providing poor and orphaned children with accommodation, food, and education while giving them an opportunity to learn traditional Cambodian dancing.  Following the traditional Blessing Dance was the Trot, a traditional dance based on two folktales, which showcases wild animals to ward off bad luck from the previous year and bring good luck and prosperity in the coming year.

Our celebration also included the folk dance Chhay Yam, which featured drummers and dancers wearing comic masks.  Chhay Yam is performed in the countryside and the cities on ceremonial occasions, such as the marking of the end of the monks rainy season retreat.  Next was an adaptation of the fairy tale Cinderella, which was presented by some of the Embassys Cambodian and American staff members.  This was followed by a fun fashion show of different forms of traditional Cambodian dress.  It was wonderful to see these colleagues share their enthusiasm and artistic talent with their co-workers.

The celebration would not have been complete without some fun and friendly competition.  One of my favorite traditional Khmer games is Bos Angkhun, which is played by throwing an inedible fruit seed (angkhun) at targets.  We also tested our physical strength in a game of tug-of-war, which is called Teanh Proatt in Khmer, and had fun racing one another in Leak Kanseng.  

 I am grateful for all of their outstanding accomplishments and hard work of our staff during the past year.  Without their talents and dedication, the U.S. Embassy would not be able to carry out its mission to engage with the Cambodian people in so many ways.  To all of my Cambodian readers, as you gather with your families and return to your home towns in the coming days, I would like to wish you a peaceful, prosperous, happy, and safe Khmer New Year.

Suor Sdey Chhnam Thmei!

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

Official Statement - State Department
Further Deterioration of Cambodias Democratic Environment (English below)
  

    (CNRP)                     
               
       -
http://khmer.cambodia.usembassy.gov/111615_pr.html

We are deeply concerned by todays removal of Cambodian National Rescue Party (CNRP) leader Sam Rainsy from the National Assembly in a unilateral move by the ruling Cambodian Peoples Party.  We call on the National Assembly to reinstate him immediately and to restore his parliamentary immunity.  We also call on the government to revoke the arrest warrant issued against Rainsy on seven-year-old defamation charges and to allow him and other opposition Parliamentarians to return to Cambodia without fear of arrest or persecution.  

Todays actions are the latest incidents of harassment and intimidation of Cambodias opposition, including the recent violent attacks against two opposition Members of Parliament and the removal of opposition party deputy leader Kem Sokha from his position as First Vice President of the National Assembly.  These developments are harmful to Cambodian democracy and contrary to the wishes of the Cambodian people.

We urge the government to take immediate steps to guarantee a political space free from threats or intimidation in Cambodia, and for the government and opposition to engage in serious and meaningful dialogue on actions to strengthen Cambodias democratic future.
http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/pr_en111615.html

AMBASSADOR HEIDT'S STATEMENT ON HUMAN RIGHTS DAY
December 10, 2015 

Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers." - Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights

The United States stands with the people of #Cambodia and billions of others around the world in celebration of Human Rights Day. This years theme highlights four freedoms  freedom of speech, of religion, from want, and from fear  which underlie the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. While there has been significant progress in advancing these and other fundamental freedoms in Cambodia, more needs to be done in order to safeguard these liberties for all citizens.
 
When reflecting on the true meaning of freedom  particularly the freedom of speech  I recall a famous quote: I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it." Freedom of expression is not only guaranteed under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights; it is also a vital element of the Constitution of the Royal Kingdom of Cambodia. Therefore, I encourage all Cambodians  members of the Royal Government, civil society, and everyday citizens  to work together to ensure that the countrys laws, the media, and the Internet are devices utilized to protect the freedom of expression.
 
The United States is deeply committed to the protection of the basic freedoms enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.  As President Obama notes, Protecting human rights around the globe extends the promise of democracy and bolsters the values that serve as a basis for peace in our world.  As U.S. Ambassador to the Royal Kingdom of Cambodia, I am proud to support the Cambodian people as the country continues to develop a strong and enduring democracy that fully promotes and protects human rights.  The U.S. Embassy remains committed to our partnerships with all sectors of Cambodian society to promote freedom and democracy  not only on #HumanRightsDay, but every day.

#AmbHeidt
#HumanRights

1961: Cambodian architect Vann Molyvann unveils the Chaktomuk Conference Hall in Phnom Penh. Considered a masterpiece of New Khmer Architecture  a movement that unites modernist sensibilities with distinctly Cambodian traditions  the building is constructed with the help of U.S. assistance. Vann Molyvann helps usher in a golden age of Khmer culture, during which architecture, music, and film flourish until the Khmer Rouge takeover in 1975.
 
1962: The International Court of Justice in The Hague rules in favor of Cambodia in a dispute with Thailand over Preah Vihear, an 11th century temple located in a disputed area near the Thai border. Former U.S. Secretary of State Dean Acheson successfully represents Cambodia in the case, which many observers had predicted would see Thailand prevail. After the verdict, Prince Norodom Sihanouk proclaims a seven-day national holiday and the country erupts into mass celebrations.

1965: With the conflict escalating in Vietnam, border incursions into eastern Cambodia increase and result in civilian casualties. Prince Sihanouk fears for his countrys territorial integrity and seeks assurances from both the United States and communist governments. His political power is further threatened by dissident groups. Meanwhile, the United States claims that the Cambodian military is cooperating with Viet Cong forces. Unable to resolve their grievances, the United States and Cambodia officially sever diplomatic ties in May. Relations are not restored until the end of the decade.

1967: Jacqueline Kennedy visits Cambodia in November as a personal guest of Prince Sihanouk. A crowd of 10,000 greets her at Pochentong Airport in Phnom Penh, including girls strewing jasmine petals in a traditional Buddhist welcome. During her trip, the former First Lady fulfills a lifelong dream of visiting Angkor Wat. She is the first American to be received with high state honors since ties were broken, signaling a promising turn in the relationship.

1969: President Richard M. Nixon orders a covert bombing campaign of eastern Cambodia. Operation Menu lasts 14 months and results in the release of some 2,756,941 tons of ordnance. Nixon authorizes the bombings in an attempt to thwart Viet Cong forces, which by 1970 occupy between a fifth and a third of Cambodian territory. The campaign does not become known to the American public until 1973.

1969: Diplomatic relations are restored. The U.S. Embassy reopens on August 16, with Lloyd M. Rives acting as Charg dAffaires ad interim and a staff of eight. Later that month, in an effort to demonstrate Washingtons renewed commitment to Cambodia, U.S. Senator Mike Mansfield visits Phnom Penh for the third time in seven years. During the visit, Prince Sihanouk calls the Senator one of the greatest and most loyal friends to Cambodia.

Apply now for the Spring 2017 #YSEALI Academic Fellows Program!

YSEALI members between the ages of 18 and 25 are eligible to apply for the YSEALI Academic Fellows Program, which offers a month-long study opportunity at prestigious U.S. colleges and universities. Academic Fellows will build their leadership skills while focusing on one of three themes: civic engagement, environmental and natural resource management, and entrepreneurship and economic development.

Fellows will visit the United States for five weeks, with four weeks of classroom activities and a one-week study tour, ending in Washington, DC. The programs are scheduled to begin in February and March 2017.

Sok Sopheak Panha is an Academic Fellow alumnus from 2016, when she studied civic engagement at Kennesaw State University in Georgia. "The Academic Fellows program helped me to have a new way of thinking, Panha says. I want to tell the Cambodian youth that you can do it! You can do better than you think. By starting with something small you can become a big success someday. 

To apply for this program, visit https://kh.usembassy.gov/yseali-academic-fellowships/. 

Not a member of YSEALI yet? Click our new quick link button under the photo at the top of our Facebook page to sign up!

Watch video of the Environmental Fair celebrating the 40th anniversary of Earth Day.

Ambassador Carol A. Rodley hosted the event, which featured displays by 14 local environmental NGOs and eco-businesses, nature-themed song and dance performances, and a recyclable art contest. The Embassy invited 10 high school teams to submit entries in the contest, which showcased conservation messages or ways in which trash can be reused. The teams rose to the challenge, creating innovative sculptures out of used paper, cans, bottles, straws, and other materials. The sculptures were judged at the fair by Ambassador Rodley, Minister of Environment Mok Mareth, Deputy Director of the Department of Education, Youth, and Sport Mr. Huot Samreth, and children from the Maryknoll Little Sprouts Program. Team Rescue from Indra Devy High School took the top prize with their rendering of a Cambodian fisherman out of recycled paper.

Preah Vihear Temple was closed for security reasons during my first tour in #Cambodia and I have wanted to visit it ever since. Sotie and I were incredibly impressed by the mountaintop location and the excellent condition of many parts of the temple. It is a remarkable cultural asset that all Cambodians should be proud of. - #AmbHeidt 

The Ambassador and his wife Sotie visited the spectacular temples of Preah Vihear and Koh Ker on May 24. These temples are being preserved and protected by the Cambodian government thanks to the contributions of people like Dr. Kim Sedara, an alumnus of The Fulbright Program and Chairman of the National Authority of Preah Vihear (NAPV). The Ambassador met NAPV representatives, Member of Parliament H.E. Yara Suos, and officials from the Ministries of Interior, Culture and Fine Arts, and Tourism to discuss projects being implemented through partnerships like ICC-Preah Vihear. While there has been significant progress in protecting the temples, much work is still needed to ensure the full protection of these historic landmarks and to increase the number of people that can visit them. 

The temple sites of Preah Vihear and Koh Ker are two of the most remarkable examples of ancient Khmer architecture found in #Cambodia. Preah Vihear Temple is one of the two cultural sites in Cambodia listed on UNESCO's World Heritage List (the other is Angkor). The temple's history can be traced to the 9th century and due to its location atop a 525-meter cliff, the site has been very well preserved. Koh Ker is another remote temple location, about 2.5 hours from Siem Reap. More than 50 temples are currently open to visitors at the site, including the pyramid-shaped Prasat Thom and Prasat Chen. 

Visit www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/ for more photos of the Ambassador and Sotie's visit to Preah Vihear and Koh Ker. And to learn more about what the United States to help preserve Cambodia's cultural heritage, log on to: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/cultural_assistance.html.

#CamWomenCan Keep People Safe
"I remember being in an embassy security vehicle once and hearing a Cambodian police officer say: Wow! The officer driving that car so well isnt a man...its a woman! - Khim Sina, U.S. Embassy Mobile Patrol Guard Supervisor.

Originally from Kandal Province, Khim Sina attended the National Institute of Management and worked as an administrative clerk before applying for a job at the U.S. Embassy in 2000 with the hope of receiving a good salary, healthcare benefits, and equal opportunity. Sina is now one of 34 female guards currently working at the Embassy and the first woman to serve on the elite Mobile Patrol unit. She was promoted to the rank of supervisor in September 2015. I encourage myself and other women with positive thoughts, Khim Sina says. This job is not something that only a man can do!

Thanks to Sina and her colleagues (below, with Secretary of State John Kerry) for their loyal service to the U.S. Embassy and for showing us that #CamWomenCan succeed in any career!

The U.S. Department of the Treasury has announced that the $20 bill - which currently has President Andrew Jackson on the front - will soon feature a portrait of Harriet Tubman, who dedicated her life to fighting for liberty. Born into slavery, she later became an abolitionist and helped others escape to freedom during the late 1800s. She is the first woman on U.S. paper currency since the late 19th century.

President Jackson and images of the White House will now appear on the back of the new $20 bill. There will also be changes to the $10 and $5 notes, as part of a plan to have the themes of democracy, diversity, and equality better represented on U.S. currency. What are these changes? Find out more by visiting https://modernmoney.treasury.gov/.

Did you know that today is #WorldHepatitisDay? Viral hepatitis is the 7th leading cause of death in the world, with about 1.4 million people falling victim to the disease each year. Although treatments and vaccines exist, less than 5% of people with chronic hepatitis know they have it and less than 1% have access to treatment. Here in #Cambodia, one of the goals of the National Immunization Program (NIP) is to reduce Hepatitis-B prevalence to less than 1% by 2017. The NIP has made a significant impact on the reduction of hepatitis and other vaccine preventable diseases, contributing to important health gains across the country. 

Hepatitis-B immunization in Cambodia has increased dramatically since its introduction in 2001. The Ministry of Health is working with a number of local and international partners, such as the World Health Organization (WHO), UNICEF, Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, CDC, and others to provide services and increase community awareness of - and demand for - immunization to combat hepatitis and other diseases. Learn more about hepatitis and what is being done around the world at http://www.who.int/campaigns/hepatitis-day/2016/en/.

The Mark Morris Dance Group Begins Asia Tour in Cambodia

As part of the U.S. Department of States DanceMotion USA program and with the assistance of Amrita Performing Arts, the Mark Morris Dance Group (MMDG) will begin its Asia tour in Cambodia, October 13-24, before continuing on to Timor-Leste, Taiwan, and China.  DanceMotion USA is a cross-cultural exchange program that connects Americas finest dance companies with international artists and communities.  

While in Cambodia, the Mark Morris Dance Group will collaborate with dancers and musicians from Amrita Performing Arts, Cambodian Living Arts (CLA), Epic Arts, Khmer Arts, RUFA - Royal University of Fine Arts, the Secondary School of Fine Arts, and Tiny Toones, and will give a live performance at the Khmer Arts Theatre in Takhmao.  

Details for the upcoming free public events are as follows:

- A Conversation with Mark Morris, Artistic Director of MMDG  Friday, October 17 , 6:00 p.m., at the French Institute in Phnom Penh

- Screening of Dido and Aenas and Q&A with Nancy Umanoff, Executive Director of MMDG  Saturday, October 18, 6:30 p.m., at the Bophana Center in Phnom Penh

- Performance by the Mark Morris Dance Group  Wednesday, October 22, 6:30 p.m., at the Khmer Arts Theater, Takhmao 
Free tickets for the performance are available beginning October 15 at Amrita Performing Arts (128G9, Sothearos Blvd.), tel: 023-220-424.

For more information on the tour, click here http://goo.gl/AoT730 .

For more information about DanceMotion USA, please visit http://www.dancemotionusa.org/.

Making the Worlds Knowledge Computable

On December 30, Ambassador Heidt and Minister of Education Hang Chuon Naron were on hand for a lecture at RUPP by world-famous scientist and entrepreneur Dr. Stephen Wolfram entitled The Future of Computation and Knowledge.  

Dr. Wolfram is the founder and CEO of software company Wolfram Research, based in the United States, and the creator of the Wolfram Language, which powers the free answer engine Wolfram Alpha.  The talk was organized by the Ministry of Education, Youth, and Sports; the U.S. Embassy; the Cambodia Science & Engineering Festival; and the Cambodian Mathematical Society.

As Dr. Wolfram explained, unlike traditional search engines Wolfram Alpha doesnt search the web for answers; it answers factual questions by computing answers.  During the presentation, Dr. Wolfram demonstrated this by entering a series of mathematical and other questions, including How many chickens in Cambodia?.  Below is Wolfram Alphas answer to that question, based on the best available data.  This graph didnt exist before Dr. Wolfram asked the question.  Rather, Wolfram Alpha created it, using the information in its database.

In his introduction, Ambassador Heidt talked about the role of science, technology, and innovation in the American economy and challenged Cambodian youth to harness technology to build an innovation society.  You can read his remarks here: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/123015_sp.html

Dr. Wolframs talk will be available on video soon in its entirety.  Check back for details.

"Unlocking Cambodia's Creative Economy" Panel Discussion

Encouraging Dialogue in Cambodia
-From the Ambassador's Penh

As a reader of my blog, you know that I have written about the amazing work of civil society and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in Cambodia.  I have no doubt that the advances that Cambodia has achieved in recent years  a growing economy, improvements in health care and schools, progress in human rights, and more  is due in great part to the work of NGOs.  Thats because NGOs often fill a pressing need where government funding for services is limited.  They also promote good governance, efficiency, and transparency  all critical elements of a healthy democracy.  I believe a strong, vibrant, and free civil society plays a vital role in addressing the future challenges facing Cambodia.  Thats why the United States is closely following the developments on the draft NGO law and other legislation, such as the cybercrime law and the pending trade union law, being considered by the Cambodian government.  As part of that effort, Scott Busby  Deputy Assistant Secretary (DAS) for the Department of States Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor  visited Cambodia this week to observe the current situation first-hand and obtain feedback on the draft laws. 

During his visit, DAS Busby met with representatives of civil society and the Royal Government of Cambodia to hear their thoughts on the draft laws.  Civil society representatives told him one of their chief concerns about the draft NGO law is they dont know what the law says.  Some of the NGOs have repeatedly called on the Cambodian government to share the draft law publicly and hold public forums so they can comment on it and offer their recommendations.  Other NGOs have expressed anxiety and concern because the law could impose restrictions or burdens that would make it difficult or even impossible for them to do their crucial work in Cambodia.  DAS Busby raised their concerns in a meeting with the Minister of Foreign Affairs Hor Namhong.  One of the points DAS Busby made is the importance of sharing the draft NGO law with the public and civil society.  He also said the draft NGO law should be reviewed and subject to a robust debate.  When discussing the issue of Montagnard asylum seekers, DAS Busby urged the Foreign Minister to allow asylum seekers to register with the government and to have their claims to refugee status heard and adjudicated.

Before departing, DAS Busby held a press conference to reiterate the purpose of his visit to Cambodia.  In his remarks, he said, as the debate over the NGO law continues, it is important to realize that the world is watching.  The United States will continue to follow the developments on the draft NGO law closely because we believe any change in the law that restricts rather than empowers civil society does not serve the best interests of the Cambodian people.  When civil society is strong, the country is stronger, DAS Busby said.  I couldnt agree more.  Thats why the United States is committed to helping the Cambodian people, including civil society, build a stronger country.

What are your thoughts about the draft laws being considered by the Cambodian government?  I encourage you to voice your opinion.  A healthy dialogue is a key part of Cambodias democracy.
