Congratulations to Dr. Pung Chhiv Kek - the president of the Cambodian League for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights (LICADHO) - for receiving the Legion of Honor, France's premier award. French Ambassador to #Cambodia Jean-Claude Poimboeuf presented the award during a special ceremony that U.S. Embassy Charge d'Affaires Julie Chung attended at the Ambassade de France au Cambodge. Dr. Kek - who founded LICADHO in 1992 after the signing of the Paris Peace Agreements - was given this prestigious honor in recognition of her dedication to promoting peace, non-violence, and respect for human rights in Cambodia. She has long been a friend to the United States, so the U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh, Cambodia applauds this remarkable achievement.

()

The U.S. Embassy and the Royal Government of Cambodia signed two bilateral agreements this morning to provide $35 million in assistance from the U.S. Agency for International Development USAID Cambodia for programs in health, agriculture, environment, and education.  The agreements were signed at the Council for the Development of Cambodia by Deputy Prime Minister Keat Chhon and USAID Mission Director Rebecca Black, with U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia William Heidt serving as a witness.

These agreements are the first part of a three-year, $137 million program from #USAID to support the Cambodian Government's national development plan.  The programs, which will be implemented primarily by non-governmental organizations, will boost the quality of healthcare, improve nutrition for mothers and children, reduce the prevalence of infectious diseases, expand agriculture markets and production, strengthen protections for Cambodia's natural resources, and help young students strengthen their reading skills.

In his remarks, Ambassador Heidt emphasized the strong collaboration between USAID and the government, saying I am very grateful for the partnership between our two countries over the past two decades.  Together, we have worked to address many key development challenges.  Together, weve pushed back HIV/AIDS from its dangerous levels in the 1990s.   Together, weve helped farmers increase their yields and enabled them to feed, educate, and access healthcare for their families.  And together, weve worked with Cambodians to take advantage of innovations in science and technology to improve many aspects of life.  

To read the Ambassadors full remarks, go to http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/033016_sp.html

     (USAID)          Rebecca Black  USAID 
                
   Heidt  USAID                      http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/033016_sp.html

"Continued economic growth in Cambodia will depend on the health and well-being of its people, especially its children, who represent the future of the nation.  With proper nutrition, Cambodias young people can grow to become the strong leaders and skilled professionals that the country needs.  Improving nutrition is one of the most important investments that Cambodia can make to ensure a better tomorrow." 

This week's column from Ambassador Todd is titled, "Investing in Nutrition for a Healthier Cambodia".  You can read the Ambassador's latest column here: http://goo.gl/6p8xEB

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Phnom Penh this evening for his official visit to #Cambodia, which will include meetings with Prime Minister Hun Sen, Deputy Prime Minister & Foreign Minister Hor Namhong, and others. The Secretary plans to discuss the upcoming special U.S.-ASEAN summit in Sunnylands, California and seek ways to further strengthen bilateral cooperation and the growing bilateral economic relationship between the United States and Cambodia.

Stayed tuned to the Embassy's Facebook page tomorrow for more updates on Secretary Kerry's special visit to Cambodia. And for more info and photos from his recent travel, log on to http://www.state.gov/secretary/travel/2016/t2/index.htm.

Statement by Secretary of State John Kerry on Khmer New Year:

"On behalf of President Obama and the American people, I would like to send my best wishes to the Cambodian people on the occasion of Khmer New Year.

This is an opportunity to honor Cambodia's culture and plans for a brighter future. Cambodia has undergone tremendous progress and growth in the past two decades, and the United States hopes to be a partner in Cambodias continued development

This year, as Cambodia plans for the National Assembly Elections in July, we support efforts to ensure a free and fair electoral process that addresses the democratic aspirations of the Cambodian people. We also look forward to recognizing and celebrating Cambodias 60 years of independence in November.

I offer my heartfelt wishes for a peaceful and prosperous new year."

Do you know what "body language" is? A person can say a lot without even using words according to Amy Cuddy, an American social psychologist, professor, and author of the New York Times best seller "Presence: Bringing your Boldest Self to Your Biggest Challenges. She was recently in #Cambodia with her students from Harvard Business School for a project that helps Cambodian entrepreneurs develop effective business plans.

The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), in cooperation with Development Alternatives Incorporated, officially launched its new Development Innovations project on March 18.  The project is designed to bring together innovators and local civil society partners to increase the use of technology for social change in Cambodia.

On Tuesday, Development Innovations held an Open House for the public.  Visitors were able to tour the projects facilities and participate in modern technology and interactive learning events, including An Hour of Code, tips on blogging, and other innovative items of interest.

On Sunday evening, Ambassador Todd was joined by three extraordinary Fulbright Program participants at a reception hosted by the international humanitarian organization CARE. CARE is hosting a Learning Tour to Cambodia on the topic of maternal and child health.  The visiting delegation includes three members of the U.S. Congress and Anita McBride of American University, who is a member of the J. William Fulbright Scholarship Board.

The Fulbright Foreign Student Program enables graduate students, young professionals and artists from abroad to study and conduct research in the United States.  Approximately 4,000 foreign students receive Fulbright scholarships each year.  To learn more about the Fulbright Foreign Student program in Cambodia, visit the Embassys website here http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/fulbright_program.html

"My life changed dramatically the day my daughter was born.  That was the day I was given responsibility for nurturing and guiding a precious baby girl through the journey of childhood, with all its bumps and turns, to becoming an empowered, resilient, and productive adult.  I also knew that along the way I would need to work hard to ensure that she had the same chances for happiness and success as any of my sons.  Now that I am serving in Cambodia and see similar struggles for this countrys young women, I am also concerned that these girls need to have the same access to education and opportunity, the same chances to succeed, and the same respect as their male peers.  Thats why I was so pleased to visit the Don Bosco Vocational Training Center for Girls in Phnom Penh last week."

(Photo: PSI) PEPFAR funds supported health workers to provide information about HIV and other infectious disease to male clients of entertainment establishments against HIV.

The 2013 State of the Union speech delivered by President Obama on February 12 marks the 10th Anniversary of PEPFARs inception.

Its a major milestone as we progress to achieving an AIDS-free Generation.

PEPFAR helped Cambodia become a global leader in the fight against HIV/AIDS by providing almost 40 percent of the money for the countrys fight against the disease.

This support helped cut adult infection rates by more than half in the past 14 years and provide treatment to 80 percent of those infected by HIV.

Read more about PEPFARs work here: www.pepfar.gov

The Counter Trafficking in Persons (CTIP II) Program recently told the story of a Cambodian woman who escaped from slavery and now fights to build a future for herself and for the child she is carrying.   She was lured to marry a wealthy man in another country and ended up being sold.  She was brave enough to run away and now asks for justice to be served.   You can read the story here: http://goo.gl/92a85i 

USAIDs CTIP II Program strives to improve Cambodias ability to fight against human trafficking and works with victims to support them on their path to a new life.  

You can learn more about our Counter Trafficking in Persons Program at: http://goo.gl/ydQBym 

Only the solidarity of communities can prevent the selling of people and can protect and support victims.  Unite with your neighbors to fight human trafficking!

Ben Skinner - an award-winning journalist and author of "A Crime So Monstrous: Face-to-Face with Modern Day Slavery" - visited Phnom Penh earlier this week to participate in a U.S. Department of State speaker program on combating human trafficking. From October 3-4, he met with a number of key stakeholders working on anti-trafficking in persons (TIP) and migration issues in #Cambodia.

Mr. Skinner first spoke with youth developing short films about human trafficking as part of the Chaktomuk Short Film Festival. He then met with members of the National Committee for Counter-Trafficking, including Secretary of State for the Ministry of Interior and Vice-Chairwoman H.E. Chou Bun Eng, to learn what the Cambodian government is doing to combat TIP. He also participated in a round-table discussion featuring civil society representatives from NGOs such as the Chab Dai Coalition, ADHOC-Cambodia, Ratanak International, Legal Support for Children and Women - LSCW, Winrock International, Legal Aid of Cambodia, and Samaritan's Purse. "Cambodia has made progress," said Mr. Skinner, while noting the ongoing efforts of government, civil society, and the private sector to further reduce human trafficking. To learn more, please visit http://go.usa.gov/xkruW.

Ben Skinner    ("A Crime So Monstrous: Face-to-Face with Modern Day Slavery")

Pichleap Sok has arrived in Washington D.C., her final stop on the Millennial Trains Project!  This day, Pichleap plans to visit nearby Baltimore, Maryland and shares her thoughts about using transportation service Uber in the United States.  Continue reading to find out what else happens:

DAY 9
"We are finally in Washington D.C. The train completely stops even though I still feel it's moving. Walking across Washington Union Station, my first impression is the city is full of historical buildings. The design and architecture of the building are so classic, historic and unique. I didn't get a chance to try the public transportation but Uber is clearly my favorite transportation in the United States. You can get a taxi whenever and wherever you are within 3 to 5 minutes through your mobile phone. It is even more convenient in DC. The weather in DC makes me feel like home. It was hot and humid. We headed to United States Capitol right away after getting off the train. I feel so privileged to be able to visit the US Capitol through Millennial Trains Project. It was quite a hectic day because we need to rush to the bus, heading to our next stop, Baltimore, Maryland. I have no interview schedule in Baltimore due to the sudden change of the plan. Nevertheless, I had a great time with my lovely Fulbright friends from Poland and South Africa. "We first went to Starbucks to charge our phone and laptop, and finish some works. Then we took Uber to Inner Harbor to sight-saw the city.", we told people when they asked about how we spent our day in Baltimore. They were surprised by how much we were into American culture because that's what Americans like to do: Starbucks, Uber, sightseeing. Well, I'm glad to know and be able to adapt to it. Inner Harbor is a landmark, historic seaport and tourist attraction of the city. We (MTP members) had a great dinner at Little Havana. Then we took a bus back to Washington DC. Oh wait! Did I mention that we still have another night on the train? But not a moving train anymore."

One more day before the train ride comes to an end!  Have any questions for Pichleap?  Ask them in the comments section below.

Supporting People with Disabilities in Cambodia:

"A number of new voices have recently joined the healthy debate that continues to take place regarding the draft NGO law.

For example, a statement released this week by the ASEAN Parliamentarians for Human Rights  an organization that includes high-ranking government officials from Cambodia and other nations throughout Southeast Asia  shows that the draft NGO law is an issue that is receiving both national and international attention.

In my opinion, it is a positive sign that Cambodias neighbors are not only focused on the upcoming ASEAN economic integration; they also recognize the important role that civil society plays throughout the region.

As the draft law next moves to the National Assembly for further discussion, I hope that Cambodias leaders will carefully consider all views  most of all the views of the Cambodian people  prior to making any final decisions.

This diverse collection of voices will be a key element in the formula for healthy reform that will lead to a more prosperous Cambodia."

 Rebecca Black  (USAID)                 USAID  ADHOC    http://www.adhoc-cambodia.org/

USAID Cambodia Mission Director Rebecca Black and other U.S. Embassy staff met yesterday with representatives from the Cambodian Human Rights and Development Association (ADHOC) - a renowned human rights organization that plays a vital role in promoting fundamental freedoms and equitable economic development in #Cambodia. ADHOC was founded by a group of former political prisoners in 1991, and over the years it has grown to become one of Cambodias leading civil society organizations with a variety of programs that help Cambodians understand and defend their basic rights. USAID is currently partnering with ADHOC to improve local governance and help vulnerable populations. Learn more about ADHOC's efforts by visiting http://www.adhoc-cambodia.org/.

A Successful First Year for YSEALI
-From the Ambassador's Penh

The Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative  known to many as YSEALI  recently celebrated its first anniversary.  Since the creation of President Obamas signature program for promoting youth leadership and networking in the region, more than 1,000 Cambodian youth have joined thousands more of their peers throughout Southeast Asia to not only discuss topics such as entrepreneurship and civic engagement, but also to take significant action to address issues that matter most in their communities.  As a reader of my blog, you are probably familiar with my excitement about YSEALI and the potential that I believe it has for creating the next generation of leaders in Cambodia.   

YSEALI has provided a number of opportunities and tools to support Cambodias youth.  Workshops in Manila and Kuala Lumpur featured enthusiastic Cambodian participants who were among the first to win grant money to create a YSEALI regional project.  Called Streams of Hope, this innovative project involved youth from Cambodia, Vietnam, and the Philippines to promote the importance of river rehabilitation.  In November, 20 YSEALI participants  two from each ASEAN member nation  met in Rangoon to examine how collaboration within their fields of interest can lead to a bigger impact in their communities and throughout the region.  In December, the U.S. Embassy sent six young Cambodians to Singapore to participate in a regional workshop entitled YSEALI Generation: The Power of Human Capital.  With help from the U.S.-ASEAN Business Council, YSEALI members were able to identify the soft skills that are crucial to gaining a quality job and ensuring career advancement. 

I was delighted to learn that the some of the young Cambodians that traveled to Singapore volunteered to serve as Digital Delegates during the workshop, using social media to give updates and respond to questions about YSEALI.  Talking about their experience and their plans upon returning home, one participant said: 

With all the valuable skills I have acquired during this workshop, I am committed to bringing back skills to share with youth in my community.  For this reason, I have initiated a project to strengthen human capital in my home country by conducting a series of informal sharing sessions with youth who are in need of soft skills, as a preparation for those seeking improvement to reach their full potential in their career. 

Utilizing Facebook and the popular #YSEALI on Twitter, these stories are being shared with others in Cambodia and around the world.  Social media is clearly having a significant impact on the success of YSEALI, and I look forward to speaking with more of you about the efforts of these young people in 2015.  

YSEALI is creating stronger links between rising leaders in Cambodia and their regional and U.S. counterparts working on matters of mutual interest.  Cambodia is among the top countries with applicants for the YSEALI Professional Fellows Program, which sends some of the best and brightest community leaders from ASEAN to the United States for one month to engage with experts in the fields of civic engagement, NGO management, economic empowerment, governance, legislative process, and environmental and natural resources management.  After a successful program in 2014, the number of applications for the spring 2015 program has tripled from the region, reaching new audiences by attracting more than half from outside the capital cities.   

I would like to congratulate everyone for their hard work and commitment to YSEALI in its first year.  This initiative has created an amazing network of young people working together to address issues that are important to Cambodians and others in Southeast Asia.  I could not be more proud of the program, and I invite all between the ages of 18 and 35 to join this active and growing community.  To find out more about YSEALI and sign up for membership, please go to https://youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov/. 

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

Did you know that you can study at West Point and other four-year U.S. military schools?  Every year, the U.S. invites qualified young people from Cambodia to study alongside American military students at prestigious degree-granting institutionsmilitary academies serving the U.S. Army, Navy, Air Force, and Coast Guard.
  
Graduates receive world-class educations that will develop them morally, mentally, and physically.  Tuition, books, and housing are free.  International students receive the same pay and education as American students.  After four years Cambodian students graduate with bachelors degrees and return home as officers in the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces.  

This opportunity is open to men and women who are between 17 and 22 years old and meet high standards of academics, English proficiency, leadership, and physical fitness.  You can find out more by coming to an information briefing on June 16th at 8am at Passtra University of Cambodia ( PUC ) South Campus, No. 184, Norodom Blvd, Phnom Penh.  Email PUC at eduUSA@puc.edu.kh to attend. 

Today, two Cambodians attend the U.S. Naval Academy, and three Cambodians have graduated from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point.  Email eduUSA@puc.edu.kh to sign up for the information briefing on the 16th!

U.S. Embassy Statement on Reports of Violence at National Assembly (English below)

              

The US Embassy is aware of reports that two Cambodian National Rescue Party politicians were assaulted outside of the National Assembly.  Exercising the freedoms of assembly and speech do not justify violence and we condemn these actions.  We call on the authorities to carry out a thorough and transparent investigation into these attacks, to maintain order at the National Assembly, and to ensure the safety of politicians from all parties.

Welcoming Our New Deputy Chief of Mission
by Ambassador Todd

Two weeks ago I had the great pleasure to welcome an important new member to the U.S. Embassy team  Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung.  The Deputy Chief of Mission, or DCM for short, is the number two position in the Embassy and is often considered to be the chief operating officer because of the many roles and responsibilities that he or she handles.  The DCM is the right hand of the Ambassador and serves as the acting Ambassador, or Charg dAffaires, in the Ambassadors absence.

The best DCMs share certain characteristics, including an intense curiosity, strong management skills, and a keen diplomatic touch.  Anyone who has met Julie knows that she has all of these qualities and more.  Julie is full of energy and enthusiasm and brings a genuine love of diplomacy and foreign cultures to her new position.  She truly wants to make a positive impact in the world and she understands how to bring people together to address the challenges of the 21st century.

Julie is a highly experienced career Foreign Service Officer who has worked in many of the State Departments most important and challenging posts around the world, including Iraq and Colombia.  Most recently Julie headed the Economic section in Bangkok, where she and her team worked to develop closer economic and trade ties between Thailand and the United States.  This experience will serve her well here in Cambodia, where trade and economic cooperation forms the backbone of the U.S.-Cambodia bilateral relationship.  She also has extensive experience coordinating development programs and promoting human rights  two other cornerstones of the U.S. relationship with Cambodia.  Her particular interest in engaging civil society will further expand opportunities to have a dialogue with those of diverse backgrounds and opinions.

Julie has spent much of her career in Asia.  Besides Thailand, she also served in Vietnam, Japan, and China, and covered Korea from our headquarters in Washington.  Julies interest in Asia stems in part from her personal background.  Julie was born in South Korea, and her family emigrated to the United States when she was five years old.  At the time Julie didnt speak any English, but with a work ethic instilled in her by her parents she channeled her efforts towards becoming a public servant.  Julie is proficient in seven languages, and spent the past year studying Khmer in Washington, DC.

Julies life and career path has brought her to Cambodia at a very special time in this countrys history, with the new National Assembly just beginning its work.  Julie will be using all of her skills and talents to strengthen the U.S.-Cambodian relationship and to help our partners to address the challenges that Cambodians face every day.  I am proud to have her on the U.S. Embassy team.

Please join me in welcoming Julie to Cambodia in the comments section.  And when you meet Julie, be sure to make her practice her Khmer!

Read this and other blog posts at: http://goo.gl/3BHGs6

President Obama announced last week the expansion of the Papahnaumokukea Marine National Monument in Hawaii, making it the worlds largest protected area. The Presidents announcement quadruples the size of the protected area, which is larger than all U.S. national parks combined!  The name  Papahnaumokukea (pronounced Pa-pa-hah-now-mo-koo-ah-keh-ah) comes from an ancient Hawaiian tradition about the formation of the Hawaiian Islands, where President Obama was born.   

The  Papahnaumokukea Marine National Monument contains more than 7,000 species, including whales, birds, and sea turtles. For more information about this initiative, please see https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2016/08/26/president-obama-designates-worlds-largest-marine-protected-area.

Today, Ambassador Todd met with the family members of several of the women who were sentenced to a year in prison for protesting the flooding of their community at Boeung Kak Lake (BKL). Do you want to take a ride on a train?  Join Fulbright Fellow Pichleap Sok as she travels from Los Angeles, California to Washington, DC aboard the Fulbright Millennial Trains Project!  Her train ride includes unique opportunities to experience American culture and shell meet with successful people in the technology industry along the way.  #Fulbright #MTP

Day1:  It was a very productive and exciting day because the train embarked that day at 9:45pm. In the morning, we attended three talks. Our first speaker was so inspiring. She talked about how we can use what we are so passionate and/or skillful at to make a social impact to the community. Next, we were so honored to be able to sit there and listen to the founder of Craigslist, Craig Newmark about how important the elevator pitch is. Last but not least, IDEO design thinking workshop was done by Scott Patterson, a project lead from IDEO. After the workshops we get the chance to kick off our individual project.  I had great three interviews with three amazing women in technology, Audrey, a founder of StartupDTLA, Rebecca, a mother of a son and a co-founder of two startups in Los Angeles, and Murriel, a young, nice, cheerful and positive woman in technology I have ever met. It was my great pleasure to meet with and talk to them. They were so collaborative and supportive for what I am doing. I do believe their stories will inspire others as much as they inspire me. Later in the evening, we gathered at Union Station. We all were so excited to see how the train would look like. I couldn't wait to see how my bedroom would look like for the next 10 days. Now it is time. We finally get aboard. This is no longer a dream. Everything is now so real."

Two new health care facilities in Kampong Cham - a regional blood center and a laboratory at the provincial hospital - are now up and running thanks to support from the U.S. Embassy in Cambodia and its partners at the U.S. Pacific Command (PACOM), the Defense Threat Reduction Agency, the Naval Medical Research Unit Two, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and the U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). 

Yesterday, Ambassador Heidt was joined by Minister of Health H.E. Mam Bunheng and more than 700 people from the local community for a ribbon cutting ceremony and tour of the facilities. The new blood center is a valuable asset to the collection, storage, and distribution of a clean and safe blood supply in #Cambodia, while the new laboratory will help doctors identify a variety of diseases and design appropriate treatment plans for patients, significantly improving the quality of health care for the citizens of Kampong Cham.

YSEALI: Bringing Together Young Leaders in Southeast Asia
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Wherever I go in Cambodia, I am constantly impressed by the energy and enthusiasm of the young people that I meet.  Cambodias young adults have high hopes and expectations and they are driving change in this country  not simply waiting for it to happen.  They want to know how they can work together with other young people in the region to help make a positive impact in their communities and the world.  Todays youth want a cleaner environment, responsible economic development, and more opportunities to create a world of peace and prosperity.  They do not shy away from hard work and challenges in order to achieve these dreams.

That is why I believe that Cambodia can be a model country for the Young Southeast Asian Leadership Initiative, known as YSEALI, to thrive.  YSEALI was launched by President Obama in 2013 and brings together bright young leaders aged 18-35 from Cambodia, Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Burma, Philippines, Laos, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.  The purpose of YSEALI is to encourage young people with a vision from across the ASEAN region to work together to find innovative solutions to challenges such as economic development and environmental protection.  YSEALI members can network, learn, share ideas, and even apply for funding for projects that address real-world challenges.

Who can join YSEALI? Any Cambodian between the ages of 18 and 35 can go to the website and click on the link Become a Member.  https://youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov/join/  When you do, you will be instantly connected to a community that is already 7,000 strong and growing quickly.  This is an exciting time to get in on the ground floor and to play a part in YSEALIs development, especially as Cambodia prepares to host the first major YSEALI event of 2015: a youth summit convening dozens of YSEALI members from across the region.

So far, more than 750 Cambodians have already signed up for YSEALI, making Cambodia one of the biggest groups.  Cambodias YSEALI members are already starting to make a difference.  This last weekend, a team from Cambodia organized a visit by a U.S. professor of environmental science, Dr. Eric Pallant, who shared his expertise about keeping rivers and waterways healthy.  This visit was part of a project called Streams of Hope, which is promoting new solutions to significant environmental problems.  You can read more about Dr. Pallants visit on our Facebook page.

Streams of Hope is one example of how YSEALI members in Cambodia, Vietnam, and the Philippines came together to make clean water a reality by raising awareness about water systems and conservation.  The initiative has already carried out a number of programs, including a workshop on environmental protection in Kratie province in July.  I am very proud that Cambodians are playing a leading role in Streams of Hope, which is one of the pioneer projects of YSEALI.

Three other great projects from Cambodia have already been approved for funding and will be getting underway soon, thanks to the YSEALI Seeds for the Future program, which offered up to $10,000 for teams from at least two ASEAN countries to carry out a program.  In one of these projects, youth from Cambodia and Thailand will work together to promote good governance and to battle corruption.  A second project in Cambodia, Malaysia, and Thailand will bring together urban and rural youth to help them be more competitive in the workforce and provide entrepreneurial training.  A third project will support the full inclusion of women in society in Cambodia and Burma.  I know that there are many issues and challenges that the young people of Cambodia want to tackle, and even more creative ideas that YSEALI can help foster.

In addition to special projects, YSEALI also brings together youth from around the region at workshops where they can learn from experts and from each other.  It is through this networking, mentoring, and hands-on training, that young people can lead communities in addressing economic, environmental, educational, and civic engagement issues. 

When U.S. President Barack Obama was young, he started out as a community organizer ensuring people in his community received job training and help in getting a university degree. He knows from personal experience that young people can be powerful agents for good in their communities. YSEALI carries on President Obamas legacy by fostering community leadership among youth in ASEAN member countries. 

As you can see, YSEALI is a dynamic network of young people who are working together to address issues that are important to Southeast Asia.  I could not be more excited about this program.  If you are between 18 and 35 and want to be a part of this active and growing community, please consider becoming a member.  I invite everyone  especially parents and teachers  to go to the website to learn more about YSEALI and to encourage young Cambodian leaders to sign up.  You can find all of the information here: https://youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov/.

What do you think about the YSEALI initiative?  Please let us know in the comments section or on Facebook or Twitter (@USEmbPhnomPenh).

To see the other activities YSEALI is engaged in, you can also visit Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative Facebook page.

In his latest weekly column, Ambassador Todd returns from the United States to share his thoughts on Cambodias growing economy, the road ahead for the newly formed National Assembly and the efforts of Cambodias elected leaders to finalize critical electoral reforms and lay the groundwork for continued development:

We're now accepting applications for the The Fulbright Program! What's it like to be a #Fulbright Scholar from #Cambodia? Meet Sovath, who is currently studying in the United States:

I am currently doing my masters degree in Hydrology and Hydrodynamics, generally known as Water Resources Engineering, at the University of Washington. I choose this major field of study because I want to make a difference in Cambodia's future and improve the well-being of Cambodia and its people through sustainable development in water resources. Cambodia has several water-related issues ranging from water quality to sewage and water management system. I plan to use the knowledge and practical skills from my study in the United States to develop more human resources in water resources engineering, and together with other professionals, I strongly believe that we can sustainably solve these water-related problems by developing wastewater treatment plants, hydraulic structures and electric energy generation to response to the growing water demand, environmental threats and projected global climate change.

Active in more than 160 countries, the Fulbright Program offers grants to study, teach and conduct research for non-U.S. citizens to come to the United States and for U.S. citizens to go abroad. For more details, please visit http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/fulbright_announcement.html. And for help on completing and submitting your application, go to http://go.usa.gov/c74Pz. Applications are due by June 1st. Good luck!

The Royal Government of #Cambodia and USAID Cambodia implementing partner Wildlife Conservation Society signed a carbon credit project agreement on August 11, 2016, witnessed by Ambassador Heidt and Minister of Environment H.E. Say Samal. This agreement will implement Cambodia's first large-scale private-sector sale of carbon credits, which will benefit an important climate change mitigation project in Keo Seima Wildlife Sanctuary, which covers 300,000 hectares in Mondulkiri province.

    (REDD+)            '

The carbon credit transfer took place under the UN-backed Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation program (REDD+). This transfer will avoid 14 million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions over a 10-year period between 2010 and 2019.

  Heidt    REDD+    

In his remarks, Ambassador Heidt said that this new agreement would "lay the groundwork for additional REDD+ agreements in the future that will benefit both Cambodias forests and the communities that live in and around them"

To see the Ambassador's full remarks go to https://kh.usembassy.gov/remarks-ambassador-william-heidt-signing-ceremony-project-agreement-keo-seima-wildlife-sanctuary-redd-project/.

Ambassador Todds column this week focuses on the importance of learning English  the indispensable language of the 21st century  and how the U.S. Embassy is supporting this effort:

The U.S. Embassy believes strongly in the power of English and works hard to promote English-language instruction in Cambodia, both through direct scholarships and through teacher training.  The U.S. governments flagship program is the English Access Microscholarship Program, which offers two-year English language scholarships to disadvantaged teenagers around the world.  In Cambodia, the Embassy currently works with outstanding partner institutions such as the Islamic Community Kan Imam-San of Cambodia in Kampong Chhnang and the American Education Center in Phnom Penh, who teach lessons at six locations across the country.  More than 1000 Cambodian students have participated in the program since it began in 2004.



All of these programs have one overarching goal: to increase Cambodias competitiveness.  Speaking English helps Cambodians to pursue an education, to get great jobs, and to give back to the community.  Most of all, it makes it possible for the Cambodian people to contribute to the global conversation and to have their voices heard by more people in more places.  By improving their abilities in English, young Cambodians in particular are setting themselves apart from their peers in the region and around the world and putting themselves in a position to drive Cambodias development.

Read the Ambassadors full column, Helping Cambodians to Learn English, in The Cambodia Herald at: http://goo.gl/7vIxLQ  

For more information on the English Access Microscholarship visit http://exchanges.state.gov/non-us/program/english-access-microscholarship-program or their Facebook page at English Access Microscholarship Program - Headquarters  

For more information on the American Education Center in Phnom Pehn, visit: http://www.aec.edu.kh/

Press Release by the White House on Government Assessment of the Syrian Governments Use of Chemical Weapons on August 21, 2013:
_____________

The United States Government assesses with high confidence that the Syrian government carried out a chemical weapons attack in the Damascus suburbs on August 21, 2013.

We further assess that the regime used a nerve agent in the attack.

These all-source assessments are based on human, signals, and geospatial intelligence as well as a significant body of open source reporting.

Our classified assessments have been shared with the U.S. Congress and key international partners.

To protect sources and methods, we cannot publicly release all available intelligence  but what follows is an unclassified summary of the U.S. Intelligence Communitys analysis of what took place.

The U.S. Embassy will be closed in observance of Columbus Day on Monday, October 8, 2012.

     Columbus Day 

October 12, 1492, is of enormous significance in Western history.

It is the day when explorer Christopher Columbus completed his journey across the Atlantic Ocean and landed in the New World.

What Columbus actually reached on that October day was an island he named San Salvador that is now part of the Bahamas. 

Columbus believed he had found a new route to India, and described the peoples he met as Indians.

Read more: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/inbrief/2012/10/20121002136992.html#ixzz28UcTQ9hg

#AmbHeidt & Mrs. Heidt Tour Khmer Art Collection at The Cleveland Museum of Art
 Heidt  Heidt  Cleveland

The Ambassador and Mrs. Heidt took time out of their summer vacation last week to see the Indian and Southeast Asian Art collection at the Cleveland Museum of Art (CMA), one of the leading art museums in the United States.  The CMA has one of the worlds highest quality collections of Angkorean and pre-Angkorean art, which includes an exquisite 7th century sculpture of Ganesha. They also toured several of the CMAs conservation laboratories. There they saw a nearly 200-kilogram fragment believed to be from a Krishna Lifting Mount Govardhan statue, originally found at Phnom Da in 1935 and returned by the  National Museum to the CMA in October 2015. The CMA plans to exhibit the restored Krishna statue in 2017.

The CMA has a very active cooperative agreement with the Ministry of Culture and Fine Art ( :) and the National Museum. In May 2015, it voluntarily returned to #Cambodia a 10th-century statue of Hanuman after uncovering evidence that it was likely looted during Cambodias civil war. At the same time, the CMA signed a Memorandum of Understanding on cultural cooperation with the National Museum, the first such agreement between the National Museum and a U.S. museum.

Please join us in congratulating Mr. Thy Vanna and Mr. Ung Chantrea for completing the 10-week Department of State E-Teacher Scholarship Program.  Both participated in an online course titled: Introduction to Pedagogy and Practices for Teaching English to Other Speakers of Other Languages from the University of Oregon.  During their visit to the U.S. Embassy to receive their Certificates of Completion from the University of Oregon, both Mr. Chantrea and Mr. Vanna noted how this experience taught them first how to learn online and then about different teaching concepts and practices. 

Mr. Chantrea was very inspired by the course and is already making plans to use his newfound knowledge.  It has helped me improve my teaching.  I already have plans to share what I have learned from the course with all my teacher-colleagues in order to improve the quality of education at our school, he said.  I would like to express my sincere appreciation to the U.S. Embassy and especially to the Department of State which gave me a chance to participate in this program.

Message by Ambassador William E. Todd on Khmer New Year

  

         

      

Phnom Penh | April 09, 2015

On behalf of the U.S. Embassy, I would like to congratulate the people of the Kingdom of Cambodia on the occasion of Khmer New Year. 

I look forward to the year ahead as our two nations identify even greater opportunities to strengthen our bilateral ties and work together on mutual areas of interest.  We value the commitment of the Cambodian people to further the social, economic and democratic development of the country. 

As we enter the Year of the Goat, I wish everyone in Cambodia peace, health, and prosperity, both now and in the future.

Secretary of State John Kerry will soon release the 2013 Human Rights Report, which covers the status of human rights in 199 countries and regions around the world.

On December 13, Major General James Pasquarette, Deputy Commanding General for U.S. Army Pacific, based in Hawaii, was joined by Cambodian Minister of Health His Excellency Mam Bun Hen at the groundbreaking ceremony for a new blood donation center in Phnom Penh constructed with the support of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.  The building will be the new home of the National Blood Transfusion Center in Phnom Penh and is the first of three new blood donation centers to be built by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in Cambodia.  The center will help ensure a safe blood supply for the capital city and also serve as the national headquarters for storing blood.  

The National Blood Transfusion Center is the largest project ever constructed using Overseas Humanitarian, Disaster, and Civic Aid funding from the U.S. Department of Defenses Pacific Command.  This project includes additional support from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, Global Fund, the Australian Red Cross, and U.S. Pacific Command Surgeon's Office.

Archaeologists have utilized light detection and ranging technology  - or LIDAR - to detect evidence of large, medieval cities hidden beneath the forest floor in #Cambodia. The research, released on Monday in the Journal of Archaeological Science, provides details about multiple cities that are between 900-1,400 years old, some of which were larger than the size of Phnom Penh.

"The new LIDAR survey is so exciting," says U.S. archaeologist Dr. Alison Carter, a Visiting Assistant Professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. "There are plenty of opportunities for young Cambodians to take part in researching their culture and heritage. I hope this will also encourage them to take the lead on preserving these sites." To read the full story about the LIDAR study, visit https://goo.gl/Ur14Em.

Internships -The Benefits of Hands-On Learning
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Despite an impressive rate of economic growth in Cambodia over the past several years, many young Cambodians are still facing challenges in finding good-paying jobs. One reason for this is that employers are increasingly looking to hire workers who have already demonstrated the skills that they need to perform. If young people entering the work force do not yet possess the right skills, employers may overlook otherwise promising hiring opportunities. One way that businesses, governments, and organizations can help bridge these gaps is through internships, a practice that is widely used in the United States.

I strongly believe that the work experience young people gain through internship programs can serve as a catalyst for professional success. That is why the U.S. Embassy runs a yearly summer internship program for promising Cambodian university students. We just concluded this years internship program where twelve interns gained valuable work experience in the areas of financial management, consular affairs, information technology, human resources, public affairs, program management, and procurement. We are extremely thankful for their meaningful contributions. I hope this unique experience will provide each of them with the confidence and skills that will open doors to more opportunities.

In order to further tap the potential of Cambodias bright students, my Youth Council has partnered with the American Chamber of Commerce to place highly qualified students in internship positions with some excellent companies. The Youth Council has also organized internship workshops which offer training on resum writing, preparing for a job interview, office etiquette, and professional ethics. More than 300 young Cambodians have attended these workshops and more than thirty internship candidates in the program have been successfully placed with twenty different companies in Cambodia.

In the United States, we find that many executives once started off as interns. In 1972, Bill Gates was an intern for the U.S. House of Representatives. Just two years after his internship, Gates co-founded Microsoft, one of the worlds leading corporations. Steven Spielberg was an intern before becoming a global icon in moviemaking. My Deputy at the Embassy was once a State Department intern who enjoyed the experience so much it led to her applying to become a diplomat.

Internships can and should be beneficial both to the hiring company and to the intern. In many cases, what hiring managers want and what applicants offer are very different. The gap between the skills presented and the skills required can be remedied by providing on-the-job training. Joining an organization or company as an intern provides a student the opportunity to work hands-on in a professional environment while also helping an employer evaluate how the student would fare in the actual workplace. It serves as a sort of test run for both the student and employer.

Interns are also valuable to employers for many reasons. In addition to creating an effective pathway for hiring, interns fill positions and assist employers with innovative ideas and technology. Young motivated interns can add fresh perspectives and ideas to increase organizational productivity while giving students a space to develop professionally.

I hope more employers continue to see the value of hands-on internship programs designed to mentor and cultivate todays young leaders, strengthen their understanding of the job market, and prepare them for future career opportunities.

If you are interested in an internship at the U.S. Embassy, please keep updated about future opportunities as information is posted on our website and our Facebook page.

Hawaii is the 50th and most recent state of United States of America, receiving statehood on August 21, 1959. Known as the "Aloha" state  Aloha is Hawaiian for both hello and goodbye  Hawaii is made up of eight main islands, many of which have become a favorite destination for honeymooners, surfers, golfers, and hikers. The population is very diverse, with large native Hawaiian, Asian, and Hispanic communities. Hawaii is a state with a rich history and stunning natural beauty.  It is known for its volcanoes, including Kilauea, which has been erupting for decades, and Mauna Loa, which is the largest volcano on earth. 

Many well-known people come from Hawaii, but perhaps the most famous is U.S. President Barack Obama, who was born in Honolulu on August 4, 1961.

Hawaii is also home to the East-West Center  an important education and research center established in 1960 by the U.S. Congress. In 2015, Architect Pen Sereypagna of the Vann Molyvann Project had an internship at the East-West Center through the International Council on Monuments and Sites (US/ICOMOS), which was sponsored in part by the U.S. Embassy. Many Cambodians have studied at the University of Hawaii at Manoa, which is one of the few U.S. universities to offer a Khmer Language Program!

Learn more about the great state of Hawaii here https://share.america.gov/hawaii-volcanoes-big-waves-and-chapels/?utm_source=productiondesk&utm_medium=shareamericanews&utm_campaign=dosnyhawaii&utm_content=hawaii:pearlharbor,perfectwaves,vol

"After spending the New Year with my family in the United States, I decided to cut my holiday short and return to Cambodia given the recent political upheaval in Phnom Penh. At this time, my thoughts and prayers go out to those who lost their lives on Veng Sreng Boulevard as well as to the family and friends they left behind.  My in-box was flooded with questions and comments by Cambodians concerned that this tragedy and the new ban on demonstrations would have a serious negative impact onthe countrys democratic development...

Links to Ambassador Todd's column "Getting Back on the Democratic Path":

() http://www.cen.com.kh/localnews/show_detail/29?token=NWE4NDQzYT

(English) http://www.thecambodiaherald.com/opinion/detail/3?token=MzY4NWNmMzQ3OTYzNmQ4MzIzZTUyM2Y4OTgxZDE5

Yesterday, our U.S. diplomatic post in Benghazi, Libya was attacked.

Heavily armed militants assaulted the compound and set fire to our buildings.

American and Libyan security personnel battled the attackers together.

Four Americans were killed. They included Sean Smith, a Foreign Service information management officer, and our Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens.

We are still making next of kin notifications for the other two individuals.

This is an attack that should shock the conscience of people of all faiths around the world.

We condemn in the strongest terms this senseless act of violence, and we send our prayers to the families, friends, and colleagues of those weve lost.

All over the world, every day, Americas diplomats and development experts risk their lives in the service of our country and our values, because they believe that the United States must be a force for peace and progress in the world, that these aspirations are worth striving and sacrificing for. 

Alongside our men and women in uniform, they represent the best traditions of a bold and generous nation.

In the lobby of this building, the State Department, the names of those who have fallen in the line of duty are inscribed in marble.

Our hearts break over each one. And now, because of this tragedy, we have new heroes to honor and more friends to mourn.

Chris Stevens fell in love with the Middle East as a young Peace Corps volunteer teaching English in Morocco. He joined the Foreign Service, learned languages, won friends for America in distant places, and made other peoples hopes his own.

In the early days of the Libyan revolution, I asked Chris to be our envoy to the rebel opposition. He arrived on a cargo ship in the port of Benghazi and began building our relationships with Libyas revolutionaries. He risked his life to stop a tyrant, then gave his life trying to help build a better Libya. The world needs more Chris Stevenses. I spoke with his sister, Ann, this morning, and told her that he will be remembered as a hero by many nations.

Sean Smith was an Air Force veteran. He spent 10 years as an information management officer in the State Department, he was posted at The Hague, and was in Libya on a brief temporary assignment. He was a husband to his wife Heather, with whom I spoke this morning. He was a father to two young children, Samantha and Nathan. They will grow up being proud of the service their father gave to our country, service that took him from Pretoria to Baghdad, and finally to Benghazi.

The mission that drew Chris and Sean and their colleagues to Libya is both noble and necessary, and we and the people of Libya honor their memory by carrying it forward. This is not easy. Today, many Americans are asking  indeed, I asked myself  how could this happen? How could this happen in a country we helped liberate, in a city we helped save from destruction? This question reflects just how complicated and, at times, how confounding the world can be.

But we must be clear-eyed, even in our grief. This was an attack by a small and savage group  not the people or Government of Libya. Everywhere Chris and his team went in Libya, in a country scarred by war and tyranny, they were hailed as friends and partners. And when the attack came yesterday, Libyans stood and fought to defend our post. Some were wounded. Libyans carried Chris body to the hospital, and they helped rescue and lead other Americans to safety. And last night, when I spoke with the President of Libya, he strongly condemned the violence and pledged every effort to protect our people and pursue those responsible.

The friendship between our countries, borne out of shared struggle, will not be another casualty of this attack. A free and stable Libya is still in Americas interest and security, and we will not turn our back on that, nor will we rest until those responsible for these attacks are found and brought to justice. We are working closely with the Libyan authorities to move swiftly and surely. We are also working with partners around the world to safeguard other American embassies, consulates, and citizens.

There will be more time later to reflect, but today, we have work to do. There is no higher priority than protecting our men and women wherever they serve. We are working to determine the precise motivations and methods of those who carried out this assault. Some have sought to justify this vicious behavior, along with the protest that took place at our Embassy in Cairo yesterday, as a response to inflammatory material posted on the internet. Americas commitment to religious tolerance goes back to the very beginning of our nation. But let me be clear  there is no justification for this, none. Violence like this is no way to honor religion or faith. And as long as there are those who would take innocent life in the name of God, the world will never know a true and lasting peace.

It is especially difficult that this happened on September 11th. Its an anniversary that means a great deal to all Americans. Every year on that day, we are reminded that our work is not yet finished, that the job of putting an end to violent extremism and building a safe and stable world continues. But September 11th means even more than that. It is a day on which we remember thousands of American heroes, the bonds that connect all Americans, wherever we are on this Earth, and the values that see us through every storm. And now it is a day on which we will remember Sean, Chris, and their colleagues.

May God bless them, and may God bless the thousands of Americans working in every corner of the world who make this country the greatest force for peace, prosperity, and progress, and a force that has always stood for human dignity  the greatest force the world has ever known. And may God continue to bless the United States of America.

Thank you.

"December 4th, 2012, will be the first-ever Wildlife Conservation Day.

Our goal is to inform more people about this global conservation crisis.

Attacks on rhinos and elephants are multiplying at an alarming rate.

Species around the globe such as tigers in Asia are endangered.

By some estimates, the black market for wildlife trafficking is rivaled in size only by the illegal arms and drug trade.

The slaughter of endangered species robs communities of income from tourism, reduces biodiversity, encourages corruption, undermines good governance.

That's why we are training officials and educating prosecutors about wildlife crimes and helping countries strengthen their enforcement laws.

But we cant do this without you.

Please, join us. Become part of the solution.

You have the choice to refuse to purchase products made from endangered wildlife.

Together we can save these animals before it is too late.

Stand up and speak out, and stop this trade.

Visit www.wildlifepledge.org.

Take the pledge to respect and protect the worlds wildlife."

Recently, a USAID-funded business grant was given to Narin from Kampot province to help launch his now thriving farm.  Narin was a migrant worker in Thailand when a Counter Trafficking in Persons (CTIP) trained Moto taxi driver told him that #USAID partner Healthcare Center for Children (HCC) could help him make a better living.  There he learned to raise chickens, pigs and ducks and received a grant to purchase materials and animals.  Narin had this to say: "If I compare my current life to the one I had before, I can say that today I earn money and have a permanent job.  Thank you for the USAID's grant".

A topic of increasing interest in the world of finance is ethical banking, where banks adopt environmentally and socially conscious practices.

  USAID      

Now, thanks to a new project supported by USAID Cambodia, for the first time ever Cambodian banks have agreed to consider environmental and social impacts when making decisions about what projects to support. This agreement sets a new model for the region for corporate social responsibility by major banking institutions. 

      (ABC)   ABC    USAID    

The new commitment was signed on Monday by Association of Banks in Cambodia (ABC) acting chairman Charles Vann. The ABC designed the language with technical support from USAID's Mekong Partnership for the Environment (MPE) regional program. Other partners include the Ministry of Environment, the National Bank of Cambodia, and the National Council for Sustainable Development.

 Julie Chung          

U.S. Embassy Charge daffaires Julie Chung spoke at the signing event, noting that Integrating environmental and social principles into investment decisions is not only important to ensure long-term business growth, but it is also integral to protecting and sustaining the human and natural resources that Cambodia will need in the future.

"What are you thankful for?" was the question on everyone's mind at the Phnom Penh Access Center on Tuesday evening. 
 
Andrea Echelberger, U.S. English Language Fellow, led the Access students in a lesson about the history and traditions of Thanksgiving, finishing up with a discussion about thankfulness.  When asked what she is thankful for, one student responded, "I am thankful for my school because it gives me good opportunities for my future to help my mother and father." Many other students answered that they are thankful for parents, sisters and brothers, friends, and teachers.  However, at the end of the lesson, all of the students unanimously agreed that they are thankful for Facebook!

The English Access Microscholarship Program (Access) provides a foundation of English language skills to talented 13-20 year-olds from economically disadvantaged sectors through after-school classes and intensive sessions.  

Access gives participants English skills that may lead to better jobs and greater educational opportunities. Participants also gain the ability to compete for and participate in future exchanges and study in the United States.

The English Access Microscholarship Program is available to students in Phnom Penh, Banteay Meanchey, Battambang, and Kampong Speu.

 : http://investinclimate.org/

In this picture, a Cambodian farmer ploughs his rice field after the flood subsides. Challenging climate conditions like drought and floods resulting from climate change can be overwhelming for Cambodian small farmers.  Government programs like USAID's Feed the Future help them by drawing on the latest innovations including improved plant breeding techniques, knowledge of behavior change, and enhanced information about pests and diseases.

The private sector also plays an important role in ensuring a healthy planet.  On October 20-21, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry will convene the Secretarys Climate and Clean Energy Investment Forum which will bring together investors, corporations, philanthropies, and policymakers to discuss the impact that climate and clean energy investments can have in the fight against global climate change. 

Learn more about this event at: http://investinclimate.org/

APEC summit highlights the importance of Asia-U.S. Business Ties

This past weekend, President Obama met with Chinese President H.E. Xi Jinping, Indonesian President Joko Widodo and other leaders from the Asia Pacific region at this years Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.  The main theme for APEC 2014 was making a stronger connection between economies in the Asia-Pacific region by removing barriers to trade and investment.  The annual summit brings together heads of state, economic leaders, and business executives from across the world to discuss economic issues in the Asia-Pacific region, and to promote regional trade, investment, and cooperation.  President Obama explained why "few global forums are watched more closely by the business community" than the APEC CEO Summit:  Watch the President's full remarks at the APEC CEO Summit here. 
  
Read more about the outcomes from the APEC forum 2014 here: http://goo.gl/bgOGJd.  Follow President Obama on his latest trip through Asia on the official White House blog here http://goo.gl/4Afws0

Every year, thousands of animal species become extinct.

Animals that once roamed the Earth in abundance are permanently disappearing from our planet at a heart-stopping pace.

Scientists estimate that the current rate of extinction is 1,000 times greater than it would normally be because of one factor.

What has caused this rapid rise in extinctions? The alarmingly simple answer: humans.

Heidt  USS Ronald Reagan (CVN 76)     U.S. Navy c-2 Greyhound           !     

     Yokosuka           http://www.navy.mil/navydata/ships/carriers/cv-list.asp  

On July 7, #AmbHeidt visited the USS Ronald Reagan (CVN 76), one of 10 U.S. Navy aircraft carriers that are in active service. He arrived via a U.S. Navy C-2 Greyhound airplane, undergoing an arrested landing and experiencing a catapult launch on the way back to #Cambodia. During his time aboard the ship, the Ambassador observed flight operations, talked with senior leadership, and also met the ship's "Sailor of the Year" and learned that she is married to a Cambodian! This visit was an amazing experience, showcasing U.S. military-to-military capability and underscoring our mutual interest in regional maritime security.  

Since August 2015, the USS Ronald Reagans home port has been Yokosuka, Japan. The ship has an established history of operating in the Pacific. This includes providing assistance after the 2011 tsunami in Japan, which ably demonstrated the ships potential for contributing to regional security. To learn more about the USS Ronald Reagan and other U.S. Navy aircraft carriers, please visit http://www.navy.mil/navydata/ships/carriers/cv-list.asp.

What would you get a robot to do for you? The potential of robots was discussed last Friday at the inaugural Conference on Robotics in #Cambodia, a joint endeavor by the U.S.-based NGO GOLDEN WEST HUMANITARIAN FOUNDATION, MoEYS Cambodia, and Villanova University in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania. With funding from the U.S. Department of State, Cambodian engineers have collaborated with U.S. university students to develop robots that can be used for demining efforts. In addition to these projects, the conference introduced Cambodian students to opportunities in #STEM and served as a platform for how future technology could be used in Cambodia.

Young children in Cambodia are also excited about robots! Last month, the Liger Learning Center and Development Innovations Cambodia - supported by USAID Cambodia - hosted an event called "Robotics Basics" that introduced robotics to students in grades 4-6. The students were able to share their knowledge and enthusiasm while encouraging others to learn more about robotics.

What do you think about the impact that robots can have in Cambodia? Please share your comments below.

The Solidarity Center:  Helping to Improve Labor Conditions in Cambodia 
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Readers of my blog know that I take great pride in writing about individuals and organizations that work to improve the quality of life for all Cambodians.  Today, I would like to highlight a remarkable organization that is making an enormous contribution in the field of labor rights:  the Solidarity Center.  As the non-governmental organization (NGO) affiliate of the American Federation of Labour (AFL-CIO), the Solidarity Center has programs in over 60 countries around the world, working with independent trade unions to promote workers rights and to conduct labor law advocacy.  Under the leadership of Canadian citizen David Welsh, the Solidarity Center in Cambodia has received praise for its high level of engagement with important stakeholders including the Royal Government of Cambodia, international corporations, the United Nations International Labor Organization (ILO), and various partners in the human and labor rights NGO community.

Over the past decade, much of the discussion on trade unions, labor rights, and the minimum wage in Cambodia has been related to the garment sector.  As the countrys top foreign currency earner, the industry has greatly contributed to Cambodias economic growth while providing opportunities for many Cambodians to supplement their incomes.  But there are also major concerns about salaries, unsafe conditions, and the overall treatment of workers.  The Solidarity Center has been deeply engaged in advocacy responses to these and other issues in the garment sector.  They played a significant role in the recent negotiations over the minimum wage and continue to work on key reforms, including Cambodia's proposed Trade Union law and the National Social Security Fund, which seeks to broaden the economic security of Cambodian workers.

The Solidarity Center provides support to trade unions and workers in every major sector in Cambodia through training and advocacy.  In addition to the garment sector, this also includes construction, hospitality and tourism, civil service, and education.  One of the areas of emphasis is promoting collective bargaining, which allows workers to negotiate with management as a group, giving them more leverage than they would have as individuals.  In recent years, the organization has also been at the forefront of legal proceedings involving the welfare of workers, helping to establish government, international brand, and industry liability in several cases regarding bankruptcy, accidents, and fatalities.  

Earlier this week, the U.S. Embassy hosted a roundtable discussion for members of a U.S. Congressional Delegation led by House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi.  The delegation met with key leaders in civil society to learn about a number of issues in Cambodia, including the recent Human Rights Watch report on garment factories.  I was pleased that Solidarity Center Cambodia Director David Welsh was able to join us.  His insights on workers rights and the conditions of garment factories in Cambodia were highly valued by the delegation members.

I greatly appreciate the efforts of the Solidarity Center to protect and advance workers rights through training, support, and advocacy.  The U.S. government is proud to support labor rights in Cambodia, especially since the United States is Cambodias largest trading partner, with approximately 40 percent of all Cambodian exports  the bulk of which are from the garment industry  bound for the United States.  Cambodias strong economic growth would not be possible without the valuable partnerships that the Solidarity Center has established with the Cambodian government, garment buyers, and other stakeholders.  By continuing to work together with the Solidarity Center and other organizations in both the public and private sectors, we can improve working conditions, encourage corporate social responsibility, strengthen commercial ties, and create economic opportunities for hundreds of thousands of Cambodians.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia Solidarity Center

Farewell to Two Outstanding Civil Society Leaders
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Over the course of my two-and-a-half years in Cambodia, I have been fortunate to have met with many dedicated individuals who are making a difference in the lives of the Cambodian people.  Two of these people will be departing Cambodia shortly, and before they leave, I want to highlight their important contributions  those of Jill Tucker, program manager at Better Factories Cambodia, and Laura Thornton, senior director at the National Democratic Institute.

For the past three years, Jill Tucker has been leading the efforts of Better Factories Cambodia (BFC) to improve working conditions for Cambodias 600,000 garment workers.  BFC monitors working conditions in Cambodian factories, helping to improve those conditions and make labor policies more transparent.  Perhaps Jills most important legacy is making BFCs findings available to the public in an online database.  

BFCs programs also support workers by educating them on the labor law and helping them better understand their rights.  One example of how BFC promotes workers rights is through the use of mobile phone technologies.  The Kamako Chhnoeum (outstanding worker in Khmer) mobile phone project is an interactive voice response system which allows factory workers to call toll-free to take a short quiz that will help them learn about labor rights, occupational health and safety, and personal health.  Another mobile phone application provides an interactive and searchable version of BFCs guide to the labor law, putting valuable information in the hands of workers, factory management, and others who work in the garment industry.

With an excellent record of BFC achievements, there is no doubt Jills efforts have been instrumental in assisting Cambodian workers, while at the same time creating opportunities for the garment industry to improve its reputation for providing decent working conditions.

Laura Thornton has been leading the way at the National Democratic Institute (NDI) for the past six years, and during that time she has tirelessly championed for strengthening Cambodias democracy.  Lauras work in Cambodia actually began in 1997, when she served as a consultant for USAID in Phnom Penh.  Her extensive work to empower citizens with the information they need to make informed choices has made a powerful impact.  During last years national elections, NDI held the countrys only candidate debate between representatives of the major political parties.  The televised debate was broadcast nationwide to make information about the political parties more accessible to voters.

Further expanding access to information, NDI has conducted constituency dialogues across Cambodia for the past ten years.  These town hall meetings provide an important opportunity for citizens to present unscripted questions to ruling party and opposition lawmakers.  Laura and NDI have also worked in partnership with other civil society organizations in the Electoral Reform Alliance (ERA).  NDI provided expertise in support of an ERA report which provided an analysis of public electoral data showing fundamental problems in Cambodias election system.  This report became a key talking point during the negotiations to end the nearly year-long political stalemate between the major political parties, and can be the basis for an electoral reform that boosts public confidence that voters voices are being heard.  

I am personally grateful for all of the hard work and important contributions of Jill and Laura over the past several years.  I know all of us who have interacted and worked alongside these civil society champions join me in wishing them both all the best as they pursue the next chapters in their lives.  Jill and Laura, thank you for your dedication to improving the lives of the Cambodian people.  You have truly made a difference.

#AmbTodd

Photo: Jill Tucker (right) joined me in addressing guests at a reception I hosted to honor the work of Better Factories Cambodia.

Why Mentoring Matters
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Have you ever had a mentor or been a mentor to someone?  If you have, then you probably recognize the impact that mentoring can have on a person.  But if you think that you have never been a part of this kind of relationship, it might have to do with how you define mentoring.  So what exactly is mentoring?  There are many different ways to answer this question, but a basic definition is that a mentor is someone who works with others in a positive, constructive way so that both mentor and mentee have the potential to grow through the relationship.  Moreover, it is important to keep in mind that mentoring is not an event  it is a collaborative process.  Benjamin Franklin once said, Tell me and I forget, teach me and I may remember, involve me and I learn.  Open and honest interaction between mentor and mentee not only ensures trust; it also guarantees that both individuals will benefit from the relationship. 

I have been a mentor and been mentored my entire career.  One of my mentors along the way taught me two valuable lessons: you have to be able to take risks to grow, and it is fine to make mistakes as long as learn from them.  I also learned that you are never too old to grow and develop. Since I have been here in Cambodia, I have continued to be mentored by closely working with civil society.  I am very grateful for the knowledge and experiences that they have shared with me, and I sincerely believe that I am a better leader today because of their support and ideas.

As President Obama said in his 2014 proclamation that recognized January as National Mentoring Month in the United States, Mentors push our next generation to shape their ambitions, set a positive course, and achieve their boundless potential.  I believe that effective leaders always give back, especially to younger generations.  This is a driving force behind our work with the Ambassadors Youth Council (AYC).  Aside from advising me on the concerns of youth in Cambodia, AYC members serve as mentors to other Cambodians, helping people gain access to valuable work experiences, educational resources, and skill-building activities that will help improve their lives and the lives of others.

With approximately 70 percent of the population being under the age of 30, it is clear that Cambodias future would greatly benefit from mentoring.  Recognizing the value of youth, political parties have created programs for mentoring and information sharing, with both the Cambodian Peoples Party and the Cambodian National Rescue Party establishing their own youth councils.  A number of civil society groups in Cambodia have also developed initiatives that encourage mentoring as a means of empowering the next generation of leaders.  By embracing the role of the mentor, the leaders of today can help educate and inspire young Cambodians, improving their chances of securing better academic and professional opportunities in the future.

Mentoring can come in many forms.  For example, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) helps to ensure that midwives and other certified health providers in Cambodia learn life-saving skills and practices through training, coaching, and mentoring activities.  Development Innovations  another project funded by USAID  is also promoting mentoring to grow a community of innovators in Cambodia.  Through its Mentor Network, local and international mentors provide support for mentees with promising technology-based initiatives.  With the knowledge and experience gained from civil society, technology development, and social enterprise, these mentors assist others in creating solutions that make Cambodia a better place for everyone.

Later this year, 250 young leaders from throughout the ASEAN region will be selected as YSEALI Professional Fellows, serving for five weeks in non-profit organizations and government offices in the United States.  Working directly with their American counterparts, the YSEALI Professional Fellows will enhance their practical expertise, leadership skills, and professional contacts in the fields of civic engagement, NGO management, governance, law, economics, and environmental and natural resources management.  When the young Cambodians participating in this program return home, they have the potential to become remarkable mentors for others seeking to address challenges and create new opportunities.  In fact, one of the most powerful aspects of YSEALI is that it serves as a natural conduit for mentoring.  This is one of the reasons why I am encouraged by the substantial number of youth in Cambodia getting involved with YSEALI.

Is mentoring right for you?  Do you want to be a mentor or a mentee?  Please share your comments, follow us on social media, and go to our U.S. Embassy website for more information about these and other opportunities.

EducationUSA Fair 2016 was an amazing event! More than 1,000  young people came to the InterContinental Phnom Penh yesterday to get valuable information about opportunities to study in the United States. U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung and H.E. Lao Chhiv Eav - Undersecretary of State for the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports - stopped by the fair to show their support and encourage more students from #Cambodia to apply to study at U.S. colleges and universities. And with the help of an outstanding group of volunteers, over 100 participants became members of the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative. Earlier in the day, EducationUSA also brought U.S. school representatives to the CIA FIRST International School for a fair that attracted an additional 100 students. These events not only prove just how enthusiastic Cambodian youth are about education and studying in the United States; they also demonstrate the wide number of people, programs, and partnerships dedicated to helping students achieve their dreams.

On June 20th, the U.S. Embassy organized its annual Access English Camp for over 100 students from 5 provinces, all of whom are studying English through the U.S. State Department's "English Access Microscholarship Program."
