International Education Week: 5 Steps to Studying in the United States 

Step Two:  Finance Your Studies
   
Don't let the cost of studying in the United States scare you! 
Make a budget and write down a list of resources that can assist you in paying for the program you want to attend. 

As you prepare your budget, keep in mind that costs are determined by the institutions tuition charges, classroom supplies and living expenses, such as room and board and health insurance. 

So where do most of the reliable sources of funding for school abroad come from? 
Depending on the type of program you choose, the following may be available:

        Scholarships
        Grants
        Student Exchange Programs

You might also obtain funding from:

        Social, Community, or Non-governmental organizations
        Multinational companies or local businesses


Once you have chosen your desired program of study, check the EducationUSA website for financing information specific to your program here http://goo.gl/Xg8HNw   

EducationUSA is a U.S. Department of State-supported network of hundreds of advising centers around the world, including in Cambodia.  The EducationUSA office in Pannasastra University provides free counseling services to all students interested in studying in the United States.

PHNOM PENH, CAMBODIA
JANUARY 26, 2016
"Today I had candid and constructive meetings with Prime Minister Hun Sen and Foreign Minister Hor Namhong. I also met with the acting head of the opposition, Kem Sokha. And just now, a few minutes ago, I was able to spend some time with members of Cambodian civil society, young people who are working so vigorously on land reform, on environment, on sustainable energy, on accountability, deforestation challenges. And in every meeting, in every meeting, I made clear that we are committed  we, the United States of America, are committed to the relationship between our country and Cambodia and we are committed to building on the progress that we have already made in education, health, cultural preservation." - U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry

November 25th is the International Day to End Violence against Women, which kicks off the 16 Days of Activism against Gender Violence (November 25th-December 10th). This year, the United Nations celebrations, led by the UNiTE campaign, will take place under the theme "Orange Your Neighborhood - End Violence Against Women and Girls Now.  The campaign focuses on local actions towards ending violence against women and girls, while using orange as the uniting color of all advocacy efforts.

THE AMBASSADOR'S VISIT TO LONG BEACH, CALIFORNIA
"The Cambodian-American community in Long Beach, California gave my family and me a very warm welcome during our visit last week. An overflow crowd of 350 people joined a community forum at the La Lune Imperial Restaurant in Long Beach. I made a presentation entitled '#Cambodia: Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow' that outlined recent developments in Cambodia and Americas role in encouraging positive change. The audience asked many tough questions about economic relations between the United States and Cambodia, Cambodias prospects for having free and fair elections in 2017 and 2018, corruption, the very sad killing of #KemLey, and U.S. visa policy." - #AmbHeidt

* What is "blue state" and "red state"?

Blue state is a term used to refer to a U.S. state where the majority of voters usually support Democratic candidates and causes.

Red state refers to a U.S. state where the majority of voters usually support Republican candidates and causes.

Today is the International Day of Persons with Disabilities, which promotes awareness and mobilizes support for the inclusion of persons with disabilities in society.

In Cambodia, there are an estimated 700,000 persons who are disabled and many of them face physical, social, and economic barriers that prevent them from realizing their potential and playing a greater role in their communities.  Earlier this year, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) launched the Rehabilitation and Prosthetics Program for Persons with Disabilities in Cambodia.  The program will allow Veterans International Cambodia (VIC) to continue to provide rehabilitation and prosthetic services for persons with disabilities.

Judith Heumann, Special Advisor for International Disability Rights at the Department of State said, The United States is committed to inclusion and to empowering people with disabilities to stand up for their rights and to oppose discrimination in all of its forms.  You can learn more about Special Advisor Heumanns work to promote the rights of the 1 billion people worldwide who live with a disability here:  https://share.america.gov/what-makes-successful-civil-rights-advocate/

Photo caption: Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung, H.E. Sem Sokha, Secretary of State at the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veterans and Youth Rehabilitation, VIC Country Director Keo Rithy, and other guests at the official launch of VICs Rehabilitation and Prosthetics Program.

Ambassador Todd addresses the issue of land disputes and the need to protect citizens from forced evictions: 

In recent weeks, we have seen hundreds of people marching into the capital to protest over land concessions, bringing renewed attention to this long-standing issue.  Land is a finite resource, and increased population growth and economic activity put an increasing strain on public lands.  A fair and effective land management policy that advances economic development and also protects individual rights is something that individual families and businesses both demand. 

Last week, Samdech Prime Minister Hun Sen expressed his own concerns about land concessions and called for greater accountability by local officials in the handling of land disputes.  It was also reported that the Prime Minister set up a new high-level inter-ministerial committee to review whether companies are abiding by the rules of the economic land concessions, which is a promising idea.  For Cambodian citizens who have been affected by land concessions, the Prime Ministers call for action has raised hope that positive changes may be within reach, but implementation will be key.

Read the Ambassadors full column, titled Resolving Land Disputes and Protecting Citizens Rights, in The Cambodia Herald at http://goo.gl/cqYCKJ

Opening Doors to Entrepreneurship for Women
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Cambodias economy has been one of the fastest growing in the world over the past decade.  As the country continues to reform and improve its business and foreign investment climate, a key element for further economic growth is the increased presence of entrepreneurs in Cambodia, particularly among women.  With last months visit of First Lady Michelle Obama and the celebration of International Womens Day, we were once again reminded of how women and girls are critically important to families and communities in Cambodia, just as they are in the United States and around the world.  By unleashing the creativity, drive, and sound judgment of women we can help more women in Cambodia become successful entrepreneurs.

This is why I was delighted to see that Julie Chung, my Deputy Chief of Mission at the U.S. Embassy, participated in a recent seminar on entrepreneurship for Cambodian women, co-sponsored by the U.S. Department of State and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan.  Along with Ministry of Womens Affairs Secretary of State Chan Sorey and Japanese Ambassador Yuji Kumamaru, Julie joined more than 100 Cambodian business owners, aspiring entrepreneurs, and NGO representatives for this event that addressed barriers to womens entry into business in Cambodia.  With panelists from U.S. companies including General Electrics Country Manager Dararith Lim and U.S. social entrepreneur Janice Wilson, discussions on womens economic empowerment were led by business executives and experts from the United States, Japan, and Cambodia.

The event was part of joint efforts between the United States and Japan to expand regional cooperation through the Lower Mekong Initiative (LMI).  The U.S. Department of State is also working with the Ministry of Womens Affairs on the Womens Entrepreneurial Centers of Resources, Education, Access, and Training for Economic Empowerment (WECREATE) Program.  One of the main outcomes of the LMI WECREATE Program will be the establishment of a womens entrepreneurial center in Phnom Penh in late 2015.  At this center, women will have a safe and centralized location with resources that will allow established businesses to build capacity and newer microenterprises to move from the informal sector into the formal sector, both of which generate momentum for measurable economic and societal change in Cambodia.

Through efforts like the entrepreneurship seminar and the future WECREATE center, women will have better access to the resources they need to start and develop their own businesses.  But we have also learned that entrepreneurs are even more likely to succeed when they develop support networks with local business mentors and role models who can provide advice and services.  This is why I think organizations like the Cambodia Women Entrepreneurs Association (CWEA) are so vital to the countrys development of future business leaders.  Others can learn a lot from the expertise of CWEA members  women that have been successful in a range of business sectors, including food production, hospitality, handicrafts, and telecommunications.  

The United States is proud to assist Cambodian women to receive quality education, resources, and mentoring to support their specific needs to start, scale, and grow businesses.  By connecting women around the world and providing access to opportunity, we can accelerate growth and enhance economic prosperity for all Cambodians.

Do you have any thoughts about women and entrepreneurship in Cambodia?  Please share your comments.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

Using Mobile Technology to Help Fight HIV
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Cambodia has been recognized for making tremendous progress in the prevention and treatment of HIV.  In the past decade, Cambodia has cut adult HIV infection rates by more than half, and today more than 80 percent of patients diagnosed with HIV receive life-saving treatment.  Many people in the country remain at a high risk of HIV infection, however, so it is critical to continue to expand the reach of HIV services and health information to hard-to-reach groups.  

Thats why I am so excited about yesterdays release of an innovative tool to help fight against new HIV infections in Cambodia.  The mobile health platform  called mHealth  was launched this week by USAIDs Cambodia HIV/AIDS Flagship project in collaboration with the National AIDS Authority and the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications.  The Cambodia HIV/AIDS Flagship project is a consortium of local and international non-governmental organizations (NGOs) funded by the U.S. Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) through the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID).  The mHealth platform is an example of how the U.S. government partners with the Royal Government of Cambodia and NGOs to provide potentially life-saving HIV-related information and services to underserved populations, including  entertainment workers.

In a previous blog, I mentioned how mobile phones can help improve the lives of people by providing access to information.  The mHealth platform is an example of mobile phone technology being used to help at-risk populations receive access to the HIV information and services they need.  The mHealth platform features Voice4U, a mobile phone interactive voice response system that provides callers with on-line counseling, on-demand HIV and health-related information, and medication and appointment reminders.  Another component of mHealth is My Community, a set of interactive websites and Facebook pages that offers electronically-mapped service locations and downloadable referrals, HIV and related news and information, individual risk screening, and more.

Cambodias achievements in preventing and treating HIV are a testament to the strong leadership and strategic direction of the Ministry of Health and other key government agencies as well as to the support of NGO and development partners.  The United States is proud to support Cambodia as it continues to work towards the goal of eliminating all new HIV infections by 2020.  
#AmbTodd #Cambodia #USAID

Happy World Fisheries Day!  Observed on November 21, World Fisheries Day seeks to promote sustainability by drawing attention to overfishing, habitat destruction, and other threats to our marine and freshwater resources. 

A recent UN study reported that more than 2/3 of the world's fisheries have been overfished, and more than 1/3 are in a state of collapse.  The stakes are high.  According to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization, 2.5 BILLION people receive at least 20% of their animal protein intake from fish, and fisheries and aquaculture support the livelihoods of 10-12 percent of the worlds population. Learn more about how the U.S. is working to protect fisheries and other marine resources:  http://www.nmfs.noaa.gov/.  #OurOcean2014 #WorldFisheriesDay

   USAID                          

    USAID        http://capmalaria.org/ 

Each year, #WorldMalariaDay provides an opportunity to recognize global efforts to eliminate malaria. The United States provides $4.5 million annually to the Control and Prevention of Malaria Project (CAP Malaria) - funded by USAID  through the President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) - to fight #malaria in #Cambodia. How does this help?
 
In FY2015, USAID Cambodia procured and distributed more than 122,000 mosquito nets to at-risk populations. Village malaria workers made over 143,000 visits to households and over 22,000 visits to development farms to educate people about malaria prevention. And after training more than 900 health facility and community workers in case management, close to 26,000 patients were confirmed malaria positive and received proper treatment.

To eliminate malaria in Cambodia by 2025, USAID is working with the National Malaria Program Center to pilot a malaria elimination intervention package, with the hope that it will one day serve as the basis for a model that can be replicated throughout the country. To find out more, please visit http://capmalaria.org/.

In the 1920s, a popular American band known as Waring's Pennsylvanians recorded a song called "I Scream, You Scream, We All Scream for Ice Cream." Almost 100 years later, people still love ice cream, including here in #Cambodia. So we're very excited about the arrival of Cold Stone Creamery to the Kingdom!

Founded in 1988 in the U.S. state of Arizona, Cold Stone Creamery is one of the latest American companies to bring quality customer service and job opportunities to Cambodia. #AmbHeidt was at the official opening of Cold Stone Creamery Cambodia, located in Phnom Penh on Kampuchea Krom Boulevard (Street 128) next to Asia Euro University (AEU). Cambodia is now among 29 countries in the world with a Cold Stone Creamery store. With a wide variety of flavors and toppings, customers can try one of Cold Stone Creamery's signature items or even make their own ice cream creation. So if you're an ice cream lover like us, we'll see you there soon!

FILL IN THE BLANK:
On ... (date) in 1492, ten o'clock at night, Columbus saw a light. The Pinta kept sailing, and reported that the ligth was, in fact, land. The next morning at dawn they landed. Christopher Columbus and his crew had expected to see people native to India. They called the first people they saw "Indians" They had gone ashore in their best clothes, knelt and praised God for arriving safely. From the "Indians" they learned that the island was called Guanahani. When they landed on the island that is now Cuba, they thought they were in Japan. Columbus died a rich and famous man, but he never knew that he discovered lands that few people had imagined were there.

Staying the Course
  - From the Ambassador's Penh

As I begin this final entry to my blog, I would first like to say thanks to all of the people of this great nation.  It has been both an honor and a privilege to spend these last three years serving as the U.S. Ambassador to the Royal Kingdom of Cambodia.  I especially appreciate all of the comments and questions that you have shared with me.  I think back to my very first blog entry in June 2012, when I stated that my top goal was to foster a more effective relationship between the people of the United States and Cambodia.  Today, I am proud to say that there has been significant progress made because of the contributions and dedication of civil society members.  Their efforts have encouraged a growing number of people to play an active role in the development of Cambodia.

Over the course of more than three years in Cambodia, I have been fortunate to have met with and learned from several wonderful and dedicated individuals who are making a difference in the lives of the Cambodian people.  When I think about what has already been achieved and the challenges that lie ahead, the efforts of these men and women make me very hopeful.  Many of these individuals are a part of Cambodias vibrant civil society.  In fact, frequent readers of my blog know that I have often written about the amazing work of civil society and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), since much of Cambodias success in recent years  a growing economy, improvements in health care and schools, a greater focus on human rights, and more  is due in great part to the work of civil society leaders and organizations.

Many readers of my blog would often ask me about my thoughts regarding the role of NGOs and civil society in Cambodia.  No matter if it is Cambodia, the United States, or any other nation  I firmly believe that when civil society is strong, the country is stronger.  I also think that any effort to restrict the freedoms of assembly and expression is not conducive towards a healthy and sustainable democracy.  With the Royal Government providing the space for NGOs to operate freely, civil society was able to make significant contributions to the electoral process and built voter confidence during the 2013 national elections.  It is my hope that government and civil society leaders will continue to work together to promote democracy, protect human rights, and bring prosperity to all citizens of Cambodia.

History shows that government alone cannot deliver social and economic progress that is broad-based and sustainable.  A thriving civil society is needed to empower citizens, to find innovative solutions to challenges, and to hold government leaders accountable.  Furthermore, when there is limited government funding for public services, civil society helps to fill important gaps, especially for people living in under-served communities.  Here in Cambodia, there have already been many achievements in the areas of health, nutrition, education, environmental protection, and community development due to the efforts of the NGO community.  With the sustained presence of effective programs and partnerships with civil society, there is potential to help Cambodia reach even greater heights.

Not long after arriving to Cambodia, I invited a number of representatives from civil society to be a part of my NGO Advisory Council.  The Council proved to be an effective avenue for engaging with Cambodian civil society directly on a wide range of important topics, including the role that U.S. government programs and policies play in addressing some of the leading challenges in Cambodia.  I would like to thank all of the members of the NGO Advisory Council for providing me with your expertise and advice these past three years.  We have had some excellent and very frank discussions together, which has helped me and my U.S. Embassy team to strengthen the relationship between the United States and Cambodia. 

In the United States, many people use the expression staying the course, which means to pursue a goal regardless of time, obstacles, or criticism.  As Cambodia moves forward, I encourage members of civil society to stay the course and continue improving the quality of life for the Cambodian people.  By working together with the Royal Government, the private sector, and other partners found in the region and around the world, Cambodias civil society will continue to help lead the country towards achieving all of its development goals.

I want to again thank everyone for your support during my time in Cambodia.  I look forward to hearing about even greater success in the future.  May God bless each of you and your families, may God bless the Royal Kingdom of Cambodia, and may God bless the United States of America.

Ambassador Heidt met with Minister of Environment H.E. Dr. Say Samal today to discuss bilateral cooperation on environmental issues in #Cambodia. The Minister highlighted the importance of developing the country's Environmental Code, an area in which  USAID - US Agency for International Development is providing support. "We would like your help to closely collaborate with U.S. institutions like the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)," expressed the Minister, while #AmbHeidt noted the "impressive reforms" that the Minister of Environment has implemented.

With more people migrating from the provinces to the capital, as well as people from other countries who have decided to live and work in Phnom Penh, the city is facing a wide variety of challenges to keep up with its growing population.

Many residents do not have access to adequate land, housing, or clean water.

The high volume of traffic continues to increase, and yet the city lacks an efficient traffic management system.

Upgrades and expansion of Phnom Penhs roads, sewer system, power grid, and other infrastructure projects are overdue.

And for the citys young population to learn and grow up in a healthy environment, they will need improved access to education, public health services, and safe spaces.

Like other rapidly growing cities around the world, including the United States, Phnom Penhs success and viability will be measured by how it develops a master plan to meet these challenges and serve the needs of the people.
Read more at: http://www.thecambodiaherald.com/opinion/becoming-a-resilient-city-1421

May 26, 2016

The U.S. Embassy is deeply concerned about the recent events in #Cambodia. The deployment of paramilitary forces at the Cambodian National Rescue Party (CNRP) headquarters and armed confrontations with CNRP supporters on May 26 are disproportionate and dangerous steps. Heidt               HARVEST  NOURISH         CARD   

Today, Ambassador Heidt met with H.E. Dr. Yim Chhay Ly - Deputy Prime Minister and Chairman of the Council for Agricultural and Rural Development (CARD) - to congratulate the people of Cambodia for improvements in the areas of nutrition and health. During the meeting, the Deputy Prime Minister expressed his appreciation for the work of U.S. government projects such as USAID's HARVEST and NOURISH, while noting the importance of focusing on youth and education as a way to better Cambodia's future. The Ambassador also highlighted wildlife trade as a possible area for cooperation in the future and looks forward to hearing from CARD on how the United States and Cambodia can work together on this important issue.

Remarks by the President on the Ebola Outbreak

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Atlanta, Georgia

4:01 P.M. EDT

THE PRESIDENT:  Good afternoon, everybody.  Please be seated.  I want to thank Dr. Frieden and everybody here at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for welcoming me here today.  Tom and his team just gave me an update on the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, our efforts to help mobilize the international community to fight it, and the steps that were taking to keep people here at home safe. 

Tom and his team are doing outstanding work.  Between the specialists they have on the ground in West Africa and here at headquarters, theyve got hundreds of professionals who are working tirelessly on this issue.  This is the largest international response in the history of the CDC.  After this, Ill be meeting with some of these men and women, including some who recently returned from the front lines of the outbreak.  And they represent public service at its very best.  And so I just want them to know how much the American people appreciate them.  Many of them are serving far away from home, away from their families.  They are doing heroic work and serving in some unbelievably challenging conditions -- working through exhaustion, day and night, and many have volunteered to go back.  So we are very, very proud of them.

Their work and our efforts across the government is an example of what happens when America leads in confronting some major global challenges.  Faced with this outbreak, the world is looking to us, the United States, and its a responsibility that we embrace.  Were prepared to take leadership on this to provide the kinds of capabilities that only America has, and to mobilize the world in ways that only America can do.  Thats what were doing as we speak. 

First and foremost, I want the American people to know that our experts, here at the CDC and across our government, agree that the chances of an Ebola outbreak here in the United States are extremely low.  Weve been taking the necessary precautions, including working with countries in West Africa to increase screening at airports so that someone with the virus doesnt get on a plane for the United States.  In the unlikely event that someone with Ebola does reach our shores, weve taken new measures so that were prepared here at home.  Were working to help flight crews identify people who are sick, and more labs across our country now have the capacity to quickly test for the virus.  Were working with hospitals to make sure that they are prepared, and to ensure that our doctors, our nurses and our medical staff are trained, are ready, and are able to deal with a possible case safely.

And here Ive got to commend everybody at Emory University Hospital.  I just had the opportunity to meet with Doctors Gartland and Ribner and members of their team and the nurses who -- sorry, doctors, but having been in hospitals, I know -- (laughter) -- theyre the ones really doing the work.  And I had a chance to thank them for their extraordinary efforts in helping to provide care for the first Americans who recently contracted the disease in Africa.  The first two of those patients were released last month and continue to improve.  And its a reminder for the American people that, should any cases appear in the United States, we have world-class facilities and professionals ready to respond.  And we have effective surveillance mechanisms in place.  

I should mention, by the way, that I had a chance to see Dr. Brantly in the Oval Office this morning.  And although he is still having to gain back some weight, he looks great.  He looks strong and we are incredibly grateful to him and his family for the service that he has rendered to people who are a lot less lucky than all of us.

As we all know, however, West Africa is facing a very different situation, especially in the hardest hit countries:  Liberia, Sierra Leone, and in Guinea.  Tom and others recently returned from the region, and the scenes that they describe are just horrific.  More than 2,400 men, women and children are known to have died -- and we strongly suspect that the actual death toll is higher than that.  Hospitals, clinics and the few treatment centers that do exist have been completely overwhelmed.  An already very weak public health system is near collapse in these countries.  Patients are being turned away, and people are literally dying in the streets.

Now, heres the hard truth:  In West Africa, Ebola is now an epidemic of the likes that we have not seen before.  Its spiraling out of control.  It is getting worse.  Its spreading faster and exponentially.  Today, thousands of people in West Africa are infected.  That number could rapidly grow to tens of thousands.  And if the outbreak is not stopped now, we could be looking at hundreds of thousands of people infected, with profound political and economic and security implications for all of us.  So this is an epidemic that is not just a threat to regional security -- its a potential threat to global security if these countries break down, if their economies break down, if people panic.  That has profound effects on all of us, even if we are not directly contracting the disease.

And thats why, two months ago, I directed my team to make this a national security priority.  Were working this across our entire government, which is why today Im joined by leaders throughout my administration, including from my national security team. 

And weve devoted significant resources in support of our strategy with four goals in mind.  Number one, to control the outbreak.  Number two, to address the ripple effects of local economies and communities to prevent a truly massive humanitarian disaster.  Number three, to coordinate a broader global response.  And number four, to urgently build up a public health system in these countries for the future -- not just in West Africa but in countries that dont have a lot of resources generally.

Now, this is a daunting task.  But heres what gives us hope.  The world knows how to fight this disease.  Its not a mystery.  We know the science.  We know how to prevent it from spreading.  We know how to care for those who contract it.  We know that if we take the proper steps, we can save lives.  But we have to act fast.  We cant dawdle on this one.  We have to move with force and make sure that we are catching this as best we can, given that it has already broken out in ways that we had not seen before.   

So today, Im announcing a major increase in our response.  At the request of the Liberian government, were going to establish a military command center in Liberia to support civilian efforts across the region -- similar to our response after the Haiti earthquake.  Its going to be commanded by Major General Darryl Williams, commander of our Army forces in Africa.  He just arrived today and is now on the ground in Liberia.  And our forces are going to bring their expertise in command and control, in logistics, in engineering.  And our Department of Defense is better at that, our Armed Services are better at that than any organization on Earth. 

Were going to create an air bridge to get health workers and medical supplies into West Africa faster.  Were going to establish a staging area in Senegal to help distribute personnel and aid on the ground more quickly.  We are going to create a new training site to train thousands of health workers so they can effectively and safely care for more patients.  Personnel from the U.S. Public Health Service will deploy to the new field hospitals that were setting up in Liberia.  And USAID will join with international partners and local communities in a Community Care Campaign to distribute supplies and information kits to hundreds of thousands of families so they can better protect themselves. 

Were also going to build additional treatment units, including new isolation spaces and more than 1,000 beds.  And in all our efforts, the safety of our personnel will remain a top priority.  Meanwhile, our scientists continue their urgent research in the hope of finding new treatments and perhaps vaccines.  And today Im calling on Congress to approve the funding that weve requested so that we can carry on with all these critical efforts.     

Today, the United States is doing even more.  But this is a global threat, and it demands a truly global response.  International organizations just have to move faster than they have up until this point.  More nations need to contribute experienced personnel, supplies, and funding thats needed, and they need to deliver on what they pledge quickly.  Charities and individual philanthropists have given generously, and they can make a big difference.  And so were not restricting these efforts to governmental organizations; we also need NGOs and private philanthropies to work with us in a coordinated fashion in order to maximize the impact of our response. 

This week, the United States will chair an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council.  Next week, Ill join U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to continue mobilizing the international community around this effort.  And then, at the White House, were going to bring more nations together to strengthen our global health security so that we can better prevent, detect and respond to future outbreaks before they become epidemics. 

This is actually something that we had announced several months ago at the G7 meeting.  We determined that this has to be a top priority; this was before the Ebola outbreak.  We anticipated the fact that in many of these countries with a weak public health system, if we dont have more effective surveillance, more effective facilities on the ground, and are not helping poor countries in developing their ability to catch these things quickly, that there was at least the potential of seeing these kinds of outbreaks.  And sadly, we now see that our predictions were correct.  It gives more urgency to this effort -- a global health initiative -- that we have been pushing internationally.    

Let me just close by saying this:  The scenes that were witnessing in West Africa today are absolutely gut-wrenching.  In one account over the weekend, we read about a family in Liberia.  The disease had already killed the father.  The mother was cradling a sick and listless five-year-old son.  Her other son, 10-years-old, was dying, too.  They finally reached a treatment center but they couldnt get in.  And, said a relative, We are just sitting. 

These men and women and children are just sitting, waiting to die, right now.  And it doesnt have to be this way.     

The reality is that this epidemic is going to get worse before it gets better.  But right now, the world still has an opportunity to save countless lives.  Right now, the world has the responsibility to act -- to step up, and to do more.  The United States of America intends to do more.  We are going to keep leading in this effort.  Were going to do our part, and were going to continue to make sure that the world understands the need for them to step alongside us as well in order for us to not just save the lives of families like the one I just discussed, but ultimately, to make sure that this doesnt have the kinds of spillover effects that become even more difficult to control.

So thank you very much to the entire team thats already doing this work.  And please know that youve got your President and Commander-in-Chief behind you.  Thank you. 

*****

The LaValla School: Helping to Provide Education for All Children
-From the Ambassador's Penh

In my role as the U.S. Ambassador, I get the chance to travel across Cambodia and meet with amazing people making significant contributions to the countrys development.  As many readers of my blog have learned, I believe that one of the most critical aspects of Cambodias future growth is the education of its children.  Making sure that every child in Cambodia has access to a quality education will help children to fulfill their potential and help the country develop economically.  This is why I was delighted to have the opportunity to visit the LaValla School last week, as it is a remarkable example of an organization that is committed to the education of all children, including those with physical disabilities.

Located in Takhmao, Kandal Province, the LaValla School was established by the Marist Brothers in 1998 to provide a residential elementary program for children with physical disabilities.  In fact, it is the only school that the Royal Cambodian government has approved to provide full primary education to children with physical disabilities.  There are approximately 100 students currently attending the school and about 35 percent of the students are girls.  In addition to their approved and accelerated curriculum, the LaValla School also offers extended learning programs, which include English language, traditional Khmer music, basic computing skills, physical and hydro-therapy, and more.  Furthermore, the school works as a resource center to prepare children from low-income families for future integration into regular schools.

When I arrived at LaValla, I was kindly greeted by Brother Terry Heinrich and other members of the school management team.  Brother Terry has been living in Cambodia since 1997 and works with Marist Solidarity Cambodia, an international NGO that promotes empowerment and advocacy, and provides referral services for appropriate rehabilitation, education, vocational training and livelihood and employment opportunities to the children and youth with disabilities.  After meeting the staff, I had the opportunity to tour the school facilities, participate in an inauguration ceremony for a new boys dormitory, watch a music performance, and speak with the students.  It was important to let them know about the unique opportunity that they are receiving at the LaValla School.  With a good education and support from caring people like those at LaValla, these young people will have a better chance to succeed and help improve the lives of others as well.

In addition to the youth studying at LaValla, the school also supports another 400 children with disabilities throughout the country.  Most of the schools funding comes from the Grapes for Humanity Global Foundation (GHGF).  During my visit to LaValla, I met GHGF founder and director Ms. Arlene Willis and members of the Foundations board.  Along with the work they are doing at LaValla, GHGF also received funding from the U.S. government for a public-private partnership on humanitarian mine action.  Recently, the Foundation was able to raise $100,000 for Cambodian survivors of landmine and unexploded ordinance accidents.  These funds will be granted to the Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation to construct new rehabilitation facilities in Prey Veng.

I would like to thank everyone at the LaValla School for the kind invitation and warm welcome during my visit.  I had a wonderful time speaking with the youth, teachers, and staff.  The commitment and the hard work that I witnessed will keep me and others hopeful about the future.  I have no doubt that the LaValla School and its students will have a powerful and positive impact on the development of Cambodia, proving that a quality education can bring success to all.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

Kim Sokngim  today's #CamWomenCan Club member  on why she decided to study engineering: 
In #Cambodia, the field of engineering offers very few women higher positions. Many engineering companies will hire only men for higher positions because they think that women are weaker and less powerful than men... I went against this discrimination by choosing to study civil engineering. I want to empower equal opportunity of gender in every workplace in Cambodia. I believe that women can do anything that the men can do, because women are smart and creative.

Sokngim  who is from Kandal Province and is a graduate of The Harpswell Foundation  is completing her studies at the University of Georgia. After graduating, she hopes to return to Cambodia to start her own civil engineering firm that will build roads and bridges throughout the country. My roads and bridges would propel the economy and Cambodia would have the strongest economy in Southeast Asia. My roads would also mean that children in the provinces could ride the bus to school and so they would receive education and help Cambodia in the future.

A SPECIAL JULY 4TH MESSAGE FROM AMBASSADOR HEIDT
(as seen in The Phnom Penh Post)

On November 8, the American people will come together to select a new President of the United States, along with thousands of other federal, state, and local ofcials. This years election is shaping up to be one of the most hotly contested in our history, with strong views on both sides. 

Despite the rhetoric and passion of the election, no matter who wins, the fundamental principles of our democracy will remain intact. The winners will celebrate, the losers will concede, and the decision of the American people will be respected, as it has been for more than two centuries. The candidates and the political parties will put the election behind them. The winners will get on with the business of governing; the losers will start getting ready for the next election.  

There is more than one recipe for democracy. What works for the United States may not necessarily work for Cambodia. But in any democracy, political forces must share a basic acceptance that their opponents have a legitimate right to engage in politics.  Politicians from all sides may not agree on the issues, or even like each other, but they must accept that their opponents have the right to advocate for their interests, and treat them accordingly.  

I have gotten to know many of the leaders of the government and opposition since I returned to Cambodia nine months ago. By and large, they are good and patriotic people trying to do their best for Cambodia. But neither side seems to accept the other as legitimate. Little more than a year after the Culture of Dialogue was announced, once again I see little respect or polite discourse in contemporary Cambodian politics. When it comes to accepting the right of your opponent to pursue his interests  the essence of reconciliation  I feel saddened to say that there has been little progress on either side since my previous assignment here in the late 1990s.

If Cambodian democracy is going to endure, as the Cambodian people clearly want, politicians from all sides need to separate the political from the personal. They need to understand that two sides can disagree about the direction of the nation while sharing a love for the country, its citizens, and its institutions. They need, above all, to recognize the good in each other.

There is a fundamental difference between disagreeing with your opponent and considering him or her to be an enemy. Politicians in the United States have radically different points of view on every issue imaginable. But our best politicians  our statesmen and stateswomen  respect their opponents right to pursue their interests and compete in elections. They know that calling each other traitors, or challenging each others patriotism, cheapen our politics.

In all honesty, it has not always been that way. In the early part of our history our politicians often engaged in stghts and worse, and it took many years of bitter politics for them to realize that this was counter-productive to their interests, and the interests of the nation.

Since arriving in Cambodia as the U.S. Ambassador last September, I have been amazed with the progress that this country has made since the 1990s. The economy is booming, the infra-structure is more developed, the people are healthier and more educated, and civil society is stronger. Cambodias youth are optimistic, proud of their country, and eager to participate in shaping its future. Cambodia has overcome many obstacles over the years, but the inability of Cambodias political leaders to work with each other for the benet of the nation continues to prevent this great country from reaching its full potential. 

On July 4, we will celebrate the 240th anniversary of the independence of the United States of America. We have been through many ups and downs over the years, but over time our democracy has not just survived but ourished. The work of democracy is never nished, but we are making progress. As a friend of Cambodia, it is my earnest hope that both the government and opposition can reach out to each other in a spirit of patriotism and reconciliation to do the same.

#AmbHeidt #Cambodia #USA #July4th

State Department on Opening of Cambodian National Assembly:

On September 23, Cambodian King Sihamoni presided over the opening of the new National Assembly and called for all elected lawmakers to show unity and work in the interest of the nation.

The opposition Cambodian National Rescue Party (CNRP) did not participate in the event, in light of unresolved disputes over election results.

The United States has an interest in the democratic process, but does not support any particular political party or individuals.

In that context, we continue to believe there should be a credible and transparent review of irregularities in the July elections to assess and address flaws in the electoral process and give the Cambodian people greater confidence in the electoral system...

The Impact of Climate Change in Cambodia 
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Scientists have recently confirmed that 2014 was the warmest year since 1880, and 14 of the 15 warmest years on record have occurred this century.  Closer to home, researchers expect that Cambodia will experience increases in average temperature, a longer and warmer dry season, and more rainfall during the wet season.  The variation in the weather also includes the recent cold snap we experienced over the past month here, with temperatures dropping to the low teens in some areas and the government advising people to bundle up in warmer clothing as a preventive measure against colds, influenza, and other respiratory illnesses associated with cold weather.  All of these variations are the result of climate change.

Whether in Phnom Penh or traveling to other parts of the country, I have seen Cambodians dealing with the effects of climate change.  We experienced some of the coolest temperatures that I have felt since my time in Cambodia.  However, a different day or a different part of the country will bring large amounts of dust and dry temperatures.  Along with having an impact on our individual sense of comfort and clothing preferences, these changes have a noticeable effect on Cambodias most important resources.

Last week, I had the opportunity to visit a number of rural areas in Cambodia, where approximately 80 percent of the population lives.  The people I met rely on agriculture, fisheries, and forestry for their livelihoods.  Agriculture, in particular, is one of the pillars to Cambodias economic growth.  However, scientists and economists note the countrys vulnerability to climate change, which can lead to lower agricultural output and greater food insecurity for millions of Cambodians.  Shifts in rainfall and flooding patterns resulting from climate change threaten traditional agricultural production, which accounts for 85 percent of all rice production in the country.

I have also visited the Cardamom Mountains, the largest tropical moist broadleaf forest in Southeast Asia and home to a vast population of plant and animal life.  You can already see the huge impact that climate change is having in the area.  Adding to the damage that has been caused by cutting down too many trees, changes in Cambodias weather have started to create problems for trees in the rainforest.  The continued loss of trees could result in limited food security, dust storms, droughts, record flooding throughout the year, and extreme temperatures that can be especially dangerous.
 
Newly released maps help show that Cambodia continues to suffer major deforestation.  The loss of forest cover magnifies the impact of climate change by altering the water supply and leading to intensified floods and droughts.  It is important to remember that Cambodias precious forests not only provide livelihoods for many Cambodians, but the forests ability to hold carbon helps reduce greenhouse gas emissions for the entire world, further helping to combat global climate change.

Several U.S. government initiatives help Cambodias farmers adapt to challenges caused by changing weather patterns.  Cambodia HARVEST, an integrated food security and climate change program, is helping thousands of farmers increase their income, improve food security, and adapt to the consequences of climate change.  As part of its work with rice farmers, HARVEST introduced flood- and drought-tolerant seed varieties that allow farmers to delay or accelerate planting according to unpredictable weather conditions.  I have visited several HARVEST-supported farms, and it has been gratifying to see how the program helps farmers and their families boost their standard of living by evening out crop production.

In his State of the Union Address this week, President Barack Obama said, And no challenge  no challenge  poses a greater threat to future generations than climate change.  I strongly believe that, working together, the United States and Cambodia can do much to address climate change and its threat to the countrys agricultural productivity and food security.

Today is World Intellectual Property (#IP) Day, a time to celebrate the role that IP protections play in allowing creativity and innovation to thrive in #Cambodia and around the world. In recognition of #WorldIPDay, #AmbHeidt joined Minister of Commerce and Chairman of the National Committee for Intellectual Property Rights (NCIPR) H.E. Pan Sorasak, Cambodian-American pop star Laura Mam Music, and other special guest speakers for a discussion on Digital Creativity: Culture Re-imagined." Several members of Cambodia's business community were in attendance to highlight the importance of protecting IP rights. 

Entrepreneurs, artists, and people with ideas for new products can benefit from learning their rights and taking action. Only two stops left for Fulbright Fellow Pichleap Sok aboard the Millenial Trains Project!  Join Pichleap on day 7, as she arrived in New Orleans, Louisiana and found it to be one of her favorite cities so far.  Continue reading to find out who she met and what amazing American culture she experienced:

"It is beautiful to see how unique culture, accent, identity, people and food each city has. New Orleans, Louisiana is my most favorite city so far, probably because things went pretty smoothly as planned. In the morning, we made a visit to New Orleans Mission, a shelter for the homeless and the needy, to donate 40,000 pounds of chicken sponsored by Tyson Foods.  
After visiting New Orleans Mission, we met with Mayor of New Orleans to talk about the community innovation in New Orleans and how New Orleans was rebuilt after the effect of hurricane Katrina.    
After all, it was a very productive day. I met with and talked to five influential women in technology. Here is why I think storytelling is so powerful in empowering people who want to walk the same path, those people always left me feel so inspired every time after listening to their stories. Therefore, I hope their stories will reach out to other young girls and women out to be as passionate as they are. After the interview, with other millennials and mentors on the train we went to Frenchmen Street to get the true taste of New Orleans. Frenchmen street is one of the best known places for the citys popular live music, bars, coffee shops and night market. I had a great time in New Orleans. I will definitely come back to New Orleans one day before returning to my country."

The USAID-funded ASEAN Youth Volunteer Program (AYVP) held a closing ceremony at the Institute of Technology of Cambodia yesterday to celebrate a month of activities in Cambodia to develop the skills of young eco-leaders.  During the four-week program, 50 young leaders  including 11 from Cambodia  discovered how ASEAN youth can come together to play a role in developing their communities, in particular, by protecting the environment.  As part of their activities, they engaged with communities at the Krakor Floating Village in Pursat Province on projects related to water sanitation and personal hygiene.  During the closing ceremony, the youth were challenged to continue their efforts as members of the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative and serve as positive role models for youth throughout the region.  To see more photos from the closing ceremony, please go to https://www.flickr.com/photos/usaidasia/sets/72157657310766089/with/20938585132/.

The #tuberculosis (TB) mortality rate in #Cambodia has reduced by more than half since 1990. However, it is estimated that as many as 40% of TB cases in Cambodia still go undiagnosed. To achieve the goal to eliminate deaths from TB by the year 2035, the Ministry of Health - Cambodia and the National Center For Tuberculosis and Leprosy Control (CENAT) are working with a number of partners to identify and treat cases throughout the country.

The opening ceremony for the 21st Annual National TB Conference took place today, hosted by CENAT and featuring officials from the Ministry of Health, USAID Cambodia, the World Health Organization (WHO), and others joining the fight to #EndTB in Cambodia and around the world. To learn more about USAID's collaboration with Cambodia's National TB Program, please visit https://www.usaid.gov/cambodia/tuberculosis-and-malaria.

Pictured: Mr. Kea Vutha, Chief of Kor health center collecting possible TB samples in Tbong Khmum.  Photo credit: FHI360

Building off of a successful visit in March 2015, U.S. Science Envoy Dr. Geraldine Richmond recently wrapped up her second trip to #Cambodia last week. Among her many activities included giving a talk entitled Why I Love Being a Scientist, one of the highlights of the 2nd Cambodia Science & Engineering Festival. Talking about her experience at #CSEF2016, Dr. Richmond said, "I was blown away by it and all the incredible students that I met.  It makes me more optimistic than ever about Cambodias future with efforts like the Festival and all the energy and enthusiasm of the students."

Recipient of the National Medal of Science - the highest award for scientific achievement in the United States - Dr. Richmond is the Presidential Chair of Chemistry at the University of Oregon, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and the founder and chair of the Committee on the Advancement of Women Chemists (COACh for Women Scientists and Engineers). Her work in Cambodia and throughout the region is in support of President Obamas initiative to strengthen science and education in Southeast Asia. To learn more about "science diplomacy" at http://www.state.gov/e/oes/stc/stem/index.htm.

* What are your views on the Cambodian economy and Cambodias economic progress?

Ambassador Todd: Many of you already know about the impressive economic growth that Cambodia has achieved over the past decade  you see shops opening, factories being built, and buildings rising higher and higher on Phnom Penhs skyline.

With an average annual growth in the gross domestic product (GDP) of more than eight percent between 2000 and 2010, and a reduction in the number of people living below the poverty line by seven percent in the last five years, Cambodia is a rising star in Asia.

The large labor pool and the Royal Government of Cambodias willingness to allow foreign companies to own 100 percent of their business interests in Cambodia have been important factors in this success...

Would you like to work for the U.S. Embassy?

We are seeking an individual for the position of Veterinary Health Specialist.

For more information, click the link below:
http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/job3.html

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
. Master's Degree in Veterinary Medicine/Animal Health, Tropical Veterinary Science, or Public Health is required

. A minimum of five (5) years in progressively more responsible project/ program management and advisor positions, with experience in the guidance, development,  implementation, and evaluation of projects/programs in animal health and surveillance for avian influenza and veterinary diseases, including laboratory testing, required.

. Level III (Good Working Knowledge) Speaking/Reading/Writing English and Level IV (Fluent) Khmer are required. Language proficiency will be tested.

. Knowledge of avian influenza and other animal pathogens of zoonotic significance and epidemic/ pandemic potential required.

. Demonstrated ability to work across USG and international agencies. Intricate knowledge about Cambodian Veterinary systems, with ability to work as a team member with both RGC animal and human health agencies, and with diplomatic skills to synergistically bridge animal and human health sectors.

On September 29, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) posted a notice regarding #Zika in Southeast Asia. Travelers have returned from certain areas of the region with Zika virus infection. Several countries have reported occasional cases or small outbreaks of Zika virus infections. Though no new cases of Zika have been reported in #Cambodia since 2010, travelers to Southeast Asia are advised to be aware of the latest guidelines. Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung attended a gala celebration this weekend hosted by the Golden West Humanitarian Foundation to celebrate ten years of cooperation with the Kingdom of Cambodia in its efforts to eradicate explosive remnants of war throughout the country.  The relationship between Golden West and the Kingdom of Cambodia is making a significant contribution to the welfare of Cambodias citizens by delivering innovative solutions to organizations that remove mines before accidents occur.  The U.S. State Department is proud to be a financial supporter of Golden Wests work in Cambodia.  The U.S. government is the worlds largest single financial supporter of efforts to clear landmines and unexploded ordinance, with more than $2.1 billion in assistance since 1993.  

DCM Chung highlighted the human cost of unexploded ordinance (UXO), saying that,  Accidents from mines not only leave physical and emotional scars on a Cambodian family  they render land unusable.  If there was a blast in a farmers field, then that plot of land wont produce at the next harvest, and if the blast occurred on a dirt road used by villagers in the dry season to take goods to market, then those people will lose time and money taking a longer route.  

The United States has invested more than $61 million in demining and UXO clearance operations in Cambodia over the past 20 years, including by providing the Royal Government of Cambodia with mine detection technologies and training on the disposal of explosives.  Cambodia is sharing its knowledge in the field joining UN Peacekeeping Operations in Africa and using its demining expertise to assist other countries in need.  
                
 Read the full remarks by DCM Julie Chung from the event here http://goo.gl/0lwhRc 
                

Photos: (From left) Deputy Chief of Mission, Julie Chung during her remarks; underwater UXO search and removal equipment; Julie Chung with Cambodian UXO search & removal team; replica display of a landmine

YSEALI    (WAKE)      Wake   Google, Oracle,  Salesforce    Tech2Empower ()    

Young Cambodian Women in #YSEALI were invited to U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh for a special panel discussion with the U.S. NGO WAKE: Women's Alliance for Knowledge Exchange entitled, The Womens Leadership Breakfast: Personal Branding for Women Leaders.   Members of WAKE  made up of accomplished businesswomen and executives from companies like Google, Oracle, and Salesforce  are in Cambodia for their #Tech2Empower workshop.  They have held workshops this week on leadership with The Harpswell Foundation, Friends-International, and others.  They are also visiting the Development Innovations Cambodia Lab, where the focus will continue to be on utilizing #STEM to solve problems.

  Julie Chung   Rebecca Black  USAID       WAKE  

Joined by Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung - who gave the opening remarks - and Rebecca Black of USAID Cambodia, the women enjoyed light refreshments and engaged in passionate talks, that included hearing from YSEALI members about the challenges and opportunities facing professional women in Cambodia. The event then came to a close with a fun selfie session.  The U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh would like to thank all of the members of WAKE for making this great event a success! 

To learn more about WAKE and their activities in Cambodia, go to http://wakeinternational.org/cambodia/

International Day of the Girl, October 11 Statement by Secretary Kerry

(Photo: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry poses for a photo with a Cambodian woman wearing the traditional sampot before he delivered remarks at the US-ASEAN Business Council 30th Anniversary Event in Washington, D.C October 2, 2014)

As we celebrate International Day of the Girl, I congratulate Malala Yousafzai of Pakistan who has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.  As a recipient of one of the worlds highest honors, Malalas resilience and courage challenge us all to support the struggle against brutality, ignorance, and violence.  She inspires hope in millions of people and embodies our commitment to human rights and education. 

International Day of the Girl reminds us of the need to recommit to investing in the worlds 850 million girls so that they can use their talents to contribute to their communities and countries.  Every year of schooling increases a girls individual earning power by 10 to 20 percent, and the return on secondary education is even higher.  Adolescent girls who attend secondary school will marry later, raise fewer but healthier children, and be less likely to be infected by HIV/AIDS.  Countries with higher levels of female secondary school enrollment have lower infant mortality rates, lower birth rates, lower rates of HIV/AIDS, and better child nutrition.  Each additional year of a mothers secondary schooling reduces the probability of infant mortality by 510 percent, and a child born to a mother who can read is 50 percent more likely to live past age five. 

Unfortunately, we live in a world where girls are often not valued.   Today, 250 million girls live in poverty, one in three girls in the developing world will be married before turning 18, and 62 million girls are out of school--deprived of an education that would lead to positive health and economic outcomes. Worldwide, an estimated 150 million girls have experienced sexual violence, and nearly half of all sexual assaults are committed against girls younger than 16 years of age.  In 2013, nearly 80 percent of all new HIV infections among those ages 15 to 24 affected adolescent girls and young women.  Thus, the consequences of failing to adequately invest in girls are enormous. 

The United States understands that when a girl is kept from achieving her potential it is a loss not only for that individual girl, but also for her family, community, and country.  We know that empowering girls, keeping them free from violence, and providing them with an education is one of the best ways to ensure that societies thrive.  Nowhere is this more true than in Afghanistan where women and girls have persevered despite seemingly insurmountable obstacles, and made incredible gains over the past 13 years to help put their country on the path to peace, prosperity, and security.  

We must involve elders, faith leaders, educators, and influential community figures in this effort. Governments must educate their citizens about the correlation between investing in programs for girls and the benefits to society, and hold accountable those individuals responsible for acts of violence and oppression.  Make no mistake, educated girls, empowered with knowledge, are the best rebuke against the brutal forces of violent extremism.

It is not a coincidence that girls and women are targeted by these groups like ISIL and Boko Haram.  We must stand against those extremists groups that have arbitrarily targeted women and girls and subjected them to sexual violence and forced marriage.  Their plight underscores the challenges we face to ensure girls grow up in a world where every girl lives a life of dignity, free from violence.

By working together as a community of nations, we can build a world in which girls are not treated as property, chattel, or spoils of war, but rather as individuals with their own voice, talents, and freedom to realize their potential and contribute to our collective humanity. This is the message Malala has taught us, and this is the message of progress and justice.

#Cambodia is working to establish a national School Feeding Programme (SFP) that will improve children's health by helping them learn how to grow and prepare nutritious food. In support of this effort, a delegation of Cambodian government officials and representatives from the United Nations, the World Food Programme (WFP), and USAID Cambodia recently visited eight schools in Siem Reap Province that currently implement the SFP.  During the two-day mission, the delegation met local government and school authorities, community members, and families with children benefiting from the program. 

The SFP has reached up to 840,000 beneficiaries in Cambodia each year since 2011 and is working with the government to establish a national school feeding program by 2021. The U.S. government is working with Cambodia to achieve its nutrition goals through initiatives like Feed the Future and USAIDs HARVEST project. The U.S. Department of Agriculture is WFP Cambodias largest donor, contributing more than $44 million since 2003 through the McGovern-Dole International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program. Find out more at https://www.wfp.org/countries/cambodia.

Helping Families Take Care of Their Children
-From the Ambassador's Penh

If you are a regular reader of my blog, you know that children and family are very important to me.  Family is the most basic building block of any society.  Keeping families together and raising healthy children is a priority for me.  Thats why I was so happy to spend some time last week with my friends at the Cambodian Childrens Fund (CCF).  Since I first learned about CCF and saw their work first hand, Ive followed the work they do to help families in Phnom Penh.  Founded in 2004, Cambodian Childrens Fund helps vulnerable children and their families from some of Cambodias most destitute communities.  In the beginning, CCFs work revolved around the health and well-being of many children working at the highly toxic Steung Meanchey landfill in Phnom Penh that is now closed.  Today, CCF cares for more than 2,000 students and has extended its services to help entire families and communities meet their needs for childcare, health care, counseling, and even job training.

As a father, the welfare and happiness of my children is something I think about every day.  Their nutrition, their education, and their place in their community  these are the priorities that led me to make many of the most important decisions of my life.  In Cambodia, too many parents are faced with impossible choices.  Should they send their children to school or have them work so that the family has enough to eat?  Should they pay for the medicine that their kids need or the school books for their education?  Should they buy better seed for their rice paddy or shoes for their children?

Some families are forced to leave their children in institutions, because they feel they are unable to provide them the care they need at home.  These are choices that families should never have to make.  My visit to CCF reminded me that a helping hand is often enough to change this equation.  By helping families provide their children with good education, nutrition, and protection from harm  we can keep families together and help children become healthy, active, and productive citizens.

This was made even clearer to me when I visited the Rice Academy  a school run by CCF and funded by the generous donations of John and Cammie Rice.  The kids I met were enthusiastic, energetic, and eager to learn.  I have a feeling we are going to see great things from these children.

As I mentioned at the start of this blog, keeping Cambodian families together is a priority for me.  In fact, the U.S. government is collaborating with the Cambodian government, NGOs, development partners, and the private sector this week to design a special initiative that will improve the lives of children who are living outside of family care and to prevent avoidable family-child separation.  The Family Care First initiative reflects President Obamas recognition of the importance of families to the well-being and growth of children. 

Family Care First will not only complement the work of CCF, but that of the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veterans, and Youth Rehabilitation as well as our partners like Friends International who recently launched a very creative information campaign called the Keep Families Together, which is aimed at discouraging Cambodian families from placing their children into orphanages, by highlighting how they can access appropriate support to enable them to keep their children with them.

Whether its an organization like CCF or individuals like John and Cammie Rice  we all have a role to play in helping todays Cambodian children become tomorrows leaders.  Keeping families together is a great way of doing that.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia Cambodian Children's Fund

Congrats to Kimsy Tor, the valedictorian of Manhattan Colleges class of 2015!  Kimsy graduated as the top student in the class, earning a bachelors degree in mathematics and a minor in computer science. Kimsy, who plans to pursue her doctorate in mathematics and return to teach in Cambodia, said: It is my great honor to be chosen to be a valedictorianit took a great amount of hard work from the whole Manhattan College community to get me here and I want to take this opportunity to thank them for everything they have done. Going Green: To do your part in making our Earth green and making water resources last, you should reduce the amount of water you use daily:

. Turn off faucet while brushing your teeth, washing your face or shaving.
. Use lowflow shower head or adjust the water flow so as to not waste water while showering.
. Use the correct amount of laundry detergent and water while washing your clothes. Putting too much powder demands more water to wash it. 
. Set your washing machine to the corresponding load size...

     USAID       

                      

  worldhumanitarianday.org 

#WorldHumanitarianDay was celebrated last week  when aid-worker heroes  who help and advocate for millions of people affected by crises around the world are honored.  Two active humanitarian forces in Cambodia today are #USAID and the U.S. Navy #Seabees.

In 24 years of operation USAID Cambodia has provided over $1 billion in assistance to the Cambodian people, much of it in humanitarian and rehabilitation assistance to meet the basic needs of Cambodians.

Since 2008, the Seabees have constructed water wells, clinics, and other modern facilities throughout Cambodia. They also provide basic life support (BLS) training on proper sanitation and hygiene, snake bites, and basic stitching methods. Over the next three years the Seabees will construct new facilities throughout six provinces, serving more than 77,000 people in over 90 villages.

To learn more about helping others go to worldhumanitarianday.org

In his weekly column released Sunday, Ambassador Todd addressed President Obama's recent trip to Asia, human rights, and the creation of 500 new fellowships to the United States under the YSEALI program.

"The strength of our relationship with Asia is, and always will be, our people-to-people connections.  For me, the highlight of President Obamas trip was his address at a town hall event in Burma on Friday, where he announced the creation of 500 short-term academic and professional exchanges to the United States through the Young Southeast Asian Leadership Initiative (YSEALI).  Two Cambodian YSEALI members  Hazan Illyasak and Huot Sok Im  were selected to travel to Burma to attend a workshop and to participate in this town hall.

I encourage all Cambodians between the ages of 18 and 35 to follow in the footsteps of Illyasak and Huot Sok and to become YSEALI members, where you can network with young leaders from the region, share experiences, and engage with experts from the United States.  You can find out more about President Obamas new YSEALI Fellows program at https://youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov/."

Access the full column here: http://goo.gl/9ovU5r

English skills get a boost as a successful U.S. Embassy program begins its third year

The Lower Mekong Initiative (LMI) Professional Communication Skills for Leaders (PCSL) program provides intensive English-language seminars for Cambodian government officials  helping them participate in regional forums and workshops where English is the common language.  The seminars are taught jointly by a teacher from the United States and two teachers from Cambodia.  The PCSL program focuses on the six pillars of LMI:  education, connectivity, health, agriculture, energy, and environment. 

The program just completed the first seminar of the third year.  A report about the seminar can be viewed at  https://www.facebook.com/LMIUSELFCAMBODIA/posts/716245198456588

On October 2, 17 members of the U.S. Embassys Ambassadors Youth Council (AYC) met for the first time with Ambassador William A. Heidt.

The Ambassadors Youth Council was established in 2012 to cultivate young Cambodian leaders, engage Cambodian youth on topics of interest, and generate feedback on U.S. Embassy programs in Cambodia.

Ambassadors Youth Council members meet regularly with the Ambassador, participate in a wide variety of U.S. Embassy programs, and develop and implement their own initiatives.

To date, 43 young Cambodians have served as members of the Council.

For more information about the Ambassadors Youth Council follow them on Facebook at  https://www.facebook.com/theUSAYC.

Exchange Program Spotlight:  Global UGRAD

Education can be your gateway to adventure!  Through the Global Undergraduate Exchange Program (Global UGRAD) outstanding undergraduate students receive semester and year-long scholarships to enroll in full-time non-degree study at a U.S. university.  Courses taken during the program are combined with community service, internships, and cultural enrichment opportunities.  The announcement for 2015 program applicants will be coming soon.  

This year, Uk Sovannara attended Florida Gulf Coast University on the Global UGRAD program.  Of his experience he said:

My life journey in the U.S left a glorious, indelible mark. It was an adventure of a lifetime which provided me unique and priceless experiences.  Over the course of some 4 months, Ive gained tremendous experience through deep and meaningful engagement with socially good and cultural activities both on and off campus. I attended an engineering club, conferences, workshops, and educational excursions offered by my university.  In addition, this program allowed me to explore the land. Ive been to many places, participated in multiple different fun activities, and met hundreds of people from different corners of the world, some of whom have become my closest friends. The impact of UGRAD on my life is profound, shaping my perspective on the world and how I behave in the society. Although I have completed the program, I still can reap the ongoing benefits from it by keeping in touch with the local U.S Embassy and the Fulbright and Undergraduate State Alumni Association of Cambodia (FUSAAC). I am also encouraged to share my experience and apply lessons I have learned from my U.S exchange program with young, enthusiastic Cambodian students across the country. Global UGRAD is an agent of change for the better. 

Global UGRAD is sponsored by the U.S. Department of State.  To receive more information or to apply, visit the U.S. Embassy webpage here http://goo.gl/ZKyE2O

#CamWomenCan Build Greatness
"I wanted to be an architect because architecture is rich with constructive ideas for serving people. An architect is a person who understands political, economic, historic, artistic, geographic, and philosophical concerns." - Cheam Phally

Meet Cheam Phally, Senior Architect and Coordinator for the World Monuments Fund in #Cambodia and a trailblazer in the field of cultural heritage preservation. Phally manages a number of major architectural conservation projects at the Angkor Archaeological Park, including the ongoing restoration of the ancient Phnom Bakheng temple, which has been supported by the U.S. Embassy and the U.S. Department of State since 2003. The work that Phally and her team are carrying out will preserve Cambodia's extraordinary cultural heritage for future generations. Find out more about Phally's life and work by watching this video: https://www.wmf.org/video/architect.   

Like us, Phally believes every woman is capable of building great things. Why? As Phally says, "Women can do everything because they don't just have 2 arms...they have 8 like Vishnu!"
