Streams of Hope is a river rehabilitation project designed by members of the Young South East Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI).  Members from Cambodia, the Philippines, and Vietnam joined together to form a three-country YSEALI team focused on maintaining clean water resources in the region.

Dr. Eric Pallant, Chair of the Environmental Science Department at Allegheny College in Pennsylvania, USA, will be travelling to the region in support of this project.  As part of the U.S. Department of States Speaker Program, Dr. Pallant will meet with high school and university students, members of civil society, government officials, and others who have a stake in maintaining clean water resources.  

Watch this space for updates on Dr. Pallants trip as he spends time in Phnom Penh with YSEALI members to raise awareness about the importance of protecting Cambodias water resources and preserving the health and biodiversity of Cambodias waterways.

You can also follow Dr. Pallants trip via Twitter with #StreamsOfHope.

To join YSEALI and partner on projects like this, visit: http://goo.gl/c2ORS0

Twenty-three members of the U.S. Naval Construction Force, also known as Seabees, are in Sihanoukville building new bathrooms for the Hun Sen Head Facility Primary School, improving sanitation for the children at the school.

The team, based in California, are the fifth consecutive team of Seabees to work in Cambodia.

Learn more about the Seabees at http://www.seabee.navy.mil/

The Fulbright Program's U.S.-ASEAN Visiting Scholar Initiative
Application Deadline: October 31, 2016

Hi! My name is Phauk Sophany, a faculty member at the Royal University of Phnom Penh. I am an alumnus of the #Fulbright U.S.-ASEAN Visiting Scholars Initiative in 2015. It was a great opportunity for me to have hands-on experience doing scientific research in entomology with experts at the Illinois Natural History Survey. Besides brilliant support from the program, I had a chance to travel in the United States and learned a lot about U.S. culture and good governance. The program does not only provide knowledge and experience; it also improved my professional development as an entomology scientist in #Cambodia. So what are you waiting for? Apply for the Fulbright U.S.-ASEAN Visiting Scholar Initiative!

The Fulbright U.S.ASEAN Visiting Scholar Initiative is open to university faculty, government officials, and professional staff of think tanks and other NGOs throughout ASEAN to travel to the United States for scholarly and professional research on issues that are relevant and useful to the region and the U.SASEAN relationship. To find out more and to apply, please visit kh.usembassy.gov/fulbright-u-s-asean-visiting-scholar-initiative/.

Please help us welcome new Public Affairs Officer Jay Raman to the U.S. Embassy family!

Last week, Ambassador Todd hosted a cocktail reception at his official residence to welcome Jay to Phnom Penh.  As the Public Affairs Officer, or PAO, Jay is responsible for all of the Embassys press, cultural, English language, and academic exchange programs.  He is also the Embassy spokesman.

Jays most recent assignment overseas was in Quito, Ecuador.  He has also served in Guatemala, Estonia, and the Dominican Republic.  He spent the last year in Washington, DC studying Khmer.

Jay is a graduate of Harvard Law School and his home town is Oak Ridge, Tennessee.  Before joining the State Department he practiced law in Washington, DC.  

The reception was a chance for Jay to mingle and meet with representatives from the media, universities, and cultural institutions.  The Ambassador was a gracious host, and after the speeches everyone enjoyed some nice appetizers, drinks and conversation.

Welcome to Phnom Penh, Jay!

Follow Jay on Twitter at @ramanjr.

On Saturday, October 11, Charg d'affaires a.i. Julie Chung assisted in the grand opening of the Hard Rock Caf Angkor in Siem Reap, Cambodia.  The Hard Rock Caf is a U.S. chain of theme restaurants that use memorabilia of American rock and roll music to decorate their restaurants.  In her comments, Ms. Chung noted how the restaurants theme was a good fit for Cambodia:

The Hard Rock Caf showcases American rock music including legends like Elvis, the Beach Boys, and Nirvana. It also reminds us of a time in Cambodias history when the music of Sin Sisamuth, Ros Sereysothea, Pen Ron, and Sos Math made a clear imprint on a unique music scene full of energy and optimism.

Cambodia is the 56th country to have a Hard Rock Caf. 

Photo:  No ribbon cutting here!  Charg dAffaires a.i. Julie Chung and Cambodian Minister of Tourism H.E. Dr. Thong Khon had the very cool honor of smashing a guitar to signify the opening of the new location.  (Photo: Jose Collazo)

Yesterday, Charg dAffaires Julie Chung met with children, families, and staff at Khyang Primary School in Kampong Chhnang Province.  The school is a beneficiary of the U.S. Department of Agricultures (USDA) International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program, implemented by International Relief and Development (IRD).  Through this program, children receive nutritious meals at school and to take home, lessons about health and nutrition, and activities that promote literacy and community awareness.  The project has benefited more than 90,000 people in Kampong Chhnang Province.  To learn more, click here: http://goo.gl/2KHwBE

U.S. Department of Agriculture International Relief and Development #Cambodia

Important Notice:

Same-sex spouses of U.S. citizens and Lawful Permanent Residents (LPRs), along with their minor children, are now eligible for the same immigration benefits as opposite-sex spouses.

Consular officers at U.S. embassies and consulates will adjudicate their immigrant visa applications upon receipt of an approved I-130 or I-140 petition from USCIS.

Diversity Visa applicants may include same-sex spouses in their initial entries or add spouses acquired after their initial registration.

Those spouses who will follow-to-join DV 2013 applicants must make application on or before September 30, 2013.

Spouses of DV 2014 applicants, even those not included in the initial entry, must apply before September 30, 2014.

For further information, click the link below:
http://travel.state.gov/visa/frvi/frvi_6036.html

Yesterday, a group of more than 100 young Cambodians from different universities across Phnom Penh city gathered together to organize the first #Wildlifeday celebration under the theme Youth Participation in Wildlife Conservation in Cambodia. The ceremony co-organized by Winrock International in partnership with Enrich Institute and Global Shapers Community helps participants increase understanding of wildlife conservation and encourage them to take actions combat wildlife poaching and trading in Cambodia. The ceremony also included photo exhibition of importance wildlife and its habitat, threats and solution, quiz about wildlife, and writing postcards to be sent to government officials and community rangers.

#Cambodia USAID - US Agency for International Development Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs Winrock International

"One Woman"

In Kigali, she wakes up,
She makes a choice,
In Hanoi, Natal, Ramallah.
In Tangier, she takes a breath,
Lifts up her voice,
In Lahore, La Paz, Kampala.
Though shes half a world away
Something in me wants to say 

We are One Woman,
You cry and I hear you.
We are One Woman,
You hurt, and I hurt, too.
We are One Woman,
Your hopes are mine.
We shall shine.

In Juarez she speaks the truth,
She reaches out,
Then teaches others how to.
In Jaipur, she gives her name,
She lives without shame
In Manila, Salta, Embu.
Though were different as can be,
Were connected, she with me

We are One Woman,
Your courage keeps me strong.
We are One Woman,
You sing, I sing along.
We are One Woman,
Your dreams are mine.
And we shall shine.
We shall shine.

And one man, he hears her voice.
And one man, he fights her fight.
Day by day, he lets go the old ways,
One Woman at a time.
Though shes half a world away,
Something in me wants to say.

We are One Woman,
Your victories lift us all.
We are One Woman,
You rise and I stand tall.
We are One Woman,
Your world is mine
And we shall shine.
Shine, shine, shine.
We shall shine
Shine, shine, shine.
We shall shine.
Shine, shine, shine.

#ThrowbackThursday - Longtime Embassy employees Gnean Maly (left) and Lay Thenghong (right) with #AmbHeidt today and during his previous assignment to #Cambodia in 1999. Maly and Thenghong served as Embassy guards during the Ambassadors earlier assignment to Phnom Penh, when he was the Embassys economic officer. All three have come a long way since then!  Maly has risen to the rank of Shift Commander, supervising many other guards. Thenghong is one of the Embassys three telephone operators, answering calls in both Khmer and English. The Embassy is very proud of its nearly 700 loyal and hardworking Cambodian employees, a number of whom have been with us since the Embassy reopened in 1995! #tbt

Forty-five special, young leaders in Kompong Thom and Banteay Meanchey provinces had reason to celebrate this weekend when they graduated from the U.S. Embassys English Access Microscholarship Program. The students received their certificates in ceremonies attended by local officials and representatives from the U.S. Embassy Public Affairs Section.

           

The Access Program provides two years of English-language instruction to academically talented students in underserved communities across Cambodia. These students spent countless hours before and after school and on weekends learning and practicing English, but the hard work paid off!

           !

The U.S. Embassy has provided the English Access Microscholarship Program in Cambodia for more than 11 years. Cambodian Access Program alumni have utilized their English language skills to attend college, to join the Ambassadors Youth Council, and even to receive scholarships to study in the United States.  We cant wait to see what these students will do with their language skills!

The United States Air Force Band String Quartet held a special concert last night for His Majesty King Norodom Sihamoni, Her Majesty Queen Mother Norodom Monineath Sihanouk, and other invited guests to commemorate a performance that took place on May 9, 1956 in Phnom Penh at the invitation of the late King Norodom Suramarit and Queen Sisowath Monivong Kossomak Nearireath Serei Watana. Joined by two Cambodian artists, The United States Air Force Band String Quartet played a mix of American, European, and Cambodian music, including two pieces by King Sihanouk that premiered in 1956. The musicians concluded the 60th Anniversary Concert with a special birthday message for HM King Norodom Sihamoni and a heart-warming encore performance of "Monika" in honor of HM Queen Mother Norodom Monineath Sihanouk.

For more photos from this historic event, please visit the Embassy's Flickr: https://www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/albums/72157667471323780.

On Monday, Ambassador Heidt met with Aun Porn Moniroth, Minister of Economy and Finance. The Ambassador and the Minister both recalled working together in the late 1990s. Their discussion also focused on U.S.-Cambodia bilateral ties and the positive developments taking place in Cambodias educational and health sectors. 

 #AmbHeidt #Cambodia

#AmbHeidt recently visited the Phnom Penh Special Economic Zone () (SEZ)  Cambodias most advanced industrial park  to survey a number of U.S. companies operating there. The Ambassador was welcomed by Chairwoman Madam Lok Chumteav Okhna Lim Chhiv Ho and escorted by members of the Phnom Penh SEZ management team. "It's a very impressive facility," noted Ambassador Heidt. "These companies are all in different sectors, all bringing a high level of technology and employee benefits to Cambodia. They all have reported very positive experiencesfinding Cambodian employees very hard working and efficient. That to me is a very positive message."

Laurelton Diamonds, Aprati Foods and Coca-Cola are some of the U.S. companies that have set up operations in the Phnom Penh SEZ. To learn more about the Phnom Penh SEZ, please visit www.ppsez.com.

"In todays complex world, governments and businesses alone cannot deliver social and economic progress that reaches all people.

Such a goal also requires an effective civil society playing a fundamental role in ensuring that all citizens have the opportunity to help shape, and share the benefits of, a countrys development.

In my own country, civil society organizations (CSOs) play a vital role in helping to combat disease, protect environmental treasures, and build confidence in the economy.

Here in Cambodia there are more than 3,000 CSOs working to address the challenges facing society..."

Read more on the Ambassador Todd's blog: http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/2014/05/07/pung-kek-working-to-give-all-cambodians-a-voice/

U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh Statement on the Conviction of 11 CNRP Activists
 
 CNRP 

July 25, 2015

The United States is closely monitoring the case of the 11 CNRP activists convicted of insurrection arising out of July 2014 protests in Phnom Penh.  Peaceful protest and freedom of expression are fundamental aspects of democracy.
    
The group, which includes U.S. citizen Meach Sovannara, was summarily convicted and received sentences that many feel are inappropriate.  The Department of State takes its assistance abroad to U.S. citizens very seriously.  A consular officer visited with Mr. Sovannara on Friday, July 24.  We will continue to provide all possible consular assistance.

The United States is deeply concerned by the process leading to these convictions.  We urge the Cambodian government to carefully review its judicial processes to ensure that they are complete and transparent and in accordance with domestic law and international norms.
(http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/072515_pr.html)

Truth Telling Ceremony Helps Khmer Rouge Survivors Deal with the Scars of the Past

USAID's Truth, Reconciliation and Healing project organized a truth telling ceremony at Chum Kreal Pagoda in Kampot.  Short versions of Khmer Rouge survivors' life stories were read aloud in the pagoda in front of Buddhist monks, a traditional coping mechanism in Cambodia's spirit-based culture.

Read more about how USAID's partner -  TPO Cambodia - helps Khmer Rouge survivors deal with the scars of the past, here https://www.facebook.com/tpocambodia/posts/770522999672119

Have you heard of the sport ultimate frisbee?  Heres a story of how this sport encouraged regular exercise and inspired self-confidence in youth, especially women, in one Cambodian community.

Vicki Chan is a Peace Corps Cambodia Volunteer serving in Kampong Cham province.  She noticed that women in her community rarely participate in sports, so she decided to introduce them to her athletic passion  ultimate frisbee.  The Ultimate Frisbee Club that Vicki started now includes more than ten young Cambodian women who play and practice every day in an grassy area in front of the Kampong Cham Provincial Hall.  

Before they joined the club, none of the young women had ever played any sports before.  Their training and dedication earned them an invitation to join an all-Cambodian team to compete in the Mekong Cup, an international ultimate frisbee tournament held in Phnom Penh this month.  The Cambodian team won the Spirit of the Game award.

Ambassador Heidt and the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh congratulate Deputy Chair of the National Committee to Combat Trafficking (NCCT) Chou Bun Eng on #Cambodias upgrade to Tier 2 in the 2016 U.S. Department of State's Trafficking in Persons Report. Cambodias improved ranking this year reflects the strong leadership shown by the NCCT and acknowledges the governments significant efforts to bring itself into compliance with the minimum standards set out in the Trafficking Victims Protection Act  a U.S. law originally passed in 2000. The Trafficking in Persons Report assesses a governments efforts to prevent Trafficking in Persons, to protect victims, and to prosecute criminals.  It also offers recommendations for how countries can improve in each of these areas.

During remarks at a ceremony to launch the report, Secretary of State John Kerry singled out the story of a Cambodian named Lang Long, who was rescued after being forced into slavery on a fishing vessel. Lang Long represents the 20 million people around the world who continue to be victims of Trafficking in Persons.

For more about the Trafficking in Persons Report, visit http://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/. To read the 2016 Country Report for Cambodia (a Khmer translation will be posted soon to the U.S. Embassy website), go to http://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2016/258738.htm. To read the Secretarys remarks, see http://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2016/06/259227.htm.

A Life Worth Living 
-From the Ambassador's Penh

On December 10, the world lost a powerful voice for human rights in Cambodia with the sudden and unexpected death of Chan Soveth, who was a senior investigator for the human rights NGO ADHOC.  As many Cambodians already know, Soveth died of a heart attack after returning home from a Human Rights Day event.  He is survived by his wife and three children.

Although he died much too soon, at age 51, Soveth leaves behind a legacy that should make his family and nation proud.  Soveths primary work was to compile investigation reports on suspected human rights violations, with a focus on land disputes.  He helped to shed light cases that might otherwise have gone unnoticed by the human rights community.  Soveth didnt just bring attention to problems  he looked for solutions.  For instance, he took the lead in establishing a dialogue with the Cambodian Human Rights Committee, which led to a new found cooperation between the government and NGOs on the investigation of human rights violation cases.  

Like many of his generation, Soveth was orphaned during the Khmer Rouge regime and lived for a time as a refugee.  He was able to overcome adversity, to develop knowledge and expertise, and ultimately to find his lifes work as a human rights investigator.  Soveth worked tirelessly  day or night, weekday or weekend.  Soveth worked in some of the most remote parts of the country, and he never backed down in the face of threats and intimidation.  He always put the needs of the Cambodian people ahead of his own personal safety and comfort.  

To me, Soveths story demonstrates that one person really can bring about positive change through hard work, dedication, and persistence.  It also shows that you dont have to be famous to make a difference.  Soveth may have worked behind the scenes for most of his career, but his work has had a positive impact on many thousands of Cambodians.  Although he is no longer with us, my hope is that Soveths life will serve as an inspiration to present and future human rights defenders, both in Cambodia and throughout the world.  He has certainly been a great inspiration to me.  He will be missed.

#AmbTodd

International Education Week: 5 Steps to Studying in the United States

Step 5: Prepare for your departure

Get ready for the journey of a lifetime!  Studying in the United States is a memorable and rewarding experiencecongratulations on taking this exciting step towards your future.

As a student planning your move to the United States, you may wish to seek assistance from the local EducationUSA Cambodia Advising Center in Phnom Penh. The advisor at the center can put you in contact with the programs sponsor in the United States, and enroll you in one of the pre-departure orientations offered at the EducationUSA Advising Center.

At the orientations, EducationUSA Adviser and students who have returned from the United States provide information and resources that will help prepare you for new experiences and skills to adjust to new challenges. Topics discussed include cultural differences, motivation, changes from your home environment, academic systems and expectations, housing, and coping in a new cultural setting.

**This concludes our series 5 Steps to Studying in the United States. We hope this has been helpful to you. Dont ever give up on your quest for a better education. Scroll down to see our previous posts or visit the EducationUSA website to review all of the steps here http://goo.gl/9Li8Dj.

U.S. State Department Spokesperson on Sam Rainsy Arrest Warrant

U.S. Department of State
Office of the Spokesperson

EXCERPT FROM DAILY PRESS BRIEFING
Friday, November 13, 2015; 2:06 p.m. EST
Briefer: Mark Toner, Deputy Spokesperson

QUESTION: Cambodia  there was an arrest order for an opposition leader.

MR TONER: Right, yes.

QUESTION: Sam Rainsy.

MR TONER: Sam Rainsy, thank you.

QUESTION: Exactly...I was wondering if you had a response, either in praise or in condemnation of this.

MR TONER: Were  the United States is deeply concerned about the deteriorating political climate in Cambodia in recent weeks. That includes assaults against two opposition lawmakers, and now, as you noted, the arrest of  a warrant against opposition leader Sam Rainsy. The timing of these charges gives the appearance of undue political influence in the judicial process. More broadly, the pattern of actions against the opposition suggests a return to the harsh political practices and tactics of the  that the Cambodian people have made clear they no longer want. So were obviously monitoring the situation closely and calling on the Cambodian authorities to drop the charges against Sam Rainsy.

Message to U.S. Citizens

The Department of State is updating the Worldwide Caution to provide information on the continuing threat of terrorist actions and violence against U.S. citizens and interests throughout the world. U.S. citizens are reminded to maintain a high level of vigilance and to take appropriate steps to increase their security awareness. This replaces the Worldwide Caution dated April 10, 2014.

The Department of State remains concerned about the continued threat of terrorist attacks, demonstrations, and other violent actions against U.S. citizens and interests overseas. On September 22, 2014, the United States and regional partners commenced military action against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), a designated  terrorist organization in Syria and Iraq. In response to the airstrikes, ISIL called on supporters to attack foreigners wherever they are. Authorities believe there is an increased likelihood of reprisal attacks against U.S., Western and coalition partner interests throughout the world, especially in the Middle East, North Africa, Europe, and Asia.

Please read the entire message here:  http://travel.state.gov/content/passports/english/alertswarnings/worldwide-caution.html

SIGN UP FOR THIS NEW ONLINE U.S. UNIVERSITY COURSE ON DEMOCRATIC DEVELOPMENT:

The U.S. Embassy invites you to take advantage of an opportunity to participate in an online U.S. university course on Democratic Development.

This course was launched in April of 2013 by Stanford University and is being taught by Larry Diamond, a leading scholar of democratization.

The course will provide world-class instruction in how democratic institutions and governance are established, maintained, and
strengthened.

THE COURSE HAS ALREADY BEGUN, BUT IT IS NOT TOO LATE TO ENROLL.

Registration and additional information are available online at https://www.coursera.org/course/democraticdev.

The course also provides a chance for individuals who share a commitment to democratic values to connect with each other around the world.

This course is primarily intended for individuals in college or beyond, with some academic background or preparation in political science or the social sciences and a proficiency in English.  

However, it seeks to be accessible to a diverse international audience, including educators at the secondary and college levels, government officials, development professionals, civil society leaders, journalists, bloggers, activists, and individuals involved in a wide range of activities and professions related to the development and deepening of democracy.

The time commitment for the course is approximately 1 to 2 hours per week for a total of 10 weeks.

For those who sign up and take the course, we will be hosting some discussion sessions here at the Embassy and we will hold a graduation ceremony for those who complete the course.

If you would like to receive information about these events, please let us know if you sign up for the course by sending an email to IRCPhnomPenh@state.gov.

BREAKING NEWS: U.S. Department of State Announces First-Ever 
NBA-WNBA Sports Envoy Program to #Cambodia!
 !

The U.S. Department of State, in collaboration with the National Basketball Association (#NBA) and Womens National Basketball Association (#WNBA), will send Wayne Ellington and Sue Wicks as Sports Envoys to Phnom Penh, Cambodia, July 1217. The Sports Envoys will develop skills and generate even more interest in Cambodia for one of the world's most popular sports.  Cambodian youth will not only learn and improve basketball skills; the Sports Envoys will also focus on teamwork, effective communication, building self-esteem, and other lessons learned through playing basketball.

The U.S. Embassy is working together with MoEYS Cambodia, the National Olympic Committee Of Cambodia, the Cambodia Basketball Federation, and the Fulbright and Undergraduate State Alumni Association of Cambodia (FUSAAC) to host the Sports Envoys and organize a wide range of activities throughout the week.  Among these are two signature events that are free and open to the public:

 July 14, 9:00 am  A basketball court renovation project at Wat Koh High School in Phnom Penh, open to volunteers from the local community.
 July 15, 5:00 pm  Special event at the National Olympic Stadium in Phnom Penh, with basketball games, musical performances, and more.

Sports Envoys are athletes and coaches who travel overseas to lead programs developed by U.S. embassies and consulates. The Sports Envoys hold clinics for young people and coaches, participate in community outreach activities, and engage youth in a dialogue on the importance of leadership and respect for diversity. SportsUnited - U.S. Department of State manages the Sports Envoy programs, working in cooperation with the U.S. Olympic Committee, U.S. sports federations, and professional leagues. Stay tuned for more information about the NBA-WNBA Sports Envoy Program in Cambodia!

   Wayne Ellington  Sue Wicks                     

       Fulbright

Ambassador Todd discusses the importance of transparency in his most recent column in The Cambodian Herald.  

The decisions made in the ongoing deliberations will impact the lives of all Cambodians, so the public has a compelling interest in observing and understanding the decision-making process.  A process that takes place behind closed doors  particularly if accompanied by threats of arrest  without public access or oversight leads to rumors, uncertainty, and misinformation, all of which jeopardize the progress that has been made and the prospect for key reforms.

Read the entire column, Moving Forward with Openness, Transparency, and Inclusivity, here: http://goo.gl/rvltGN

Cambodian engineers are part of a special team from Golden West Humanitarian Foundation (GWHF) that created the Advanced Ordnance Training Materials (AOTM) Program, which has been named as an Innovation Awards Honoree at the prestigious International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas - better known as CES 2016. Selected in the "Tech For A Better World" category, AOTM products are manufactured in Phnom Penh in GWHF's Design Lab, Cambodias largest 3D-printing facility. 

With startup funding from the U.S. Department of State, the AOTM program improves the quality of materials available to humanitarian mine clearance and unexploded ordnance disposal personnel in Cambodia and around the world. "Winning this major international award is an honor we share with the people of Cambodia and recognizes the global impact Cambodian-created products can have," noted Allen Tan, Director of Applied Technology at GWHF.

Update on Status of Intercountry Adoptions between the United States and Cambodia:

The United States has determined that it will not be able to process intercountry adoptions in Cambodia at this time, under the Hague Convention on Protection of Children and Co-Operation in Respect of Intercountry Adoption (the Convention).

Despite Cambodias initiatives to strengthen its child welfare system and improve the integrity of its domestic and intercountry adoption processes, it does not yet have a fully functional Convention process in place...
Read more: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/intl_adoption2.html

Until They Are Home. Today is National POW/MIA Recognition Day for the United States.

The U.S. Embassys POW/MIA specialist, Peter Loverde, and two Cambodian villagers departed for an investigation to Tang Island in Sihanoukville Province on September 4, 2013, to search for the remains of Americans from the Vietnam Conflict. Fifty-three Americans are unaccounted-for in Cambodia from that period. The people of Cambodia and the Royal Government continue to be great partners in our efforts to recover the remains of our missing Americans.

How many slaves work for you?

Take the survey: http://slaveryfootprint.org/

Two months ago, the Fairtrade Fund launched Slavery Footprint, a web- and mobile-based application that allows users to understand how their lives intersect with modern slavery.

The app works by asking users to complete a quick survey about where they live and what they buy and eat.

That information is processed in an algorithm that analyzes the 400 most common consumer items and determines the likelihood that those items were tainted by modern slavery somewhere along the supply chain.

More: http://blogs.state.gov/index.php/site/entry/one_million_footprints_on_the_path_to_freedom

"This past January, I saw firsthand the challenge Cambodia faces in dealing with landmines and unexploded ordnance (UXO)... In Oddar Meanchey Province, a village chief expressed to me his deep appreciation for the U.S. efforts to help clear the area of mines. He noted that in the six years since the village was declared mine-free, the village population had risen sharply and the amount of farmland cleared for cultivation had also increased... The task, however, is far from over. I hope that our combined efforts to rid Cambodia of landmines and UXO continue to brighten futures, so that Cambodian villagers may live without fear of harm in their communities."  - Charg daffaires Julie Chung

To read the full version of Charg daffaires Julie Chung's DIPNOTE blog entry, "In Cambodia, Clearing Landmines Brightens Futures", go to https://blogs.state.gov/stories/2015/08/18/cambodia-clearing-landmines-brightens-futures

Happy #InternationalChildrensDay! This is a very special day in #Cambodia given the country's young and vibrant population. "Tompaing snorng russey" () or "bamboo shoot is the future bamboo" is a well-known Khmer proverb which reminds us all that children are the future of Cambodia and the rest of the world. That's why the U.S. Embassy partners with the Cambodian government, civil society organizations, and local communities to help make a difference in the lives of hundreds of thousands of children across the country. By making substantial investments in the countrys children, the "future bamboo" will be much stronger.

Ambassador Todd:  "Each year thousands of U.S. citizens adopt children from abroad, and many families in other countries adopt U.S. children.  We have seen the great benefit that intercountry adoption can bring to children in need.  The loving bonds that make a family strong transcend race, nationality, culture, and religion.  This conviction forms the foundation of our cooperation with Cambodia on adoption issues and our shared commitment to a transparent and ethical process for intercountry adoption.  The United States will continue to work closely with the Cambodian government to ensure that the well-being of Cambodian children remains a top priority and that, when intercountry adoptions do resume, everyone can be confident that the welfare of the children continues to come first."

#WorldTBDay
FACT #1: The rate of tuberculosis (TB) prevalence in #Cambodia was cut in half between 2002-2011.
FACT #2: Cambodia reached its Millennium Development Goal (MDG) target of 50% reduction of TB mortality prior to 2015.
FACT #3: There is still much work to be done to #EndTB in Cambodia.

Through USAID Cambodia, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention(CDC) and the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the United States works with Cambodia's national TB program to increase case detection and ensure high quality TB diagnosis and care services. To learn more about what the United States is doing to #EndTB in Cambodia and achieve a #TBFreeWorld, please visit https://goo.gl/HKxWF7.

Erland Herfindahl         (GSP)   Herfindahl   (GMAC)  Pactics Factory   Suntex Factory   GSP  

 GSP   Julie Chung        go.usa.gov/xgbYT 

Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) Deputy Assistant Erland Herfindahl had a successful visit to #Cambodia from July 25-28 to promote the expansion of the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) program. Along with a representative from the U.S. Department of Labor, Mr. Herfindahl met with the Minister of Commerce, GMAC - Garment Manufacturers Association in Cambodia, and toured the Pactics Factory in Siem Reap as well as the Suntex Factory in Phnom Penh. The inclusion of Cambodian-made travel goods in the GSP will help diversify the economic base and alleviate poverty in Cambodia.

The benefits of GSP depend on a commitment to internationally-recognized workers' rights. As U.S. Embassy Charge d'Affaires Julie Chung noted, "Higher labor standards attract higher-quality, more stable investment, and we hope to see Cambodia continue down this path." To see her full remarks, please visit go.usa.gov/xgbYT.

First Lady Michelle Obama talks about her experience meeting a Cambodian student.  (English below)

   Fortune      

    

 

         --  "      "

At the Fortunes 50 Most Powerful Women Summit last week in Washington, First Lady Michelle Obama told the story of a very special Cambodian girl who is trying to overcome hardships to pursue her dream of becoming a math teacher.  Mrs. Obama met this Cambodian student on her historic visit to Cambodia in March.

In her speech, the First Lady said:

She stood up in front of me, the First Lady of Cambodia, and dozens of international reporters and camera crews, and let me tell you, she spoke so eloquently about her life.  She was poised and confident.  And this is what she told us.  She said -- and these are her words -- she said, I have been through a lot of hardships.  I know that I need to overcome them.  She said, Ive never thought that they are the barrier to stop me.  Ive never thought of giving up, she said.  I never lose hope in myself.

Watch the video of Mrs. Obamas remarks at:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-dNrObuUlgo&t=941, or read the transcript of the speech at: https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/10/13/remarks-first-lady-fortunes-50-most-powerful-women-summit

SECURITY MESSAGE FOR U.S. CITIZENS: #KemLey Funeral Procession
July 24, 2016

The U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh notifies U.S. citizens residing in or traveling to #Cambodia of the planned funeral procession for Kem Ley in Phnom Penh on Sunday, July 24, 2016. The funeral procession is scheduled to depart from the Wat Chas pagoda near the Sokha Hotel at 7:00 A.M. The procession is reportedly planned to proceed across the Japanese Bridge to Monivong Boulevard and Russian Boulevard until it reaches the Chom Chao roundabout near the Phnom Penh International Airport. The procession will then continue on National Road 3 to Takeo Province. News reports indicate participants could number in the tens of thousands and the procession is likely to take several hours.

For more details, please visit go.usa.gov/xr3xA.

Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi led a bipartisan delegation from the U.S. House of Representatives on a three-day visit to Cambodia from March 28-30 to focus on a number of critical issues including security cooperation, human rights, and trade.  The visit to Cambodia is the first stop in a five-country trip to Asia.  During a visit to Siem Reap the delegation toured two facilities that are supported by the U.S. government:  demining NGO HALO Trust and the HIV/AIDS Salvation Centre Cambodia at Wat Thmey.  The delegation also visited the Angkor Wat complex.  In Phnom Penh, the delegation had a meeting with Prime Minister Hun Sen and later held a discussion with key leaders in Cambodian civil society. #CamWomenCan Compete
"My biggest wish is to finish the #marathon at the #Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, be in good shape, and inspire the younger generation to follow my path."  Dr. Nary Ly

Like the women in yesterdays post, Nary Ly is also a medical doctor. But more than that, she wants to show the world that #CamWomenCan participate in The Olympic Games! 

Dr. Nary Ly is charting a new path for Cambodian women through her work in medicine and her passion for competitive running. Nary is a former research scientist with the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit Two and a lecturer at the University of Health Sciences. Earlier this year, she was nominated by the National Olympic Committee of Cambodia to represent her country at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Nary, who is currently training in Spain, is set to become the first Cambodian woman to compete in an Olympic marathon.

Nary's strength and determination to run in the Olympics has taken her on a journey around the world. Help support Nary as she continues to follow her dream at www.facebook.com/narylyrunning.

NATO is not just an alliance of friends who come to the aid of each other in times of need. It is also an alliance based on national self-interest.  Whether it is regional aggression going unchecked or the prospect that foreign fighters could return from Iraq and Syria to pose a threat in our countries, the problems we face today threaten the security of British and American people, and the wider world, say Prime Minister Cameron and President Obama.

#CamWomenCan Become Doctors
I do not think that women are appreciated enough in #Cambodia, even though we earn an income, have good education, and care for our children and husbands. Yes, it is hard to be a woman in this country...but we are very strong." - Dr. Neou Leakhena

Dr. Leakhena knew from a young age that she wanted to work in pediatric medicine. Studying in Phnom Penh in the 1990s, she was one of only 17 women in her class of more than 100. After years of hard work and dedication, today Dr. Leakhena directs neonatal care at the Angkor Hospital for Children in Siem Reap, which receives support from the U.S. government for its vital work in pediatric HIV/AIDS treatment. She is among a growing number of Cambodian women that are working in the health sector - not only in the traditional roles of nurses or assistants - but also as doctors and healthcare administrators.

For example, the Sihanouk Hospital Center of HOPE in Phnom Penh - which trains medical professionals and provides free high quality care to the poor - also has several amazing female doctors on its staff. Pictured below are Dr. Huy Sophea, Dr. Uch Muzen, Dr. Soth Sotheary, Dr.Chhun Sreymao,  Dr. Heing Kosalthyda, and Dr. Say Sothea. They all agree that education is the key to success for women. As Dr. Sreymao says, "If you dont want someone to look down at you as a woman, you should try to build your capacity and knowledge. When you have an education, no one can look down at you.

Spotlight on Women and Girls in Cambodia: The Harpswell Foundation
-From the Ambassador's Penh

For my first blog post of March, I thought that it would be fitting to highlight the fact that this is Womens History Month in the United States. This is a time when Americans honor the many economic, political, and social achievements of women. And on March 8, the United States will join Cambodia and several countries around the world to celebrate International Womens Day. As my mothers son, my wifes husband, and my daughters father, I am blessed to have so many remarkable women in my family. In my time as U.S. Ambassador, I have seen that Cambodian women are also critically important to their families and to society. In recognition of all the great things women have accomplished  as well as the challenges they continue to face  the U.S. Embassy will utilize its multiple social media platforms this month to spotlight current individuals, organizations, and events that focus on women and girls in Cambodia. I would like to start this series with a valued U.S. Embassy partner: the Harpswell Foundation.
Founded by U.S. academic and humanitarian Alan Lightman, the Harpswell Foundation provides education, housing, and leadership training for young Cambodian women while they attend university. The organization is dedicated to improving the conditions of women and the societies they live in by promoting women's education, leadership, and empowerment. To support this mission, I have participated in a number of events at Harpswell, including last years inauguration of their Womens Empowerment Program. Last week, Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung had the opportunity to visit Harpswell and like me, she was very impressed with the young women that she met.

During her visit, Julie spoke about her own experiences as a woman, as an Asian American, and as an immigrant to the United States. Connecting with the young women on a personal level, she encouraged them to face the challenges of discrimination and achieve their dreams by having self-confidence, working hard, and demonstrating their capabilities through action. Sharing her story, she said, I was a backpacker student in Cambodia in 1996never did I imagine I would return to be the Deputy Chief of Mission at the U.S. Embassy. So I say that one of you in this room can someday perhaps be Cambodias Ambassador to the United States. Young women like the ones at Harpswell are the future leaders of the country and are needed to help develop Cambodia into an even greater nation.

The experiences that Harpswell provides for young women have led to significant improvements in a number of areas, including public speaking, critical thinking skills, knowledge of national and international events, computer literacy, and English language ability. With these skills, Harpswell students have ranked at the top of their classes at several of the major universities in Cambodia. All of the young women that have graduated are now either studying for advanced degrees or currently employed. At least 20 of these alumni have received scholarships for post-graduate study in the United States and many others are completing masters degrees in Cambodia. Employed Harpswell alumni can be found in a wide variety of career fields, working as journalists, teachers, assistants in laws firms, project managers in NGOs, and financial consultants. Both the short-term and long-term accomplishments of these young women serve as evidence of Harpswells impact on the lives of young women and on Cambodias overall development.

The young women at Harpswell fill me and the members of my team with hope for the future of Cambodia. I would like to commend them for all of their hard work and say that no matter their backgrounds or hardships, they deserve the same opportunities as boys to accomplish what they want in life. The U.S. Embassy strongly supports the mission of the Harpswell Foundation. We look forward to further progress in our successful collaboration with this and other organizations that are dedicated to improving the lives of Cambodian girls.

To be eligible, applicants must have the following qualifications:

* Demonstrate commitment to public service and potential for advancement in their professions.

* A minimum of five years of professional experience commensurate with the type of study and training experience they seek and should be policy rather than research or technically oriented.

* Completed a university degree program requiring at least four years of full-time study in order to qualify for admission to U.S. programs of graduate study.

* Proficiency in both written and spoken English with a minimum TOEFL test scores of 525 paper-based or 71 Internet-based. Candidates with lower scores may be nominated for the Long Term English Training.

* Demonstrate the required experience, skills, and commitment while also indicating how they can benefit from this program in ways that they have not already experienced.

Corporate Social Responsibility: Doing Good is Good for Business
-From the Ambassador's Penh

I am happy to learn that more international companies are investing in Cambodia to build their business and create new jobs for Cambodians.  This investment is an important driver of trade, growth, and economic prosperity for the country.  Along with the creation of jobs, some companies are also committed to improving environmental and labor standards in Cambodia by the way they run their business.  In the past,  I have highlighted  examples of strong corporate social responsibility (CSR) practices in Cambodia, which are both good for the employees and good for business.  These include GEs contributions to supporting schools and medical equipment training as well as Tiffany & Co.s state-of-the-art diamond polishing factory that provides free medical care for its workers.

Last week, I had the opportunity to see firsthand another company that promotes both CSR and quality work standards in Cambodia.  Pactics, established in 2004, operates a factory in Siem Reap that employs 325 full-time Cambodian staff.  The company specializes in manufacturing microfiber bags and other accessories for sunglasses, jewelry, and electronics which it supplies for a number of U.S. companies such as eyeglass manufacturer Oakley.

During my tour, I learned how Pactics invested money to incorporate sustainable building measures and energy saving technology when designing its factory.  For example, windows are north-facing to provide natural light while reducing electricity usage by minimizing heat-generating direct sunlight.  Strategically placed vents create a naturally cool workspace, rainwater is collected to flush toilets, and solar panels power the LED lights used after dark.  General manager Boris Ploum explained that Pactics efforts to minimize its environmental impact may seem expensive but actually reduces operating costs over the long run.

The Cambodian government can encourage the use of green technologies by providing incentives to companies that invest in these technologies.  I commend the announcement of a recent proposal by Environment Minister Say Samal to make eco-friendly and green technologies tax-free to help reduce the cost barriers associated with importing green technologies, such as solar panels.

After touring the factory and meeting the workers, I appreciated more than ever the vision set by Pactics management to think beyond just profits to broader contributions they could make to the community.  The company also offers its employees fair wages, reasonable working hours, safe and clean working conditions, subsidies for motorbike helmets for a safe commute, and a full array of other benefits aimed to keep workers healthy.  Companies such as Pactics demonstrate that it is possible to run a successful business while caring for employees and the environment.  I encourage other companies in Cambodia to follow the example set by Pactics to improve working conditions for employees because it is not only the right thing to do; it is also good business.

Where Can YSEALI Take You?
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Recently, many people in Cambodia have asked me about the Young Southeast Asia Leaders Initiative (#YSEALI), President Obamas signature program for promoting youth leadership and networking in the Southeast Asia region.  I was happy to describe to them the many opportunities YSEALI offers and highlight the events that Cambodians have participated in.  I have also encouraged young Cambodians to join YSEALI, not only to engage with their peers on key issues, but to harness their potential as the next generation of leaders in the region.

Here in Cambodia, YSEALI members have hosted a forum to discuss the future economic integration of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and participated in Embassy sponsored events, including a live viewing party for a speech by the U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Antony Blinken and a live Twitter chat with Richard Stengel, the Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs.  These events provided YSEALI members with great opportunities to interact with senior U.S. government leaders and discuss a broad range of topics including democracy, tolerance, anti-corruption, and civic engagement.  In addition to these events, I shared in a previous blog that Cambodia also hosted YSEALI Generation: EARTH, a four-day regional exchange that helped foster a deeper understanding of climate change, deforestation, and other challenges to the environment facing the ASEAN region.

The YSEALI program also encourages promising youth leaders to carry out their own projects that improve their communities, countries, and the region through YSEALI Seeds for the Future, a small grants competition that provides funding of up to $20,000 for projects focusing on civic engagement, economic development, education, and environmental protection.  A select group of Cambodian YSEALI members, along with their counterparts from Thailand, recently organized a forum in Phnom Penh for more than 200 participants using a grant they won from last years YSEALI Seeds for the Future competition.  The forum was aimed at preparing Cambodian and Thai youth for the upcoming ASEAN economic integration and provided a platform for them to network and exchange ideas.  If you have an idea for a project, I encourage you to apply for the next round of YSEALI Seeds for the Future.  The deadline is June 15, 2015.

The YSEALI program has also given Cambodians the opportunity to travel abroad.  Six Cambodians  Muyheng Hong, Seila Sar, Suonvisal Seth, Se Chhin, Phalla Mey, and Sovanna Sek  spent six weeks in the United States through the YSEALI Professional Fellows Exchange program.  They participated in a hands-on fellowship to gain practical experience in leadership, education, environmental sustainability, and civic engagement.  To cap off their fellowship, they were among the 75 YSEALI Fellows from all 10 countries in ASEAN that were invited to the White House last week to meet with President Obama and share their experience in the United States.  In his remarks, President Obama recognized Suonvisal Seth for the good work he is doing in Cambodia.  In a press interview, Suonvisal said that he learned about good governance in the U.S. and plans to use his newfound knowledge to help develop Cambodia by improving the National Assemblys research department.  Suonvisal also said, I hope students here will see my trip as an impetus to work harder and get involved in more things.  I want to inspire Cambodian children to focus on advancing the countrys technology and leadership sectors.  If you want to make a difference like Suonvisal, you have the chance to apply for the YSEALI Professional Fellows program as well.  The deadline for this program is also June 15, 2015.  

From what Ive seen, Cambodian youth are clearly interested in engaging with their peers on the important issues that will determine the worlds future.  I firmly believe youth in Cambodia are embracing YSEALI to empower themselves to make a difference in their communities.  For example, weve received a significant number of applications for the YSEALI Professional Fellows program and the Seeds for the Future grant competition.  If you are not already a member of YSEALI and are between the ages of 18 and 35, I invite you to join this active and growing community.  To find out more about YSEALI and sign up for membership, go to https://youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov/

I want to recognize all the YSEALI members for the great work they are doing in Cambodia.  Please continue your efforts and tell me where YSEALI takes you.
#AmbTodd #Cambodia

170 Cambodian students expressed their creative visions at the Create Cambodia Arts Festival in Kandal Province last week.

Organized by Peace Corps Volunteers in partnership with six non-governmental organizations, the three-day festival brought students from 10 provinces together for workshops on visual arts, music, theater, dance, and other art disciplines.  

The festival culminated in splendid performances and exhibitions by the students who had worked very hard on perfecting their pieces with the help of their teachers and Peace Corps Volunteers in their villages.

National winners in Cambodias 2016 Microsoft Office Specialist World Championship  hosted by IIG Education Cambodia and their partners  were awarded prizes today during a ceremony held at the Cambodia-Japanese Cooperation Center. The event's top prize winners will travel to the U.S. to compete in the world championship in Orlando, Florida!  

DCM Julie Chung was a guest speaker for the event  along with HE Tekreth Kamrang, Secretary of State for the Ministry of Commerce and Vice General Director of Metfone Mr. Nhong Din Than.  In her remarks, Julie reminded the students that Science, technology, engineering and math or #STEM, is at the core of every thriving society and encouraged them by saying that Software and equipment alone dont result in innovation. Its the ideas behind the tools that drive the way ahead.  It is all of you in Cambodia who will help fill the blank white page.  Second place winner from the 2015 worldwide competition Kong Davin was also recognized during the cermony.  

The United States is proud to support all of Cambodias future innovators and wishes those going to Orlando good luck!

Volleyball Diplomacy Strengthens U.S.-Iranian Relations

On August 7, the Iranian National Mens Volleyball Team arrived in the United States for a series of four friendly matches in southern California between August 9 and 16 in a program supported by the U.S. Department of State.  This is not the first sports diplomacy activity between the United States and Iran. The U.S. National Wrestling Team participated and won bronze in the World Cup of Freestyle Wrestling in Tehran in February 2013. Irans Freestyle Wrestling Team competed in the United States in May 2013 in New York and February 2014 in Los Angeles. The Department of State supports exchanges between the American and Iranian people in arts, culture, sports, and education as a way of promoting understanding and good will between our two nations.

Read more about this historic visit at http://goo.gl/kRciGc

U.S. Currency Education Program 

  ,  ?

            

Michael Lambert      uscurrency.gov/km    !

$1.4 TRILLION. That is the value of U.S. currency in circulation...but do you know the difference between real and counterfeit U.S. dollars? 

Between one-half and two-thirds of the value of all U.S. currency circulates outside of the United States. To ensure that consumers and businesses in #Cambodia and around the world know how to authenticate genuine U.S. dollars and report suspect counterfeits, the Federal Reserve Boards U.S. Currency Education Program conducts international outreach.   

Michael Lambert  the Director of Banknotes for the U.S. Federal Reserve System  is in Cambodia this week to raise awareness about educational resources available in Khmer at uscurrency.gov/km.  Please visit the website and check out this video to learn some interesting facts about U.S. currency!

U.S. Citizens in Cambodia cast their votes at the U.S. Embassy.

More photos: https://picasaweb.google.com/106739195343586325665/EarlyVotingAtTheEmbassy

A significant change in balloting in recent years has been the adoption of procedures that make ballots available to voters before the election.

This trend started with provisions for absentee ballots, issued to voters who anticipate being away from their home (and their voting place) on Election Day.

Another new provision is early voting, for which voting machines are set up in shopping malls and other public places for up to three weeks before Election Day.

Even though early ballots are becoming more popular, they are not counted until tabulation begins after the polls close, so that no official information can be released about which candidate is ahead or behind.

EBOLA OUTBREAK UPDATE
(Source: CDC website http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/outbreaks/2014-west-africa/index.html) 

-On October 23, the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported a case of Ebola in a medical aid worker who had returned to New York City from Guinea, where the medical aid worker had served with Doctors Without Borders. The diagnosis was confirmed by CDC on October 24.

-On October 23, Mali reported its first confirmed case of Ebola in a child who had traveled there from Guinea. The child passed away on October 24.

-WHO officially declared Senegal and Nigeria free of Ebola virus transmission on October 17 and 20, respectively.

Professor Eric Pallant begins 3-country Streams of Hope river rehabilitation tour, sponsored by the Department of State.

On Saturday, September 13, 2014, visiting Professor Eric Pallant accompanied the Cambodian Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) team members around Phnom Penh as part of a program to introduce the importance of maintaining clean water resources in Cambodia. 

In the morning, the YSEALI team escorted Professor Pallant to Pannasastra University of Cambodia where he gave a presentation to 80 university students on river rehabilitation and some of the simple steps each of us can do to help keep the rivers clean  including educating others, collecting rainwater and even some innovative agricultural practices.  There was a lively discussion after the presentation as the university students shared their perspectives and asked great questions. 

On the way to enjoy a good Cambodian lunch, the YSEALI team and Professor Pallant stopped to examine a small stream at Chroy Bassac, in Cambodias capital city Phnom Penh.  Professor Pallant used this opportunity to talk to the YSEALI group and some interested passers-by, about the challenges of cleaning up dirty water in densely populated areas like this part of Phnom Penh City.

After a satisfying lunch, the group went to the American Intercon Institute where a gathering of high school students and members of local non-government organizations (NGOs) were assembled to hear Professor Pallant speak.  The presentation again focused on the different methods to protect clean water and strategies to rehabilitate dirty rivers.  The students were very attentive and again asked great questions. 

Following the afternoon presentation, the YSEALI team and Professor Pallant went to examine a lake polluted by sewage water at the Beoung Tro Bek Water Pumping Station in Phnom Penh.  The site visit demonstrated, in very real terms, the need for action to care for Cambodias water resources.  

Professor Eric Pallant, Chair of the Environmental Science Department at Allegheny College in Pennsylvania, USA, is visiting Cambodia, the Philippines, and Vietnam to help the three-country YSEALI team with their Streams of Hope projects. Members from Cambodia, the Philippines, and Vietnam joined together to focus on maintaining clean water resources in the region.  As part of the U.S. Department of States Speaker Program, Professor Pallant will meet with high school and university students, members of civil society, government officials, and others who have a stake in maintaining clean water resources.

You can follow Professor Pallants trip throughout the region on Facebook.  He is in Cambodia until September 15, then he will be in Manila for three days where you can follow him on U.S. Embassy, Manila Philippines Facebook page, and then on to Hanoi for three days where you can follow him on the U.S. Embassy in Hanoi Facebook page.
 
You can also follow Dr. Pallants trip via Twitter with #StreamsOfHope.

To join Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) and partner on projects like this, visit: http://goo.gl/c2ORS0

BREAKING NEWS: FIRST LADY MICHELLE OBAMA IS COMING TO CAMBODIA!

Coming on the heels of the President and First Ladys launch of the Let Girls Learn international girls education initiative, Mrs. Obama will travel to Japan and Cambodia from March 18-22, 2015. She will visit Tokyo on March 18-19, Kyoto on March 20, and Siem Reap on March 21-22.  She will be joined by Peace Corps Director Carrie Hessler-Radelet for the trip. While in Japan, the First Lady will highlight the importance both countries place on international girls education, and the plans to deepen our partnership on this issue through development programs and collaboration between the Peace Corps and Japans Overseas Cooperation Volunteers.  The First Lady will then travel to Cambodia, one of the first 11 countries to be included in the Let Girls Learn Peace Corps initiative in the programs first year.  In Cambodia, Mrs. Obama and Peace Corps Director Hessler-Radelet will see up close how community-driven solutions are changing girls lives, a key component of the Let Girls Learn Peace Corps program. For more information on the Let Girls Learn Initiative, please go to http:/www.whitehouse.gov/LetGirlsLearn and http:/www.letgirlslearn.peacecorps.gov/.

Additional details about the First Ladys trip are forthcoming.

	Dishonest agencies in Phnom Penh have been extorting money from winners of the DV program.  These agencies have assisted Cambodians to apply for the DV program and later charged the winners outrageous fees.  THERE IS NO FEE TO ENTER THE LOTTERY!

	There has also been a notable increase in fraudulent emails and letters sent to DV program applicants.  The scammers behind these fraudulent emails and letters are posing as the U.S. government in an attempt to extract payment from DV applicants.  Applicants are encouraged to read our FRAUD ALERT regarding the DV program here: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/diversity_visa.html.

	No organization can send you a notification of your selection in the DV program.  Any individual or organization that promises to secure a visa to the United States for you is ENGAGING IN A FRAUDULENT PRACTICE.  Only U.S. consular officials have authorization to approve or deny your visa application.

	DV-2015 is closed since November 2, 2013.  DV-2015 applicants can use their confirmation number to check their entrant status at http://www.dvlottery.state.gov/ESC/.  

	The opening date of DV-2016 has not yet been announced.  That date will be announced on our website and Facebook page once DV-2016 is open for applications.

	For more information, please contact our Consular Office at IVPhnomPenh@state.gov.

To Defeat Terror, We Need the Worlds Help
By U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry
August 29, 2014

In a polarized region and a complicated world, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria presents a unifying threat to a broad array of countries, including the United States. Whats needed to confront its nihilistic vision and genocidal agenda is a global coalition using political, humanitarian, economic, law enforcement and intelligence tools to support military force.

In addition to its beheadings, crucifixions and other acts of sheer evil, which have killed thousands of innocents in Syria, Iraq and Lebanon, including Sunni Muslims whose faith it purports to represent, ISIS (which the United States government calls ISIL, or the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant) poses a threat well beyond the region.

ISIS has its origins in what was once known as Al Qaeda in Iraq, which has over a decade of experience in extremist violence. The group has amassed a hardened fighting force of committed jihadists with global ambitions, exploiting the conflict in Syria and sectarian tensions in Iraq. Its leaders have repeatedly threatened the United States, and in May an ISIS-associated terrorist shot and killed three people at the Jewish Museum in Brussels. (A fourth victim died 13 days later.) ISIS cadre of foreign fighters are a rising threat not just in the region, but anywhere they could manage to travel undetected -- including to America.

There is evidence that these extremists, if left unchecked, will not be satisfied at stopping with Syria and Iraq. They are larger and better funded in this new incarnation, using pirated oil, kidnapping and extortion to finance operations in Syria and Iraq. They are equipped with sophisticated heavy weapons looted from the battlefield. They have already demonstrated the ability to seize and hold more territory than any other terrorist organization, in a strategic region that borders Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey and is perilously close to Israel. 

ISIS fighters have exhibited repulsive savagery and cruelty. Even as they butcher Shiite Muslims and Christians in their effort to touch off a broader ethnic and sectarian conflict, they pursue a calculated strategy of killing fellow Sunni Muslims to gain and hold territory. The beheading of an American journalist, James Foley, has shocked the conscience of the world.

With a united response led by the United States and the broadest possible coalition of nations, the cancer of ISIS will not be allowed to spread to other countries. The world can confront this scourge, and ultimately defeat it. ISIS is odious, but not omnipotent. We have proof already in northern Iraq, where United States airstrikes have shifted the momentum of the fight, providing space for Iraqi and Kurdish forces to go on the offensive. With our support, Iraqs leaders have come together to form a new, inclusive government that is essential to isolating ISIS and securing the support of all of Iraqs communities.

Airstrikes alone wont defeat this enemy. A much fuller response is demanded from the world. We need to support Iraqi forces and the moderate Syrian opposition, who are facing ISIS on the front lines. We need to disrupt and degrade ISIS capabilities and counter its extremist message in the media. And we need to strengthen our own defenses and cooperation in protecting our people.

Next week, on the sidelines of the NATO summit meeting in Wales, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel and I will meet with our counterparts from our European allies. The goal is to enlist the broadest possible assistance. Following the meeting, Mr. Hagel and I plan to travel to the Middle East to develop more support for the coalition among the countries that are most directly threatened.

The United States will hold the presidency of the United Nations Security Council in September, and we will use that opportunity to continue to build a broad coalition and highlight the danger posed by foreign terrorist fighters, including those who have joined ISIS. During the General Assembly session, President Obama will lead a summit meeting of the Security Council to put forward a plan to deal with this collective threat.

In this battle, there is a role for almost every country. Some will provide military assistance, direct and indirect. Some will provide desperately needed humanitarian assistance for the millions who have been displaced and victimized across the region. Others will help restore not just shattered economies but broken trust among neighbors. This effort is underway in Iraq, where other countries have joined us in providing humanitarian aid, military assistance and support for an inclusive government.

Already our efforts have brought dozens of nations to this cause. Certainly there are different interests at play. But no decent country can support the horrors perpetrated by ISIS, and no civilized country should shirk its responsibility to help stamp out this disease.  ISIS abhorrent tactics are uniting and rallying neighbors with traditionally conflicting interests to support Iraqs new government. And over time, this coalition can begin to address the underlying factors that fuel ISIS and other terrorist organizations with like-minded agendas.

Coalition building is hard work, but it is the best way to tackle a common enemy. When Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait in 1990, the first President George Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III did not act alone or in haste. They methodically assembled a coalition of countries whose concerted action brought a quick victory. Extremists are defeated only when responsible nations and their peoples unite to oppose them.

You can read this article on the U.S. State Department Official Blog, DipNote, at http://goo.gl/P6oIhQ

Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Possible Demonstrations in Phnom Penh
September 5, 2016

The United States Embassy in Phnom Penh alerts U.S. citizens residing in or traveling to #Cambodia of the possibility of political demonstrations in Phnom Penh on Monday, September 5.  The Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) has announced planned demonstrations at or around CNRP Headquarters, located at 576 National Road 2, as well as at or around the Phnom Penh Municipal Court, located on Samdech Monireth Blvd. Additional demonstrations may occur throughout Phnom Penh through the week of September 5, including in the areas surrounding CNRP headquarters and the Phnom Penh Municipal Court.

U.S. citizens are reminded of the Embassys existing guidance that even demonstrations intended to be peaceful can turn confrontational and have the potential to escalate into violence without warning.  The U.S. Embassy recommends you avoid areas where demonstrations are taking place and exercise caution when in the vicinity of any large gatherings, protests or demonstrations and immediately leave any area where there are large gatherings.  You should  remain alert of local security developments by monitoring local news reports, exercising vigilance regarding your preparedness and personal security, remaining aware of your surroundings, and planning your activities accordingly.  Please follow the guidance below to receive the most updated security information from the U.S. Embassy.

For further information:

         See the State Department's travel website (http://travel.state.gov/) for the Worldwide Caution (http://travel.state.gov/content/passports/english/alertswarnings/worldwide-caution.html), Travel Warnings, Travel Alerts, and Cambodia Specific Information.

         Enroll in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program (https://step.state.gov/step/) to receive security messages and make it easier to locate you in an emergency.

         Contact the U.S. Embassy in Cambodia, located at No. 1, Street 96, Sangkat Wat Phnom, Khan Daun Penh, Phnom Penh, at +855 (0)23 728 402 or + 855 (0)23 728 051, 8:00 am to 5:00 pm, Monday through Friday. After-hours emergency number for U.S. citizens is + 855 (0)23 728 000.

         Call 1-888-407-4747 toll-free in the United States and Canada or 1-202-501-4444 from other countries from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time, Monday through Friday (except U.S. federal holidays).

         Follow us on Twitter (http://twitter.com/travelgov) and Facebook (http://www.facebook.com/travelgov).

Camera traps in the Preah Vihear Protected Forests  funded by the #USAID Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project  captured two rare photos of a golden Jackal and Gaur bison roaming the forest. Farewell and Best Wishes to an Outstanding Doctor
-From the Ambassador's Penh

This week, I joined our Embassy community in bidding farewell to Dr. Claire Uebbing, MD, affectionately known by many of her patients and friends simply as Dr. Claire.  A board certified emergency medicine physician, she has completed three years of extraordinary service at the International SOS Clinic of Phnom Penh.  Now, she will be returning to the United States for more training and continue her career in emergency medicine.

Since August 2012, Dr. Claire has served as the de facto Emergency Room savior to members of our Mission, the U.S. military, American tourists, the expat community, and Cambodians as well.  In fact, Cambodians represent more than 60 percent of the patients that she has treated during her time in the country.  Her expertise and caring bedside manner  the relationship between doctor and patient  has made a huge difference in the lives of thousands of people.  Dr. Claire was always willing to adjust her schedule to accommodate her patients, even when she was busy with other tasks.  She has also served as a role model for her peers.

Like many other American doctors and nurses, Dr. Claire came to Cambodia due to her strong interest in helping people and practicing medicine abroad.  She has made a significant impact during her time in Cambodia, showing a commitment and genuine passion caring for patients and families with routine illnesses as well as severe medical crises.  Not only did she provide direct consultation and treatment, she was also able to reach people throughout the country by providing medical advice in newspapers, guide books, and online health resources.

Dr. Claire played a key role for the team at International SOS Cambodia.  Since establishing a medical clinic in Phnom Penh in 1998, the organization has served the needs of the public with help from both Cambodian doctors and international physicians like Dr. Claire.  The clinic specializes in a number of areas, including general practice, womens health, dermatology, internal medicine, emergency medicine, travel medicine and dental care.  While they will miss Dr. Claire, I am confident that their team will continue to provide quality services to people living and traveling in Cambodia.

In her advice to other health professionals, Dr. Claire says, Consciously seek out opportunities for you to experience medicine, in a clinical setting, as well as just volunteering at home and in the school community.  You know more about what you are getting into with this kind of experience."  I am personally grateful that Dr. Claire decided to serve in Cambodia.  For all of us who have interacted and worked alongside her during these past three years, please join me in wishing her all the best as she pursues the next chapter in her life.  We sincerely thank Dr. Claire for her dedication to improving the lives of the Cambodian people, American citizens, and others who received her quality care.  She has truly made a difference that will be remembered.

CLINTON   Kim Jong Il 
__________

 Kim Jong Il      

  

     

       

Secretary Hillary Clinton on the Passing of National Defense Commission Chairman Kim Jong Il
__________

With the passing of National Defense Commission Chairman Kim Jong Il, the Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea is now in a period of national mourning.

We are deeply concerned with the well being of the North Korean people and our thoughts and prayers are with them during these difficult times.

It is our hope that the new leadership of the DPRK will choose to guide their nation onto the path of peace by honoring North Koreas commitments, improving relations with its neighbors, and respecting the rights of its people.

The United States stands ready to help the North Korean people and urges the new leadership to work with the international community to usher in a new era of peace, prosperity and lasting security on the Korean Peninsula.

All aboard!  We continue our series from Pichleap Sok as she tells her story while riding the Fulbright Millenial Train Project.  Picheleap is aboard the train as one of 75 Fulbright fellows traveling from California to Washington D.C., experiencing American culture, listening to special guest speakers and conducting interviews.  Here is her account of Day 3 on the train:

"We have been on the train for a whole day. We learned how to tell our story in an effective and compelling way in 9 seconds. Our special guest is Amy Wilkinson, an author of the Creators Code and a lecturer from Stanford Graduate School of Business. She taught us about six keys to become a successful entrepreneur which is written in her book The Creators Code. The key take away which really influence me the most is we have to feel comfortable with the uncomfortable. It is okay to feel the butterfly in the stomach because it is a good sign. We need to really get out of our comfort zone and overcome the fear. Thats one of my favorite workshops. 
We are so fortunate to have chefs on the train. We get to eat nice meals and snacks. Thanks to all the organizers and chefs in particular. In evening, we get to see the border of Mexico and the United States. Its so refreshing. The train is now heading to San Antonio."

The YSEALI Generation: EARTH regional exchange will bring 72 rising young leaders and 24 mentor leaders from across Southeast Asia to Siem Reap in order to address the environmental challenges facing the ASEAN region and beyond. WHAT'S THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN A COLLEGE AND A UNIVERSITY?

The terms, college and university, are used interchangeably and mean the same thing in the U.S. As a general rule, colleges tend to be smaller and usually offer only undergraduate degrees, while a university also offers graduate degrees. Within each college or university you will find schools, such as school of arts and sciences or the school of business.

What is a watershed? It is an area created by a water system that hosts a wide variety of living things.  Well-managed watersheds protect biodiversity, maintain forests and water sources, and preserve fish stocks.  They also benefit people who generate their livelihoods from forests, agriculture, and fisheries.  

As Cambodia develops, watersheds have come under threat, particularly from over-logging, economic concessions, and slash and burn agriculture.  Find out how USAID is helping Cambodia protect watersheds:  http://bit.ly/1bO8MoA (English), http://bit.ly/1j7jgnv (Khmer)
