Bringing Home the Victims of Human Trafficking
-From the Ambassador's Penh

According to estimates, more than 20 million people around the world are living as modern-day slaves  many lured away from their homes by promises of higher paying jobs.  On Tuesday, we received some good news when 59 Cambodian fishermen arrived at Phnom Penh International Airport, bringing to an end their nightmare of emotional and physical abuse on fishing boats in the seas around Indonesia.  Some of the men had been away for as long as five years, financially and physically shackled to an industry that is often known for taking advantage of people who are unable to defend themselves.

The U.S. government is proud to have played a role in the return of these 59 fishermen through USAIDs Counter Trafficking in Persons (CTIP) program, which financed their voyage back to Cambodia.  Id like to thank USAIDs partners, Winrock International and the International Organization for Migration (IOM), for taking on this important project to bring them home.

I can only imagine how deeply emotional the mens return will be to their families and friends.  Many of the families havent heard from their sons, husbands, or fathers for several years.  All of them will begin a new journey now as they look to reintegrate into Cambodian society.  In addition to physical wounds, many of the returnees have suffered mental and emotional trauma.  They will need help to reconnect to the communities that they left behind.  They will also need new skills and a helping hand to start a business or find a job that will support them and their families.  The U.S. Embassy and our partners will continue to provide support through the CTIP program as they go through this process.

The mens return to Phnom Penh this week is a welcome point of light on an otherwise dark horizon.  Even though slavery is outlawed all over the world, too many men, women  and even children  are modern-day slaves condemned to lives of great suffering and injustice.  In Cambodia, sexual and labor trafficking continues to threaten the countrys youth.  Its important that we work together to protect young people from this scourge.

Im pleased to say we are working with many partners to put an end to trafficking.  USAIDs CTIP program works in lockstep with Cambodias National Committee for CTIP to implement their recently approved National Plan of Action.  Just last month, our CTIP program, working through local partner Legal Support for Children and Women (LSCW), began providing legal assistance to four Cambodian women who were trafficked to China as brides.  With help from the Cambodian embassy in China and Winrock, one of the women has returned to her community in Kampong Cham province.

Every time a trafficking victim comes home is a cause for celebration, but there is still much more to do.  The U.S. Embassy is committed to working with our local and international partners to end trafficking in Cambodia and to bring home all Cambodians who are being trafficked overseas.
#AmbTodd

Building Personal Connections through Sport
-From the Ambassador's Penh

As the U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia, I am often asked about my work as a diplomat.  In the world of diplomacy, government officials attend meetings and hold discussions to resolve differences and work towards a common goal.  While this is definitely an important aspect of U.S. engagement with Cambodia, there are many other ways where people of our two countries can connect.  For instance, the universal passion for sports is one way to transcend language barriers and cultural differences in order to bring people together.  International sporting events like the Southeast Asian (SEA) Games, where athletes from Cambodia and other nations in the region compete for gold medals in 36 sports, is a prime example of sports diplomacy.  Since 1959, the SEA Games have been held to build strong regional cooperation, understanding, and unity within the Southeast Asian community.  This year, Singapore is hosting the 28th SEA Games, which kicks off this week.

Among the many athletes who will represent Cambodia at the SEA Games are several Cambodian-Americans.  The 12-man roster of the Cambodian mens basketball team includes seven Cambodian-Americans who have committed their time and energy to represent Cambodia.  Four of the players  Sopheark Mith, Sopheeng Toun, Dominic Dar, and William Em  are from Lowell, Massachusetts, a city that has the second-highest percentage of Cambodian population of any city in the United States.  Vannak Som and Jonathan Koy are from California, and Phanat Sary Ouch hails from Texas but currently lives in Cambodia.  I believe their combined experience and love of the game of basketball will not only help the team compete at the SEA Games, but also to help develop the sport in Cambodia.  I am also proud of these young men for building connections with the Cambodian people by sharing their American culture.  

The Cambodian mens basketball team begins group play against Thailand on June 9.  I want to wish them, and all Cambodian athletes, great success at the SEA Games.  Every athlete competing at the SEA Games is an ambassador representing their country.  I hope all the athletes will interact with one another to increase dialogue and cultural understanding.  Personally, I cant think of a better way to build personal connections than through a common passion for sport.

Will you be following the SEA Games?  How do you plan to support Team Cambodia?

#AmbTodd #Cambodia #SEAGames

The U.S. Embassy will be closed on Monday, October 11 for the Columbus Day holiday.

In 1905, Colorado became the first state to observe a Columbus Day. Over the next few decades other states followed. In 1937, then-President Franklin Roosevelt proclaimed every October 12 as Columbus Day. Since 1971, it has been celebrated on the second Monday in October.

Do you have a dream of studying in the United States but think you cant afford it?  Does talk of scholarships, fellowships and grants make your head spin?  EducationUSA-Cambodia and the U.S. Embassy can help.

Veterans International Cambodia
 - From the Ambassador's Penh

In my latest column, I wrote about the importance of disability rights in Cambodia and the fact that this month marks the 25th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) in the United States.  The anniversary of the ADA is a reminder that there is still more work to be done to ensure the rights of persons with disabilities in Cambodia and around the world.  In my series highlighting civil society organizations, I want to draw your attention to Veterans International Cambodia (VIC), whose vital work is improving the lives of persons with disabilities in Cambodia.

In Cambodia, there are an estimated 700,000 persons who are disabled as a result of landmines, motorcycle and automobile accidents, birth defects, and other causes.  Ive learned that in addition to discrimination, persons with disabilities often face physical, social, and economic barriers that prevent them from receiving quality and affordable health care, rehabilitation, education, and other services.  Many of these individuals need rehabilitation, artificial limbs and braces, and other necessary services to overcome challenges in their life, thus enabling them to realize their potential and more fully participate in society.

Thats why I believe the work of VIC is so critical.  Since opening the Kien Kheang Clinic in 1992, VIC has assisted in the rehabilitation of Cambodians living with disabilities to help them meet their basic daily needs.  The organization also opened centers in Prey Veng and Kratie provinces to extend its services to other parts of the country.  To date, VIC has provided rehabilitation services to tens of thousands of Cambodians and is one of the main providers of prosthetics and orthotics in the country.

I am pleased that the U.S. government, through the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), recently launched the Rehabilitation and Prosthetics Program for Persons with Disabilities in Cambodia.  The program will allow VIC to continue to provide rehabilitation and prosthetic services for persons with disabilities.  Working in close coordination with the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veterans and Youth Rehabilitation (MoSVY), VIC is assisting the Cambodian government as it takes on greater responsibility in providing these critical services to its citizens.  The USAID-funded program will help ensure a smooth transition as the Cambodian government assumes charge of VICs three rehabilitation centers by the end of 2016.

I would like to recognize the Royal Government of Cambodia for adopting and implementing a number of laws, regulations, and policies to address challenges facing persons with disabilities in the Kingdom.  The United States is committed to working with the Cambodian government, individuals, and organizations like VIC to support persons with disabilities.  By working together, I believe we can make progress in securing equal opportunities in education, employment, and everyday life for disabled persons in Cambodia.

September 15 is the United Nations' International Day of Democracy and this years theme is "Space for Civil Society."  One example of how the United States supports civil society in Cambodia and the region is through initiatives like the USAID-funded GREEN Mekong (Grassroots Equity and Enhanced Networks in Mekong) Program.  During the past three years, the program helped train participants on how to assist people living in forest communities to work more effectively with government officials on forest management.  The final session of the program included a field visit to a forest community, where representatives saw firsthand how advocacy helped to strengthen democracy and enabled citizens to work with the government to ensure the protection of their rights.  For more info about this project, visit http://www.recoftc.org/project/green-mekong.

International Education Week: 5 Steps to Studying in the United States 

Step Three: Complete Your Application

Way to go!  At this point you have researched your options, chosen a program that fits your career goals, and created a plan to finance your studies.  Now it's time to complete the application for the U.S. college or university you want to attend.  Application and admission procedures vary based on the program, so be sure to verify requirements with the program of interest to you. 
 
Before applying, here are some things you may want to think about:
 
        What are your educational goals for completing the program? Is earning a degree important to you, or do you want to take a few classes to learn a new skill or to complete a certificate program to increase your professional status?
        What are the total costs of the program? Do the fees include books and shipping, if necessary? Are there any additional expenses? Is there any financial aid available?
        What academic or technical assistance is offered throughout the program?

Fully answering these questions prepares you for a study program in the U.S.
  
To get more information about completing your application, visit the EducationUSA webpage here http://goo.gl/QTSvYm

"I was pleased to see the U.S.-supported Mine Action Planning Unit and discuss #Cambodias international leadership in the humanitarian mine action sector with newly-appointed Cambodian Mine Action Authority (CMAA) Secretary General and Senior Minister Ly Thuch this morning. For more than 20 years, the United States has partnered with Cambodia, donor governments and international organizations to clear landmines and other explosive remnants of war, restoring lands and livelihoods to Cambodians across the country." -#AmbHeidt  

The annual casualty rate from landmines and other explosive remnants of war in Cambodia has decreased from over 4,000 per year two decades ago to under 200 today. Despite this significant progress, Cambodia remains in the top five countries in the world for mine and unexploded ordnance casualties, and contaminated land hurts the poor more than anyone. The United States is committed to its partnership with CMAA and others to help raise the profile of mine clearance activities and efficiently prioritize resources in Cambodia in order to make the country mine-free by 2025 in accordance with the Maputo Declaration. For the full text of this agreement, visit www.icbl.org/media/2146336/Maputo-plus-15-_Declaration.pdf.

Ambassador Todds column this week focuses on the Cambodian education system:

Many particulars of the Ministrys eight-point reform strategy have been taking shape in recent months.  For example, salaries of teachers were increased and the payment system for teachers has been streamlined.  Although the increase in pay is small, it is an important first step.  And the new method of making direct payment to teachers bank accounts means that salaries can be paid on time, at regular intervals, and with greater safeguards against embezzlement.  These changes help support teachers so they can focus on the quality of their work and the progress to be made in the classroom. 

Read the entire column, Focusing on Education to Attain Long-Term Prosperity, on the Cambodia Heralds website at: http://goo.gl/O957Q5.

The Camp will provide NGOs and CSOs with training to harness the latest ( ICT ) information and communications technologies to help them address some of the most pressing social challenges in Cambodia.

Note: This event is for NGOs, students are advised not to register unless you intern or work for an NGO.

The U.S. capital, Washington, DC, is named in honor of our first president:  George Washington.  But did you know that there is also a state called Washington?  The state of Washington is located in the Pacific Northwest region of the United States.  The state capital is Olympia, but the largest city and economic hub is Seattle.  Washington is the birthplace of Starbucks coffee and home to many major tech companies such as Microsoft.  Washington state is also home to a large and dynamic Cambodian-American community.  

The U.S. Embassy has a personal connection to Washington state:  Ambassador and Mrs. Heidt were married at the Asian Art Museum in Seattle, followed by a traditional Khmer wedding at home.

Find out more cool facts about Washington here: https://share.america.gov/washington-mountains-museums-innovation/

(USAID)      Montessori    Cesar Chavez  Prince George Maryland              

Last week, officials from the Royal Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Education visited the Washington, D.C. area to attend the 2015 #USAID Global Education Summit. Following the summit, the Cambodian delegation visited the Latin American Montessori Bilingual Public Charter School and Cesar Chavez Elementary School in Prince George's County, Maryland to learn more about early grade reading - a key priority in Cambodia's Education Strategic Plan. Thanks to support from the International Literacy Association and U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh, they met with U.S.-based education officials to discuss early grade literacy programs in Cambodia and the U.S., highlighting the importance of effective teaching methods, parental and community engagement, and school governance. The delegation gave very positive reviews about the experience and will now focus on implementing what they learned here in #Cambodia.

"" 

    wfr@state.gov

Have you been to an American Corner?  U.S. Embassy Charg dAffaires Julie Chung recently visited the American Corner at Passtra University of Cambodia (PUC).  With four locations in Cambodia (Phnom Penh, Kampong Cham, Battambang, and Siem Reap), American Corners offer access to books, technology, English classes, student advising, and special programs to educate students about the United States.  Sounds interesting, right?  Learn more about the American Corners in Cambodia here: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/american_corners_in_cambodia.html

PUC also hosts the EducationUSA advising center, which offers free counseling to students interested in studying abroad in the United States.  

These are great resources, so be sure to check them out!

On Monday morning, Ambassador Heidt and Minister of Environment H.E. Dr. Say Samal flew over Prey Lang Forest to raise awareness about #deforestation in #Cambodia and to highlight U.S. and Cambodian government efforts to protect Cambodias precious natural resources. The Ambassador and Minister Samal were joined by representatives from the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries, the Ministry of Interior, and USAID Cambodia. The group met with the provincial governor of Steung Treng province and gave a press conference after returning to Phnom Penh.  

The U.S. government is providing $20 million to protect and conserve Cambodias rich natural assets and unique biodiversity through USAID's Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project (SFB), implemented by Winrock International. In Prey Lang and other forested areas, USAID and its partners work closely with national and local authorities and communities to help mark protected areas, patrol community forests, and educate the public about the importance of conserving forest resources. For more information about the SFB project, please visit http://www.winrock.org/project/supporting-forestry-and-biodiversity.

This week, Ambassador Todd discusses the threat of ISIL and the strategy to combat it:

What is happening in Iraq and Syria is also an urgent humanitarian crisis.  During my time in Cambodia, I have heard many firsthand stories of what can happen when a small group of violent extremists takes hold of territory and commits unspeakable acts of violence against its own people.  Our common humanity urges us to take action to protect the innocent victims of ISIL. 



Extremists are defeated only when responsible nations and their peoples unite to oppose them, Secretary Kerry wrote. I thank Samdech Prime Minister Hun Sen for his strong words of support, and I hope that all Cambodians will join with the United States and other nations around the world to condemn this horrific violence and to call for peace, respect, and tolerance. 

Read the Ambassadors full column, titled Working Together to Fight Extremism in The Cambodia Herald at: http://goo.gl/jc6QKU

Over the past decade, the U.S. Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) has given care and treatment to over 17 million people infected with HIV worldwide.  In Cambodia, PEPFAR has helped to strengthen the country's health system and improve access to care for many marginalized people.

Going forward, how will PEPFAR work toward an AIDS-free generation?  U.S. Global AIDS Coordinator, Dr. Deborah Birx, outlined three major imperatives in the fight against HIV/AIDS.  Learn more here:   http://blog.usaid.gov/2014/05/the-future-of-pepfar/

Today marks the 26th anniversary of the American with Disabilities Act (#ADA26), a civil rights law that would inspire the world to promote equal opportunity and address discrimination faced by persons with disabilities. 
In the spirit of the ADA, we would like to recognize the amazing members of  #Cambodia's Wheelchair Basketball Federation (CWBF).

Established with support from the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), players on the Cambodian Women's Wheelchair Basketball team from Battambang and Kampong Speu provinces came to Phnom Penh for the July 15 NBA-WNBA Sports Envoy event at Olympic Stadium. For the thousands of people in the audience and viewing live via Facebook, watching the players' amazing talents and passion for the game was the highlight of the event.

Some members of the CWBF were also granted an audience with Her Majesty Queen Mother Norodom Monineath Sihanouk, who offered to lend assistance to the construction of a new roof for the basketball court at the ICRC's physical rehabilitation center in Battambang. To learn more about this and the team, please visit www.icrc.org/en/document/cambodia-queen-mother-mines-womens-wheelchair-basketball.

 Heidt            

         

On May 26, #AmbHeidt met with Dr. Pung Chhiv Kek, the president of the Cambodian League for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights, or LICADHO, and members of her staff to discuss the NGO's work in #Cambodia. Dr. Kek - who founded LICADHO in 1992 after the signing of the Paris Peace Agreements - has worked tirelessly ever since to promote peace, non-violence, and respect for the rights of every Cambodian citizen.  

#AmbHeidt said, I have known Madame Kek for nearly 20 years and remain deeply impressed by LICADHOs very principled work on a wide range of issues affecting all Cambodians, including the protection of civil, economic, and political rights. The United States is proud to support civil society organizations like LICADHO.

LICADHO advocates for womens and childrens rights, provides humanitarian legal aid and social services to people in need, and works to expand awareness about political rights in Cambodia. Additionally, LICADHO helps communities learn how effectively advocate for and protect their own rights. It is one of a number of civil society organizations in Cambodia working to empower citizens, develop innovative solutions to challenges, and hold the government accountable to the people they represent. #humanrights

"When we talk about climate change, were not just talking about the harm that is caused to the habitat for butterflies or polar bears  as some people try to mock it  as serious as those effects might be.

We are talking about the impacts on people  people everywhere  of severe droughts, rapid sea level rise.

Were talking about the impacts on whole cities of unpredictable and uncontrollable extreme weather events.

Were talking about the impact on entire countries of fundamental shocks to the global agricultural system...And the prospect of a hotter, drier climate throughout the Middle East and parts of Asia will place even more strain on the most precious and essential resource of all  fresh water.

Weve already seen tensions rise around the basins of the Nile River in Africa, the Indus River in South Asia, and of course, the Mekong River in Southeast Asia." - Secretary of State John Kerry
 
To read the full remarks on Climate Change and National Security, visit: http://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2015/11/249393.htm

Earth Day:  Working Together to Protect the Environment
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Today is Earth Day, an annual event celebrated on April 22 in which citizens take action to demonstrate their support for protecting the environment.  The first Earth Day was held in 1970 when 20 million Americans rallied to demand clean air and water.  Now, Earth Day is celebrated in more than 192 countries worldwide as a way for communities to express their environmental concerns and educate others.  Participants engage in activities ranging from tree-planting and cleanup projects to awareness raising concerts and fairs.  In Cambodia, I am encouraged to see that citizens, civil society organizations, and the government are doing their part to raise awareness about preserving the countrys precious and unique environment for future generations.

I can think of no better example of citizens taking action to address environmental concerns than the young people of Cambodia.  In particular, I want to highlight the efforts of the Ambassadors Youth Council (AYC) on addressing Cambodias environmental challenges.  Last year, AYC members visited the Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center to learn first-hand about endangered animals in Cambodia and efforts to protect them.  During visits to Mondulkiri and Koh Kong, the members got an in-depth look at the problems of illegal logging and wildlife trafficking and learned how projects that promote sustainable growth not only help rural and forest communities to prosper but also contribute to environmental protection.

Drawing on their knowledge and experience, in January the AYC teamed up with Wildlife Alliance to present a public concert called Wild for Life at the Phnom Penh Night Market.  The event featured musical and comedy performances that provided a platform to entertain and educate more than 3,000 Cambodians on the importance of environmental protection and wildlife conservation.  

Just last month, the AYC hosted another environmental education event.  The Earth Hour program at the Royal University of Phnom Penh, co-organized by World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), helped raise awareness about the need to save energy and the impacts of climate change.  The event included a screening of Earth Hour Worldwide and a number of entertaining performances.  It is inspiring to see the many great things the AYC has accomplished in such a short time.  I am optimistic they will achieve even more in the future.

The U.S. government, through the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), is working with local forest communities in Cambodia to find ways to protect the environment while providing sustainable income.  In partnership with Winrock International and WWF, USAIDs Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project recently hosted a successful annual forum to spark a dialogue between private investment companies, local communities, and environmentalists in Mondulkiri province.  The forum helped stakeholders explore effective solutions to protect the forests and wildlife.  Another project provided training for women in the village of Kampong Damrey in Kratie province so they can properly manage the surrounding forest resources in ways that benefit the entire community.  We also support the Preak Toal bird sanctuary to protect the Giant Ibis, Cambodias national bird.  With assistance from the U.S. government, members of the surrounding fishing villages have been trained to serve as forest rangers, monitoring and reporting on the bird populations of the sanctuary.  By preserving bird habitats, the rangers are also protecting key fish-spawning grounds that are critical to their economic livelihood.

Meanwhile at the U.S. Embassy, were doing our part as well.  We are implementing green initiatives and educational awareness campaigns that will help us save electricity and reduce waste.  This effort includes switching over from diesel generators to the municipal power grid to reduce air and noise pollution, replacing the halogen lighting system with energy efficient LED lights, and installing water refill stations to reduce the number of plastic water bottles being thrown away.  During the Embassys Earth Day celebration, Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung presented an award to the winner of the Embassys first annual Earth Day Recycled Sculpture Art Contest.  The winning sculpture of a mother and baby elephant, made out of coffee and creamer cups, was selected for the innovative use of recyclable materials.

I hope that you had an opportunity to do something to celebrate Earth Day, but let us not forget that we can engage in activities every day of the year that will help protect the environment, address the impacts of climate change, and combat wildlife trafficking.  By working together, I believe everyone can do their part to make our planet a better place.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

To read more entries from Ambassador Todd's blog, go to: blogs.usembassy.gov/todd

The US-ASEAN Business Council (USABC) recently organized an impressive delegation of U.S. companies to visit #Cambodia for their annual mission. Representatives from ConocoPhillips, GE, Coca-Cola, Visa, P&G, Ford Motor Company, RMA Cambodia, and Herbalife met a number of government officials - including Prime Minister Hun Sen and Minister of Commerce Pan Sorasak - to express their commitment to the U.S.-Cambodia business relationship and to supporting Cambodias development efforts.  The USABC missions goals were to encourage the Royal Government of Cambodia to implement better governance and transparency, to push for deeper stakeholder engagement in policy formation, and to highlight the U.S. business communitys support for capacity building, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and human resources in Cambodia. More about USABC's activities in Cambodia is at www.usasean.org/countries/cambodia/about.

Special Olympics:  Lets Go, Team Cambodia!
-From the Ambassador's Penh

I am a firm believer that society benefits when every member is able to lead full and meaningful lives.  However, many individuals with disabilities around the world are unable to thrive because of the discrimination and stigma they encounter.  People with an intellectual disability (ID) in particular, have been largely misunderstood.  Individuals with an ID have certain limitations in cognitive functioning and skills, including communication, social, and self-care skills.  These limitations can cause a child to develop and learn more slowly or differently than a typically developing child.  The most common causes of ID are genetic conditions, complications during pregnancy or birth, and diseases or toxic exposure.  For some individuals, the cause of their ID is unknown.  What is known is that individuals with ID often face barriers that prevent them from fully participating in their community.

Thats why I was pleased to see two events over the past weekend that highlight changing attitudes on the acceptance of individuals with an ID.  On Saturday, the opening ceremony of the Special Olympics World Games was held in Los Angeles, California.  And on Sunday, the United States marked the 25th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act, a law which ensures equal rights to persons with disabilities and prohibits discrimination in all areas of public life.

Founded by Eunice Kennedy Shriver, the Special Olympics is an organization that changes lives and advances human dignity through sport.  The Special Olympics provide sports training and athletic competition for children and adults with an intellectual disability, giving them opportunities to develop physical fitness, demonstrate courage, and experience joy.  Billed as the worlds largest sports and humanitarian event, people with an ID have been showcasing their athletic abilities to the world since the first Special Olympics in 1968.  Back then, a thousand people from 26 U.S. states and Canada gathered in Chicago, Illinois to compete in track and field, swimming, and floor hockey.  This week, 6,500 athletes and 2,000 coaches representing 165 countries will participate in 25 sports in the biggest athletic gathering in Los Angeles since the 1984 Olympics.

This will be the third time Cambodia has competed in the Special Olympics Summer Games.  Cambodia is represented by a delegation of eight athletes and five coaches and staff at the games and will be competing in the athletics competition and bocce.  I want to recognize the athletes  Uth Sam Ang, Meas Makara, Vorn Sochoulia, Kien Sreypov, Phally Ampor Pich, Thay Sokunthim, Poeung Vuthy, and Rath Samphors  for their dedication and perseverance to become members of Cambodias Special Olympics team.  As you compete to bring home the gold, I want to repeat the Special Olympics oath, Let me win, but if I cannot win, let me be brave in the attempt.

I am proud of the Cambodian Special Olympics athletes, as well as their families and coaches, for their tremendous accomplishment.  I am equally proud of all the people with intellectual disabilities in Cambodia who have participated in the Rural Expansion of Sports initiative, launched last year through a partnership with the Special Olympics, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), and the Royal Government of Cambodia.  This project is helping to recruit and train the next generation of athletes with intellectual disabilities so that they can represent Cambodia at the Special Olympics.  More importantly, this project is giving them an opportunity to participate in a sport as well as their communities.

Through the power of sport, I believe we can enable every member of society to lead full and meaningful lives.  Events like the Special Olympics help foster the acceptance and inclusion of all people.  By working together, I believe we can carry on the spirit of the Special Olympics to change attitudes and create a better world long after the games have ended.

I hope you will join me in cheering for the Cambodian athletes at the Special Olympics.
#AmbTodd #Cambodia

Meet Mr. Sam San, a Cambodian English teacher at Pannasastra University of Cambodia.  San is an alumnus of the U.S. State Departments E-Teacher Scholarship Program, which offers foreign English teaching professionals the opportunity to take one of nine innovative, online university-level classes through the University of Oregon.  As an alumnus, San was selected to participate in a recent three-day U.S. State Department sponsored seminar on Globalization and Language Education in Seoul, Korea.  The program brought together more than 50 E-Teacher alumni from the region to network and share experiences and ideas.

Now back home in Cambodia, San reflects on the program:  The seminar provided me with the opportunity to interact globally and network regionally using English as a norm. Moreover, it helps me to enhance my teaching career and opens my way to a bigger world ahead.

Our Continuing Support for the Roka Community
-From the Ambassador's Penh

In early December 2014, all of us in Cambodia heard the shocking news of a cluster of HIV cases in the Roka village located in Battambang province, affecting both young and old. The Ministry of Health (MOH) quickly and effectively responded to this outbreak, following appropriate procedures that have been put in place over many years. At the same time, the MOH reached out to partners to help investigate and respond to this outbreak. The United States did not hesitate in responding to the MOHs call for support, as part of our committed partnership with Cambodia to reduce the rate of HIV infection in the country. With funding from the Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), experts from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) continue to provide assistance to the Roka community and the entire country. 

 To date, there have been 212 people confirmed to be HIV positive as a result of the collaborative investigation in Roka village. We have actively engaged with the Ministry and other health partners, and there are a number of activities that the U.S. has supported to respond to the recent outbreak. Along with the technical advice that we provided to develop and implement the initial confirmation and investigation of the cluster, counseling and education services are being provided for people who were found HIV positive and the overall community. The local health center receives ongoing support in managing patient care and treatment, including identifying and treating opportunistic infections. We are providing treatment and adherence support through home visits to patients. Assistance is also directed towards laboratory testing and further analysis. 

 Cambodia is a recognized global leader in the fight against HIV/AIDS, having been able to rapidly respond to the epidemic by scaling up programs. The tragic situation in the Roka village illustrates the fact that despite Cambodias history of success, it is critically important to remain vigilant in identifying new cases and ensuring a strong health system is in place to respond. The U.S. government has been supporting HIV/AIDS efforts in Cambodia since the mid-1990s, providing more than $200 million dollars. As we look to the future, the United States remains committed to the global HIV/AIDS response and the goal of achieving an AIDS-free generation in Cambodia. Prior to the outbreak, the U.S. government worked with Cambodias National Center for HIV/AIDS, Dermatology and STDs (NCHADS) to establish a new case management system to actively track recently identified HIV patients and immediately enroll them in care, support, and treatment services. I am encouraged by this and other innovations that will play a vital role in assisting the Roka community and others throughout Cambodia. 

 During my time as U.S. Ambassador, I have been fortunate to have worked with and learned from several individuals dedicated to the fight against HIV/AIDS. Unfortunately, one of these people is departing Cambodia. Dr. Dora Warren, the CDC Country Director since October 2009, will soon begin her new role as CDC Country Director in Burma. During her time in Cambodia, Dr. Warren and her team focused on investigating outbreaks of diseases and cooperated with a wide range Cambodian and international partners to identify effective methods of prevention and treatment. For those of us who have interacted and worked with Dr. Warren, we are well aware of not only her professionalism and expertise; she is also a pleasure to spend time with and has a warm personality. She was dedicated to improving the overall quality of health in Cambodia, and her example served as inspiration for countless others. I want to thank Dr. Warren for her contributions to the Cambodian people and to the U.S. Embassy community. She has truly made a difference and will be greatly missed. 

 I am grateful for the hard work and important contributions of Dr. Warren and others committed to the fight again HIV/AIDS in Cambodia. To the people of the Roka community, we stand with you and will continue to provide support in dealing with the recent outbreak. In response to this tragic situation, I encourage everyone to honor people living with and affected by HIV/AIDS. The people of Roka need our compassion and ongoing care more than ever. Furthermore, it is important to recognize the hard work of health workers, scientists, and community members providing assistance. To reach the goal of an AIDS-free generation in Cambodia, we need to learn as much as we can from this recent event and renew our efforts to ensure that something like this does not happen again. 

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

Steve Jobs: "Getting fired from Apple was the best thing that could have ever happened to me"

In 2005, the late Steve Jobs, co-founder of Apple Inc., addressed the graduating class of Stanford University, in Palo Alto, California.  In his speech, Jobs explained how failure can sometimes lead to unexpected success.  

Jobs understood the power of perseverance - the ability to keep doing something despite difficulty or delay in achieving success.  As Jobs once said in an interview, "I'm convinced that about half of what separates the successful entrepreneurs from the non-successful ones is pure perseverance."

Watch Steve Jobs' speech in the video or read the text here: http://news.stanford.edu/news/2005/june15/jobs-061505.html.

Cambodian Youth: Bamboo Shoot is the Future Bamboo
-From the Ambassador's Penh

I firmly believe that supporting Cambodias children, from nutrition to health care to education, is the best investment that we can make in this countrys future. The government and the international development community have a big role to play, of course, but charitable giving can also have a significant impact.

I am particularly proud that many U.S. citizens and companies are contributing to this team effort through donations of time, money, and talent to make a positive difference for Cambodias children. One excellent example is John and Cammie Rice  two Americans who are committed to improving education in Cambodia.

On Wednesday morning, Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung represented the Embassy at a ceremony to celebrate the opening of the Rice Academy  a new community-based education facility in Phum Russey run by a fantastic NGO called the  Cambodian Children's Fund (CCF).  The Rice Academy is the result of the support of John and Cammie Rice, who are making a major investment in Cambodias youth. The Rice familys contribution represents the spirit of giving that is an essential part of the character of the United States.

Thanks to their support, CCF will be able to provide quality education, healthcare, nourishment, and safe shelter to nearly 200 children living in one of Phnom Penhs most impoverished areas  and do it in a sustainable way in partnership with the Cambodian government.

All in attendance at the Rice Academy launch were honored by the presence of two forward-looking government leaders: Minister of Education Hang Chuon Naron and Minister of Commerce Sun Chantol. In his remarks, Minister Naron highlighted that supporting education for children requires the attention of not only governments and companies, but that every individual in the community has that responsibility. Mothers, fathers, grandmothers, and grandfathers provide the foundations of love and encouragement. Both ministers have shown their commitment to implement the necessary reforms in their respective ministries to give young Cambodians more of the support they need to succeed in life.

John Rice is the Vice Chairman of General Electric (GE), which is one of the most famous and iconic U.S. companies. Like many U.S. businesses, GE has a long history of contributing to local communities around the world through its corporate social responsibility program. GE is particularly active in Cambodia. Since 2009, GE has contributed more than $9 million dollars in advanced medical equipment to hospitals throughout the country and also provided the necessary training for using the equipment. In Phnom Penh, GE has donated advanced ultra sound equipment, x-ray machines, ventilators, and patient monitors to Calmette Hospital. On Thursday of this week, GE launched its new Safe Water for Cambodian Health Facilities program, which will provide water purification filters, training, and research to improve the quality of water for up to ten hospitals and clinics. GEs contributions are being used every day to save and improve lives of Cambodians.

I would also like to personally thank Scott Neeson, the executive director at CCF, and the many staff and volunteers for their commitment to the children of Cambodia. Scott left a successful career in the film business to dedicate his life to helping Cambodians. During my visit to CCF last year, I learned about the work that the organization is doing to provide quality education and other support services to underprivileged and vulnerable children so they can achieve their potential. Their community-based education model is a success because it also supports the students families. CCF believes that no mother should have to decide between sending her children to school and putting food on the table. I couldnt agree more. CCFs dedication to the children of Cambodia is truly inspirational.

I have no doubt that the Rice Academy will have a powerful and positive impact on the lives of the children of Phum Russey and for the future of Cambodia. There is a Khmer saying tompaing snorng russey, or bamboo shoot is the future bamboo. By helping these eager young bamboo shoots to grow, John and Cammie Rice are building a brighter future for all of Cambodia.

The U.S. Embassy Sale Open to the Public September 14 to September 17
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Krangmeas Computer, in conjunction with the  U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh, Cambodia is conducting a sealed-bid sale of excess vehicles, office and household furniture, household appliances, equipment, computers, and other items for the general public.
The sale will be located at Phum Kork Khlieng, Sangkat Phnom Penh Thmey, Khan Sen Sok,Street Oknha Try Heng 2011, west of Chamkar Pring resort, Wat Somrong Andaet, Phnom Penh, Cambodia

Date and Time of Sale 
September 14, 15 and 16
8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Sale items are available for inspection.
September, 17
8 a.m. to 10 a.m. The general public may inspect lots and place bids.
10:15 a.m. Bids will be opened. Successful bidders will have 15 minutes to make full payment in cash. Purchased merchandise must be removed on September 17  or on September 18 from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Conditions of Sale 
Public sale (Sealed-Bid Sale), property will be sold to the bidder offering the highest bid price for merchandise offered. 
Property is sold on an as-is, where-is, non-returnable basis for cash payment without refund or warranty. 
Krangmeas Computer reserves the right to reject any bid that is considered not to be commensurate with the value of the property, or to reject any bid where there is evidence of connivance, collusion, or bribery. 
Successful bidders will have to make full payment in cash to the Krangmeas Computer cashier at the sale site and remove all merchandise purchased within four business days after the sale. 
All arrangements and payment of cost necessary to effect removal of the property are the responsibility of the purchaser. 
In order to remove goods from the sale site, you must present a signed receipt and other documents issued by Krangmeas Computer cashier showing payment in full as well as a receipt(s) showing taxes or customs duties paid. 
The tax rate is 26.50%.

Kent State University in the U.S. state of Ohio shares a special historical link with #Cambodia. On May 4, 1970, four unarmed students were killed during a demonstration against the announcement of U.S. military action in Cambodia. In remembrance of this pivotal moment in U.S. history, Kent State is hosting an educational series this week entitled Cambodia After Kent State. Event organizers include Cambodian graduate student Savina Sirik and Professor Dr. James Tyner, who has been working with the Documentation Center of Cambodia (DC-Cam) for the past 20 years.

The event features discussions with S-21 survivor Chum Mey and author of First They Killed My Father Luong Ung, as well as a special screening of the award-winning Dont Think Ive Forgotten hosted by director John Pirozzi and Khmer Rouge survivor LinDa Siphan. To learn more, please visit http://www.kent.edu/kent/news/kent-states-may-4-visitors-center-host-discussions-cambodia-after-kent-state.

By Jennifer 8. Lee
Fortune cookies are universally recognized in the United States, but they confuse people in China. If you give fortune cookies to the Chinese, they are utterly perplexed. First they ask you, What is it? When you tell them its from America, they will nod. Then they will bite into it and become startled when they find a little piece of paper either in their mouth or in this cookie. They ask you what that paper is. You tell them, Its a fortune. They will mutter, Americans are so strange. Why are they putting pieces of paper in their cookies?

Here's what Ambassador Heidt had to say about his meeting today at the Ministry of Labor and Vocational Training:
"I really enjoyed meeting Minister of Labor and Vocational Training Ith Samheng today. We had worked together closely in the late 1990s when I was the Economic Officer at the Embassy and #Cambodias garment industry was just getting started. I told the Minister that the United States is committed to working with Cambodia on labor and vocational training issues, and that I was very impressed by the growth of the garment industry over the past 15 years. The large increase in employment, factories, and shipments to America (over $3 billion in 2015) have all been good for Cambodia. The Minister briefed me on the Ministrys very broad reform agenda and important issues like harmonizing industrial relations, implementing the new trade union law, guaranteeing freedom of association, improving the minimum wage setting process, and rolling out a social security labor law.  

To me, the key challenge facing the garment sector today is improving perceptions among Cambodias international partners about conditions in the industry. It will be important to implement the new trade union law fairly and transparently, further refine the minimum wage setting process, settle industrial disputes professionally and fairly, and improve working conditions across the industry. I think Cambodia could make progress on some of these issues quickly, like developing a safer transportation system for garment factory workers and understanding the mass fainting issue better. I look forward to working with the Minister and his team to do just that." - #AmbHeidt

 Heidt  
                 ( )

More U.S. companies are choosing to invest in #Cambodia. For example, Starbucks just opened its third location in the country - the company's flagship store on Street 57 in Phnom Penh's BKK1 neighborhood. Jacqueline Kennedy visits Cambodia in November 1967 as a personal guest of Prince Sihanouk. A crowd of 10,000 greets her at Pochentong Airport in Phnom Penh, including girls strewing jasmine petals in a traditional Buddhist welcome. During her trip, the former First Lady fulfills a lifelong dream of visiting Angkor Wat. She is the first American to be received with high state honors since ties were broken, signaling a promising turn in the relationship.

 Jacqueline Kennedy

Dear All, Scholarship Opportunity:

USAID      

A recent workshop by the #Cambodia Ministry of Environment called for assistance in exploring the effects of climate change on available groundwater in Cambodia.  Through USAID Cambodia's liaison U.S. Pacific Command (PACOM), the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers responded to the Ministry's need to measure and monitor groundwater resources.  

 Evan Ting            Andrea Stone  USAID

The workshop opening ceremony included U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Program Manager Evan Ting, Ministry of Environment Officials Secretary General H.E. TIN Ponlok and H.E Madam Mey Bouthwithy and #USAID's Andrea Stone. 

            

The event continued with workshop participants from other Ministries and local NGOs conducting a site visit to the Batheay District of Kampong Cham, discussed methods for determining groundwater table at a former mine pit near Cheung Chhnok Village and weighed options for water distribution/treatment techniques at the water tower for the Tang Krang commune.  All involved came away with concepts and tools that can be used to further study the impact of climate change in Cambodia.    

 
To see more photos from this event, go to https://www.flickr.com/photos/usaid_cambodia/sets/72157669279097513/with/28850840371/

Visit the U.S. Embassy's Flickr page (goo.gl/yBl05M) for photos from the recent visit to #Cambodia by the senior economic official at the U.S. Department of State, Under Secretary of State for Economic Growth, Energy, and the Environment Catherine Novelli.

During her June 8-10 visit, Under Secretary Novelli joined #AmbHeidt and senior Cambodian government officials for a helicopter tour of Prey Lang Forest, organized by USAID Cambodia's Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project. She later met with Sok Chenda of the  The Council for the Development of Cambodia, Acting Minister of Commerce H.E. Kem Sithan, and a diverse group of Cambodian women entrepreneurs. Under Secretary Novelli also lent her expertise to a panel discussion on Unlocking Cambodias Creative Economy, which was live-streamed and still available for viewing on the Embassy's Facebook page. Finally, she was able to meet with our partners at the World Monuments Fund in Siem Reap to visit the U.S.-funded restoration of Phnom Bakheng Temple and other temples in the Angkor Park complex. We were proud to welcome Under Secretary Novelli to Cambodia and she had an amazing time here. To find out more about her activities, follow her on Twitter at @CathyNovelli.

On World Wildlife Day (March 3), The U.S. Ambassador's Youth Council gave a presentation on wildlife protection to 30 students majoring in Environmental Studies.  Held at the American Corner at Passtra University of Cambodia in Phnom Penh, the presentation focused on the Youth Councils environmental protection projects, including a survey with 380 people to collect information on wildlife trafficking and the impact of land concessions on wildlife habitats in Cambodia.

The presentation was part of the Youth Councils efforts to raise awareness of wildlife protection among Cambodian youth, and to use examples of the Youth Councils work to encourage other young Cambodians to take actions to protect the environment.

On May 2 nearly 40 Cambodian natural resource managers completed a 2-week training to measure carbon in mangrove areas.

This exercise, funded by USAID and the USDA Forest Service, will help Cambodia better understand its carbon stocks - an important part of combatting global climate change.

The participants received hands on training in the mangroves of Koh Kong.

Photo: Chalita Sriladda

Julie Chung                (NAMRU-2)          

During a recent trip to Koh Kong and Sihanoukville Provinces, U.S. Embassy Charg de affaires Julie Chung observed how the U.S. Navy is working with its Cambodian partners to address issues with maritime security in the region.  She visited the Royal Cambodian Navys Ream Naval Base, where the United States previously donated six rigid-hull inflatable boats and is currently assisting with the repair and renovation of the naval bases pier.  Also, with assistance from the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit-2 Detachment (NAMRU-2), a brand new medical laboratory is now operating at the naval base, providing a significant upgrade in the quality of medical care for 3,000 service members and dependents as well as an additional 25,000 people living in surrounding communities.

The purpose of the training  supported by USAID - is to increase Cambodian journalists technical ability to produce unbiased and well-researched stories on electoral reform.  Twenty professional journalists from the The Cambodia Daily, The Phnom Penh Post, Voice of America, Radio Free Asia, Voice of Democracy, Cambodian News Channel, Womens Media Center Radio, and Club of Cambodian Journalists, participated in the training.

U.S. Embassy Statement on Victory Day
January 7, 2016

   

Cambodias Victory Day on January 7 marks the liberation of Phnom Penh from the Khmer Rouge, one of the most unambiguously evil regimes in history.  Victory over the Khmer Rouge is a victory shared by all Cambodians.  Today, we wish to express our grief for the loss of nearly two million lives and the disruption of so many others.  As friends of the Cambodian people, our strong wish is that Cambodians of all creeds continue to work together to build a more democratic and prosperous future.

                 

#Cambodia

Cambodian Womens Crisis Center:  Helping Women Help Themselves
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Over the last several years, I have spoken often about the many ways my life changed the day my baby girl was born.  I have said how important it is for my daughter to have the same opportunities for happiness and success as my sons.  In continuing with the theme of Womens History Month, I want to talk about a woman who works tirelessly to make a better future for at-risk women and girls  Pok Panhavichet, the Executive Director of the Cambodian Womens Crisis Center (CWCC).  Panhavichet was born in Kandal province and educated in Phnom Penh.  For many years, she has advocated for the rights of women and girls, having worked for the Cambodian government, international development agencies, and local civil society.

CWCC, founded in 1997, helps survivors of domestic violence, rape, and human trafficking recover from the suffering and violence they endured.  I believe the success of CWCC in ensuring the protection of womens rights is best summed up by their motto:  Helping Women Help Themselves.  One of the core functions of CWCC is to provide women and children refuge and support in one of three shelters they operate in Phnom Penh, Siem Reap, and Banteay Meanchey.  The shelters not only provide temporary safe accommodation for women and their children escaping violence, but also offers them medical care and counseling, legal protection, literacy and vocational training skills, and reintegration classes.

Another aspect of CWCCs response to violence against women is their legal assistance program, which aims to empower women to leave abusive or exploitive situations and to provide these women legal advice and support to hold the perpetrators accountable for their violent and criminal actions.  This service is vital, as many of the women are too poor to secure their own legal representation.

Human trafficking is a growing concern in Cambodia, and CWCC is there to assist women and children return to their homes and communities.  The organization has established a program to reduce unsafe migration by conducting campaigns that raise awareness on trafficking.

For years, CWCC has been at the forefront of changing peoples attitudes on violence against women.  They have partnered with government officials to provide training for police officers and local authorities to help them recognize and enforce the laws that protect the rights of women and children in rural communities across the country.  In nearly two decades of operations, CWCC has helped almost 20,000 people escape from suffering and rebuild their lives.  I want to thank Panhavichet for her outstanding leadership of CWCC and her commitment to empowering the victims of violence and human trafficking in Cambodia to build better lives for themselves and their children.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia CWCC

Ambassador Heidt gave remarks today at the National Committee for Counter Trafficking's meeting for #Cambodia's National Plan of Action to Counter Human Trafficking. Presided over by Deputy Prime Minister & Minister of Interior Sar Kheng, the event helped launch the new Cambodia Counter Trafficking in Persons (CCTIP) program and the Victim Identification Guidelines for human trafficking. For #AmbHeidt's full remarks, please visit: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/022516_sp.html.  

The CCTIP program - which will be administered by USAID Cambodia partner Winrock International - seeks to address root causes of trafficking by providing vocational training and employment opportunities to at-risk populations, increasing the likelihood of prosecutions, and strengthening local governance. The Victim Identification Guidelines - one of the key recommendations in the most recent U.S. Department of State Trafficking in Persons Report -  represent an important step in Cambodia's commitment to strengthening services and support to victims of human trafficking.

Using Mobile Technology to Improve Effective Political Outreach 
-From the Ambassador's Penh

With mobile phone penetration in Cambodia reaching over 90% of the population, there is tremendous opportunity for Cambodians to learn more about the positions and platforms of the political parties that want their votes.  One tool that can take advantage of the extensive use of mobile phones is Interactive Voice Response (IVR).  This tool is a great way to improve access to information for Cambodian voters  and thats why the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) is funding the use of IVR for Cambodias political parties.

Last week my deputy attended a workshop organized by USAIDs Accountability in Governance and Politics (AGAP) program to highlight the use of IVR technology with the political parties.  I was glad to see that most of the participants were from the youth wings of five parties  Cambodian Peoples Party (CPP); Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP); FUNCINPEC; Republic Democratic Party (RDP); and League for Democracy Party (LDP).

I understand that these five political parties established IVR platform hotlines in August of this year, and in the eight weeks since then, the hotlines have received over 17,000 calls.  The interest being generated among Cambodians is terrific, demonstrating the unprecedented potential of information technology to enable political parties to more effectively reach and mobilize the citizenry. Anyone can call the hotlines to find out more about each partys priorities, policies, and leadership.

The IVR workshop is a perfect example of how Cambodians are using technology to further expand democratic participation and become an informed electorate.  It also reminds me of the great success of the voter education IVR program that was established in the run-up to the 2013 parliamentary elections.  That one generated over 600,000 calls!

I am proud of the United States contributions to promoting technology and innovative tools to further democratic development.  Through the AGAP program, we are actively supporting political competition and promoting the accountability of elected leaders with activities like the IVR platform hotlines.  We also support constituency dialogues, womens forums, and leadership trainings.  These activities are designed to increase political party effectiveness and give the electorate a greater voice in the political parties.  

In addition, through the USAID-funded Development Innovations program, we support a Social Innovation Lab as a gathering place and learning center for the tech community.  The Lab is helping promote the use of technology to meet Cambodias development challenges by connecting resources with those in civil society and the private sector who most need to harness new technologies.

I encourage Cambodias political parties  small and large, old and new  to continue using technology, like the IVR hotlines, to provide information to voters.  Establishing ways for citizens to interact with the political parties and relay their concerns improves the sharing of information and strengthens democracy.  The potential for expanding the use of technology to promote Cambodias democratic development are limitless  so I hope you take advantage of it!  For more information about the IVR hotlines, you can check this website:  http://open.org.kh/en/spice#.VE9e2vmSygZ.

#AmbTodd

Do you work to create safe spaces for women and girls in your community?  Do you advocate for clean energy, green schools, or banning plastic bags?  Do you work with youth to build more peaceful communities?  If so, you might be a Community Solutions Leader!

The 2016 Community Solutions Program Application is officially open!!!  

We are looking for the best and brightest community leaders working in Transparency and Accountability, Environmental Issues, Tolerance and Conflict Resolution, and Women and Gender Issues.  The program is open to Cambodians between the ages of 25-38 who have at least two years of experience working on a community project or initiative.  Proficiency in spoken and written English is required.

The Community Solutions Program is a U.S. Department of State exchange program that helps leaders from Cambodia and around the world to strengthen their capacity for leadership and development in their home countries. Selected candidates will participate in: (1) a four-month U.S. fellowship with a local non-profit organization or government agency; (2) structured virtual learning and networking via the Online Community Leadership Institute; and (3) the design and implementation of follow-on projects in their home countries.

The application deadline is Friday, October 30, 2015.  For information on how to apply; please visit: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/community_solutions_program.html

If you have any questions about this opportunity please contact the U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh Public Affairs Section at NornS@state.gov

In this weeks column, Ambassador Todd points out why climate change matters to Cambodia and emphasizes the importance of taking action:

Climate change is a complex issue with global implications, but sometimes it is a small indicator of this threat that hits the closest to home.  This past weekend, there was a heavy rain storm over Phnom Penh, and the neighborhood around the U.S. Embassy flooded.  Close to a meter of water made it impossible to navigate the streets.  I later saw in the newspapers that the rising water flooded many peoples homes and damaged their property.  As higher frequency and greater intensity of severe weather events are linked to global warming, the dramatic flooding was a small but clear reminder of the impact of climate change and the importance of working together to address it. 

Please read the Ambassadors full column, Adapting to Climate Change, in The Cambodia Herald at http://goo.gl/IzW7ZS 

#AmbTodd #ClimateChange

Learn about U.S. Election:

Did you know? American people, technically, do not vote directly for the president and vice president.

When they cast their vote, they are actually voting for a group of people known as electors.

This indirect election system, called the Electoral College, reflects the federal governing system of allocating powers to a national government representing not only the people but also the states.

The Electoral College is composed of 538 electors.

Each elector casts one electoral vote following the general election. The candidate that gets more than half (270) wins the election.

Learn more about Electoral College: http://go.usa.gov/YHzG

Picture credit: www.c-spanclassroom.org

On this first day of #BlackHistoryMonth, we honor astronaut, physician, educator & entrepreneur Dr. Mae Jemison. On September 12, 1992, Dr. Jemison became the first African American woman to travel in space when she went into orbit as a crew member on NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Space Shuttle Endeavour. Prior to this historic feat, she was also a Peace Corps Medical Officer and volunteered in a Cambodian refugee camp in Thailand. Today, Dr. Jemison is a worldwide respected leader and voice in the fields such as space exploration, sustainability, and #STEM - science, technology, engineering and mathematics education.

Every February, the United States celebrates the heritage of African Americans and their contributions to the world. The U.S. experience shows that diversity and social inclusion are valuable goals that all societies can pursue. To find out more about Black History Month, visit http://www.africanamericanhistorymonth.gov/.  

(Photo Credit: NASA)

#CamWomenCan: Suos Srey Len, Coca-Cola Forklight Operator

In both #Cambodia and the United States, transportation and warehousing are male-dominated professions. But dont tell that to Ms. Suos Srey Len - one of 3 female forklift operators and 6 female truck drivers working at Coca-Cola in Phnom Penh! We think Len and her colleagues may be the first female forklift operators in Cambodia!

Srey Len is 26 years old and has been driving a forklift at Coca-Cola for two years. When talking about why she loves her job, she said: I was hesitant to take the role as forklift driver when I was first asked because the job is generally for men. With encouragement from my family and friends, I decided to take the job. At first, I was nervous; but after a period of time, I got used to it.

The Coca-Cola Company  one of Americas largest and best known companies  is a leading U.S. investor in Cambodia. It is known for its global commitment to empowering women, both through its hiring practices and its programs that help women entrepreneurs throughout the Coca-Cola value chain.

In his weekly column released Sunday, Ambassador Todd addressed the topic of raising the minimum wage for garment workers in Cambodia:

A minimum wage that is determined through a fair and transparent process based on scientific research and international standards is critical for a healthy economy, and workers and management both benefit when workers receive such protections.  Importantly, our emphasis is not so much on a specific number but rather on the methodology that is used to determine the minimum wage.  As Cambodia seeks to become a destination of choice for international companies, it is important to recognize that international brands must carefully guard their image, which in turn depend on the image of the factories and countries from which they source their products.  Cambodias reputation and practices with respect to labor rights and working conditions in the textile factories, therefore, matter greatly.

Read this week's full column entitled, Establishing a New Minimum Wage for Cambodian Workers here http://goo.gl/6i0F88

U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh, Cambodia will be closed on Monday, October 10, 2016, in observance of Columbus Day, a U.S. holiday. Business operations will resume as usual on Tuesday, October 11, 2016.
This blog post is by Captain Lisa Franchetti, commodore of DESRON 21 and mission commander of Pacific Partnership 2010.

Partners in Promoting Health in Cambodia 
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Today, we live in an increasingly mobile world where people have the ability to travel to a different continent in a matter of hours.  However, this also means that diseases can cross borders and oceans as freely as humans.  The people of Cambodia are its greatest asset and a healthy population is critical to the countrys economic development.  Keeping everyone around the world and in Cambodia healthy requires international cooperation.  Im proud that the U.S. government is committed to helping the Cambodian people have a healthy future.  Roughly one half of our development assistance in Cambodia is dedicated to health programs that are combatting diseases such as malaria, and weve seen some tremendous successes in recent years.

Our efforts to improve the health of Cambodians involve more than just development agencies.  Last week, Lieutenant General Patricia Horoho, U.S. Army Surgeon General and Commander of the U.S. Army Medical Command, visited Cambodia to assess U.S. military research units in the country and to discuss bilateral cooperation between the United States and Cambodia on a variety of health issues.  Lieutenant General Horoho is the first woman and first nurse to ever hold the title of Surgeon General in the 239-year history of the U.S. Army.

Along the Cambodia-Thailand border north of Siem Reap, Lieutenant General Horoho reviewed the bilateral malaria control activities of the Armed Forces Research Institute of Medical Sciences (AFRIMS), one of the U.S. Armys premier research units, and the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces (RCAF).  The border area is currently home to a strain of malaria resistant individuals to some of the most powerful and effective drugs available.  In partnership with Cambodias National Malaria Center (NMC) and the RCAF, AFRIMS has been working to build research capacity and conduct high quality biomedical research in Cambodia to develop new drugs to fight the spread of malaria.  

In Phnom Penh, Lieutenant General Horoho toured the laboratories of the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit-2 Detachment (NAMRU-2), which work with NMC and other government health offices to conduct research and surveillance detection for malaria and other infectious diseases.  Lieutenant General Horoho also met with Cambodian health officials, toured the RCAF Health Science Institute, and visited the Preah Ket Mealea Army Hospital.

During her visit, Lieutenant General Horoho also took time to talk about the Armys new wellness campaign, the Performance Triad as it is called, which emphasizes getting quality sleep, engaging in activity, and improving nutrition.  By taking these steps to take care of ourselves, we can improve our health to be able to lead productive, long, and happy lives.  After all, as the saying goes, Your health is your greatest wealth.

I want to thank Lieutenant General Horoho for her visit to highlight the continuing collaboration between the United States and Cambodia in the effort to improve the health of the Cambodian people.  By partnering with RCAF and Cambodias government health sector, the U.S. military complements the efforts of other U.S. government agencies in the Kingdom to assist Cambodians to lead healthy lives.  I would also like to recognize the Lieutenant General for being an excellent role model for girls to pursue a career in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).  Her rise to become the U.S. Army Surgeon General, the highest-ranking position in the Armys medical department, is a tribute to her hard work and dedication.  I hope that more girls and young women, especially here in Cambodia, will consider a career in the STEM fields.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

April 30 is International Jazz Day! 

Jazz  a music genre that originated in African-American communities in the southern United States during the late 19th and early 20th centuries  is celebrated for its diverse cultural traditions and musical styles.  International Jazz Day was designated by the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) to generate global appreciation for the art form and as a way to foster unity among different cultures.
 
Last night, President Obama and the First Lady hosted an International Jazz Day concert on the South Lawn of the White House.  The full concert will air at 8 p.m. on April 30 (7 a.m. in Cambodia on Sunday, May 1), and will be available on the United Nations, UNESCO, U.S. State Department and White House websites.
 
In the meantime, to see some more great jazz watch and listen to these musicians, each with their own unique style. http://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2016/04/28/475892969/throwback-thursday-five-great-jazz-tiny-desk-concerts

Captain Mark J. McCadden and other members of the U.S. Coast Guard Port Security Team, who are visiting Cambodia for its biennial port inspection in connection with the International Port Security Program (IPS Program), pose with their Cambodian counterparts at the Sihanoukville Port on September 12.

36 Countries Issue Joint Statement of Concern on Human Rights in #Cambodia

    

A joint statement expressing concern about the human rights situation in Cambodia was issued today at the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) in Geneva, Switzerland. The statement was read by U.S. Ambassador to the UNHRC Keith Harper on behalf of Albania, Australia, Canada, Japan, Macedonia, Norway, Switzerland, the 28 EU member states, and the United States.

       Keith Harper            

The statement reads in part: We are deeply concerned about the current escalation of political tensions in Cambodia, which threatens legitimate activities by opposition parties and human rights NGOs.  There is particular concern about the appearance that legal action is being disproportionately pursued against critics of the government. We are equally concerned about the status of culture of dialogue between the two main political parties, which has ceased to function. We lament the recent murder of commentator and analyst Kem Ley and note the chilling effect this crime has had upon civil society and independent voices in Cambodia.

                  

The statement also reiterates previous calls by UN Special Rapporteurs to to ensure a safe and enabling environment for human rights defenders and civil society, which play a critical role in holding the Government to account and bringing benefits of human rights to the whole of Cambodian society.  

      

The full statement is available in English here: https://kh.usembassy.gov/human-rights-situation-cambodia-joint-statement/   

  https://kh.usembassy.gov/km/human-rights-situation-cambodia-joint-statement-km/

Ramadan Kareem
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Muslims around the world are observing Ramadan, Islams holiest month, which started last week.  During this period of reflection and renewal, Muslims fast from dawn until sunset daily to increase their thankfulness and consciousness of Gods mercy.  This time is also characterized by the act of giving  Muslims reach out to assist those afflicted by conflict, hunger, poverty, and disease.  Here in Cambodia, the Cham Muslim minority are also observing Ramadan, which is one of the five pillars of Islam.  During my tenure as Ambassador to Cambodia, I have made it a priority for the U.S. Embassy to build connections and strengthen the bonds of friendship with every community in Cambodia, including the Cham Muslim population.

Throughout the year, the U.S. Embassy engages with Cambodian Muslims in an effort to help strengthen their communities through a number of programs.  For example, we have hosted Iftar events for the Muslim community to celebrate Eid al-Fitr, the conclusion of Ramadan.  Our English Access Microscholarship Program provides opportunities to hundreds of Cambodian students each year  particularly in Islamic communities  to improve their English language skills.  In a previous blog, I wrote about how the English Access program enabled Afiny Math to find employment using her English skills to build a brighter future for herself and her family.

Additionally, we have promoted the themes of religious tolerance and anti-violence in youth-oriented Peace Concerts held throughout the country.  Tens of thousands of Cambodians attended the concerts this year in Banteay Meanchey, Battambang, Kampong Cham, Kampong Chhnang, Pursat, and Tboung Khmum provinces.  Our Muslim Dialogue Program allows Cambodian Muslims to participate in workshops with guest speakers from throughout Southeast Asia.  The workshops focus on a variety of key topics, including interfaith cooperation, womens empowerment, community leadership, and conflict resolution.  The U.S. Embassy also supports Cham Muslim heritage through the publication of Mukva  a periodical written in both the Khmer and Cham languages.  This periodical is the first of its kind in Cambodia and provides information and stories relevant to the Cham Muslim population, helping to preserve an important component of Cambodias cultural and linguistic heritage.

These are just a few of the many U.S.-sponsored programs that are helping Cambodian Muslims to develop skills and gain knowledge that will help them achieve their goals in life and contribute positively to their communities and to Cambodian society.  I look forward to continuing to strengthen these bonds of friendship and cooperation with the Muslim community in Cambodia.

Finally, I would like to extend a Ramadan Kareem to all Muslims this month.  I hope this Ramadan is filled with blessings for you and your families.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

U.S. State Department Spokesman John Kirby lists his most important foreign policy moments of 2015.

Today the Secretary sent a note to State Department staff summing up a busy year and charting the course ahead. His message got me thinking about the pivotal foreign policy events that took place this year, and a great hashtag  #2015in5Words  which was recently trending on Twitter.

Surely the year was not without challenges. Our hearts are with the families that lost loved ones to terrorism, natural disasters, disease, and violence. Our work to secure our national interests and to build peace and enhance prosperity around the world continues in honor of them. 

At the same time, its also important to take a step back and look at how the United States has helped change the world for the better. Our diplomats have been busy, and they have met with significant success across a range of issues  each of these issues vital in their own way to ensuring the safety, security, and prosperity of the American people. So, here's my take on #2015in5Words.
