Friends International: Socially Responsible Business in Cambodia 
-From the Ambassador's Penh

I recently spoke with members of my team at the U.S. Embassy about their visit to the Phnom Penh office of Friends International.  Some of my readers may already be familiar with this award-winning international NGO, which was established in Cambodia in 1994 and its local NGO known as Mith Samlanh (friends in English).  Today, Friends International works with young people and their families in four different continents.  Among the long list of innovative programs and activities that my team learned about and observed in practice was how Friends International utilizes a social business model to support youth development in Cambodia.  By offering vocational training, employment, and other means for generating income, their social businesses provides an opportunity for both the young people and the organization to receive high social and financial returns.  While empowering youth, Friends International is also helping them to become more actively involved in improving the lives of others in Cambodia.

When Nobel Prize Laureate Professor Muhammad Yunus developed the social business model, he envisioned an enterprise that would be driven by more than just the goal of financial gain.  He once said, Business is a very beautiful mechanism to solve problems, but we never use it for that purpose. We only use it to make money.  It satisfies our selfish interest but not our collective interest.  The impact that the business has on people and their communities  not the amount of profit made in a given period  is what measures the success of a social business.  While financial profit may still be an objective, those funds are used to assist others, creating products and supporting programs that have a social purpose.  Here in Cambodia, more people are seeing the potential for the establishment and expansion of social business, and organizations like Friends International are sharing best practices that have begun to spread throughout the country. 

To ensure the organizations sustainability, Friends International operates a wide range of income generating activities.  Here in Cambodia, they have restaurants, a beauty salon, and other training businesses that give students from their Vocational Training Center the chance to gain experience in real business environments.  Parents are also given instruction on how to start their own social businesses so that they can earn income and send their children to school instead of having them work on the streets.  These activities also help the organization generate profit, with the money being used to fund additional projects that benefit youth and their families.  In fact, Mith Samlanh is able to fund more than half of its own financial needs directly with the income that comes from these social business ventures.

I have spoken before about the strong commitment that the U.S. Embassy has for individuals and organizations that support innovation, youth development, and economic empowerment in Cambodia.  We promote entrepreneurship not only as a means of expanding Cambodias middle class; socially responsible business can also play a valuable role in solving problems and advancing progress in the country.  While Friends International is a nongovernmental organization with a social purpose at the heart of its mission, the notion of social responsibility can be expanded throughout civil society and the business sector.  This is why Im especially proud of USAIDs support for this organization. From small and medium enterprises to large multinationals, more companies are emphasizing the importance of social responsible business practices in the economic development of Cambodia.  I would like to commend the efforts of organizations like Friends International, which is taking a lead role in helping others understand and utilize socially responsible business.  They serve as a remarkable example of how an innovative business model can be financially successful in Cambodia, all while having a positive social impact on the entire country.  

Do you have ideas about socially responsible business practices in Cambodia?  If so, please share your comments.

Last month, USAIDs Development Innovations project helped organize BarCamp in Rattanakiri.  The event attracted 425 young participants eager to learn more about tech-related subjects.  In its first appearance in the province, BarCamp offered 28 speakers presenting 43 topics throughout the weekend.  A panel discussion on "Start Up Business and Asian Integration" drew the largest audience, while topics as diverse as "Short Film Techniques" and "IT Careers in Cambodia" also had enthusiastic audiences.  For many youth, BarCamp provides a first exposure to information and learning opportunities on technology.  In addition to support from USAID - US Agency for International Development, the event was also sponsored by Build Bright University, Cellcard (Mobitel), Ezecom, and Sabay, among others.

What are the best ways to prevent the spread of Ebola?

Basic Ebola Facts from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC):
+ Ebola is not transmitted through the air.
+ Individuals who are not showing signs of illness, even if infected, cannot spread the virus to others.
+ Health care workers who meticulously follow standard procedures to protect themselves from infection will be safe and able to provide medical care while protecting the entire community.

Today, the  Ministry of Commerce hosted a press conference on the expansion of the U.S. General System of Preferences (GSP). The GSP expansion - which went into effect July 1 - means that #Cambodia can now export travel goods such as luggage, handbags, and wallets, duty free to the United States.   Ambassador Heidt, Minister of Commerce H.E. Pan Sorasak, and Chairman of GMAC - Garment Manufacturers Association in Cambodia Mr. Van Sou Leng welcomed the expansion as an opportunity to increase exports and create up to 100,000 jobs in Cambodia.  

This announcement has the potential to open up an entirely new market for Cambodian exporters and to create thousands of jobs for Cambodians," says #AmbHeidt. "We encourage Cambodian manufacturers to take advantage of this new opportunity, which would help to diversify Cambodias economic base, spur economic growth, and alleviate poverty. To learn more about GSP, visit https://ustr.gov/issue-areas/trade-development/preference-programs/generalized-system-preference-gsp.

"If I cross the finish line, it is the most powerful inspiration for the young generation." Nary Ly, Cambodian Olympic Athlete and Scientist.

        Rio      Heidt   (NAMRU-2)      

Long-distance runner Nary Ly represented Cambodia in the 2016 Rio Olympics, proudly finishing the marathon with the Cambodian flag on her back. Today, she shared her story with Ambassador Heidt and the staff of the U.S. Embassy, including her former colleagues at the Embassys Naval Medical Research Unit (NAMRU-2), where she worked as a scientist from 2011 to 2014.

      

Nary talked about her life as a runner, which started as a hobby during post-graduate studies before rising to Olympic levels. She also talked about the hard work that goes into preparing for an Olympic marathon, including training at high altitude in Africa.

       Rio 

Most impressive of all is Narys love for #Cambodia. Her desire to be a role model for young Cambodians carried Nary through fatigue, pain, and blisters all the way to the finish line in Rio.

#AmbHeidt and U.S. Foreign Agriculture Service Administrator Phil Karsting  visited students at Thlock and Wat Run Primary Schools in Siem Reap this past weekend to observe firsthand the outstanding work done by the World Food Programme (WFP) and the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).  These students are among thousands of children at 850 primary schools across #Cambodia receiving nutritious meals through USDA's McGovern-Dole Program, which encourages school attendance and provides lifelong lessons about nutrition and food safety. During the visit, Mr. Karsting signed an agreement to provide a $15.2 million grant which enables the WFP to continue a multi-year school feeding program that provides school and take home meals for approximately 160,000 children each year.  

Since 2001, USDA has provided a total of $45.8 million to the WFP.  The United States actively supports the WFPs goal to improve food security and nutrition for the most vulnerable while promoting long-term development in Cambodia through programs designed to break the poverty cycle. To learn more about these efforts taking place around the globe, please visit http://www.fas.usda.gov/programs/mcgovern-dole-food-education-program.

AmCham Night at the Embassy 
-The Ambassador's Penh

Last night, I was delighted to host the American Chamber of Commerce in Cambodia  better known as AmCham  for their monthly networking event.  It was a wonderful opportunity for the Cambodian business community, special guests, and members of the U.S. Embassy to meet one another, to learn about recent activities of the vibrant business community here, and to discuss ways we can work together.  We had a great turnout with over 200 guests representing the private sector and NGOs who came to network and develop new relationships for doing business in Cambodia.  Acleda Bank, Samaritans Purse, Visa, and the Cambodia Women Entrepreneurs Association represent some of the diverse guests who attended the event. 

The U.S. Embassys partnership with AmCham has played a critical role in our efforts to expand U.S. trade and investment in Cambodia.  Over the last two years, I have traveled with AmCham on two reverse trade missions to the United States and three regional trade missions to Thailand and Singapore.  We have also co-hosted a webinar on doing business in Cambodia and worked together on AmCham-sponsored roundtables that featured such speakers as Minister of Commerce Sun Chanthol and Minister of Education Hang Chuon Naron.  As I emphasized last night, Amcham members can be confident that my U.S. Embassy team is an advocate for building and expanding their outreach.

I am pleased we are starting to see the fruits of our cooperation.  More and more American companies are looking at increasing trade and investing in Cambodia.  Earlier this year Tiffany & Co., an iconic American jewelry company, opened a diamond-polishing factory in Cambodia.  Several other large U.S. companies are planning to start operations next year.

I want to thank everyone who attended the AmCham networking event.  Your presence made the night a tremendous success.  With your help, we can continue to attract new American companies, expand bilateral trade, and support investment in Cambodia.

AmCham and its members deserve considerable credit for the work they do to create a more secure and prosperous future for the people of the United States and Cambodia.  Amcham provides its members with a template for developing successful and efficient business methods, corporate social responsibility programs, ethical commercial practices, and nurturing future leaders through internship opportunities.  Are you interested in learning more about the role of AmCham in Cambodia or becoming a member?  For more information check out AmChams website(www.amchamcambodia.net) and one of my previous blog entries on this topic: The U.S. Embassy and AmCham  Working Together to Promote Business and Investment in Cambodia http://goo.gl/ikpC5N.

1991: At the Paris Conference in October, Phnom Penh and the anti-government resistance reach an historic peace accord, setting the stage for UN-administered elections. On November 14, Prince Norodom Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 13 years in exile. He rides from the airport into Phnom Penh in a 1963 Chevrolet Impala convertible, as a large crowd lines the road, cheering and waving flags. Later that month, the city celebrates its first water festival  one of the biggest celebrations on the Khmer calendar  since 1969.

1991: In November, the United States restores diplomatic relations with Cambodia, ends economic sanctions, and resumes development assistance. On November 11, a U.S. liaison office opens in Phnom Penh and Charles H. Twining is appointed U.S. Representative. By 1992, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) re-opens its permanent mission to Cambodia, and the agencys total budget for the decade reaches $264 million. U.S. assistance 
re-opens National Road 4, which was originally built by the United States in the 1950s and runs from Phnom Penh to the countrys only deep-water port, Sihanoukville.

1992: The UN Transition Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC) takes over administration of Cambodia. U.S. assistance pays for 30% of UNTACs budget and supports its mandate of establishing a freely elected government. Leading the mission is Yasushi Akashi, a senior UN diplomat in charge of 16,000 soldiers and 5,000 civilians. Two of these civilian advisors, American diplomat Timothy Carney and American academic Stephen Heder, supervise the opening of Cambodias first free press since 1972 and create Radio UNTAC, a popular source of unbiased information in Khmer.

1993: On May 28, 90% of Cambodians ignore threats of violence and vote in the countrys first democratic election, surpassing even the most hopeful predictions. FUNCINPEC party receives 45% of the vote, while CPP receives 38%. In September, the newly formed Constituent Assembly approves a constitution, and Norodom Sihanouk is crowned King. He appoints Prince Ranariddh as First Prime Minister and Hun Sen as Second Prime Minister.

1998: On April 15, Pol Pot dies of natural causes in a jungle camp near the Thai border. His body is cremated on a funeral pyre made of tires. The Khmer Rouge, which had been dwindling in numbers due to defections of key leaders, perishes with him. President Clinton who was in Chile at the time, issues a
written statement noting that ''Although the opportunity to hold Pol Pot accountable for his monstrous crimes appears to have passed, senior Khmer Rouge, who exercised leadership from 1975 to 1979, are still at large and share responsibility for the monstrous human rights abuses committed during this period. We must not permit the death of the most notorious of the Khmer Rouge leaders to deter us from the equally important task of bringing these others to justice.''

SECURITY MESSAGE FOR U.S. CITIZENS: Possible Demonstrations in Major Cambodian Cities

The U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh alerts U.S. citizens residing in or traveling to Cambodia of the heightened possibility of political demonstrations near Cambodias international airports in Phnom Penh and Siem Reap, on the evening of Monday, November 16, and possibly into the following day. Additional caution should be taken throughout Phnom Penh and other Cambodian cities. Press reports indicate the main opposition leader, for whom an arrest warrant has been issued, is scheduled to return to Cambodia late on Monday, November 16.

For more details, please visit: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/acs_111615.html.

#CamWomenCan: Women in Technology
"My goal is to be a leader in an IT company. I have a strong desire to improve technology and to encourage women in #Cambodia to work in this field." - Heng Somphas, Computer Science Engineering major at the Institute of Technology of Cambodia (ITC)

Pictured below are three outstanding women who are studying for careers in technology: Heng Somphas, Chea Sovannara (Information Technology, Thammasat University, Bangkok), and Chhin Chileap (Information and Communication Engineering, ITC). They're among a growing number of female university students with tech-related majors.  All three are currently serving as interns as they prepare to graduate and move on to exciting high-tech careers.

Somphas, Sovannara, and Chileap are following in the footsteps of other women pioneers. In his recent visit to the Pactics factory in Siem Reap, #AmbHeidt met Huonh Chun and Pour Choun, who both studied for two years at the National Polytechnic Institute of Cambodia in Phnom Penh.  Chun and Choun are currently finishing their probationary period at Pactics and will soon be working as Industrial Engineers for the company! Their message to other women interested in technology is simple: "Knowledge has nothing to do with gender. Believing in yourself is key!"

Call for Proposals: Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation 

What does the temple at Phnom Bakheng have in common with Khmer classical dance techniques?  What is the link between oral folklore and the earthworks at Cheung Ek?  All are part of the amazing cultural patrimony of Cambodia, and all are being preserved for future generations with help from the U.S. State Departments Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation (AFCP).

The AFCP is the U.S. governments flagship program to promote cultural heritage preservation and protection worldwide.  Since its creation in 2001, the AFCP has sponsored 16 grants in Cambodia totaling more than $2.3 million  the second highest figure for any country in the world!  For more information about the projects that have been funded in Cambodia, click here http://goo.gl/TVVWy0.

Meet United States Air Force Staff Sergeant (SSgt) Virak Dara, a first generation Cambodian-American serving at Cannon Air Force Base in the U.S. state of New Mexico. He is part of a Defense Institute for Medical Operations (DIMO) capacity-building mission in #Cambodia. The DIMO team - comprised of medical and public health experts from the Air Force and U.S. Public Health Service - spent this week teaching a course on disaster preparedness to emergency managers from each of Cambodia's provinces. Not only did SSgt Dara serve as support staff and translator for the team; since he grew up in Phnom Penh he was a cultural liaison during courses and exercises, helping to amplify the lessons taught by the instructors. The team's chief said, SSgt Dara is a real force multiplier, hugely contributing to this missions success."

SSgt Dara moved to the United States when he was 16 years old with his father, mother and older brother. Growing up in Lowell, Massachusetts, he graduated high school in 2004, attended college, and decided to join the Air Force in 2007. He has excelled in his military service, earning the title of distinguished graduate for Civil Engineering, serving two tours in Afghanistan, achieving high language proficiency through the Language Enabled Airman Program, and his recent promotion to the rank of E-6. Please join the U.S. Embassy in thanking SSgt Dara for his service - both to the United States and to Cambodia.

"Michelle and I send our warmest wishes to all those who will be celebrating the Lunar New Year this Sunday, February 10th.

Exchange Program Spotlight: Fulbright Foreign Student Program


Throughout International Education Week (November 17-21), the U.S. Embassy will highlight a different U.S. government-sponsored exchange program each day!

We will start with the oldest and most famous (and most competitive) of all of our exchange programs -- the Fulbright Foreign Student Program, which was started in 1946.  The Fulbright Foreign Student Program enables graduate students from abroad to study and conduct research in the United States at U.S. universities or other appropriate institutions -- usually for two years.  In Cambodia, the application period begins around June, approximately 15 months before the beginning of the academic program.

There are currently 14 Cambodians participating in the Fulbright Foreign Student Program in the United States.  Sivhoang Chea from Phnom Penh is a recent graduate from the University of California, Los Angeles.  According to Sivhoang:  "Through the Fulbright program I obtained my Master degree in Law (LL.M) in 2014, specializing in international law.  Two years ago, I had a career dream to participate in finding justice for Cambodian people who have suffered under the Khmer Rouge Regime.  Two months after graduation, I was employed as an associate legal officer in the Trial Chamber at the Khmer Rouge Tribunal.  Without the Fulbright program, I would not have achieved the dream I once had!"        
 
To learn more about the Fulbright program, please visit http://exchanges.state.gov/non-us/program/fulbright-foreign-student-program#sthash.ue3hPvyp.dpuf

Restarting the Water Festival Tradition
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Like many people in Cambodia, I was delighted to learn that the Water Festival would take place this year after a three-year hiatus.  The tragedy of 2010 should never be forgotten, but it is important that this great tradition continue now and long into the future.

I had the high honor to attend the opening ceremony of the 2014 Water Festival in the presence of His Majesty King Norodom Sihamoni on Wednesday afternoon, along with the Prime Minister and leaders from the National Assembly.  It was a delight to see the boats race gracefully down the river, much as they have for hundreds of years.  I also enjoyed some Ak Ambok, which I ate with banana and coconut juice.  It was a delicious treat!

The Cambodian Water Festival  or Bon Om Tuk  began as a way to honor the naval forces under King Jayvarman VII and to express profound thanks to the Tonle Sap and Mekong rivers.  Today, the rivers continue to be the life blood of Cambodia, providing food and jobs for millions.  Water Festival is an opportunity to consider the importance of rivers to Cambodians and to rededicate ourselves to protecting this precious resource.

The Water Festival in Phnom Penh is the biggest and best known in all of Cambodia, but Water Festivals are taking place across the country in towns big and small.  There is even a Water Festival in Lowell, Massachusetts, which is home to a large and active Cambodian community.  Although Water Festival in Cambodia takes place in October or November, the one in Lowell takes place in August when the weather is warm.

I hope that all of my readers have a wondrous Water Festival.  If you are coming to Phnom Penh from out of town, I wish you safe travels.  I would also like to congratulate all Cambodians on the 61st anniversary of your independence, on November 9.  I wish everyone peace and happiness as we celebrate this important day.

See more photos from the Water Festival opening ceremony and all of Ambasssdor Todd's blog posts here http://goo.gl/fOTn6D

The Office of Defense Cooperation (ODC) at the U.S. Embassy in Cambodia is pleased to invite young Cambodians to compete for appointment to the United States Service Academies for the Class of 2020.

An information brief on the appointment process will be conducted on Wednesday, October 7 at 2:00 p.m. at Passtra University of Cambodia, South Campus, No. 184, Norodom Boulevard (South of Independent Monument).  For directions you can contact (eduUSA@puc.edu.kh or 015 563 235).  

Interested applicants must: 
* Be unmarried and within 17-22 years old. 
* Have strong English proficiency.  
* Earn competitive scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) or the American College Test (ACT).
* Earn competitive scores on an Embassy-administered Candidate Fitness Assessment (CFA). You can learn about each part of the CFA with this YouTube video:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AlIZz9O7QiQ. 
* Have a medical exam showing they are free of communicable diseases or major health problems. 
* Perform well in an individual interview process administered by the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh in cooperation with the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces.

To help assess and prepare applicants for the scholastic and fitness tests, the ODC has scheduled practice tests at the U.S. Embassy.  If you meet the eligibility requirements listed above, contact the ODC at ODCCambodia@state.gov with your name, age, and contact information to reserve a place.    

Important dates:  
* October 15 at 2:00 pm  Practice SAT at the U.S. Embassy 
* October 16 at 6:00 am  Practice CFA at the U.S. Embassy
* October 22 at 2:00 pm  Practice SAT at the U.S. Embassy
* October 29 at 2:00 pm  Practice SAT at the U.S. Embassy
* October 30 at 6:00 am  Practice CFA at the U.S. Embassy
* November 1- Deadline for interested applicants to have completed at least one practice  SAT and one practice CFA.  Scores on these tests will be used to determine which  candidates are competitive enough to continue in the selection process.
* November and December  Competitive applicants will have individual interviews with members of the U.S. military and the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces.  

For more information, visit the U.S. Embassy web site at   http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/the_united_states_service_academies.html

"The U.S. Embassy has long worked with Cambodia to help protect the Kingdoms unique historical and cultural heritage, and last week we had another milestone in the history of this important partnership  the launch of an online catalog by the National Museum of Cambodia. 

This inventory project, which began all the way back in 2004, documents the museums entire collection of over 16,400 works of art. I am pleased to recognize the role of the Center for Khmer Studies, a leading U.S.-funded educational organization in Cambodia, for training the museums staff to photograph and enter information on each object into the new searchable database. 

Now, museum curators and others around the world can quickly find and identify any object in the National Museums holdings  making Cambodias rich cultural heritage available to anyone, anywhere, with an Internet connection..."

Staff at the U.S. Embassy are getting into the Halloween spirit!

In the United States, Halloween is celebrated on October 31.  While it is not an official holiday, Halloween is much beloved by children, for whom the day is a chance to dress up in costumes and knock on neighborhood doors shouting "Trick or Treat!" to collect candy.  Americans also celebrate Halloween by carving pumpkins, decorating homes with witches, ghosts, and black cats, and going to parties.

Excessive bleeding after child birth is the leading cause of maternal death in Cambodia.

USAID is supporting efforts to find new and effective ways to stop these deaths.

With 70% of Cambodian women delivering at local health centers, the newly introduced anti-shock garment is an efficient, simple and inexpensive solution to temporarily reduce bleedingjust long enough to transport critical patients to a better equipped hospital.

While still being piloted, usage of this garment has a potential to save hundreds of women's lives across Cambodia.

Credit: URC/BHS, Heng Vinmony

The U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh will be closed from Friday, February 1, to Monday, February 4, for the King Fathers cremation and associated activities.

An influx of over three million people into Phnom Penh is expected during this four-day period, with many activities centered in the Wat Phnom area.

Due to the increase in population and government-mandated road closures, movement around the city will be heavily restricted.

The U.S. Embassy advises all U.S. citizens to exercise caution while traveling in and around Phnom Penh, and strongly recommends avoiding large crowds.

The Embassy will reopen Tuesday, February 5.

http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/embassy_will_be_closed.html

Clinton  Trump      !    Massachusetts   Middlesex    Lowell 

A historic election will take place this year in the United States, but were not talking about Clinton vs. Trump. We are talking about Rady Mom vs. Kamara Kay! These two Cambodian-Americans will face off against each other in November for a seat in the Massachusetts state legislature. The two candidates are battling to represent the 18th Middlesex District, which encompasses the city of Lowell.

       

Kamara Kay was born in Battambang province and arrived in the United States as a refugee in 1982. He is a senior analyst at an information technology firm.

         Massachusetts    

Rady Mom was born in the Pailin province in 1970 and naturalized as a U.S. citizen in 1990.  He won election to the Massachusetts legislature in 2014 and is now running for a second term.

Did you know that Cambodias Tonle Sap Lake is designated a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve?  

In the wet season, the Tonle Sap is one of the largest freshwater lakes in Asia, swelling to 12,000 square kilometers before shrinking back to 2,500 square kilometers during the dry season. It is an important food source for local people and a breeding ground for large water birds.

 Sotie     String Quartet                  

The U.S. Embassy joins the people of #Cambodia in celebrating the 80th birthday of Her Majesty Queen-Mother Norodom Monineath Sihanouk on June 18. Earlier this week, Mrs. Sotie Heidt was part of a Royal Audience with Her Majesty at the Pavilion Serey Mongkol. The Queen-Mother seems happy and in good health," said Sotie. "Of course, she is always the most classically beautiful person in the crowd!"   

Sotie was honored to receive a gift book from the Queen-Mother that included pictures from memorable events in Her Majesty's life, including the May 8, 2016 concert by The United States Air Force Band String Quartet that was dedicated to His Majesty King Norodom Sihamoni and Her Majesty the Queen-Mother. Please join us in saying "Happy Birthday" to the Queen-Mother and wishing her good health and happiness.

Helping the World Remember Cambodias Past
-From the Ambassador's Penh

In previous blogs, I have highlighted the tireless efforts of Youk Chhang and the Documentation Center of Cambodia (DC-Cam), which works to document Khmer Rouge atrocities while helping Cambodians reconcile with their past and move towards a brighter future.  With the worlds largest repository of documents and other original materials related to the Khmer Rouge era, DC-Cam has contributed to a number of research projects, education and outreach programs, and even the legal cases against former Khmer Rouge leaders.  Now, thanks in large part to DC-Cam, even more people around the world can learn about Cambodias history.

This week, in partnership with DC-Cam, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, D.C. inaugurated two special exhibits on Cambodia and the Khmer Rouge.  As one of the worlds most important museums related to genocide, the Holocaust Museums education and outreach programs have helped inspire citizens worldwide to confront hatred, prevent genocide, and promote human dignity.  Although the museum focuses on the Holocaust  the mass murder of six million Jewish people in Europe in the 1930s and 1940s  it also hosts special exhibits on other mass atrocities, such as those which occurred during Khmer Rouge era.

While I could not attend the opening in person, my good friend and colleague Ambassador Scot Marciel, Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, was there to represent the State Department and provide opening remarks.  He noted that the exhibits  like the work of the Khmer Rouge Tribunal and all those who strive to ensure that these tragic events are remembered  will continue to be essential for Cambodians, Americans, and the rest of the world to understand this past and move towards a brighter future.

The two exhibits  Cambodia 19751979 and I Want Justice!  explore the cruel actions taken by the Khmer Rouge and the international communitys efforts to pursue justice for the victims and hold accountable those responsible for these crimes.  In the Cambodia 19751979 exhibit, museum visitors learn about the terror of the Khmer Rouge era through historical photographs, film, and contemporary art that depict the regimes establishment of its Democratic Kampuchea forty years ago.  By some estimates, up to two million Cambodians died as a result of execution, starvation, exhaustion, or disease during this four year period.  The exhibit features images of Phnom Penhs two million residents being driven out of the city within hours and sent to the countryside, where they were quickly pressed into forced labor brigades on massive earthworks and rice paddies.  Visitors will experience a profound sadness when observing this exhibit, but for many Cambodians, these tragic events of the past are at times impossible to view.

However, in the I Want Justice! exhibit, visitors can find out about the current efforts to hold perpetrators of genocide and mass atrocities accountable through court proceedings, including the ongoing Khmer Rouge Tribunal (KRT)  for which the U.S. government has provided millions of dollars in contributions each year.  The exhibit also looks at ways Cambodian survivors are seeking other forms of justicepersonal, cultural, historicalas they continue to struggle with the legacy of the murderous Khmer Rouge era.  With its extensive outreach and educational programming to help Cambodians and the rest of the world understand the history of the Khmer Rouge, it is no surprise that DC-Cam played a significant role in bringing the exhibit to the United States and helping people to heal.

The exhibits will run through October 2017, giving people an opportunity to learn about a critical part of Cambodias history and reflect on what it means today.  The website of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum also features details about the exhibits for those interested in learning more about Cambodias history.  I encourage more people  especially youth  to take the time to learn more about the mistakes of the past so that they are not repeated in the future.  The crimes that occurred during the Khmer Rouge era are almost too horrific to mention, but the stories of the victims must continue to be told lest we forget.  

(Photo courtesy of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum)
http://www.ushmm.org/information/exhibitions/museum-exhibitions/cambodia-1975

On November 6, Cambodian Member of Parliament Mu Sochua was recognized as one of San Francisco State Universitys alumnae of the year in a ceremony in San Francisco, California.  According to the university:

The Honorable Mu Sochua, who graduated from SF State in 1979 with a B.A. in psychology, will also receive recognition as one of the alumnae of the year.  Sochua is a member of the Cambodian parliament and was formerly that country's minister for women's affairs.  As a political activist, Sochua has worked tirelessly to improve conditions for women in Cambodia by taking on issues including domestic violence, the spread of HIV/AIDS and abuse toward minors.

Congratulations to Mu Sochua on this outstanding accomplishment!

USAID just launched Family Care First, a call to action to identify solutions that give Cambodias lost children a fighting chance.  The program will support children at risk of separating from their families or already separated from their families or orphaned because of poverty, safety concerns, or the fact that many of them are not able to benefit from health, education or other services. YSEALI River Rehabilitation Project, Day Two 

On Sunday, Professor Pallant and the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) team had another full day of activities.  They started the morning by visiting the Royal University of Agriculture (RUA) in Phnom Penh where Professor Pallant delivered a seminar on River Rehabilitation to 50 university students.  The students showed strong interest in the topic by asking tough questions and sharing what they were learning.  

After the seminar, the team and Professor Pallant were escorted by RUA faculty and staff to learn about an aquaponics experiment being conducted by RUA students.  Aquaponics is the method of growing crops and fish together in a re-circulating system. The water from the fish tank is filtered and then used in a hydroponic farming system, where the plants are not in soil but get their nutrients from water.  As the water leaves the hydroponic system, it flows back into the fish tank.  

The team then headed to one of Phnom Penhs four water treatment plants, this one located in northern Phnom Penh.  In coordination with the Phnom Penh Water Supply Authority (PPWSA), Professor Pallant and the YSEALI team got to see the water treatment process up close and understand how PPWSA treats the undrinkable water from the river in order to supply clean water to households in Phnom Penh. 

Monday is Professor Pallants last day in Cambodia before he continues his three-country Streams of Hope River Rehabilitation Speaker Tour in the Philippines, and then on to Vietnam.  

Professor Eric Pallant, Chair of the Environmental Science Department at Allegheny College in Pennsylvania, USA, is visiting Cambodia, the Philippines, and Vietnam to help the three-country YSEALI team with their Streams of Hope project. Members from Cambodia, the Philippines, and Vietnam joined together to focus on maintaining clean water resources in the region. As part of the U.S. Department of States Speaker Program, Professor Pallant is meeting with high school and university students, members of civil society, government officials, and others who have a stake in maintaining clean water resources.

You can follow Professor Pallants trip throughout the region on Facebook. He is in Cambodia until September 15, then he will be in Manila for three days where you can follow him on U.S. Embassy, Manila Philippines Facebook page, and then on to Hanoi for three days where you can follow him on the U.S. Embassy in Hanoi Facebook page.

You can also follow Dr. Pallants trip via Twitter with #StreamsOfHope.

To join Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) and partner on projects like this, visit: http://goo.gl/c2ORS0

Cambodian-American performance artist Anida Yoeu Ali has been named winner of this year's prestigious Sovereign Asian Art Prize.  The Sovereign Art Foundation chose her original artwork out of 236 nominations from 13 countries in the Asia-Pacific, including Australia, Singapore, Pakistan, and Dubai.  Ali said she hoped that in winning the award she would motivate and inspire other artists to keep pursuing contemporary art-making and performance art, no matter how difficult.  Ali is a Muslim-Khmer who escaped the Khmer Rouge to the United States.  She is also co-founder of Studio Revolt, an independent artist-media lab in Phnom Penh.  Read the full story from Voice of America here: http://bit.ly/1IiuIwg

Social Media in Cambodia 
-From the Ambassador's Penh

If you are reading this blog, you probably have access to a computer and have a Facebook account.  Cambodians are increasingly connected online, and the U.S. Embassy in Cambodia is proud to be a small part of this technological revolution.  

When I began my service as the U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia, our Facebook page had just over 25,000 fans.  Today, a third of 1 million fans along with more than 34,000 Twitter followers  prove that Cambodians want to connect with us and receive news about the programs we support.  Furthermore, it shows that people want to participate in dialogue on important issues in the country.  All of you who have commented on our Facebook page, responded on my blog, or have sent me questions for my weekly Ask the Ambassador column, have greatly contributed to the valuable conversations we are having about Cambodias future.

Today, the Internet provides unprecedented reach and freedom for people to gather information and express their opinions.  Even more important, this technology is interactive, allowing users to select the content they find most useful and relevant in their lives.  This ability to access accurate and independent information is the engine of a free and democratic society.  Despite low access to the Internet in several parts of the country, the fact that so many Cambodians are taking advantage of online resources when they are available is an indication of their desire to be well-informed, active participants in the countrys growing democracy.    

With 1.23 billion users across the world, Facebook has become an increasingly important way of obtaining information not only about friends and family, but also about world events.  Along with Twitter, YouTube, and other platforms, social media is having a tremendous impact on the way Cambodians are receiving and sharing information about what is happening in the country and around the globe.  The attraction of social media is that it enables a two-way dialogue, something that is not possible with traditional media.  This form of communication has continued to grow in significance and now serves as a powerful tool for soliciting ideas and feedback on the issues that matter to Cambodians, particularly with young people.

Social media has provided a large number of Cambodian youth with opportunities to express their views about the countrys development.  With one of the youngest populations in Southeast Asia, Cambodias hope for the future lies in the minds and the lives of these young people.  The number of Facebook pages, Twitter accounts, and YouTube videos being created in Cambodia represents the desire for knowledge and innovation by young Cambodians.  This intellectual curiosity is a great equalizer when it comes to competing for opportunities in the country, throughout the ASEAN region, and across the world.  Therefore, along with face-to-face outreach, the U.S. Embassy works hard to connect with youth via social media, posting content that appeals to young Cambodians and making an effort to respond to their questions and comments. 

When the U.S. Embassy promotes its social media platforms, it is not to compete with other individuals or organizations to see who can get the most fans.  Whether you choose to follow your favorite singer, news source, or a public official; we support a free and democratic society in Cambodia which allows its people to access and select content from the Internet and other media of their choosing.  The reason why we seek your support is because every time that you like and share our Facebook posts or retweet our Twitter content, you help us reach more users.  This gives more Cambodians access to information about education, exchanges, President Obamas Young Southeast Asian Leadership Initiative (YSEALI), English language learning, and a host of other programs.  So while 333,333 is remarkable (and a very lucky number), this is only the beginning.

Our next goal is to reach 500,000 Facebook fans.  Would you like to help us achieve this next milestone?  We will do our part by making sure our Facebook page is a source of meaningful, noteworthy and helpful information, and you can assist us by letting all of your friends know that we invite them to join our online family.  With our combined efforts, I am confident that we will make it to 500,000 Facebook fans and beyond.

When friends are in trouble, America Helps.  President Barack Obama

Watch President Obamas remarks on Super Typhoon Haiyan:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xgbguv0Olvw

Transcript:

"Over the past few days, I think all of us have been shaken by the images of the devastation wrought by Typhoon Haiyan.

Its a heartbreaking reminder of how fragile life is, and among the dead are several Americans.

So our prayers are with the Filipino people, and with Filipino Americans across our country who are anxious about their family and friends back home.

One of our core principles is, when friends are in trouble, America helps.

As I told President Aquino earlier this week, the United States will continue to offer whatever assistance we can.

Our military personnel and USAID team do this better than anybody in the world, and theyve been already on the ground working tirelessly to deliver food, water, medicine, shelter, and to help with airlift.

Today, the aircraft carrier USS George Washington and other ships arrived to help with search-and-rescue, as well as supplies, medical care and logistical support. And more help is on the way.

Americas strength, of course, has always been more than just about what our government can do  its also about what our citizens can do. 

Its about the big-heartedness of the American people when they see other folks in trouble.

So today, I would encourage everybody who wants to help, to visit WhiteHouse.gov/typhoon -- that's WhiteHouse.gov/typhoon -- and that will offer you links to organizations that are working on the ground and ways that you can support their efforts.

Our friends in the Philippines will face a long, hard road ahead, but theyll continue to have a friend and partner in the United States of America."

Feed the Future  the U.S. Governments global hunger and food security initiative  is providing support to Cambodian horticulture farmers working together in producer groups to coordinate on vegetable production, build relationships with traders, and receive bulk discounts on purchases.  These producer groups are strengthening the horticulture value chain, resulting in increased food security in Cambodia and better incomes for farmers and buyers.  To date, farmers have formed 77 producer groups and have sold 2,715 tons of vegetables, resulting in $845,198 in new sales.  The groups have been so successful that non-program farmers are joining.  To find out more about this initiative, go to http://go.usa.gov/3MPVd.

U.S. Embassy Statement on the Inaugural Session of the Fifth Legislature of the National Assembly:

Ambassador William E. Todd attended the Inaugural Session of the Fifth Legislature of the National Assembly today under the patronage of His Majesty King Norodom Sihamoni.  His attendance is not an endorsement of any election outcome or of any political party.

The United States urges a transparent review of irregularities in the July 28 national elections which would help efforts to assess and address flaws in the electoral process and give the Cambodian people greater confidence in the electoral system.

We believe that a functioning National Assembly requires the participation of both major political parties.  We call on the two parties to follow through on their September 16 joint statement denouncing violence, supporting discussion of electoral reforms, and agreeing to resolve national problems through dialogue. 

All parties should seize this opportunity to improve democratic processes and implement meaningful reforms which strengthen the rule of law and increase respect for human rights.  The United States urges the party leaders to work together for an outcome that unites the country and best serves the Cambodian people.

Rady Mom, a former refugee from Cambodia, made history last night by becoming the first Cambodian-American to be elected to a state legislature.  Mom will represent the 18th Middlesex House District in Massachusetts after winning more than 60 percent of the vote.  Mom was born in Cambodia and lives in Lowell, Massachusetts, which has a large Cambodian community.  He became a U.S. citizen in 1990.

According to Mom:  I am a Cambodian-American who represents and works with all.  I'm going to inspire the younger men and women of the entire community about how important education is, for them to step up and think differently.  We've never been taught to think positively. I'm going to do that.  Here's proof: A man who didn't speak a word of English and can do this.

Read more about Rady Moms story here:  http://www.bostonglobe.com/magazine/2014/11/05/cambodian-american-rady-mom-house-win-makes-history/5eGOk46Dno9HtlV410Vg8K/story.html

Say hello to Marie Watts and Nancy "Marion" Sanchez - the latest U.S. citizens participating in the "American Outbound" experience that is a vital element of the #YSEALI Professional Fellows Program managed by ICMA - International City/County Management Association. Marie (Assistant to the City Manager in Cedar Hill, Texas) and Marion (Community Engagement Consultant for the city of Austin, Texas) are visiting #Cambodia and being hosted by YSEALI alumni Ret Thuang, Nuon Makara, Sam Oeurn, Sothy Roth and Sean Sok Phay, who all completed intensive fellowships in the United States designed to broaden their professional expertise. Now, they are helping Marie and Marion have their own unforgettable experience right here in Cambodia, as they conduct a wide variety of activities across the country until the end of August.

For example, Marion met with a group of women entrepreneurs at WECREATE I CAMBODIA last week and gave a presentation about business and marketing, while Marie talked with students at the Royal School of Administration of Cambodia_RSA/ERA about planning a sustainable green city. They will continue to meet with other individuals and organizations to discuss topics ranging from the role of a public servant to how environmental concerns addressed in urban planning. You can find out more about their activities by reading their blogs at http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/blogs/blog/18/Professional_Fellows_Exchange_Program.

On November 17, the world commemorated the World Prematurity Day, a global movement to raise awareness about prematurity.  Each year, 15.1 million babies and their families are affected by premature birth.  For any newborn, their chance of death, disability or survival depends on the care they receive where they are born.  

With USAIDs support, Cambodia has already achieved its 2015 Millennium Development Goal targets for infant mortality, under-5 mortality, maternal mortality, and HIV/AIDS.  Want to know more? Check out http://www.usaid.gov/cambodia

On July 6, students of the Access program from Battambang, Kampong Chhnang, Kratie, Phnom Penh, and Ratanakiri came to the Embassy for the 8th annual full-day English Camp. They played games, conducted video interviews, and performed skits, all in English. Our three English Language Fellows and Fulbright and Undergraduate State Alumni Association of Cambodia (FUSAAC) volunteers were invaluable and inspired the participants with their leadership and support.

Funded by the U.S. government, the English Access Microscholarship Program (Access) provides a foundation of English language skills to talented 13-20 year-olds from disadvantaged communities through after-school classes and intensive sessions, empowering them to contribute to the development of their country while boosting their ability to participate in U.S. exchange and study programs.  More info on Access can be found here: http://exchanges.state.gov/non-us/program/english-access-microscholarship-program.

VisionFund Cambodia, a microfinance institution, opened its newest branch in Phnom Penh today in a ceremony attended by Ambassador Heidt and other distinguished guests. 

VisionFund Cambodia has been providing loans to Cambodians since 2003. These loans have helped families and communities to support small businesses, to improve farms, and to help communities provide food, clean water, and access to basic health care.

Ambassador Heidt cited the importance of making credit available to all, noting that The U.S. government has long supported the important role micro finance plays in development around the world. Ensuring that economic growth is broad based and reduces poverty has become a fundamental development challenge. In many countries, poor people cannot fully participate in, or enjoy the benefits of, economic growth.

VisionFund is run by World Vision, a U.S.-based NGO that works to help children and families combat poverty and injustice.

The inauguration ceremony of a new building was held at Prek Norin Health Center in Battambang.

In the past five years, the U.S. government has provided infrastructure valued in excess of $15 million to the people of Cambodia.

This project show the continuing contributions of the United States to help the Royal Government of Cambodia improve its health systems.

"You do not need to be a ...."

Americans hear this sentence often. It means you do not need to be extremely intelligent to understand something.

This is how you might hear the words used.

Workers in an office are afraid to try to use their new computer system. Their employer tells them not to be foolish. "You do not need to be a ... to learn this," he says.

New Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Potential for Violence and Severe Travel Restrictions in and Around Phnom Penh:

Today, the Royal Government of Cambodia announced a prohibition on all public demonstrations in and around Phnom Penh.  Separately, the main political opposition party has stated it intends to conduct a mass rally and march through Phnom Penh on Sunday, January 5, 2014.  There is a potential for violence should security forces attempt to disperse demonstrations in the capital over the next several days.  Based on the governments handling of past protests, the U.S. Embassy anticipates that major roads into Phnom Penh will be blocked and significant restrictions on vehicular movements will be imposed within the city, resulting in severe traffic disruptions coming into and throughout Phnom Penh.  The Embassy recommends that U.S citizens within Phnom Penh limit any unnecessary travel away from their residences and avoid large crowds and immediately leave any area where crowds are gathering.  U.S. citizens outside of Phnom Penh should expect significant delays traveling into the city.  The Embassy also notes that violence, including fatalities, has occurred at roadblocks in the recent past.  You should remain alert to local security developments by monitoring local news reports, be vigilant regarding your personal security and preparedness, be aware of your surroundings, and plan your activities accordingly.  Please continue to monitor our website for updates regarding the Embassys operating status.

http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/acs_violent_demonstrations_in_phnom_penh.html

Thun Saray:  Cambodian Human Rights and Development Association (ADHOC)
-From the Ambassador's Penh

A large number of readers of my blog have given positive feedback about my goal to feature more Cambodian civil society organizations and leaders who are making significant contributions for the betterment of their fellow citizens.  For this entry, I want to recognize the efforts of Mr. Thun Saray, President of the Cambodian Human Rights and Development Association  also known by many in Cambodia and around the world as ADHOC.  Since its founding in December 1991 by a group of former political prisoners after the signing of the Paris Peace Agreement, ADHOC has become one of the most influential NGOs in the country, working to promote respect for human rights in Cambodia through monitoring, legal assistance, and community empowerment.

Thun Saray was a political prisoner on two separate occasions  including under the Khmer Rouge regime.  After his release from prison, he turned his attention to becoming a human rights activist, focusing on basic rights, freedoms, and liberties in Cambodia.  With a career that has endured for more than 20 years championing these areas, Thun Saray has become a well-respected defender of human rights.  Along with his role as the President of ADHOC, he is also the President of the Board of Directors of the Committee for Free and Fair Elections (COMFREL) in Cambodia and a member of the Cambodian Human Rights Action Committee Board of Directors.

With his recognition in both local and international circles, Thun Saray has helped ADHOC become a vital and respected member of Cambodias civil society.  Under his leadership, ADHOC has organized non-violent demonstrations to preserve political space and called for the release of imprisoned human rights activists.  While its headquarters are located in Phnom Penh, the organization has branch offices throughout the provinces.  Recently, my Deputy Chief of Mission visited the ADHOC office in Kampong Cham, meeting with the representatives about their local advocacy for labor rights and civic participation.  Some of ADHOCs initiatives include the Human Rights Monitoring Program, the Land and Natural Resources Rights Program, the Womens and Childrens Rights Program, the Khmer Rouge Tribunal Project, and the Alternative Dispute Resolution Project. 

With support from the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), another noteworthy program that ADHOC has implemented is called Empowering Marginalized Communities.   This initiative looks to strengthen marginalized communities through legal and advocacy activities to obtain fairer redress for victims of human rights abuses.  Furthermore, these activities seek to improve inclusive participation in, and monitoring of, the communal development process.  The project began in January 2015 and will be implemented in 16 Cambodian provinces over three years, reaching 150 target communities.  In the first three months, ADHOC staff has provided capacity-building trainings, conducted 200 sensitization courses, and identified 50 target communities.  As the project continues, we can look forward to seeing more community members with knowledge about their rights and the law, enhanced solidarity between communities, greater protection for community representatives and activists, the discovery of fair and peaceful solutions to human rights violations, and the promotion of inclusive participation of community members in the decision-making process in Cambodia.

Under the leadership of Thun Saray, I am confident ADHOC will continue to play a prominent role in promoting human rights in Cambodia.  I applaud the important example that he has set for all who are working towards a better tomorrow for the country.  For more information about the great work that ADHOC is doing in Cambodia, I encourage you to go to their website.  As with so many civil society leaders, Thun Saray displays a passion for progress and is helping to instill that passion in others.  I look forward to continuing our efforts to support his essential work with ADHOC and other civil society organizations that are helping to promote and protect human rights in Cambodia.

1961: Cambodian architect Vann Molyvann unveils the Chaktomuk Conference Hall in Phnom Penh. Considered a masterpiece of New Khmer Architecture  a movement that unites modernist sensibilities with distinctly Cambodian traditions  the building is constructed with the help of U.S. assistance. Vann Molyvann helps usher in a golden age of Khmer culture, during which architecture, music, and film flourish until the Khmer Rouge takeover in 1975.
 
1962: The International Court of Justice in The Hague rules in favor of Cambodia in a dispute with Thailand over Preah Vihear, an 11th century temple located in a disputed area near the Thai border. Former U.S. Secretary of State Dean Acheson successfully represents Cambodia in the case, which many observers had predicted would see Thailand prevail. After the verdict, Prince Norodom Sihanouk proclaims a seven-day national holiday and the country erupts into mass celebrations.

1965: With the conflict escalating in Vietnam, border incursions into eastern Cambodia increase and result in civilian casualties. Prince Sihanouk fears for his countrys territorial integrity and seeks assurances from both the United States and communist governments. His political power is further threatened by dissident groups. Meanwhile, the United States claims that the Cambodian military is cooperating with Viet Cong forces. Unable to resolve their grievances, the United States and Cambodia officially sever diplomatic ties in May. Relations are not restored until the end of the decade.

1967: Jacqueline Kennedy visits Cambodia in November as a personal guest of Prince Sihanouk. A crowd of 10,000 greets her at Pochentong Airport in Phnom Penh, including girls strewing jasmine petals in a traditional Buddhist welcome. During her trip, the former First Lady fulfills a lifelong dream of visiting Angkor Wat. She is the first American to be received with high state honors since ties were broken, signaling a promising turn in the relationship.

1969: President Richard M. Nixon orders a covert bombing campaign of eastern Cambodia. Operation Menu lasts 14 months and results in the release of some 2,756,941 tons of ordnance. Nixon authorizes the bombings in an attempt to thwart Viet Cong forces, which by 1970 occupy between a fifth and a third of Cambodian territory. The campaign does not become known to the American public until 1973.

1969: Diplomatic relations are restored. The U.S. Embassy reopens on August 16, with Lloyd M. Rives acting as Charg dAffaires ad interim and a staff of eight. Later that month, in an effort to demonstrate Washingtons renewed commitment to Cambodia, U.S. Senator Mike Mansfield visits Phnom Penh for the third time in seven years. During the visit, Prince Sihanouk calls the Senator one of the greatest and most loyal friends to Cambodia.

"Across the world, it is no coincidence that countries with a free and active trade union movement are more democratic, more transparent, and more prosperous.  According to the Ministry of Industry and Handicraft, about 700,000 Cambodians currently work in the 1,200 garment businesses located throughout the country, with women representing 90 percent of these employees.   Along with supporting workers in disputes with management, Cambodian unions also help with social services, financial assistance, and medical support.  With ASEAN integration approaching later this year, Cambodia has an opportunity to set itself apart from other countries in the region in a positive way by becoming more attractive to foreign business and investment.  it is essential that trade unions work together with the government, private sector, and civil society to peacefully resolve disputes and find equitable solutions to labor matters." #AmbTodd #Cambodia

That proverb kept running through my mind during a recent U.S. Embassy-organized seminar that focused on the challenges facing the agricultural sector and possible solutions using modern technology. How can Cambodia ride the buffalo towards increased production, higher incomes for farmers, improved nutrition, and better food security?"

Chak Sopheap  A Rising Leader in Cambodia
-From the Ambassodor's Penh

This year, Ive made it my goal to highlight Cambodian civil society leaders who are making significant contributions for the betterment of their fellow citizens.  Thats why I was so delighted when Chak Sopheap, Executive Director of the Cambodian Center for Human Rights (CCHR), was recognized by President Barack Obama during his speech at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York City on September 23rd.  He praised Sopheap as a leader who keeps organizing and marching and mobilizing youth to demand justice.

Sopheaps recognition on a global stage is testimony to the important efforts civil society organizations (CSOs, also called non-governmental organizations, or NGOs) are making to improve human rights in Cambodia.  Since joining the CCHR in 2005, she has worked on several campaigns for the release of imprisoned human rights activists, organized non-violent marches to preserve political space, campaigned for the protection of fundamental rights, and argued that defamation within the penal code should not be misused to unfairly punish free speech.  Earlier this year she accepted the role of executive director at CCHR.  Under her leadership, I am confident CCHR will continue to play a prominent role in promoting greater protections of human rights.  As a longstanding partner of the U.S. government, CCHR was just awarded $500,000 from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) on a new project that will further promote and protect fundamental freedoms of speech and assembly.

I was really pleased that, in support of her efforts, Sopheap was recently selected to join a professional exchange program sponsored by the U.S. Department of State.  In September, she attended the International Visitor Leadership Program titled President Obamas Stand with Civil Society.  During her two weeks in the United States, Sopheap met with CSO leaders and representatives from local, state, and federal government, think tanks, academia, foundations, and businesses in order to share ideas and develop strategies to build a more robust civil society in Cambodia.  I believe that with new information and a newly acquired network of like-minded counterparts, Sopheap will become even more effective as a civil society leader.  In fact, upon her return to Cambodia, Sopheap wasted no time in building on the success of the program by partnering with another participant to write an opinion piece that appeared in the newspaper last week.

It has been inspiring to see that Sopheaps promotion of human rights does not end with her formal role at CCHR.  She is tech savvy, and not surprisingly, active on social media with a growing number of Twitter followers.  Since 2006, Sopheap has been blogging about opinions on society, politics, and good governance.  She also co-organized the third regional BlogFest Asia 2012 in Cambodia in an effort to bring greater international attention to the country.  I encourage you to check out her blog: http://sopheapfocus.com/.  As with so many great leaders, Sopheaps passion for progress is playing out in both her personal and professional life.  

I look forward to continuing our efforts to support the essential work of civil society in Cambodia.

How has civil society made a difference in your life?

For more information on The Cambodian Center for Human Rights, visit their Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/cchrcambodia or their Website at http://www.cchrcambodia.org/

Q: WHAT'S THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN A COLLEGE AND A UNIVERSITY?

A: The terms, college and university, are used interchangeably and mean the same thing in the U.S. As a general rule, colleges tend to be smaller and usually offer only undergraduate degrees, while a university also offers graduate degrees. Within each college or university you will find schools, such as school of arts and sciences or the school of business.

Q: WHO CAN BECOME A COLLEGE OR UNIVERSITY STUDENT? ARE THERE AGE LIMITATIONS TO ATTEND U.S. COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES?

A: A high school education is usually required to become an undergraduate university student. Many institutions will not accept international students who are younger than age 17. There are sometimes exceptions to that general rule.

"I believe that, at this time, the [Cambodian] government has the opportunity to not only promote laws that make society more inclusive and free, but to also implement reforms that promote the rule of law... In my opinion, the country would best be served by focusing on topics that benefit the average Cambodian.  Rather than making a new NGO law the top priority, which I believe is not needed, the National Assembly could consider addressing poverty, education, health care, and environmental protection.  However, improving the rule of law, which encompasses a broad range of topics that would ultimately benefit Cambodian citizens, is an area where both parties could work together... The United States encourages Cambodia to continue on the path towards meaningful reform by focusing on promoting and strengthening the rule of law, which not only has a wide impact on the countrys overall economic prosperity and development, but will also lead to an increasingly democratic and prosperous future." #AmbTodd #Cambodia

World AIDS Day 2014
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Watching the news yesterday, I was impressed to see stories about the many different ways people throughout Cambodia commemorated World AIDS Day 2014.  December 1 is a day to not only reflect on the many lives lost and forever changed as a result of AIDS, but also to celebrate the lives saved and recognize those working to eliminate this disease.  As I have stated before, the U.S. partnership with Cambodia to reduce HIV/AIDS infection rates here is one the most successful stories among our development assistance programs.  But with an estimated 75,000 people in Cambodia living with HIV and approximately 1,100 newly infected people each year, there is still much work to be done.  I commend the ongoing efforts of those taking on the challenge to create an AIDS-free generation in Cambodia, which includes government and civil society organizations.

The United States has focused its resources for eradicating HIV/AIDS in Cambodia and throughout the world through the Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).  With resources from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the PEPFAR office in Cambodia supports partnerships, programs and activities focused on saving lives.  Last year alone, PEPFAR assisted Cambodia in providing treatment to almost 50,000 people and HIV testing to over 80,000 pregnant women.  These and other PEPFAR-supported endeavors make the goal of an AIDS-free generation an achievable one.  To build on prior success, the total amount of U.S. government funding available through PEPFAR in 2015 for HIV/AIDS programs implemented by USAID and CDC in Cambodia will remain the same as in 2014.  The focus of this support is on delivering the highest impact interventions, bringing them to scale among the most vulnerable populations, and maintaining a sense of urgency to stop this epidemic.

I was recently reminded by a friend to reflect on what we have achieved together in Cambodia to fight HIV/AIDS.  Not so long ago, resources were so limited that hospital beds were filled with dying patients, while others lay dying on the floor.  Nearly 35 years into the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and more than 20 years since the first cases were detected here, Cambodia today is one of 12 countries in the world that provide universal access to HIV treatment, and the HIV prevalence rate in adults decreased by more than half from 1998 to 2010.  At the end of the day, the results of our joint efforts lives saved and new infections averted determine whether or not we are winning the fight against HIV/AIDS.  Without a doubt, Cambodias story is a true achievement.  Now the question is: how do we build off of our past achievements to obtain even greater success in the future?  

On World AIDS Day 2014 in Cambodia, organizations like Friends International and the AIDS Healthcare Foundation held programs that included youth activities and HIV testing.  The Labor Ministry awarded several companies in a range of sectors  including the garment industry, hospitality, banking, telecommunications, and entertainment  for providing HIV/AIDS education and counseling services to their employees.  These are just a few examples of the numerous individuals involved in the fight against this disease.  However, no one entity alone can create an AIDS-free generation in Cambodia.  That is why we must not only work towards our shared goal on December 1; it is a prolonged commitment.

The United States and the Royal Government of Cambodia have developed a strong partnership and have collaborated with other international, non-governmental, and civil society organizations to fight against HIV/AIDS.  With advances in science and technology, lifesaving knowledge and health care can be brought to even more people throughout Cambodia via collaboration.  Moving forward, I hope to see a continued emphasis on partnership to ensure that our collective investment is used efficiently and effectively, with maximal results. 

The vision for the next phase in the fight against HIV/AIDS is a defined, shared, and sustainable result.  I genuinely believe that if Cambodia maintains its commitment and continues to work with its partners, it has a very good chance of becoming the first country in the world with an AIDS-free generation.  Each of us can play a vital role in helping to create an AIDS-free generation in Cambodia.  On an individual level, we can make smart choices that will protect ourselves and our loved ones.  At the community level, we can embrace those who are struggling with HIV/AIDS and ensure that they have access to quality care and treatment.  And at the national and international level, we can continue working together through programs like PEPFAR to provide resources where they are needed most.  In recognition of World AIDS Day, I encourage each of you to do your part in the fight against HIV/AIDS in Cambodia.

What did you do in recognition of World AIDS Day 2014?  Please share your comments.

#AmbTodd

THE WHITE HOUSE
Office of the Press Secretary

For Immediate Release                           November 26, 2014 

THANKSGIVING DAY, 2014
- - - - - - - 
BY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
A PROCLAMATION

Thanksgiving Day invites us to reflect on the blessings we enjoy and the freedoms we cherish. As we gather with family and friends to take part in this uniquely American celebration, we give thanks for the extraordinary opportunities we have in a Nation of limitless possibilities, and we pay tribute to all those who defend our Union as members of our Armed Forces. This holiday reminds us to show compassion and concern for people we have never met and deep gratitude toward those who have sacrificed to help build the most prosperous Nation on earth. These traditions honor the rich history of our country and hold us together as one American family, no matter who we are or where we come from. 

Nearly 400 years ago, a group of Pilgrims left their homeland and sailed across an ocean in pursuit of liberty and prosperity. With the friendship and kindness of the Wampanoag people, they learned to harvest the rich bounty of a new world. Together, they shared a successful crop, celebrating bonds of community during a time of great hardship. Through times of war and of peace, the example of a Native tribe who extended a hand to a new people has endured. During the American Revolution and the Civil War, days of thanksgiving drew Americans together in prayer and in the spirit that guides us to better days, and in each year since, our Nation has paused to show our gratitude for our families, communities, and country. 

With God's grace, this holiday season we carry forward the legacy of our forebears. In the company of our loved ones, we give thanks for the people we care about and the joy we share, and we remember those who are less fortunate. At shelters and soup kitchens, Americans give meaning to the simple truth that binds us together: we are our brother's and our sister's keepers. We remember how a determined people set out for a better world -- how through faith and the charity of others, they forged a new life built on freedom and opportunity. 

The spirit of Thanksgiving is universal. It is found in small moments between strangers, reunions shared with friends and loved ones, and in quiet prayers for others. Within the heart of America's promise burns the inextinguishable belief that together we can advance our common prosperity -- that we can build a more hopeful, more just, and more unified Nation. This Thanksgiving, let us recall the values that unite our diverse country, and let us resolve to strengthen these lasting ties. 

NOW, THEREFORE, I, BARACK OBAMA, President of the United States of America, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the United States, do hereby proclaim Thursday, November 27, 2014, as a National Day of Thanksgiving. I encourage the people of the United States to join together -- whether in our homes, places of worship, community centers, or any place of fellowship for friends and neighbors -- and give thanks for all we have received in the past year, express appreciation to those whose lives enrich our own, and share our bounty with others. 
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand this twenty-sixth day of November, in the year of our Lord two thousand fourteen, and of the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred and thirty-ninth. 

BARACK OBAMA

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, is a serious illness that has a number of reported cases in South Korea.  There are no known cases in Cambodia, but to help protect yourself and others from MERS and other diseases you should wash your hands often with soap and water, avoid close contact with sick people, and cover your mouth with a tissue when you cough and sneeze.  With assistance from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the World Health Organization (WHO), and other partners, Cambodia has screening procedures in place at the airport and is able to test for MERS if anyone is suspected of having the illness.  For more information about MERS, please go to http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/mers.html

In his weekly column, Ambassador Todd discusses the importance of foreign investment in Cambodias economic development:  

As I promote the benefits of doing business in Cambodia to U.S. companies, I was glad to see Cambodian leaders also working actively to increase foreign investment in Cambodia.  At the investment conference of the International Business Chamber of Cambodia held in Phnom Penh this past week, Prime Minister Hun Sen said that in order to encourage greater investment, Cambodia must address the challenges of combating corruption, implementing legal, judicial, and financial reforms, and aligning education and vocational training with the demands of the job market.  The Prime Minister was absolutely right that progress in those areas will significantly boost investor confidence, as those concerns were often mentioned during my discussions with business leaders in the United States and in the ASEAN region.  Serious efforts to implement those reforms will attract more foreign investment, which in turn will lead to more business creation and better paying jobs in Cambodia.

Please read the Ambassadors full column, Investing for Cambodias Future, in The Cambodia Herald at http://goo.gl/U7kEZ0
