Tabitha:  Empowering Cambodian Families
-From the Ambassador's Penh

When I fly back to the United States, I often take gifts for my family and friends.  In my search for unique gifts made in Cambodia I have visited many stores in Phnom Penh, and one of my all-time favorite places to shop is Tabitha Cambodia, a non-profit organization started in 1994 by Canadian citizen Janne Ritskes.  Not only do I find special, wonderfully-made handicrafts at Tabitha, but I know that my purchases help to support local families and communities. 

I have long admired Tabitha Cambodias cottage industry program, which provides training, employment, and income for poor Cambodians to manufacture the silk handicrafts and other products Tabitha is famous for.  I also learned about the range of community development programs the organization uses to help the poorest people in Cambodia become self-sufficient and independent.  For example, one of Tabithas main programs focuses on personal and financial development.  The Family Partnerships and Savings Program helps families with no savings to set financial goals to make their lives better.  Through sustained support by Tabitha staff and interest earned on their savings, families obtain a sustainable source of income and are able to achieve their goals, including providing for their own food, clean water, and shelter.  Since its foundation, this program has made a positive impact on over half a million families in Cambodia!

Janne has tremendous energy and drive.  In addition to her responsibilities at Tabitha Cambodia, Janne has embarked on an ambitious endeavor to build the Nokor Tep Womens Hospital, which will treat impoverished women in need of gynecological medical care in Cambodia when completed.  Having lived in Cambodia for the past two decades, Janne realized how few quality medical services were available to women in the country.  Last weekend, the Nokor Tep group held their fourth annual walkathon, which brought together more than 750 participants and raised more than $75,000 for the hospital.

For over 20 years, Janne has worked tirelessly to empower the poorest families in Cambodia to lift themselves out of poverty.  Jannes story is truly inspiring, and is a testament to the power of one individual to create a positive impact and bring about long-lasting change.  I want to personally thank Janne for her long-term commitment to the Cambodian people.  Janne, you are truly an inspiration to us all!

Janne Ritskes (center) is the founder and director of Tabitha Cambodia. (Photo courtesy of Tabitha Foundation)

Press Statement on Conviction of Mam Sonando:

We are deeply concerned by the conviction and harsh sentence of Mam Sonando, a Cambodian independent broadcaster.

Today the Phnom Penh Municipal Court sentenced him to 20 years in prison for alleged insurrection.

A number of observers in Cambodia have noted that the charges against him appear to have been politically-motivated, based on his frequent criticism of the government.

We strongly support freedom of expression, including the rights of members of the press to peacefully express political views without fear of persecution, retribution, or intimidation, consistent with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. We call on the Cambodian government to release Mam Sonando immediately, to ensure that its court system is free from political influence, and to reaffirm its commitment to guaranteeing its citizens basic human rights.

http://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2012/10/198518.htm#.UGqD-s_xTSA.facebook

Cambodians around the world are justifiably proud of their extraordinary cultural heritage.  The Temples of Angkor were recently selected by the travel company Lonely Planet for the number one spot on its Ultimate Travel List 2015.  

The U.S. Government has been supporting restoration work at the Phnom Bakheng temple in the Angkor Archaeological Park since 2004, largely through the State Department Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation.  To date the U.S. government has provided nearly $3 million to protect and preserve this incredible monument for future generations, including a new $450,000 grant announced in July.  The delicate and difficult work to preserve Phnom Bakheng is being conducted by the World Monuments Fund in close coordination with the APSARA Authority.

But there is much more to the work at Phnom Bakheng than just restoring the temple.  With financial support from the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh, the World Monuments Fund has produced three videos to tell some of these stories.  Check out this video entitled The Villagers to learn more about the people who work and live near Phnom Bakheng.  

Please check back on Thursday and Friday for two more videos!

Highlights from Assistant Secretary Danny Russels Visit to Cambodia
-From the Ambassador's Penh

This week, I had the pleasure to welcome back my friend and colleague, Danny Russel, U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs (you should follow his office on Twitter @USAsiaPacific).  This was not the Assistant Secretarys first visit to Cambodia.  Three years ago, he traveled to the Kingdom with President Barack Obama for meetings held here during Cambodias 2012 chairmanship of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).  As part of President Obamas rebalance to the Asia-Pacific region, Russels visit highlights the United States commitment to strengthening our important bilateral relationship with Cambodia, as well as increasing cooperation with all of the countries of ASEAN.  

During his visit, Assistant Secretary Russel met with the government, political parties, civil society, youth, members of the press, and my Embassy team.  His first stop was a meeting with acting Foreign Minister Ouch Borith to continue our engagement with the Royal Government of Cambodia.  The two leaders discussed opportunities to boost bilateral ties and exchanged views on a number of regional issues.  The Assistant Secretary made clear that the United States supports progress in political reforms in order to strengthen Cambodian institutions.  They also talked about ways to create jobs and expand trade and investment for both countries.Next, the Assistant Secretary spoke to a diverse audience about the U.S. rebalance to the Asia-Pacific region at a talk hosted by the Cambodian Institute for Cooperation and Peace (CICP).  I would like to thank the CICP for not only arranging the talk, but also for their work over the last 20 years to help inform the Cambodian government and people about important policy matters.

During a meeting with representatives of civil society, Assistant Secretary Russel learned how these organizations are involved in supporting reform efforts in Cambodia.  In previous blogs, I have highlighted some of the countrys top civil society leaders who are making significant contributions.  I firmly believe that civil society plays a vital role in addressing the challenges facing Cambodia.  Later that afternoon, Assistant Secretary Russel participated in a lively discussion with Cambodian members of President Obamas Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) who were invited to the Embassy.  He listened to their hopes and their aspirations for Cambodia and answered their questions about the issues that matter most them.  As he said, one of the ways we can support Cambodia youth is through the YSEALI program.  I couldnt agree more, and I hope more Cambodian youth join this active and growing community.  He later told me that the discussion with YSEALI members was his favorite event of the whole day.

Although he was only here for a short time, Assistant Secretary Russels visit demonstrates the commitment of the United States to partner with everyone  the government, political parties, civil society, and youth  to bring greater opportunity, prosperity, and democracy to the people of Cambodia.  I would like to personally thank all of the people who made this visit a success and who helped our Assistant Secretary to feel at home in Cambodia!

#AmbTodd #Cambodia

BREAKING NEWS: PRESIDENT OBAMA IN #CUBA
President Obama is the first U.S. President to visit Cuba in nearly 90 years. During his two-day trip, the President will focus on the progress made in the ongoing process of normalizing bilateral relations between the United States and Cuba and reaffirm U.S. support for universal values like freedom of speech, assembly, and religion. For more about the visit, go to https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/02/20/weekly-address-new-chapter-cuba. 

As with his historic trip to #Cambodia in 2012, President Obama believes the best way to promote U.S. interests and values is through engagement. Air Force One - one of the most recognizable symbols of the U.S. presidency - makes it possible to engage with people around the world. Learn more about Air Force One at https://share.america.gov/air-force-one-traveling-white-house/.

Mark Morris, the well-known dancer and dance choreographer from the United States, will be speaking at the Institut Franais du Camodge this evening with Chey Chankethya, Artistic Director of Amrita Performing Arts.

Come hear Mark talk about his life, work, artistic motivations, and his current dance tour through Asia.  Mark Morris has worked with the San Francisco Ballet, the Pacific Northwest Ballet, and American Ballet Theatre, and also directed and choreographed at the Metropolitan Opera and the Royal Opera in London, England.  This should prove to be a fascinating discussion.

Mark Morris is Artistic Director of the Mark Morris Dance Group (MMDG), which is visiting Cambodia as part of the U.S. Department of States DanceMotion USA program. The world-renowned contemporary dance group from Brooklyn, New York, USA is known for their style,  grace, and professionalism on stage.  DanceMotion USA is a cross-cultural exchange program that connects Americas finest dance companies with international artists and communities.

Create a video short that completes the phrase Democracy is

THE PRIZE

An all-expense paid trip to Washington, D.C., New York and Hollywood.
Gala screenings of the winning videos in Hollywood, New York and Washington.
Exposure to filmmakers and the U.S. film and television industry.
Meetings with democracy advocates from government, media and civil society.

THE TIMELINE

SUBMISSION DEADLINE  MIDNIGHT GMT JANUARY 31, 2010.
Challenge semifinalists will be selected on or about March 31, 2010.
An independent jury will narrow down the semifinalists to 21 finalists on or about May
15, 2010.
The general public will vote online for the winning videos May 15  June 15, 2010.
Seven winners  one each from the Western Hemisphere, Europe, Middle East/North Africa, Sub-Saharan Africa, South & Central Asia, East Asia/Pacific and one anonymous winner  will be announced in mid-June 2010.
The six publicly identified winners, one from each of the six geographic regions, will travel to the
United States to claim their prize in the fall of 2010.

THE DETAILS

You must be 18 or older to enter. 
Videos can be any style: fiction or documentary, animated or live action.
Videos must be no longer than three minutes.
Videos must be in English or have English subtitles.
Contestants may enter anonymously, but anonymous winners cannot collect the grand prize.

See contest site for a complete list of rules, www.videochallenge.america.gov.

Jonas Salk is the American scientist who first discovered and developed the vaccine for polio in 1955. His vaccine has saved a countless number of lives around the world. By 1979, Dr. Salks vaccine had eliminated polio in the United States and many other counties. 

Cambodia was certified as polio free in 2000. Jonas Salk would have celebrated his 100th birthday on Tuesday.

Congratulations to Youth and Media Literacy in #Cambodia (YMLC) for being among this year's winners of the Alumni Engagement Innovation Fund (AIEF) competition! YMLC is a media training project developed by #YSEALI and U.S. exchange program alumni Cheng Mengchou, Borei Sylyvann, Ket Monny Vathna, and Lim Sreysros. The project will provide youth living in rural communities across Cambodia the chance to learn more about the proper use of social media, the importance of ethics in media, and freedom of expression online.  

YMLC was one of only 61 winning proposals chosen from more than 800 submissions worldwide (https://alumni.state.gov/aeif-2016-winners). I feel glad and grateful that the project is selected to win the AEIF," said project director Ket Monny Vathna. "I hope it can help improve the quality of the understanding of media in our society.

The U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh is proud to support Cambodias 2016 AEIF  winners! Are you an also aspiring leader with ideas to make a difference? Then join more than 5,000 other Cambodian youth and become a YSEALI member today! Get started at youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov.

Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Potential for Civil Unrest on Saturday, March 8, 2014

This security message is being issued to alert U.S. citizens residing in or traveling to Cambodia that the leaders of various unions have announced plans for a public forum of up to 30,000 people to be held in Phnom Penhs Freedom Park (Streets 106/108 between 51 and 63) on Saturday, March 8, 2014, beginning at 8:00 a.m. Cambodian authorities have publicly stated that the unions have been denied a permit for the event, but organizers have indicated they intend to proceed with the gathering. Additionally, local press have quoted union leaders as saying they anticipate clashes with government security forces...

The Embassy encourages U.S. citizens to avoid crowds and other gatherings and to immediately leave any area where crowds are gathering. U.S. citizens should remain alert to local security developments by monitoring local news reports, be vigilant regarding their personal security and preparedness, be aware of their surroundings, and plan their activities accordingly...

Please read full text of message here:
http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/030714_acs.html

  Christoph Heinrich  Denver Art Museum  Rama   

 Heinrich        

       Heidt  Anne Lemaistre  UNESCO        https://www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/ 

This morning, a ceremony was held at the Council of Ministers to celebrate the homecoming of a 10th century statue of the Torso of Rama from Prasat Chen, Koh Ker, which had been in the collection of the Denver Art Museum for 30 years.  The Torso of Rama was returned by the Denver Art Museum after experts confirmed that the object had in fact been looted from its original home.

In his remarks, Denver Art Museum director Dr. Christoph Heinrich called the Torso of Rama an Ambassador of Cambodias distinguished tradition and culture that brought delight and wonder to millions of our visitors of our museum.

We are happy today to see this honorable Ambassador returning back home to be united with other important pieces from the temple of Koh Ker, said Dr. Heinrich.  The Torso of Rama is the seventh object from Koh Ker to be returned from U.S. collections.

The homecoming event was led by H.E. Yim Nolson, Vice-Chairman of the Economic, Social and Cultural Council of Cambodia, and was attended by Ambassador Heidt, UNESCO Representative in Cambodia Anne Lemaistre, and many distinguished guests from the diplomatic and cultural community.  The activities included a blessing dance and a garland ceremony.  To see more photos from this event, go to https://www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/

U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh, Cambodia shares in the Cambodian people's outrage and grief over the brutal murder of Dr. Kem Ley. Dr. Ley was a brave critic of injustice wherever he saw it. We are honored that he generously shared his wisdom and expertise with us on issues ranging from health to worker rights to education and democracy. If there was a single theme that united his work, it was a belief in Cambodias future and its people. Though Dr. Leys voice was silenced, we are confident his spirit was not. The United States stands by the people of Cambodia in this time of sorrow.

Visit http://go.usa.gov/xc7PG for an official U.S. Department of State statement from Assistant Secretary and Spokesperson John Kirby.

Panhchapor Chhim, Seyha Doeurn, Sereyvuth Thai, and adviser Dr. Reasmey Tan from the Institute of Technology of Cambodia -  make up "Team CFK" (Cam Fermentation Kit), one of top three finalists of the USAID Asia & Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative World Food Innovation Challenge! #FoodChallenge2016 invited #YSEALI members from across the region to submit their technology solutions to challenges in agriculture, aquaculture, and fisheries. Team CFK developed a project to improve quality and sanitation in cucumber pickling, which can help farmers preserve their crops and contribute to food security in #Cambodia. "We believe that we can reduce losses in vegetable harvests, and at the same time produce a better pickle for everyone," say the members of Team CFK.

       Austin  Texas        CFK  !

The team will now present their innovation at the ASEAN Ministerial Meeting on Science and Technology later this month in Cambodia. They will compete against teams from Indonesia and Malaysia for the grand prize of a study trip to Austin, Texas - one of the main technology hubs in the United States - in March 2017. Join us in congratulating Team CFK and wishing them good luck!

VOA Khmer recently interviewed Erin Moriarty Harrelson about her work with Cambodias deaf community.  Erin, who is also deaf, is a Fulbright National Geographic Digital Storytelling Fellow and looks to make a difference by documenting the lives of deaf people in rural Cambodia.  Cambodias deaf population lack sufficient access to education and information due to the absence of closed caption television and other resources.  

Erin's work can assist policymakers and NGOs improve conditions for the countrys deaf people.  I hope to help raise awareness about deaf people in Cambodia and their everyday lives.  I also plan to develop material that deaf people here and the NGOs that work with them can use to advocate for themselves. Center for Khmer Studies  Supporting Research in Cambodia
-From the Ambassador's Penh

As a reader of my blog, you know that I am deeply committed to assisting the people of Cambodia in improving their lives and their country.  Sharing this commitment are the members of my team at the U.S. Embassy  which includes Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung  and remarkable organizations like the ones that I like to write about in my blog.  Recently, Julie visited the Center for Khmer Studies (CKS), a premier international research center in Cambodia.  Based in Siem Reap, CKS supports and participates in a wide variety of research programs.  Dr. Krisna Uk, Executive Director of CKS, gave an overview of the centers work to support research, teaching, and public service in the social sciences, arts, and humanities in Cambodia.  Krisna is a distinguished international scholar, having studied and received degrees from universities in the United States, the United Kingdom, and France.  She has worked extensively in Cambodia, from documenting the lives of the Jarai ethnic minority for her PhD to researching the impact of landmines and unexploded ordnances in communities living in high risk areas.

Founded in 1999, CKS receives support from the U.S. Department of States Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs to fund a variety of projects, including fellowship programs, conferences and lecture series, and new academic programs in collaboration with U.S. academic institutions.  As the only member of the Council of American Overseas Research Centers located in mainland Southeast Asia, CKS provides scholars and visitors around the world with excellent training and research opportunities, first-class academic publications, and unique research facilities.  I also learned that CKS operates one of Cambodias few public libraries  which is also the largest one outside of Phnom Penh.

For many years, CKS has offered institutional support, fellowships, and language training to U.S. students and scholars.  This has enabled American scholars to develop a greater understanding of the economic and cultural forces shaping Cambodia.  The center also helps foster cultural exchanges and academic collaborations between American scholars and their Cambodian counterparts in order to build human resources, transfer knowledge and expertise, and develop strong partnerships.  Thus, I am pleased that U.S. Fulbright scholar Cheryl Yin is a Senior Fellow at CKS, researching how the Khmer language has changed since 1979 for her dissertation and PhD. 

CKS has established partnerships with a number of U.S. institutions of higher learning to educate American students about the history and culture of Cambodia.  The University of Wisconsin-Madison sends undergraduate students for a three-week study abroad course entitled Buddhism and Service Learning in Cambodia.  During this course, students work with local NGOs and schools to closely examine the intersections of religion, ethics, social problems, and social work in the majority Theravada Buddhist community in Siem Reap.  In the Chinese Empire and the Cambodian Experience course, students from Cornell University and from community colleges in the surrounding New York area come to CKS to learn more about Cambodias history and relations with other countries in the region.  Later this year, CKS will expand this model of success by bringing students from the University of California-Berkeley and community colleges in Californias Bay Area to Cambodia for a quality educational experience.

I appreciate the efforts of Krisna and CKS to support academic research and provide an environment for scholars, students, and artists to collaborate.  I am proud the U.S. government can support CKS to strengthen Cambodias cultural and academic institutions and integrate Cambodian scholars into the international community.  This is just one example of how Americans and Cambodians work together to increase mutual understanding and deepen the connections between our two countries.

Center for Khmer Studies

"The key innovation of Feed the Future is that it goes beyond simply feeding people and tackles the problem at its source...In #Cambodia, that means addressing the challenges faced by rural farmers and families, who form the backbone of Cambodias agricultural sector. It means educating farmers about agricultural techniques and management practices. It means teaching them better business strategies. It means connecting them with input suppliers and markets both here and abroad. It also means working hand-in-hand with our national and provincial partners and with the private sector, who will carry this work forward over the long term." - #AmbHeidt

Ambassador Heidt joined Deputy Prime Minister H.E. Dr. Yim Chhay Ly at the Intercontinental Hotel this morning to commemorate five years of the U.S. government's Feed the Future programs in Cambodia. Farmers, policy makers, donors, government officials, private companies, and members of civil society will be in Phnom Penh from June 2-3 to review the significant achievements in #agriculture, #nutrition, and poverty reduction that have taken place through the Feed the Future initiative, implemented by USAID Cambodia in cooperation with the Royal Government of Cambodia. The United States is proud of this successful partnership and recognizes that strong leadership from the Cambodian government in the agriculture sector is critical to future progress. To see the Ambassador's full remarks, please visit http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/sp_060216.html.

Ambassador Todd addresses the issue of child malnutrition and hunger in Cambodia in his weekly column titled: Helping Cambodian Children to Grow Up Healthy and Strong. 

Lack of food is not the only cause of malnutrition and hunger.  Two other major factors are infectious disease and sanitation, which affect the bodys ability to ingest and utilize food.  A brand-new USAID program called Nourish is going to be launched in the next couple of weeks and will support Cambodias efforts to improve the nutrition of women and children through improved sanitation and hygiene.  Improving the nutritional status of women and raising awareness about nutrition and sanitation among mothers will go a long way towards creating a better future for Cambodias children. 

I am proud of the work that the U.S. Embassy is doing in conjunction with the Cambodian government, the NGO community, and other international partners to improve food security and nutrition in Cambodia.  This is clearly an issue where Cambodians of all political parties should work together for the benefit of Cambodias most vulnerable groups.  The United States will continue to look for ways to bring groups together to advance our common goal of ending malnutrition and hunger in Cambodia and to help the next generation of Cambodians to achieve their full potential. 

Read the Ambassadors full column in The Cambodia Herald at http://goo.gl/7sOQ8M

#AmbTodd

Interested in studying in the United States? EducationUSA Cambodia is here to help! EducationUSA Advisor Mao Kolap recently presented information on U.S. higher education and scholarships to students, parents and staff at Passtra University of Cambodia (PUC) and the Abundant Life International School-ALIS. "Study any major and pursue any profession as long as you have a passion for it," Ms. Kolap said to the students. "The passion of your career will help you positively influence your work environment and ultimately help #Cambodia.

During the presentations, Ms. Kolap explained the difference between community colleges and universities. She also emphasized reading and writing as the foundation to academic success and invited students to utilize  eLibraryUSA and other resources that #EducationUSA has to offer.  You can get even more assistance by visiting the EducationUSA office located at the PUC campus on Norodom Boulevard in Phnom Penh. For more information on their services, visit cambodia.usembassy.gov/education_advice.html.

#USAID is currently supporting Cambodian Disabled People's Organization (CDPO) on a project to increase voting access for the disabled in the electoral reform process. A workshop yesterday brought together CDPO partners representing different types of disabilities to provide recommendations on voting access to be integrated into draft laws. Priorities are for voter registration to be accessible to all voters with disability, voter information to cater voters with disabilities and recruitment policies to encourage persons with disabilities. As part of the advocacy efforts, a radio program is being prepared to inform listeners on the progress.

For the past six weeks, Professor Jack Van Doren has taught in the English Language Based Bachelor of Laws (ELBBL) program at the Royal University of Law and Economics (RULE) in Phnom Penh.  His course, called Legal Process, focused on writing and critical thinking about the law.  Referring to the twelve students in his course, Professor Van Doren said, I had a lot of fun and learned things myself and I hope and believe the students got a glimmer of the process that I did not get in my legal education at Yale!

Professor Van Doren is Professor Emeritus at Florida State University, College of Law, in the United States.  Accompanied by his wife, Sonia, he came to Cambodia as a U.S. Fulbright Specialist.  The Fulbright Specialist program promotes connections between U.S. scholars and professionals and their counterparts at host institutions around the world.  Read more about the Fulbright Specialist and Scholars programs at: http://goo.gl/aQTUHP

Navy band visits school in Sihanoukville, on-sea training continues on Day 4 of CARAT Cambodia 2014  

In the fourth day of CARAT exercises in Cambodia, training moved forward with the Royal Cambodian and U.S. Navies worked together on board the Royal Cambodian Navy fast-attack craft during a practice search and rescue mission.  This type of exercise required the team of sailors to focus on teamwork and attention to detail.  
 
On dry land, members of the U.S. Navy visited Ream primary school in Sihanoukville for an entertaining day of music and dancing.  The U.S. sailors were greeted with smiles from all the children and staff of Ream as they clapped and sang along with one another.  The music was provided by the band Orient Express, whose members are all U.S. Navy sailors.  To see the photo album from the days events, click here: http://goo.gl/av5YNQ 

Now in its fifth year, CARAT Cambodia is an annual exercise between the U.S. and Royal Cambodian Navies that focuses on military readiness.  The CARAT program began 20 years ago and now includes nine Southeast Asian nations.  The primary purpose of the program is to promote regional security cooperation, increase mutual understanding, and enhance the ability of participating forces to work together.

Languages other than English are playing a growing role in American life, as detailed in a just-released report and a new online tool.

In addition to English and Spanish, there were six languages in 2011 spoken at home by at least 1 million people: Chinese (2.9 million), Tagalog (1.6 million), Vietnamese (1.4 million), French (1.3 million), German (1.1 million) and Korean (1.1 million).

The prevalence of people speaking non-English languages at home varied widely across states, from 44 percent of the population in California to 2 percent in West Virginia.

Read more: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/article/2013/08/20130808280294.html

1950: The United States establishes diplomatic relations with Cambodia on June 29, with the appointment of Donald R. Heath as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary. The U.S. Legation opens in Phnom Penh on November 14 at the renowned Hotel Le Royal.  A Legation office and U.S. Information Service library are later established at a new location. The Legation is raised to Embassy status on June 25, 1952, at which point Heath becomes the first U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia.



1953: Cambodia declares its full independence from France on November 9, after intense negotiations between King Norodom Sihanouk and the French governmentwith the United States often acting as mediator. Throughout the talks, the United States actively supports Cambodias bid for autonomy, although France does not fully cede authority over Cambodia until the Geneva Conference in 1954.



1955: The United States establishes an assistance program in Cambodia with a budget of $50 million per year. The aid seeks to promote Cambodias economic and social progress by improving and expanding public education, building infrastructure, and modernizing the armed forces among other activities. The aid program is larger in size and scope than the combined support from all other countries and international organizations, with the United States providing $493 million in assistance by 1963.



1958: Sihanouk, who abdicated the throne in 1955 and took the title of Prince, becomes the first Cambodian head of state to visit the United States. His itinerary includes stops in Washington, D.C., New York City, Detroit, Chicago, and Los Angeles. The Princes visit causes a stir in diplomatic circles, particularly following the Cambodian-themed parties he organizes in New York and Washington that include a traditional Khmer dance recital by the Royal Cambodian Ballet. During talks with President Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Prince presents a 12th-century solid granite Angkorian Buddha that still stands today in Washingtons National Gallery.


1959: Cambodia unveils National Highway Four, built with $25 million of U.S. assistance. The 140-mile road, which links Phnom Penh to Sihanoukville, is dubbed the Khmer-American Friendship Highway. Built by American and Cambodian laborers working side by side, the road is the single largest cooperative aid project in Cambodia. U.S. development assistance also helps repair a further 800 miles of road and 43 bridges throughout the country.

Have you heard of the U.S. TV drama series "Grey's Anatomy"?  In addition to winning a Golden Globe Award for Best TV Drama, the series also won an award for addressing important issues of race.

Cambodias Music Scene
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Since arriving in Cambodia three years ago, Ive been captivated by the live music scene in Phnom Penh. The wide-ranging music, from traditional Khmer songs to more contemporary genres, that is being played at venues around the city is truly outstanding. I was sorry to learn that a number of music venues in Phnom Penh have closed in recent months due in part to increasing costs. Though this will no doubt impact some local musicians in the short term, I am hopeful that Cambodias music scene will continue to flourish and rise to even greater heights in the future.

In many ways, the music scene in Phnom Penh today is the legacy from a previous generation of Cambodian musicians who produced their own unique sound during the 1950s, 1960s, and early 1970s. That era is considered by many the golden age of Cambodian rock-and-roll. As you may recall, Phnom Penh hosted the world premiere of the documentary Dont Think Ive Forgotten: Cambodias Lost Rock and Roll last year. The film, directed by American John Pirozzi, featured video footage of the many gifted Cambodian musicians who created a vibrant music scene that symbolized the exuberance and promise of that period.

Dont Think Ive Forgotten is currently on tour in the United States, where it is getting rave reviews. Some of the screenings are accompanied by live concerts by some of the surviving musicians of the era, including the three remaining members of Baksey Cham Krong  Cambodias first surf guitar band  as well as Sinn Sethakol, grandson of legendary singer Sinn Sisamouth. Im delighted that the Embassy was able to support the travel of some of these musicians so that their music can be heard by a brand new and appreciative audience.

After the screening and concert at the American Film Institute (AFI) Silver Theater near Washington, DC last week, Sinn Sethakol told Voice of America that he learned new things about his famous grandfather after watching the film. Id seen his face on CD covers and heard his voice, Sethakol said. After I watched the movie, I became very emotional. All Cambodian families were broken apart because of Pol Pots regime, he continued. Audience member Duong Ti told VOA that the film and concert had given him a new understanding of Cambodian music and history. Seeing the performers live not only made me very proud, but also like a whole person. I am proud of them, proud of my heritage, proud to be part of the community, Duong said.
It is very encouraging to see that the film is reaching a wider audience. I have no doubt that anyone who watches the film will come away with a better understanding of the talented and dynamic musicians who emerged in Cambodia and captivated audiences in the decades before the tragedy of the Khmer Rouge period. I believe these artists musicians from Cambodias golden age will continue to inspire Cambodian musicians and influence todays music scene.

Speaking of todays music scene, earlier this week Phnom Penh welcomed American pop star Demi Lovato, who added Cambodia to her world tour after an outpouring of support from her fans on Facebook. Students from the U.S. Embassys Opportunity Fund program at the American Corner at Pannasastra University were at the concert and reported that they had a fantastic time. Cambodia has not hosted many top musical acts in recent years, but I hope that the success of Demi Lovatos concert will encourage many more to come.

Before Demi took the stage, Cambodian-American pop singer Laura Mam opened the concert with an electrifying performance that included her latest song Yosop Yulsong, which calls on young Cambodians to search for the hero within themselves and follow their dreams. Laura is from San Jose, California but now lives here in Cambodia and can be seen performing at events throughout the country. I have been following her career with great interest and expect many great things to come.
I would love to hear what you have to say about Phnom Penhs music scene and where you like to go to listen to live music. Please share your thoughts in the comments section. 
#AmbTodd #Cambodia

2003: The United States and Cambodia sign an agreement to restrict the import of Cambodian artifacts into the U.S.  market, in an attempt to prevent looting of Cambodias cultural heritage. A highlight of the deal is the repatriation in 2007 of a sandstone Apsara dancer from the 13th Century that had been smuggled into the United States. U.S. assistance also helps restore some of Cambodias most precious Angkorean monuments, including an ambitious $1.5 million project to preserve Phnom Bakheng temple.

2006: Former President Bill Clinton visits Cambodia in December. During a meeting with Prime Minister Hun Sen, he signs a memorandum of understanding under which his Clinton Foundation will provide support in the fight against HIV/AIDS. Meanwhile, bilateral U.S. assistance makes a major impact on HIV/AIDS over the course of the decade, helping to cut the diseases prevalence rate from 2% to less than 1%, making Cambodia a rare success story in the global fight against the disease.

2006: The United States opens a new Embassy in January. The facility, which is located next to the famed Wat Phnom temple on Phnom Penhs north side, occupies an entire city block and houses over 500 employees. As the first purpose-built U.S. Embassy in Cambodia, the new complex is a sign of growing U.S. engagement in the country.

2007: On April 4, the Peace Corps swears in its first class of volunteers to serve in Cambodia. The 29 volunteers serve their two-year tours living with Cambodian families in rural villages throughout the country, teaching English at upper secondary schools and regional teacher training centers. Successive classes swell in size as the decade continues.

2009: The Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia, better known as the Khmer Rouge tribunal, begins its first case on February 16. The defendant is Kaing Guek Eav, better known by his revolutionary name Duch, who oversaw the torture and execution of some 12,000 people as warden of Tuol Sleng prison. After 30 years of waiting, Cambodian witnesses finally appear in a court of law to describe the horrors they endured under the Democratic Kampuchea regime. A verdict in Duchs case is expected in the summer of 2010. Meanwhile, the four remaining Khmer Rouge leaders in custody are likely to face trial in 2011. The United States has committed $6.8 million to support the trial.

The U.S. Embassys American Corners and the Information Resource Center
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Next month, Cambodian students across the country will take their final high school examinations.  Final exams are an opportunity for students to demonstrate their knowledge and practice good study habits.  But exam season can also be a stressful time for students, especially when it is difficult to find a quiet place to study.  As students prepare for their exams, I hope that they take advantage of the academic resources that the U.S. Embassy offers to the Cambodian public. 

One example of these resources is within our very own Embassy grounds.  The Information Resource Center (IRC) is U.S. Embassy Phnom Penhs library, where students have a space to study, surrounded by books, magazines, and computers  all accessible to the public for free.  Open Monday to Friday from 8:30-11:30 a.m. and 1:30-4:30 p.m., the IRC also has an impressive online collection of books and materials available for all visitors.  

The IRC is also a space for students to practice their communication skills during our bi-monthly English language chats.  High school students, English language Fellows from the United States, and other volunteers come together to discuss a variety of topics ranging from environmental sustainability and American culture to the education in Cambodia.  I am happy to learn that many students take advantage of this opportunity to meet other young leaders, practice their English, and, most importantly, express their opinions and goals for the future.  

Along with the IRC, the U.S. Embassy is also proud to host four American Corners in Cambodia, located in Phnom Penh, Siem Reap, Battambang, and Kampong Cham.  An American Corner is a friendly and accessible space open to the public that provides current and reliable information about the United States through a large collection of books, magazines, films and documentaries.  Like the IRC, the American Corners also have free Internet and resource materials such as practice books for the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), the Student Aptitude Test (SAT), and the American College Testing (ACT) exam  examples of standardized tests that a student might take if applying to study in the United States.  The presence of American Corners throughout Cambodia is indicative of the United States commitment to providing access to education and information for all students.  I strongly encourage all students to take advantage of the spaces available to them to study for their examinations.  

The American Corner in Phnom Penh and the Royal University of Phnom Penh are also locations with EducationUSA Advising Centers.  EducationUSA provides a wealth of information on U.S. educational institutions and how to enroll in these schools.  When I meet with young Cambodian students, they often tell me that it is their dream to study in the United States.  EducationUSA can assist students in making this dream come true.  Experienced and helpful consultants are ready to meet with students for one-on-one advising and even identify possible scholarships and other financial aid sources.  

But the American Corners are more than just a place to study.  They are a place for people of all ages to learn about the culture and history of the United States, to take ownership of their education, and to have fun learning new information.  American Corner locations host speakers and events on a variety of topics.  Through diverse and consistent programming, American Corners help provide Cambodians with exciting cultural exchange opportunities.  I hope that through these experiences, people will help amplify their worldview, learn to think critically, and share their ideas and opinions in a space they can consider safe and welcoming. 

We offer these spaces and resources with students in mind, because we know that their success today will be Cambodias prosperity tomorrow.   To all students entering exams, I wish you the best of luck in your studies.  I also hope you will continue to use our American Corner locations and programming beyond the exam seasons.  Your participation will make all the difference in incentivizing more young people to become catalysts for their education and success. 

Have you visited or attended an event at one of our American Corners or the Information Resource Center at the U.S. Embassy?  Please comment and tell me about your experience. 
#AmbTodd #Cambodia

Welcoming the Newest Embassy Interns
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Ive written before on this blog about the value of internships as a way for young Cambodians to explore a possible career, gain valuable job experience, and enhance their resume.  Internships are also popular in the United States, and an increasing number of young Americans are looking for opportunities overseas in places like Cambodia.  This summer, the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh is proud to host a number of students and recent graduates from the United States.  Working alongside our diplomats and local staff, our interns will contribute in meaningful ways to the U.S.-Cambodia relationship while getting to know and appreciate this wonderful country.

Three of our interns are here on prestigious fellowships from the U.S. government.  Jessica Pham and Sandra Zuniga Guzman received the Thomas R. Pickering Fellowship from the U.S. State Department, while Emma Din is a recipient of the Donald M. Payne Fellowship through the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID).  The Pickering and Payne Fellowships are among a group of highly competitive programs that are specifically designed to increase the diversity and talent of our diplomatic corps.  Upon completion of their internships, Jessica, Sandra, and Emma will be joining the U.S. Foreign Service to begin their careers as diplomats.

The opportunity to participate in a series of internships in the United States and overseas is at the heart of these fellowship programs.  Our Embassy interns will have a chance to see how diplomacy works and to develop skills that will help them be successful in their careers.  For proof that these programs work, you dont have to look any further than here at the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh, where there are two Pickering Fellows alumni currently serving in key roles.  Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung was part of the first class of Pickering Fellows and had an overseas internship at the U.S. Embassy in Bonn, Germany (before the capital moved to Berlin).  Assistant Public Affairs Officer C.J. Woods was named a Pickering Fellow in 2009.  C.J. did his overseas internship at the U.S. Embassy in Bangkok, Thailand where, believe it or not, he worked with Julie.  It truly is a small world!

I am also proud of our former interns at the U.S. Embassy in Cambodia who have moved on to even bigger and better things.  Last summer, Pickering Fellow Donna Hernandez was an intern in our Public Affairs Section.  During her internship, Donna worked on speeches, organized cultural events, and visited our American Corners to speak with young Cambodians.  Today, Donna is in Washington, DC as a newly-minted U.S. Foreign Service officer preparing for her first assignment.  Donna says that her time as an intern in Cambodia has prepared her for a career as a diplomat and that she hopes to come back to Southeast Asia to build on her experience here. 

In addition to programs for U.S. interns, the Embassy also provides internships for Cambodian university students.  This July, we will be giving 12 promising young Cambodians an opportunity to gain experience in areas such as financial management, information technology, and human resources.  These students will have the chance to develop their leadership skills and prepare themselves for future career opportunities.  If you are interested in learning more about U.S. Embassy internship program opportunities for Cambodians, please be sure to check our website and to follow us on Facebook.

Internships are not the only way to gain experience, but done properly they can become an invaluable part of a young persons academic and professional development.  I encourage young Cambodians to follow the example of Jessica, Sandra, and Emma, who are using internships to further their careers and to make a difference in the world.  We are lucky to have them, and I wish them and their fellow interns the very best for a fun and productive summer.

U.S. Embassy Deputy Chief of Mission Attends the Launch of Century 21 in Cambodia

On September 4, U.S. Embassy Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung welcomed to Cambodia one of Americas most well-known companies  real estate leader Century 21.
  
From its beginning in California in 1971, Century 21 has grown to become one of the most recognized real estate brands in the world.  Today, Century 21 has over 100,000 sales professionals in over 7,000 offices throughout the world.  With the opening of the Century 21 Cambodia office, the Century 21 brand is now represented in 75 countries worldwide.  

According to Ms. Chung, the launch of the new Century 21 office is a significant day for Cambodia, demonstrating how far this nation has come in its development and showcasing its vast potential for foreign investment and economic development.

With over 40 years of experience applying American business concepts to real estate sales, the entry of the Century 21 brand in Cambodia is expected to help increase the level of professionalism and trust in the real estate brokerage sector in this country.

Photo: Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung (center) with officials from the Century 21 Cambodia office.

Life on Earth depends on #ourocean: The ocean covers 70 percent of our planet. A healthy ocean is central to human well-being. The ocean feeds billions of people, employs millions of workers, and generates trillions of dollars in the world economy.  Secretary John Kerry.

The third #OurOcean Conference will take place in Washington, DC on September 15-16, hosted by U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry.  This years event, titled Our Ocean, One Future, will focus on sustainable fisheries, marine pollution, climate-related impacts on the ocean, and marine protected areas. 

President Barack Obama will deliver the keynote address on September 15. Other speakers will include Secretary Kerry, actor and environmental activist Leonardo DiCaprio, foreign delegates, and members of civil society and the private sector. Cambodia will be represented at the conference by Minister of Environment Say Samal.

For the latest information about the OurOcean conference, go to www.OurOcean2016.org.

"The United States considers LGBTI rights to be human rights, and promoting human rights is our top foreign policy goal in Cambodia. Last month, there were many important discussions in Cambodia and around the world regarding the advancement of human rights for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and intersex (LGBTI) people. Many of these conversations occurred on May 17, recognized globally as the International Day against Homophobia and Transphobia (#IDAHOT). Here in Cambodia, IDAHOT was part of the 12th annual celebration of Pride Week, organized each year to raise awareness about the rights of the LGBTI community. Cambodia is not a country that criminalizes LGBTI behavior. In fact, His Majesty the late King Father Norodom Sihanouk expressed his support for same-sex marriage in Cambodia as early as 2004. I commend the Prime Minister for urging Cambodians not to discriminate against LGBTI persons. Through legal reform, open dialogue, and sustained partnerships, we can expect to bring an end to violence and discrimination against LGBTI people in Cambodia. Along with the Cambodian government, NGOs and civil society play a valuable role by partnering with us to improve conditions and promote the advancement of LGBTI rights." - #AmbTodd #Cambodia

To read the full version of Ambassador Todd's column, "Protecting the Rights of the LGBTI community" go to http://bit.ly/1Gk6EqM

This week, Ambassador Todd discusses the findings of Cambodias Violence Against Children Survey 2013.  The Ambassador also notes the leadership of the Royal Government of Cambodia, in particular the Ministry of Womens Affairs, in conducting this survey.  But first, the Ambassador outlines some of the effects of violence on children:

Before we look at the study, we have to understand the impact and consequences of violence against children.  Scientific research has shown that when a child is harmed through an act of violence, there are demonstrable physical and emotional consequences for the child.  Child victims suffer long-term adverse effects in their cognitive development and their mental health.  For example, they are more likely to suffer from mental distress, to contract sexually transmitted diseases, to inflict self-harm, and more likely to become alcoholics.  All of these impacts are detrimental for the victims who suffer them, while the cost to society of addressing these consequences is enormous.  For Cambodia alone, the estimated economic loss attributable to these impacts was $161 million in 2013, according to UNICEF.  Furthermore, children who experience violence are more likely to become victims and perpetrators of violence as adults, thereby perpetuating a tragic cycle of violence. 

You can read the entire column, titled The Importance of Protecting Children from Violence, at the Cambodia Herald at: http://goo.gl/9wQmYe

Ambassador Todd addresses what is being done to help Cambodia protect against the Ebola virus: 

I understand that people may be concerned about the Ebola virus spreading to Cambodia.  According to the CDC, the risk is very low since Ebola is not airborne and people only spread the infection after they have symptoms.  Nevertheless, our health team at the U.S. Embassy, including experts with US CDC, has been working with the Royal Government of Cambodia and with the WHO to ensure that the appropriate measures have been put in place so that infection will not spread in the unlikely event that someone with Ebola comes to Cambodia.

UT Bunchhoeun is among the latest group of #YSEALI members from #Cambodia participating in the YSEALI Professional Fellows Program. Bunchhoeun - a Program Team Leader with the NGO "My Village Organization" in Mondulkiri province - is in the United States on an exchange program hosted by the Mansfield Center of the University of Montana. Like Mondulkiri, the U.S. state of Montana is known for its natural beauty. Bunchhoeun recently visited Yellowstone National Park, the oldest National Park in the United States and the first National Park in the world. He said that he was "very lucky" to be one of the millions of people who visit the park each year to see its wildlife, forests, and "Old Faithful" -  one of the world's most famous geothermal geysers. See what else Bunchhoeun had to say about his visit to Yellowstone by reading his blog (and the blogs of other YSEALI members) at https://mansfieldprofellows.wordpress.com/2016/05/16/nature-interactions-in-america.

They were part of a dynamic group of youth leaders from across ASEAN learning effective strategies for reducing drug use and increasing public awareness in their local communities. (CSPO)          

The Cambodian School of Prosthetics and Orthotics (CSPO) provides free physical rehabilitation services to Cambodians in need, including people with birth defects or who have lost limbs in accidents. Just as important, it is a training center for Cambodian and international students who want to help others, offering a degree program for prosthetists and orthotists.  (Prosthetists and orthotists make and fit artificial limbs and other devices to help people regain mobility.)

CSPO   ( Cambodia Trust)   CSPO         CSPO   

CSPO is part of UK-based NGO Exceed (formerly called Cambodia Trust), which receives funding from around the world, including the United States.  CSPO has been in operation for more than 20 years and has trained more than 70 Cambodians, along with dozens of international students.  In addition to physical rehabilitation, CSPO also offers services to help their clients gain access to education and jobs and to improve their overall quality of life.

  Jay Raman   CSPO   

Earlier this week, U.S. Embassy Public Affairs Officer Jay Raman was invited to tour the CSPO campus in Phnom Penh, where he met with staff and was impressed by the painstaking work that goes into making prosthetic devices.

U.S. and Cambodian Navies begin 2014 CARAT exercise in Cambodia 
From Destroyer Squadron 7 Public Affairs

SIHANOUKVILLE, Cambodia - The fifth convening of the Cooperation Afloat Readiness and Training (CARAT) Cambodia exercise began at Ream Naval Base, October 27.

Vice Adm. Robert Thomas, commander, U.S. 7th Fleet, delivered opening ceremony remarks before participating U.S. Navy Sailors and members of the Royal Cambodian Navy.

"We've made steady progress in just a few years, growing CARAT from a basic port visit to a series of training events on Ream Naval Base and culminating this year in a two-day sea phase in the Gulf of Thailand."

CARAT provides a credible venue for regional navies to share best practices and foster maritime security cooperation. The RCN joined the CARAT series in 2010, making it the first dedicated exercise between both navies in several decades. 

Ashore, personnel will conduct hands-on training in damage control, navigation, tactical combat casualty care (TCCC), force protection and visit, board, search, and seizure (VBSS) techniques. For the first time, the Royal Cambodian Air Force will participate in a joint search and rescue exchange. Symposia will bring together professionals from both navies to discuss best practices in military law, military medicine and aviation search and rescue.

At sea, USS Mustin (DDG 89), embarked with Destroyer Squadron (DESRON) 7 staff and an MH-60R helicopter, will train with two RCN Stenka-class patrol boats. In addition to maneuvering and surface gunnery drills, highlights include a shiprider exchange, maritime boarding scenarios and a search and rescue exercise. 

Also as part of CARAT 2014, USNS Safeguard (T-ARS 50) and embarked mobile diving and salvage unit (MDSU) conducted a bilateral diving exercise focused on diving medicine, port security and underwater hull inspection from Oct. 21-25.

"Maritime security challenges in this region are real," continued Thomas. "No one nation can address these challenges alone which is why exercises like CARAT are critical to promoting regional stability."

Capt. Fred Kacher, Destroyer Squadron 7 commodore, remarked that he looked forward to this year's underway phase with the RCN.

"Successfully operating at-sea together is crucial as both our nations work hard to keep sea lanes safe throughout Southeast Asia," said Kacher. "I am impressed with the increased complexity that this year's CARAT exercise brings and am excited for the opportunity to operate underway with our Cambodian counterparts."

In its 20th year, CARAT is a series of bilateral naval exercises between the U.S. Navy, U.S. Marine Corps and the armed forces of nine partner nations in South and Southeast Asia.

Commander Destroyer Squadron SEVEN

(Photo: Charg dAffaires a.i. Julie Chung opened the Cooperation Afloat Readiness and Training (CARAT) Cambodia exercise at Ream Naval Base, on October 27, 2014)

Gaining Access to the World with English
-From the Ambassador's Penh

In todays globalized economy and with the economic integration of ASEAN countries in 2015, mastery of the English language is a critical tool for Cambodias future leaders.  Many jobs now require at least some ability in English, so young people are becoming more interested in learning the language.  Some communities, however, still lack adequate resources for those seeking to improve their English language skills.  To assist, the U.S. Embassy helps young Cambodians and their families through the English Access Microscholarship Program (Access).  When I hear about the Access Program, I am most inspired by stories about the impact that it continues to have on youth throughout the country.

A native of Phnom Penh, Afiny Math left school at an early age to work and help her family financially.  Due to limited financial resources, it was nearly impossible for her to have an opportunity to receive a good education.  Seeking to improve her English language skills, Afiny applied to the Access Program and was selected.  Upon graduation from the program, she received employment with the Cambodian Islamic Youth Association  the same organization that administered the Access Program where she was a participant.  Today, Afiny is a role model and a good example of how English language learning can have an impact on ones life. 

Afinys story is featured on the website for the U.S. State Department's English Access Microscholarship Program.  She is one of approximately 95,000 students from more than 85 countries that have participated in the program since 2004.  Through after-school classes and intensive summer learning activities, talented youth aged 13-20 receive a strong foundation of English language skills.  Additionally, they develop an appreciation for American culture and values, enhance their ability to compete for and participate in future U.S. government exchange and study programs, and increase their capability to successfully participate in their countrys development.

Over the past 10 years, the Access Program has provided scholarships to more than 1,000 Cambodian students in 11 provinces.  Working with a number of NGOs to administer the program, Access has provided students with friendly learning environments to practice their English language and critical thinking skills.   To enhance their English learning experience, U.S. Embassy staff visit Access Program sites across the country to present certificates, give presentations, or simply have conversations with the students.  Each year, I have the pleasure of meeting several Access Program students and teachers during the English Camp hosted at the U.S. Embassy.  We invest as much as we can to ensure that each participant in the Access Program has an enjoyable experience that will contribute to their continued study of the English language.  

I feel strongly about Cambodians having access to quality English education.  Along with the Access Program, the U.S. Embassy supports English language education in Cambodia in a variety of ways.  English Language Fellows from the United States are working with the National Institute of Education and regional teacher training centers to strengthen curriculum development and professional skills for both teacher trainers and teacher trainees.  Cambodian English language teachers receive instruction training and materials to better prepare their students.  Peace Corps Volunteers are assisting teachers and providing English instruction in 14 provinces.  These and other programs help to increase Cambodias competitiveness by giving people the ability to pursue higher quality education and better jobs.  Furthermore, Cambodians will have the opportunity to utilize the knowledge and skills that they have acquired to assist in developing their communities.  A group of Access students in Ratanakiri are already proving this by helping to establish a library in their local community.  After seeing the commitment demonstrated by the participants of our English language programs, I am confident in their ability to contribute to Cambodias progress.

Through the English Access Microscholarship and other programs, the United States remains committed to helping the people of Cambodia to achieve success and prosperity.  Whenever I speak to young Cambodians, I am pleased to hear so much excitement and interest about English language learning and studying in the United States.  In addition to giving them the skills they need to thrive, these present-day opportunities will help lead Cambodia into a more prosperous future. 

#AmbTodd #Cambodia English Access Microscholarship Program-Cambodia

Helping Cambodian Mothers and Children
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Recently, I read in the newspaper that Cambodia has made tremendous gains in the reduction of infant and children under five mortality rates. For every 1,000 children born in Cambodia, 28 die before reaching the age of one, which is down from 95 in 2000. The mortality rate of children under five is 35 per 1,000, down from 124 in 2000. Another sign of progress is the decrease in the maternal mortality rate  206 per 100,000 live births in 2010, down from 472 in 2005. This is welcome news, and I applaud the government and the Ministry of Health for its commitment to address this issue by improving Cambodias health infrastructure. Nevertheless, we can all do more to reduce the preventable deaths of Cambodian mothers and children.

Thats why I want to recognize the efforts of the many local and international organizations that are fighting to save the lives of Cambodian mothers and children. One such organization is the Reproductive and Child Health Alliance (RACHA)  under the leadership of Executive Director Chan Theary  which works in partnership with the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), the Ministry of Health, and other donors to improve the quality of maternal and newborn care, further strengthening the capacity and services at local health facilities across the country. For her efforts, the U.S. Embassy recognized Chan Theary as a Woman of Courage in 2012 for demonstrating exceptional leadership in advocating for womens rights and empowerment. To this day, Theary continues to help Cambodian girls and mothers live as healthy, dynamic participants in their communities, contributing to a more prosperous Cambodian society.

A key component of RACHAs efforts to reduce maternal mortality is the Life Saving Skills program that improves the professional skills and knowledge of midwives. RACHA provides critical training which enable midwives to identify and respond effectively to life-threatening emergencies. As the primary health care staff at local health centers in rural areas, midwives are essential to ensuring the health of mothers and their babies. If we continue working together to expand universal access to a well-educated, well-equipped, and regulated midwifery workforce, we can further reduce the number of maternal deaths in Cambodia.

Last month, health authorities said malnutrition costs the Cambodian economy $400 million a year, with maternal and child malnutrition totaling nearly $90 million a year. Malnutrition is a complicated issue that requires the private sector and government to work closely together, to deliver services such as clean water and access to proper nutrition. For its part, RACHA has implemented a number of programs that aim to improve nutrition for mothers and children. For example, RACHA trains volunteers who teach mothers and other community members about preparation of nutritional meals, food security, hygiene, home gardening, and poultry and fish farming. Another program promotes breastfeeding and growth monitoring of children under two years old. To reduce the prevalence of anemia and vitamin A deficiencies in mothers and children, RACHA has encouraged the producers of fish sauce, soy sauce, and vegetable oil to add iron and Vitamin A to their products. And to address the lack of safe drinking water, RACHA established several community-based water filtration systems that serve poor families, schools, commune offices, and village health support groups.

While tremendous gains have been made over the years, additional work is necessary to further reduce maternal and infant mortality and to improve child and maternal nutrition. Thats why the Royal Government of Cambodia, USAID, the UN Childrens Fund (UNICEF), the World Food Programme (WFP), and the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) worked together to shine a stronger light on malnutrition in Cambodia at last months Nutrition Conference. The Conference highlighted the challenges that Cambodia faces to overcome chronic malnutrition suffered by many of its mothers and children. The meeting also helped the country recognize important steps that need to be taken to overcome nutrition and health problems. It is this kind of collaboration that will ensure the health and well being of Cambodian mothers and children continue to improve.

(photo courtesy of RACHA)

During a ceremony at Wat Bo Primary School in Siem Reap on June 26, USAID Cambodia Mission Director Rebecca Black (left) joined Cambodian government representatives in recognizing the efforts of the countrys health experts, schools officials, and community members in the fight against Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs).  

NTDs are a group of parasitic and bacterial diseases that cause serious illness for more than one billion people globally, particularly affecting the world's poorest populations.

Ms. Black presented an award to Dr. Muth Sinuon (right), Head of the NTD Program of Cambodias National Center for Malaria Control, Parasitology, and Entomology (CNM).  Dr. Muth Sinuon is recognized as a hero in Cambodias fight against NTDs, particularly for her achievements and tireless effort in expanding access to treatment.

Learn more about the USAIDs work on eliminating NTDs:  http://www.neglecteddiseases.gov/about/index.html

Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Violent Demonstrations in Phnom Penh:

This security message is being issued to alert U.S. citizens residing in or traveling to Cambodia to ongoing political protests and demonstrations in the country. The Embassy has received reports of violent clashes between demonstrators and government security forces one kilometer south of the Phnom Penh International Airport on Veng Sreng Road, including possible fatalities, and advises U.S. citizens to avoid the area southwest of the airport at this time. You should remain alert to local security developments by monitoring local news reports, be vigilant regarding your personal security and preparedness, be aware of your surroundings, and plan your activities accordingly.

?     Heidt    Pactics   Cambodian Textiles Worldwide (CTW) 

 Pactics                  

 CTW          CTW  

  %   Heidt           

Did you know that the United States purchased over $3 billion in Cambodian goods in 2015? The majority of these products come from textile manufacturers located across #Cambodia. Recently, Ambassador Heidt visited two garment factories: Pactics in Siem Reap and Cambodian Textiles Worldwide (CTW) in Phnom Penh. 

Pactics employs 350 people and produces 50 million products annually, mostly microfiber cloths and pouches for designer brand sunglasses. In addition to investments made in sustainable building measures and energy saving technology, the company also offers its employees fair wages, reasonable working hours, safe and clean working conditions, and a full array of other benefits aimed to keep workers healthy.

CTW produces aprons, table linen, bed sheets, hospital apparel, and other specialty textiles. The American-owned company works diligently to maintain a work environment that is both productive and worker friendly. CTW also employs Cambodians in positions of management and actively promotes its employees.  

These two factories are vital to the success of Cambodia's garment industry, which generates over 80% of national export income. But as the managers of the companies told #AmbHeidt, their success is due to the investments made in their employees. For sustained labor productivity and economic growth in Cambodia, the health and reliability of the garment industry workforce is essential.

Do you know what makes someone a hero?  According to American writer Joseph Campbell, A hero is someone who has given his or her life to something bigger than oneself.  

This can absolutely be said about the U.S. Navy Seabees, who have had a 25 person team present in Cambodia since 2008.  The team has been busy constructing water wells, maternity ward clinics, and modern bathroom facilities to improve conditions for the people of Cambodias provinces.  The Seabees also provide basic life support (BLS) training that includes lessons on proper sanitation and hygiene, snake bites, and basic stitching methods.  The Seabees support the U.S. Embassy and USAID by constructing 2-room maternity wards and 5-stall bathroom facilities in an effort to improve pre and post natal care for mothers and to improve the health and sanitation conditions for students.  
   
The Seabees completed maternity wards are already serving a combined population of 55,278 Cambodians and supporting an average of 390 births per year.  The bathroom facilities are currently serving a student population of 3,506.  Over the next three years the Seabees will construct maternity wards and modern bathrooms throughout six provinces that will serve over 90 villages and 77,000 people.  

The U.S. Embassy is proud of the work done by the Seabees and looks forward to their continued success.  See more photos of the United States Navy Seabees in the Embassy Picasa photo album here http://goo.gl/8xDRSB .

Photo: Kep, Cambodia (Nov 10, 2014) Seabees from U.S. Naval Mobile Construction Battalion (NMCB) 4 Detail Cambodia, pose with their counterparts from the Royal Cambodia Armed Forces (RCAF) in front of a 2-room maternity ward being constructed at the Russey Srok Health Center in Kampot Province.

Seabees Kampot, Cambodia

Performers from the National Circus School of Cambodia were a big hit at the Fun Fourth event.

Students in the National Circus School enroll when they are in Grade Three.

They spend the next nine years learning their specialty in the mornings while taking general education classes in the afternoon.

When students graduate, they earn a Certificate that is equivalent to a Diploma.

They then have the skills to become professional circus performers and trainers.

With one of the most advanced laboratories in Cambodia,  the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit-2 Detachment (NAMRU-2) in Phnom Penh features a highly trained team of certified Cambodian and U.S. specialists in the early detection of viral diseases.  Their amazing work is being done with the purpose of benefiting Cambodians and others worldwide.  NAMRU-2 staff members are experts in sciences like molecular biology, examining DNA samples to help address public health issues in Cambodia and throughout the region.  State of the art lab equipment helps NAMRU-2 scientists research and develop effective vaccines and treatment for a number of diseases.  The NAMRU-2 facilities have also been utilized by the Cambodian Ministry of Health and local laboratory science students for over 11,000 hours of clinical lab training techniques.  To learn more about NAMRU-2, go to http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/namru2.html.

Congratulations to Sipar Cambodia, which is being honored by The Library of Congress for its inspiring efforts to promote literacy in #Cambodia! Sipar will be recognized during the 2016 Library of Congress Literacy Awards celebration next month in Washington, DC. APPLY NOW FOR #TechCamp H2.0 IN #CAMBODIA!! On September 24-25 in Phnom Penh, TechCamp H2.0 will bring together young leaders currently working to improve waterways in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam in order to develop practical, technology-based solutions to shared challenges. Although you don't have to be tech-savvy, participants must be members of the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (#YSEALI) and have a clear understanding of the challenges that impact waterways in the Lower Mekong region. And don't worry...all travel expenses, lodging and meals will be covered for nominated participants!

Interested? If you or someone you know would like to participate, please visit www.surveymonkey.com/r/XHJMZQM and complete the registration form by Friday, August 19. Only 30 participants from Cambodia will be selected, so act fast!

TechCamps are a U.S. Department of State initiative designed to help create low-cost, easy-to-implement technological solutions to social challenges around the world. To learn more, visit techcampglobal.org/.

Join Cambodian Fulbright Fellow Pichleap Sok as she continues her adventure with the Millennial Trains Project!  The #MTPTrain took Pichleap through the state of Texas this week, visiting the cities of Austin and San Antonio to experience American culture, learn from special guest speakers, and exchange ideas with other young leaders. Here's what she had to say about her time:

"San Antonio is definitely one of my favorite cities. San Antonio to me seems like a great place for those who want to leave their marks as the city is growing and developing. Because the day we arrived in San Antonio was Memorial Day, I had a difficult time contacting local women in technology for the interview. But it turned out to be pretty good. I got to interview a woman in tech. As other amazing women in tech I talked to, Leslie left me feel so inspired. She gave good advice to young girls and women out there. After the interview, I had a great time walking around San Antonio with other two Fulbrighters from Poland and South Africa. We took a boat ride along the river walk. The ticket costs $8.50, but it's worth every single penny. It's so relaxing and refreshing."

Have questions for Pichleap about her trip? Please post and stay tuned to find out more about her journey!

Congratulations to Cambodian Phymean Noun!

She was awarded the World's Children's Prize and $50,000 this week. The money will fund a floor of a new school building currently under construction at Stung Mean Chey.

Also called the Children's Nobel Prize, Phymean was selected for her tireless work to help some of the poorest children in Cambodia get an education.

As founder and CEO of People Improvement Organization (PIO) , she has worked with children in Phnom Penh since 2002.

Today, PIO serves over 1,300 children a day by offering education, uniforms, school material, nutritious meals, healthcare, and clean water.

To learn more about the work of Phymean Noun and PIO visit: http://peopleimprovement.org/

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OfP775xNgPA

Idaho      GMC  

In February, the Idaho National Guard participated in a maintenance exchange on the General Motors Corporation (GMC) truck fleet with members of the Royal Cambodia Armed Forces (RCAF).

The Idaho National Guard assisted RCAF instructors as they trained less experienced soldiers on the operation and preventative maintenance of GMC trucks.

The exchange included classroom instruction, hands-on training, and the repair of U.S. Army power generators donated to the RCAF.

The exchange was a big success and strengthens the military relationship between the United States and Cambodia.

 Idaho    GMC

What do you think of the new design of our website?

http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/

Website   

The new design makes the homepage more visually stimulating, with larger, more meaningful graphics and increased space for more content. This means users will have more information at their disposal directly from the top of the site. 

    * The easy-to-navigate site functions the same as the old site, so users dont have to learn a new navigation.
    * The homepage slideshow highlights the top four stories. It displays embassy events in bigger images, so its easy to grab your attention.
    * The tabbed area in the middle section of the page offers the ability to display multiple key embassy programs, social media sites and State Department reports without taking away from the daily content.
    * On the upper part of the homepage, the 7 tabs remain the same, except Policy News which is replaced by News & Events. This tab holds Embassy events articles, press releases, speeches and State Department reports.
    * For now, Khmer website of the embassy (http://khmer.cambodia.usembassy.gov/) is still in the old design. We hope the new design will be ready in a few months.

"For the past several weeks, my thoughts have often turned to the many people affected by the recent flooding throughout Cambodia. 

When a natural disaster strikes, we are reminded of our fragility.  Like Cambodia, the United States must frequently deal with the effects of powerful weather calamities and other natural forces. 

As we confront our own vulnerabilities, the U.S. government also recognizes the challenges that Cambodians face in preparing for, and responding to, natural disasters. That is why the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) is providing $200,000 to help strengthen emergency preparedness in Cambodia."
