Ambassador Heidt met yesterday with Acting Minority Leader of the National Assembly H.E. Kem Sokha, who also recently met with U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry during his official visit to #Cambodia. During the meeting, the Ambassador expressed the importance that the United States places on the ability of elected representatives from all parties to perform their responsibilities without fear of attack or arrest. Direct outreach by political parties to their constituents is an important part of democracy in both the United States and Cambodia. The Ambassador noted that both the majority and minority parties play a vital role in Cambodias development, and that dialogue between the parties can help resolve issues, strengthen democracy, and move the country forward.

Did you know that starting next spring, 250 YSEALI professionals will get the chance to study in the United States?  If you are a young professional in Cambodia, here is how you can add your name to the list. 

The YSEALI Professional Fellows Program is a professional development exchange program for the best and brightest community leaders from the ASEAN region, working in the fields of civic engagement, NGO management, economic empowerment, governance, legislative process, environmental and natural resources management. 

The program provides participants with a five-week fellowship at U.S.-based non-profit organizations, private companies, government offices, or legislative bodies. Fellows will work with community leaders to enhance their practical expertise, leadership skills and professional contacts to address issues in their home communities.

The application deadline for YSEALI Professional Fellows is December 5th, 2014, so act now if you would like to apply.  Applicants must be: 
  Between the ages of 25-35 at the time of the application, although exceptional applicants younger than 25 will be considered if they meet all other eligibility requirements;
  A Cambodian citizen;
  Currently employed and with at least two years of professional experience at the time of application;
  Proficient in spoken and written English at the time of application; and
  Eligible to receive a United States J-1 visa.

To apply now go here http://goo.gl/c1eztH. Once there, click the link to at the bottom of the page to apply.

Want to peek at what else YSEALI has to offer? Check out this video http://goo.gl/ICkLFM  

Join YSEALI today! yseali.state.gov

International Education Week: 5 Steps to Studying in the United States

Step 4: Apply for your student visa

Be prepared for the student visa process!  Become familiar with the student visa requirements and allow plenty of time to prepare your application.

You will first need to receive an admission letter a certificate of eligibility for nonimmigrant student status from your U.S. University before you can begin the visa application.

Because interviews are short, do your best to explain why you want to study in the United States, how you plan to support yourself while in school, and what your plans are for when your studies are finished.

Did you know the U.S. Department of State issued 781,719 student and exchange visitor visas in fiscal year 2011? This translates to a worldwide acceptance rate of almost 86%. 

Many accredited U.S. colleges and universities now offer entire distance education programs of study entirely online. If you are accepted to one of these programs, you will not have to apply for a visa, since you physically will not be taking classes in the United States. However, if your online degree program requires you to take a seminar in the U.S. for academic credit, then you'll need a student visa. Again, a consular officer will determine the visa category you will need based on the purpose of your travel, and your supporting documentation.

Learn more about step four: applying for your student visa here at the EducationUSA website http://goo.gl/LTzPB5

Ambassador Todd is participating in a week-long U.S.-ASEAN Business Council tour of the United States with fellow U.S. Ambassadors to Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore. Dr. Kin Phea, Director of the Department of Diplomatic Studies at the International Relations Institute of Cambodia, is currently in the United States participating in the Study of the U.S. Institute for Scholars program.  As Dr. Phea explains, he has joined a multinational group of 18 experienced foreign university faculty and practitioners who are gaining a deeper understanding of how contemporary U.S. foreign policy is formulated and implemented.  Pictured here, Dr. Phea and his colleagues at the Institute met with New York state legislators at the New York State Assembly in Albany.  

The Study of the U.S. Institutes is a program organized and funded by the U.S. Department of State to provide students, teachers, and scholars from all over the world opportunities to travel to the United States and participate in academic enrichment programs focusing on U.S. history, culture, and governance.

The Lost Kingdoms Exhibition At The MET, and Some Art Historical Issues

Today (Tuesday, August 4) at 4:00pm at the National Museum of Cambodia, John Guy, Curator of South & Southeast Asian Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (the MET) in New York City, will speak about the exhibit Lost Kingdoms: Hindu-Buddhist Sculpture of Early Southeast Asia, 5th to 8th Century, featuring loaned pieces from Cambodia and other countries.

The lecture will address how first millennium Southeast Asia is interpreted and some art historical issues which signal the distinctive character of Southeast Asian religious imagery.

River Book, co-publisher of the accompanying book, will have copies available in cooperation with Monument Books.

You can view the Lost Kingdoms exhibit online at: http://www.metmuseum.org/exhibitions/listings/2014/lost-kingdoms

POSITION: Financial Management Analyst
ANNUAL SALARY RANGE: USD 12,116  18,785
CLOSING DATE: May 23, 2013

More information: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/job3.html

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:

* Bachelors Degree in Accounting, Finance, Economics or Business Administration is required.

* At least three years progressive work experience in budget or financial management within International Organizations, Non-Governmental Organizations, or other Governmental Institutions.

* Level IV (Fluent) Speaking/Reading/Writing English and Khmer are required. Language proficiency will be tested.

* Must be able to relate financial activities (e.g., obligations, liquidations, strip coding, etc.) to financial plans and budgeting requirements for the out-year.

* Must be able to work effectively, work under pressure, and work as a team. Must have excellent administrative, mathematic and analytical skills, good interpersonal and communication skills, good attention to details, and skills in formulating, monitoring and reporting budgets.

* Must be able to operate various computer applications software.

It's #ThrowbackThursday again and we celebrate the Voting Rights Act of 1965, a historic achievement for civil rights and an inclusive democracy in the United States.  Exactly 50 years ago today, the law was enacted to help eliminate barriers to voting for all citizens.  This photo shows President Lyndon B. Johnson greeting Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Rosa Parks, and other civil rights leaders on the day that the law was signed.  Later today, President Obama will participate in a video teleconference with citizens nationwide to underscore the importance of restoring this landmark law to strengthen and protect Americans rights to vote.

Hello everyone, Im Michelle Obama, and on this Mothers Day weekend, I want to take a moment to honor all the mothers out there and wish you a Happy Mothers Day. 

I also want to speak to you about an issue of great significance to me as a First Lady, and more importantly, as the mother of two young daughters.

Like millions of people across the globe, my husband and I are outraged and heartbroken over the kidnapping of more than 200 Nigerian girls from their school dormitory in the middle of the night. 

This unconscionable act was committed by a terrorist group determined to keep these girls from getting an education  grown men attempting to snuff out the aspirations of young girls. 

And I want you to know that Barack has directed our government to do everything possible to support the Nigerian governments efforts to find these girls and bring them home. 

In these girls, Barack and I see our own daughters.

We see their hopes, their dreams  and we can only imagine the anguish their parents are feeling right now.

Many of them may have been hesitant to send their daughters off to school, fearing that harm might come their way. 

But they took that risk because they believed in their daughters promise and wanted to give them every opportunity to succeed. 

The girls themselves also knew full well the dangers they might encounter. 

Their school had recently been closed due to terrorist threats but these girls still insisted on returning to take their exams. 

They were so determined to move to the next level of their educationso determined to one day build careers of their own and make their families and communities proud.   

And what happened in Nigeria was not an isolated incident. It is a story we see every day as girls around the world risk their lives to pursue their ambitions. 

Its the story of girls like Malala Yousafzai from Pakistan.

Malala spoke out for girls education in her community, and as a result, she was shot in the head by a Taliban gunman while on a school bus with her classmates. 

But fortunately Malala survivedand when I met her last year, I could feel her passion and determination as she told me that girls education is still her lifes mission. 

As Malala said in her address to the United Nations, she said The terrorists thought that they would change our aims and stop our ambitions but nothing changed in my life except this: Weakness, fear and hopelessness died. Strength, power and courage was born.

The courage and hope embodied by Malala and girls like her around the world should serve as a call to action. 

Because right now, more than 65 million girls worldwide are not in school. 

Yet, we know that girls who are educated make higher wages, lead healthier lives, and have healthier families. 

And when more girls attend secondary school, that boosts their countrys entire economy. 

So education is truly a girls best chance for a bright future, not just for herself, but for her family and her nation. 

And thats true right here in the U.S. as wellso I hope the story of these Nigerian girls will serve as an inspiration for every girl  and boy  in this country. 

I hope that any young people in America who take school for granted  any young people who are slacking off or thinking of dropping out  I hope they will learn the story of these girls and recommit themselves to their education.

These girls embody the best hope for the future of our worldand we are committed to standing up for them not just in times of tragedy or crisis, but for the long haul.

We are committed to giving them the opportunities they deserve to fulfill every last bit of their God-given potential. 

So today, let us all pray for their safe return... let us hold their families in our hearts during this very difficult timeand let us show just a fraction of their courage in fighting to give every girl on this planet the education that is her birthright.  Thank you.

Yesterday, Ambassador Todd presided over a repatriation ceremony to honor the recovery of possible remains of missing U.S. military service members found in Kampong Cham province.

Halloween, what is it?

While not an official holiday, the traditional October 31 Halloween celebration is very popular with children in the United States.  On Halloween, children dress up in costumes  often depicting ghosts, goblins, and other supernatural creatures  and collect candy and other treats from adults.  This is called trick-or-treating.  Plenty of adults also celebrate Halloween by attending costume parties, although they might prefer to dress up to look like celebrities, political candidates, or other public figures.

Most Americans consider Halloween a festive occasion, but its roots long predate the United States and its meaning has changed greatly over time. Even today, many other nations observe their own versions of this festival.  Read more about Halloween at: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/article/2005/10/20051028160422jmnamdeirf0.9446985.html#axzz3GkjIKAoL

Halloween is also a time for frightening stories.  Stories like The Legend of Sleepy Hollow, written by Washington Irving in 1820, are told to children to add an atmosphere of fun and wonder to Halloween. VOA has a version of the story on its website.  Visit that page here:  http://learningenglish.voanews.com/content/sleepy-hollow-washington-irving-legend-american-stories/2455431.html

Exchange Program Spotlight: YSEALI Professional Fellows

Are you a professional interested in learning more ways to help your local economy?  The YSEALI Professional Fellows Program offers an exciting opportunity to join other professionals in broadening your expertise.
  
Emerging business leaders from around the world meet in the United States to complete fellowships in relevant businesses, government offices, non-profit organizations, or business associations.  The program also connects professional fellows with Americans in the same field, to develop enduring professional ties.  

YSEALI Professional Fellows is now accepting applications until December 1st, 2014.          

Chhair Sokty participated in the program this year, and shared this detailed account: 

I participated in Economic Empowerment Fellowship Program for five weeks from Oct 4 to Nov 9.  There were 14 fellows from five countries in Lower Mekong such as Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam.  We spent four weeks in Montana for lecture on U.S. social, economic, and political system, fellowship with an organization, and study tour on nature and livelihood of people; and one week in DC to visit federal offices and other organizations.  We had opportunity to meet other professional fellows from Southeast Asia and all five continents with the total number of over 250.  We have learned and shared personal, professional, and cultural experience with fellow friends and developed lasting friendship without border.  Our gratitude goes to the Department of State and Mansfield Center of Montana University which have sponsored and coordinated our activities to the maximum benefit. I also had opportunity to introduce Preah Vihear Temple to students and professors at Mansfield Center.

Find out more about the YSEALI Professional Fellows Program here http://goo.gl/c1eztH

Statement of President Barack Obama Commemorating International Women's Day

As half the planet, women make immeasurable contributions to our world. They are entrepreneurs, farmers, educators, scientists, artists, soldiers, mothers, heads of state  the list is endless. Without them, economies would collapse, political systems would deteriorate, and families and communities would fall apart. Yet in too many places, women are treated as second-class citizens. Their abilities are undervalued. And their human rights  the right to learn, to express themselves, to live free from violence, to choose whether and whom to marry  are routinely violated.

This gap between womens inherent value and how many of them are treated every day is one of the great injustices of our time. On this International Women's Day, we recommit ourselves to closing that gap.

That means supporting girls' education. Right now, 62 million girls worldwide who should be in school aren't. Millions more are at risk of losing their access to education. This week, Michelle and I announced an initiative called "Let Girls Learn," to help dismantle the barriers  economic, political and cultural  that stand in the way of girls who want to learn.

I'm convinced that a world in which women and girls are treated as equal to men and boys is safer, more stable, and more prosperous. Beyond those tangible benefits, this is simply a matter of right and wrong. Women and girls are human beings, full and equal in rights and dignity. They deserve to be treated that way, everywhere, every day. My Administration will continue working to make that vision a reality.

http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/03/08/statement-president-barack-obama-commemorating-international-womens-day

Ambassador Heidt swore in the 10th group of Peace Corps Cambodia volunteers today in a special ceremony at the HIMAWARI HOTEL APARTMENTS in Phnom Penh. A new class of 69 volunteers just finished their training and will be working in #Cambodias provinces for two years.  The volunteers live with local host families and work side-by-side with local counterparts on community health and education projects. 

The Ambassador was joined at the ceremony by H.E. Im Koch, Secretary of State of the Ministry of Education, Youth, and Sports. The ceremony featured remarks from Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung. Also speaking today were Peace Corps Deputy Chief of Staff Becca Sharp and Peace Corps-Cambodia Country Director Sue Dwyer.

The ceremony was also an opportunity to celebrate Peace Corps-Cambodias 10th anniversary. Counting the current group, more than 500 Peace Corps volunteers have served in Cambodia, serving the people of 16 provinces. 

Please join us in wishing Peace Corps a happy birthday! To learn more about the Peace Corps in Cambodia, click here: https://www.peacecorps.gov/cambodia/.

#pck10years

Congratulations to the new Peace Corps Volunteers in Cambodia!

Earlier today, Peace Corps Cambodia swore in its 8th Cohort of Peace Corps Volunteers (PCVs).  Among the distinguished guests at the ceremony were, H.E. Dr. Pit Chamnan, Secretary of State, Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport and H.E. Eng Hout, Secretary of State, Ministry of Health, Ambassador Willam Todd, U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia, and Penny Fields, Peace Corps Cambodia Country Director.  

The 53 new PCVs will join the 41 current PCVs in Cambodia to either teach English to secondary students, or work in health education and outreach throughout Cambodia.  

The volunteers will spend the next two years with their Cambodian host families and strive to become productive members of the local community. 

More about Peace Corps and the work they do around the world here: http://www.peacecorps.gov/

The Office of Defense Cooperation is pleased to invite young Cambodians (between 17 and 23 years old) to compete for appointment at distinguished U.S. military service academies such as the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, the Naval Academy at Annapolis, or the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs.  

Students will receive a world-class education and leader training that will challenge them intellectually, militarily, and physically in an environment that promotes the development of character  for free! Peace Corps: Training Teachers in Cambodia
-From the Ambassador's Penh

Ive written previously that a good education is the foundation upon which future success is built.  With 70 percent of the population under the age of 30, this is especially true for Cambodia and its economic development.  The young people I meet wherever I travel in Cambodia also realize that a good education is the key to finding higher paying jobs that will provide a better life for themselves and their families.  These youth also recognize the value of learning English, which has become the international language of business and the internet.  English will continue to grow in importance for every Cambodian as the country prepares to join the ASEAN Economic Community this year and as more international companies continue to invest in building businesses here.

It should come as no surprise that teachers play a critical role in educating the young people of Cambodia.  Thats why I was so pleased to meet U.S. Peace Corps Volunteer Roger Armendariz  a young man from Kansas who is teaching at the Angkor Thom High School in Siem Reap Province.  Roger is working with students to improve their English language skills and to help teachers develop their skills and techniques.  I was also delighted to meet Thary Loeum, Rogers counterpart teacher at the school.  Thary credits her improved teaching skills to the training she received from another Peace Corps Volunteer at the Battambang Regional Teacher Training Center.  It is wonderful to see the continuing impact of Volunteers who work side by side with their Cambodian counterparts to improve teaching in the country.  The students I met at Angkor Thom were very enthusiastic about their education and learning English.  With their improved English skills, these students will be in a good position to continue their education and to compete for opportunities and employment with companies in Cambodia, the region, and the world.  I commend these students for their commitment to their education and for making progress toward a brighter future.

Roger is a member of the latest group of Peace Corps Volunteers who have answered the call to serve.  Since 2007, more than 360 Peace Corps Volunteers have served in Cambodia, teaching English and educating communities about health in 16 provinces.  During my three years as Ambassador to Cambodia, it has been truly inspiring to meet Volunteers like Roger who care deeply about the Cambodians they live and work with.

Finally, I would like to welcome Susan Dwyer, the new Peace Corps Country Director, who arrived in Cambodia last month.  Susan has lived and worked in many countries during her 20 years of humanitarian aid work.  Most recently, she was a vice-president for the International Rescue Committee.  Although this is Susans first time in Cambodia, she recently told me that she already feels this will be one of her favorite posts.  Im delighted to see that a talented manager like Susan will lead the Peace Corps in Cambodia.  For more than 50 years, nearly 220,000 Peace Corps Volunteers have worked in countries around the world to promote peace and friendship.  Im glad this commitment by the Peace Corps continues to this day.

#AmbTodd #Cambodia #PeaceCorps

On the evening of March 20, the First Lady will travel to Cambodia, one of the first 11 countries to be included in the Let Girls Learn Peace Corps initiative.  

In Cambodia, Mrs. Obama and Peace Corps Director Hessler-Radelet will see up close how community-driven solutions  which are key components of the Let Girls Learn Peace Corps program  are changing girls lives.

While in Cambodia, Mrs. Obama and Mrs. Bun Rany, the First Lady of Cambodia, will meet with high school students and hear directly how they benefit from community-led programs like Room to Read and the Peace Corps. Room to Read is a non-profit organization that focuses on literacy and gender equality in education, specifically working in Asia and Africa.

Following the First Ladys meeting with Cambodian students, she will deliver remarks to Peace Corps Volunteers participating in a girls education training event that is part of Let Girls Learn. Community leaders and educators who serve as local partners for the Peace Corps volunteers will also be at the event, working together with their respective volunteers to affect change. The training  representative of others happening around the world  equips Peace Corps Volunteers with the necessary resources to break down barriers to girls education in their communities.

The First Lady will also host a roundtable with Peace Corps Volunteers, local community leaders, and civil society members who are implementing projects to support girls education in Cambodia. While in Siem Reap, the First Lady will also visit Angkor Wat and participate in a meet and greet with embassy employees in Cambodia.

Cambodian students who have participated in U.S. government exchange programs are encouraged to contribute to their communities upon their return.  Members of @the Fulbright and Undergraduate State Alumni Association of Cambodia (FUSAAC) recently gathered at the U.S. Embassy for a capacity building workshop.  

Among the participants were Cambodias delegates to the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) conference in Malaysia earlier this year.  They made a presentation about the lessons they learned from the conference, highlighting the importance of networking among U.S. government exchange program alumni in the region.  They also encouraged other alumni to contribute to the YSEALI programs. 

Other activities of the workshop focused on exploring new ideas for community projects and developing leadership skills.  The FUSAAC members also practiced team work in a series of team-building exercises.

Ambassador Todd discusses the importance of improving road safety in Cambodia:

On Monday of this week, my deputy Julie Chung spoke on behalf of the U.S. Embassy at the Road Management Workshop. She emphasized how developing a strong understanding of road management and traffic safety will save lives while also contributing to building a more connected and prosperous ASEAN region. Better and safer roads connecting the members of ASEAN will allow each country to take full advantage of economic benefits that result from the greater flow of people, goods, and services across borders. A better traffic system will also reduce the logistical costs of doing business in Cambodia, helping to attract more foreign investment, and create more and better-paying jobs for Cambodian citizens.

Forest community member Mr. Chan Bunna, aged 45, lives in Sam Omg village, Kampong Thom province.  Mr. Bunna has been earning a living for his family from the surrounding forests for decades.  He collects tree resin and sells it to the local market, while his wife gathers some non-timber forest products such as rattan, mushrooms, wild fruit, and vegetables to feed their family.

Learn how Mr. Bunna, along with 20 communities in Prey Lang Landscape, was helped to mark the boundaries of their forests to protect them from illegal logging and land clearance.  http://goo.gl/6gVJE2 
 
Established in 2012, the Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project is a USAID - US Agency for International Development project that works in the Eastern Plains and Prey Lang Landscapes to provide support to the government of Cambodia to help mitigate climate change, extend sustainable forest management, and increase equitable economic benefits to local communities.  This four year project is being implemented by Winrock International in partnership with the Royal Government of Cambodia through the Forestry Administration as well as the Ministry of Environment and key NGOs partners, including the Wildlife Conservation Society, World Wild Fund for Nature, and Center for People and Forests (RECOFTC). 

Photo: Mengey Eng/Winrock International

In his most recent blog post, A Strong Voice for Cambodian Women, Ambassador Todd discusses the importance of improving the rights, security, and dignity of women and girls. He also highlights a local champion for this cause:

One of Thida Khus biggest concerns  and one that I share  is the lack of women in leadership positions in Cambodia. Thida understands that if Cambodia is going to continue to develop, women must play an increasing role in all sectors of society, from business to education to politics. In order for this to happen, Cambodian women must have the same opportunities as men and to compete with men on an equal basis. This is not a problem that is limited to Cambodia but it is particularly acute here, where women hold only a small fraction of government positions.

Last month, members of the Fulbright and Undergraduate State Alumni Association of Cambodia (FUSAAC) Cambodia (FUSAAC), along with a representative of the Cambodian Rural Development Team, held a workshop called Streams of Hope to promote environmental awareness at Koh Pdao, an island village along the Mekong River in Kratie Province.

The workshop focused on the importance of protecting the Mekong River ecosystem.  Working alongside the villagers, the team demonstrated how to make a bokashi ball, a new easy-to-make tool that reduces the growth of algae in ponds and rivers.  The team also helped plant bamboo plants along the shore to stop harmful erosion.

Learn more about the workshop and the bokashi ball at: http://goo.gl/nZq6r3 

The Streams of Hope Project was designed during a Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) meeting in the Philippines.  Participants from Cambodia, the Philippines, and Vietnam joined together to discuss how to best conduct a project in their countries.  To join YSEALI and partner on projects like this, visit: http://goo.gl/c2ORS0

World leaders have gathered in Paris for the 21st UN climate change conference, known as COP21.  In an address to delegates from nearly 200 countries, King Norodom Sihamoni of Cambodia said, climate change is the defining challenge of our time.  The King also highlighted the struggles of Cambodian farmers to deal with the impacts of climate change.  President Barack Obama also expressed urgency and optimism as world leaders met to tackle climate change.  Here, in Paris, we can show the world what is possible when we come together, united in common effort and by a common purpose, the President said.

The U.S. Department of States Special Representative for International Labor Affairs Sarah Fox recently completed her official visit to #Cambodia. From October 3-5, she met with members of the Royal Government of Cambodia, civil society, the private sector, and other stakeholders to discuss freedom of association, labor courts, minimum wage, and other issues.

During talks with Minister of Labor and Vocational Training H.E. Ith Sam Heng and Minister of Commerce H.E. Pan Sorasak, Mrs. Fox learned more about what the Cambodian government is doing to foster inclusive growth with mature industrial relations. She also spoke with The Arbitration Council Foundation about their success in mediating labor and management disputes. She met with civil society leaders and labor unions to discuss workers' rights, and with international brands and factory representatives to discuss Cambodias competitiveness and future growth.

To learn more about Sarah Fox and the Department of State - Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, please visit http://go.usa.gov/xkqJd.

This project initiated by Peace Corps Volunteers promotes geography literacy in an engaging way while also building a sense of community among students.

 Peace Corps  

This year the Peace Corps is commemorating its 50th Anniversary of promoting peace and friendship around the world  a legacy of service rooted in the vision of President Kennedy. The Peace Corps has been in Cambodia since 2007. In his weekly column, Ambassador Todd identifies 3 priority reforms the Royal Government of Cambodia can implement to build a better future for the Cambodian people. 

Although there are still obstacles to overcome, including completing the electoral reform already underway, the end of the opposition boycott of parliament creates a new political environment that creates an opportunity for real, substantive reforms that will make a real difference in the lives of ordinary Cambodians.  From my discussions with people across Cambodia, three areas for reform stand out in particular:  improving labor standards and working conditions; increasing access to high-quality education; and fighting corruption.

International Education Week: 5 Steps to Studying in the United States 


In celebration of International Education Week (November 17-21), the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh will walk you through the 5 Steps to Studying in the United States -- one step for each day of the week.


Step One:  Research Your Options
   
If you want to study abroad in the United States, you need to start planning early, but how to begin?  There are thousands of colleges and universities in the United States -- which one is right for you?  

In order to figure this out you need to ask yourself some important questions, including:

        Why do you want to study in the United States?
        Where will you fit in best?
        Which colleges or universities will meet your needs?
        Will you need financial assistance?
        What are the application and financial aid deadlines?

It is important to give a lot of thought to your own personal reasons to study in the U.S.  These reasons may change over time, but they will help guide you in your search for the right educational programs and field of study. 

EducationUSA is a U.S. Department of State-supported network of hundreds of advising centers around the world, including in Cambodia.  The EducationUSA office in Pannasastra University provides free counseling services to all students interested in studying in the United States.  To get more help starting your plan, visit the EducationUSA webpage and complete their questionnaire http://goo.gl/6vu5eF

Ambassador Heidt hosted a reception yesterday to honor civil society organizations in #Cambodia.  Approximately 40 leaders of civil society organizations, including the human rights NGO ADHOC-Cambodia, joined the event along with colleagues from other diplomatic missions, the United Nations, and representatives from international NGOs.

The United States and many other countries have supported your work to make Cambodia a more democratic, just, and prosperous country for more than 20 years," #AmbHeidt said in his remarks. "A strong civil society, robust political dialogue, independent judicial system, and the will to fight genuine corruption  these are the institutions and the practices that make a country stable and strong. The United States believes that the more political space there is, the more Cambodia can achieve for its people."

Representatives from some of #Cambodia's leading hospitals, pharmacies, eye care clinics, dental clinics, and other health agencies participated in the U.S. Embassy's Health Fair last Friday. In its ninth year, the annual event featured free health screenings, educational booths, and entertainment focused on the importance of maintaining good health. Specialists provided private consultations and gave out information about heart disease, diabetes, stroke, liver and kidney diseases, blindness, cancer, and more to Embassy staff members and their families.

The Embassy's Annual Blood Drive also took place during the fair, and #AmbHeidt was among several volunteers that donated blood. During the fair, participants learned about many of the examples of quality medical and health services available here in Cambodia. This year's event was once again a major success, sharing healthcare ideas that will save money and improve nutrition for all.

Ambassador Todd participated in a signing ceremony marking the final phase of the GE Foundations equipment donation to Calmette Hospital and the establishment of a biomedical technician training program.

The equipment donation is the final donation to Cambodia under the GE Foundations Developing Health Globally initiative, which has provided approximately $8 million worth of medical equipment to hospitals across Cambodia since 2009.

Our next #YSEALIGenEarth story comes from YSEALI Environmental Fellowship Alumni Ket Monny Vathna: "YSEALI brought me to this new world where culture and environmentalism meet.  I danced in the American Indian Pow Wow ceremony, cooked with my ASEAN peers, and stayed with my host family. At Glacier National Park in Montana, I saw people taking care of every plant, creating new river streams and working hard to combat climate change.  After returning from Montana, my fellow YSEALI members and I brought 25 University students to an indigenous community in Ratanakiri.  There we planted trees and volunteered on a vegetable farm.  Through that project, the younger students learned about climate change, deforestation, and the livelihood of indigenous people.  I hope the students will go on to positively impact society. This would have never happened without my time in Montana. Thank you #YSEALI!

Attention English language teaching professionals in #Cambodia! The U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh  in conjunction with American English for Educators and eLearning company Voxy  is now accepting applications for the 2016 E-Teacher Scholarship Program. Applications will be accepted through Tuesday, September 6, 2016!  

The 12-week online program, which starts October 2, 2016, gives participants the chance to learn new language teaching methods, theories, and classroom techniques, while also helping participants to improve their own English skills. The program is open to teachers, teacher trainers, and program administrators.  

E-Teacher graduate Pin Chanleap received the top score in last year's training, and she received a scholarship to travel to the Philippines to network with other foreign language teachers at the 2016 East Asia Pacific E-Teacher Alumni Seminar. Chanleap is enthusiastic about the E-Teacher Program, saying that, "I have learned tremendous things which have changed the rest of my professional life."

To apply and for more information, go to https://kh.usembassy.gov/e-teacher-scholarship-program-2016/

This is the transcript of Dr. Frank Huffman's symposium presentation on July 22, 2010

Dr. Frank Huffman published nine books and numerous articles on Southeast Asian languages and linguistics. His Cambodian System of Writing, Beginner Reader, and Modern Spoken Cambodian were first published in 1970, and with later books including the first comprehensive English-Khmer Dictionary (1978). With his coauthor Im Proum, he began the complilation of this dictionary in 1970. In 2004 he donated his collection of Khmer books to the Buddhist Institute in Phnom Penh.

Working Together to Improve the Lives of Children
-From the Ambassadors Penh

Last month, I had the pleasure of meeting witha group of distinguished representatives of the Royal Government of Cambodia to discuss our shared interest in a critical topic  Cambodias child welfare system.  Our discussions centered on the topic of getting children out of institutions and into permanent family care.  

The importance of this issue is underscored by scientific research showing that growing up in a stable and loving family is fundamental in the development of a child.  Armed with information like this, and motivated by a passion to help children, the group I met with  representingthe Ministry of Social Affairs, Veterans and Youth Rehabilitation, the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of Interior, and the Phnom Penh Court  is engaged in aconcerted effort to implement a child welfare system in Cambodia that puts the health, safety, and wellbeing of children first.  Im very pleased that the U.S. Embassy was able to support this groups work by sponsoring them on a visitor programin the United States. 

This month, the Cambodian delegationvisitedthe United States for a ten-day, adoptions-focused visitor program that included meetings with a wide range of child welfare and adoption subject matter experts in Washington, DC, Baltimore, Maryland, and New York City.  Between site visits and meetings with U.S. counterparts, the group had a very productive exchange in the United States.  They met with family court judges and observed court proceedings.  Theylearned about the provision of services to children at the Johns Hopkins Childrens Center.  And they met with the United States Central Authority for international adoptions, among many other activities.

Throughout their program, the Cambodian delegatesexamined best practices in child welfare and discussed strategies and practical examples for implementing the Hague Convention on Inter-country Adoption.  They also gained insight into the roles played by U.S. state and local child welfare authorities and social workers.  Of particular interest was the way in which these officials find permanent family placements for children outside of family care.  

I was pleased that the Cambodian delegates also took advantage of opportunities to share Cambodias successes and the challenges that remain in formulating its child welfare regulatory framework.  They were able to solicit input and advice from U.S. experts, while also giving their American counterparts greater understanding of the work being done in Cambodia to overcome obstacles.  

The visitor program is already paying dividends  reinforcing the strong ties between our two countries, inspiring new ideas, and helping to build upon the delegates ongoing work here in Cambodia.  And feedback from the delegates is helping inform the U.S. governments effort as we assist Cambodia to improve its child welfare system.  The U.S. effort includes our Children in Adversity Action Plan, coordinated by USAID in Cambodia, to promote appropriate, protective, and permanent family care.

Lets continue working together to take on the challenges ahead.  By doing that, I believe Cambodia can reach its goal of creating and implementing a child welfare system and adoption process that puts the health, safety, and wellbeing of children first.  Such a system would also fulfill Cambodias obligations under the Hague Convention on Inter-country Adoption, demonstrating to the world how Cambodia is prioritizing its single greatest resource, its children.
